desc: NA
author: By Eric Schmitt

header: China cautions its citizens in Ukraine but doesn’t mention war.
desc: NA
author: By Chris Buckley

header: Biden warns Putin of severe consequences if Russia invades Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Anton Troianovski, Katie Rogers and Lara Jakes

header: Biden warns Putin of ‘swift and severe’ costs of any Ukraine invasion.
desc: NA
author: By Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer, Lara Jakes and Katie Rogers

header: ‘We understand all the risks,’ Ukraine’s leader says, but still urges calm.
desc: NA
author: By Anton Troianovski and Lara Jakes

header: ‘We Need to Oppose Russia’: Ukrainians Find Common Purpose
desc: A trip along the Dnieper River explores what it means to be Ukrainian at a moment of extreme peril, as the country debates Russia’s place in its past, and its future.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Brendan Hoffman

header: Tone of Ukraine Crisis Shifts as Russia Signals Openness to Talk More
desc: Diplomacy is “far from exhausted,” Russia’s foreign minister said, while President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said the prospect of his country joining NATO might be just a “dream.”
author: By Anton Troianovski and Andrew E. Kramer

header: As Russia Welcomes Talks, Biden Warns Invasion Is Still Possible
desc: President Vladimir V. Putin said he was pulling some Russian troops back from areas close to Ukraine, hinting at cooling the crisis, but U.S. officials say it is too soon to gauge his intentions.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Michael D. Shear

header: An international monitoring mission in eastern Ukraine shrinks as nations withdraw their staffs.
desc: NA
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: The U.S. relocates its C.I.A. station in Kyiv, after moving its embassy farther from the Russian border.
desc: The American secretary of state said the temporary embassy would remain engaged with the Ukrainian government.
author: By Lara Jakes, Richard Pérez-Pena and Julian Barnes

header: A hack of the Defense Ministry, army and state banks was the largest of its kind in Ukraine’s history.
desc: Ukraine’s minister of digital transformation, Mykhailo Fedorov, said the attack “bore traces of foreign intelligence services.”
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: As a bipartisan push for sanctions against Russia stalls in Congress, Republicans present their own bill.
desc: What began as an effort to present a unified front on Capitol Hill against Russia has faltered amid disagreements between Democrats and Republicans over just how far to go.
author: By Catie Edmondson

header: Germany’s chancellor promises support while in Kyiv, on the eve of a meeting with Putin.
desc: The German leader said he would encourage business to invest in Ukraine, but ruled out sending weaponry.
author: By Christopher F. Schuetze

header: The Pentagon chief will visit Belgium and Eastern Europe this week.
desc: He will consult with leaders of NATO and visit American troops in Poland.
author: By Eric Schmitt

header: A World Away From Ukraine, Russia Is Courting Latin America
desc: The Ukraine crisis has revived a struggle over Latin America between the U.S. and Russia, as Vladimir V. Putin seeks greater influence in the region.
author: By Jack Nicas and Anton Troianovski

header: Artillery Exchanges in Eastern Ukraine May Presage Invasion, U.S. Warns
desc: As shelling intensified in the east, officials warned that Moscow might use false claims of “genocide” against Russians in the region as a pretext for an attack.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Anton Troianovski

header: Ukraine Tensions Spike as West Accuses Russia of Lying About Troop Withdrawal
desc: As Russia stoked hopes of a diplomatic solution and claimed to be pulling back forces from the Ukrainian border, U.S. and NATO officials accused Moscow of building up troops instead.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Anton Troianovski and Michael D. Shear

header: On the Edge of a Polish Forest, Where Some of Putin’s Darkest Fears Lurk
desc: A U.S. missile facility in Poland is at the heart of an issue animating the Kremlin’s calculations over whether to go to war against Ukraine.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: ‘A whistling sound, then an explosion’: Shelling hits a kindergarten in Ukraine.
desc: “We’ve said for some time that the Russians might do something like this in order to justify a military conflict,” said the U.S. defense secretary, Lloyd J. Austin III. “So we’ll be watching this very closely.”
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Valerie Hopkins

header: After 30 Years of Peace, Ukraine Crisis Shakes Europeans
desc: The happy complacency of post-Cold War peace is being shattered by Russia’s threats, demands and massive military buildup around Ukraine.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: U.S. and Russian warplanes flew dangerously close to each other.
desc: Aircraft flew close in three incidents in the eastern Mediterranean, including one in which planes came within about five feet of each other.
author: By Eric Schmitt

header: The airline industry grapples with Russia’s military buildup around Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukrainian government floats prospect of holding referendum on NATO membership.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: In Pictures: Ukraine holds military drills.
desc: NA
author: NA

header: In their own words: Biden and Putin on Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Shelling Escalates in Ukraine as Thousands Flee, Fearing Attack
desc: Western leaders repeat calls for a diplomatic resolution to the crisis. Russia fires missiles in a blunt warning of where the conflict could lead.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: In Ukraine Crisis, the Looming Threat of a New Cold War
desc: If he invades, President Vladimir V. Putin is inviting a new global struggle with the West. He should think about how the last one ended, analysts say.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Vladimir Putin: Crafty Strategist or Aggrieved and Reckless Leader?
desc: Analysts puzzling over the Russian leader’s intentions say that his troop buildup around Ukraine could be a convincing bluff, but also posit that he could have fundamentally changed during the pandemic.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Ukraine’s paramilitaries prepare for conflict with Russia.
desc: Times journalists followed the members of one such group
author: By Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Brent McDonald and Dmitriy Khavin

header: The Ukraine Crisis: What to Know About Why Russia Attacked
desc: Here’s why Ukraine’s importance extends far beyond its borders.
author: By Patrick Kingsley

header: How Putin Has Already Weakened Ukraine’s Economy
desc: Flights have been canceled, commercial shipping is threatened, and people fear an invasion is not far off.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: As Shelling Picks Up, Eastern Ukrainians Are Cowering
desc: With nowhere to go, many are increasingly fearful that their villages could become the flash point for a wider war.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: A timeline of the tensions between Russia and Ukraine.
desc: Here is a look at some key events in the run-up to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: ‘Be Calm,’ He Said, as Mortar Shells Fell on the Road Behind Us
desc: As shelling intensified in eastern Ukraine, a seemingly routine press tour turned into a frantic rush to safety.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Andrew E. Kramer and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: As warnings of war grow louder, Ukrainians try to keep their bearings.
desc: The crisis has taken a toll on many Ukrainians.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora

header: Putin Orders Forces to Russia-Backed Ukraine Regions and Hints at Wider Military Aims
desc: The moves by the Russian leader were his most blatant yet in a confrontation with the West that threatens to escalate into the biggest military action in Europe since World War II.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Valerie Hopkins and Steven Erlanger

header: If War Flames in Ukraine, These 2 Little Enclaves May Be the Spark
desc: Russian-backed separatists in the Luhansk and Donetsk regions once got just passing attention. They loom much larger now as many fear what may come next in Ukraine.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Highlights from Putin’s address on breakaway regions in Ukraine.
desc: President Vladimir V. Putin said he would recognize the independence of two Russia-backed territories in eastern Ukraine. Here are highlights from his 40-minute speech.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Poised on Border, Russia May Be Seeking Pretext for Ukraine Invasion, Officials Say
desc: The pressure on Kyiv mounted after a weekend of shelling and evacuations in the east, and the extension of war games in neighboring Belarus.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Why it matters that Russia just recognized Donetsk and Luhansk.
desc: The act of recognition is fraught with meaning because the borders claimed by the Russia-backed leaders of the two breakaway regions extend into space controlled by the Ukrainian army.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Andrew E. Kramer

header: In a call with Putin, France’s Macron pursues a diplomatic solution in Ukraine.
desc: But the Kremlin signaled little optimism regarding a diplomatic path, saying Western countries were pushing Ukraine’s government to a “military solution.”
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Air France is the latest airline to limit flights to Ukraine.
desc: Lufthansa and Scandinavian Airlines also canceled flights to Kyiv as fears grow of a Russian invasion.
author: By Emma Bubola and Roger Cohen

header: ‘We are frustrated, and we are terrified’: Ukrainian expats express solidarity with their homeland.
desc: At a rally in London, many of the attendees said they hoped that a full-scale Russian invasion could be averted.
author: By Cora Engelbrecht

header: People evacuating to Russia from eastern Ukraine are uncertain about what lies ahead.
desc: Refugees crossed into Russia after a warning from Kremlin-backed rebel leaders that Ukraine was about to launch an attack on the separatist areas.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: For Ukraine’s Jews, the Threat of War Stirs Memories of Past Horrors
desc: In Odessa, Jewish leaders are preparing for the worst: hiring security guards, scoping out bomb shelters and making plans to evacuate if Russia invades the country.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Putin Announces Start to ‘Military Operation’ Against Ukraine
desc: “The invasion has begun,” Ukraine’s Interior Ministry said. Putin says he seeks “demilitarization” of Ukraine but has no plans to occupy it.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Neil MacFarquhar

header: Ukraine Enclaves Long Steeped in Conflict Face New Peril
desc: A decision by Russia to recognize two separatist territories and order in troops raises the risks of intensified fighting in an already fraught region where violence has defined life for nearly a decade.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: The Limits of a Europe Whole and Free
desc: Vladimir Putin sets down a marker in Ukraine. Does the West have the means to stop him?
author: By Roger Cohen

header: Many Russians Feel a Deep Unease Over Going to War
desc: After months of tuning out American warnings that Vladimir Putin was preparing to invade Ukraine, Russians now realize that “this is not a game.”
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Zelensky makes a dramatic appeal to the Russian people, saying ‘the people of Ukraine want peace.’
desc: NA
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Russian Mercenaries Have Covertly Entered Separatist Enclaves in Ukraine
desc: Two senior European security officials say that the paramilitary fighters are inside the rebel territories of Ukraine to lay the groundwork for war.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Eric Schmitt

header: Cyberattack hits several Ukrainian government websites.
desc: NA
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Ukraine’s president calls up reserves, urging his compatriots to fight for their country.
desc: Volodymyr Zelensky said his government would work to “raise the preparedness of the Ukrainian army to all possible changes in the operational situation.”
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Maria Varenikova

header: Taiwan, eyeing parallels to Ukraine, condemns Russian invasion.
desc: Some analysts worry that a weak global response to Ukraine could embolden China’s Communist Party to ramp up pressure on self-governed Taiwan.
author: By Amy Qin

header: U.N. leader deepens criticism of Russia over Ukraine crisis.
desc: António Guterres said Ukraine’s sovereign territory had been violated, and he rejected Vladimir Putin’s description of Russian troops as peacekeepers.
author: By Rick Gladstone

header: Ukraine Girds for Kyiv Attack Amid Signs of Slowing Russian Advance
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky warned in a video address that Russian “sabotage groups” had entered Kyiv with the aim of decapitating his government by “destroying the head of state.”
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson

header: Russia Batters Ukraine With Artillery Strikes as West Condemns Invasion
desc: Explosions were reported over Kyiv, the capital. Several countries announced severe new sanctions, as Vladimir Putin remained resolute about his decision to invade.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Eric Schmitt and Neil MacFarquhar

header: At the Polish Border, Tens of Thousands of Ukrainian Refugees
desc: They have been warmly welcomed in a country whose border guards last year beat back mostly Afghan and Middle Eastern migrants with batons.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Zelensky Steps Into a Role Few Expected: Ukraine’s Wartime President
desc: Even as doubts have lingered about his preparedness to lead, Volodymyr Zelensky, a former actor, gave the performance of his life as Russian forces prepared to invade.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Scenes from Kharkiv: Battle wreckage, the boom of artillery, and people sheltering in the subway.
desc: Ukrainian troops dug in around the nation’s second-largest city a day after a fight to push back advancing Russian forces.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Accurate U.S. intelligence did not stop Putin, but it gave Biden big advantages.
desc: The depth and quality of the intelligence strengthened the president’s hand in persuading allies to form a unified front against Moscow.
author: By Julian E. Barnes and David E. Sanger

header: Russians Now See a New Side to Putin: Dragging Them Into War
desc: The autocrat who has steered Russia for 22 years was embraced by many Russians for what they saw as his rationality and astute risk management. That image has been upended.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Russia says it won’t enter talks until Ukraine stops fighting.
desc: Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey Lavrov, made clear that Russia was seeking to topple the democratically elected government of Ukraine.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Voices from Ukraine: ‘It’s panic.’
desc: In one city in eastern Ukraine, there were long lines at banks and gas stations as anxious residents scrambled ahead of Russia’s invasion.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Another casualty of Russia’s invasion: Ukraine’s ability to contain the coronavirus.
desc: The fighting in Ukraine’s east is forcing a hurried mass migration that leaves little room for pandemic considerations.
author: By Adeel Hassan

header: Once Sleepy and Picturesque, Ukrainian Villages Mobilize for War
desc: While Russian assaults on Ukrainian cities have drawn most of the attention in the war’s early days, civilians in country towns have joined the fight, putting aside the routines of daily village life.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: Ukraine Agrees to Talks With Russia, but Fighting Still Rages
desc: Putin, accusing the West of “aggressive statements,” puts nuclear forces on alert. Kyiv remains in Russian cross-hairs as Ukrainians push back.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Anton Troianovski and Steven Erlanger

header: Russia Advances on 3 Ukrainian Cities, but Meets Fierce Resistance
desc: Ukraine’s leader said his forces had “repelled” the Russian army’s assault. Moscow claimed it had merely “paused” for the possibility of peace negotiations.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Eric Schmitt, Michael Levenson and The New York Times

header: ‘Everybody in Our Country Needs to Defend’
desc: Civilian volunteers and paramilitary groups are taking the fight to the Russian army in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Lynsey Addario

header: In Foreign Policy U-Turn, Germany Ups Military Spending and Arms Ukraine
desc: Germany agrees to strengthen its military in the latest foreign policy about-face amid pressure from allies and horror at Russia’s attack on Ukraine.
author: By Melissa Eddy

header: Putin’s War Ushers In Crisis for Russia
desc: Despite the Kremlin’s efforts to obscure the offensive in Ukraine, the costs of the war were already evident in both economic and social turmoil.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: ‘I’m a Soldier Now.’ Even in Untouched Villages, Ukrainians Prepare to Fight
desc: In cities and towns in Central Ukraine that have not yet heard the boom of Russian artillery fire, residents spent the weekend preparing furiously for the possibly of an attack.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Ukrainians in Britain Take Up the Cause Back Home
desc: Whether vowing to kill Russians or offering medical supplies, Ukrainian citizens are too impatient to sit idly by.
author: By Cora Engelbrecht

header: War in Ukraine Forces Israel Into a Delicate Balancing Act
desc: Israel is a strong ally of the United States, and its leaders have a good relationship with Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukraine’s Jewish president. But Israel also doesn’t want to provoke Russia.
author: By Patrick Kingsley, Isabel Kershner and Ronen Bergman

header: Ukraine War Forces Hungary’s Orban Into Political Contortions
desc: The pro-Russia, anti-immigrant Hungarian prime minister, who denounced any sanctions against Russia just weeks ago, has been forced to reverse himself as an election looms.
author: By Benjamin Novak

header: After a Fumbled Start, Russian Forces Hit Harder in Ukraine
desc: After days of miscalculation about Ukraine’s resolve to fight, Russian forces are turning toward an old pattern of opening fire on cities and mounting sieges.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: Spurning Rebukes, Russia Escalates Attack on Ukraine as Refugee Ranks Swell
desc: There was no sign of possible de-escalation on the sixth day of the invasion, as Russia appeared determined to toughen its tactics against a defiant neighbor.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Valerie Hopkins and Nick Cumming-Bruce

header: Russian Rocket Barrage Kills Civilians as First Talks Show No Progress
desc: The deadly rocket assault on a residential area of Ukraine’s second-largest city signaled an escalation of Russian tactics, and overshadowed efforts at diplomacy.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Steven Erlanger and Michael Schwirtz

header: Ukraine War Sets Off Europe’s Fastest Migration in Decades
desc: At least 660,000 people, mostly women and children, fled Ukraine in the five days after Russia invaded — the most intense wave of European migration since at least the 1990s.
author: By Patrick Kingsley

header: Invasion Brings Russia Global Repudiation With Cold War Echoes
desc: From culture to commerce, sports to travel, the world is shunning Russia in myriad ways to protest President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
author: By Mark Landler

header: Many nuclear power reactors in Ukraine are no longer producing electricity.
desc: Six of the 15 reactors in the country appear to be offline at the moment, with one site close to Russian troop movements reporting half of its reactors are down.
author: By William J. Broad

header: Satellite internet terminals, sent by Elon Musk, arrive in Ukraine.
desc: Responding to a plea by a Ukrainian official, Mr. Musk delivered an unknown number of his Starlink terminals, which offer online connection via orbiting satellites, bypassing conventional providers.
author: By Mike Ives

header: Africans Say Ukrainian Authorities Hindered Them From Fleeing
desc: Africans and other foreigners in Ukraine say border guards made them endure long waits and even beat them, while letting Ukrainians through quickly. Ukraine denied discriminating.
author: By Monika Pronczuk and Ruth Maclean

header: Initial talks between Russia and Ukraine yield no resolution.
desc: Russia’s delegation leader said the next meeting would take place once more along the Ukraine-Belarus border in the “coming days.”
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Watching the War in Ukraine, Taiwanese Draw Lessons in Self-Reliance
desc: Many in Taiwan see parallels with Ukraine. “We must use this time of peace to prepare for the worst,” says a nonprofit working to promote civil defense.
author: By Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien

header: On the Exodus West, Ukrainians Flee Hardship for an Uncertain Future
desc: Many thousands of Ukrainians, fearful of the war, are leaving their homes on a slow journey west, enduring difficulties but also buoyed by the generosity of their countrymen.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Kremlin Vows Victory in Ukraine as Refugees Swell to One Million
desc: Defiant Ukrainians slowed the invasion, but Russian forces gained ground in the south, and the Kremlin insisted the week-old campaign was “going according to plan.”
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: First Ukraine City Falls as Russia Strikes More Civilian Targets
desc: Russian forces seized the southern city of Kherson and besieged other cities, with casualties and destruction mounting, as Western sanctions tightened their vise grip on Russia’s economy.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: Putin’s War to Bring Ukraine to Heel Unites Eastern Europe in Alarm
desc: Many countries fear that the Russian leader’s efforts to turn back the clock and reclaim a sphere of influence lost at the end of the Cold War could spell disaster for them.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: 15,000 Are Sheltering in Kyiv’s Subway
desc: People sleep three or four to a mattress and plastic food bags litter the scene, while mothers search endlessly on their phones for news of the war.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Lynsey Addario

header: A War the Kremlin Tried to Disguise Becomes a Hard Reality for Russians
desc: Moscow posted a death toll from its attack on Ukraine for the first time, and Russians who long avoided politics are now grappling with the fact that their country is fighting a deadly conflict.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Anton Troianovski

header: Last Vestiges of Russia’s Free Press Fall Under Kremlin Pressure
desc: “Everything that’s not propaganda is being eliminated,” a Nobel Prize winning editor said as Russian authorities moved to control the narrative in the Ukraine war.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Valeriya Safronova

header: French volunteers plan to head to Ukraine to join its new foreign legion.
desc: And Ukraine is welcoming them and other volunteers with open arms.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Reports of civilian casualties rise in Ukraine, but exact counts remain uncertain.
desc: As is often the case in war zones, tolls diverged. It was not immediately possible for The New York Times to provide an independent estimate.
author: By Emma Bubola

header: More than 800 medical students, most African or Indian, are stranded in northeastern Ukraine.
desc: “It’s always one answer” for those trying to get out of the town of Sumy, said one of the students. “The roads are blocked and they are not safe.”
author: By Alexandra Eaton, Caroline Kim, Nailah Morgan and Rex Sakamoto

header: Russian Prisoners and Ukrainian Soldiers Describe Two Sides of the Conflict
desc: The accounts painted a picture of a conflict consisting largely of ambushes, at least in northern Ukraine where the Russian forces are striving to encircle and capture the capital, Kyiv.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russians Seize Europe’s Biggest Nuclear Plant and Gain in the South as More Ukrainians Flee
desc: The Russian military advance in Ukraine sowed more destruction and chaos, pointing to a worsening conflict, as the Kremlin also moved to restrict how it’s reported at home.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Michael Schwirtz and Michael Levenson

header: Russian Forces Pound Civilians, as Putin Likens Sanctions to a ‘Declaration of War’
desc: Despite a cease-fire, Russia shelled near humanitarian corridors meant for civilians to escape an embattled city, Ukraine says, while the Russian leader also warned about a no-fly zone.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson

header: In Kyiv’s Railway Station, Rumors, Near-Stampedes and Frustration
desc: As Russian forces begin to encircle the Ukrainian capital, tens of thousands are clambering for a way out that may soon be closed off.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: How the West Marshaled a Stunning Show of Unity Against Russia
desc: In a few frantic days, the West threw out the playbook it used for decades against the Kremlin and isolated Russia with unparalleled sanctions and penalties.
author: By Mark Landler, Katrin Bennhold and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: The battle for a Ukraine nuclear plant was a painful reminder of the world’s worst nuclear disaster.
desc: The director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, proposed going to Ukraine to inspect nuclear facilities. “There is no normalcy to the situation when there are military forces in charge of the site,” he said.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Fire at a Ukrainian nuclear plant is out, but Russian troops take control of the site.
desc: International observers and Ukrainian officials said that as of 6 a.m. the facility was still able to function safely.
author: By Marc Santora and William J. Broad

header: Putin likens sanctions to an ‘act of war’ and warns Ukraine might lose statehood.
desc: NA
author: By The New York Times

header: The State of Fighting in Ukraine’s Besieged Cities
desc: About two-thirds of Ukraine’s population of 44 million people lived in cities before Russia’s invasion began. Now many urban areas are in the cross-hairs of war.
author: By Damien Cave and Vjosa Isai

header: Ukraine War Forces a Question: How Far East Does Europe Go?
desc: After Russia invaded, Ukraine asked to join the European Union, quickly. Moldova and Georgia have asked, too. Member states would rather not answer.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Ukrainian Family’s Dash for Safety Ends in Death
desc: Russian forces hit a bridge being used by civilians evacuating the fighting in Ukraine. Four people were killed.
author: By Lynsey Addario and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Hate for Putin’s Russia Consumes Ukraine
desc: Much of the bitterness is directed at President Vladimir V. Putin, but Ukrainians also chastise ordinary Russians, calling them complicit.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: Proud Band of Ukrainian Troops Holds Russian Assault at Bay — for Now
desc: “Few expected such strength from our people,” said a Ukrainian colonel whose soldiers have repelled a Russian attack on the port city of Mykolaiv for three days.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Humanitarian Crisis Worsens for Ukrainians Trapped in Russia’s Onslaught
desc: Two weeks after the invasion began, tens of thousands of Ukrainians are without food, water or power. The Russians are increasingly resorting to indiscriminate shelling to help their forces advance.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Andrew E. Kramer and Rick Gladstone

header: ‘Falling Into Emptiness’: Ukrainian Families Feel the Pain of Separation
desc: With most Ukrainian men legally prohibited from leaving Ukraine, the international border gates serve as a painful filter, splitting families as women and children move on.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Monika Pronczuk

header: The third round of Ukraine-Russia talks renew the prospect of humanitarian corridors.
desc: NA
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Hate for Putin and ordinary Russians consumes Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: U.S. is exploring how to send Soviet-era fighter jets to Ukraine.
desc: The discussions follow President Volodymyr Zelensky’s impassioned plea to American legislators for assistance in obtaining more lethal military aid.
author: By Steven Erlanger and Lara Jakes

header: Ukraine warns of threat to hydroelectric power station.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Ukraine takes its case against Russia to the U.N.’s highest court.
desc: The head of the Ukrainian delegation told the court that “millions are in danger” and accused Moscow of defiling the Genocide Convention.
author: By Marlise Simons

header: They Died by a Bridge in Ukraine. This Is Their Story.
desc: Tetiana Perebyinis and her two children were killed trying to dash to safety, a moment captured by our photographer. Her husband describes their lives, and their final hours.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russia Bombards Ukraine Cities and Accuses U.S. of ‘Economic War’
desc: Misery deepened in Ukraine, where millions of people were caught in besieged cities, and in Russia, where the West’s economic sanctions were biting hard.
author: By Richard Pérez-Pena

header: Quoting Churchill and Shakespeare, Ukraine Leader Vows No Surrender
desc: In a dramatic video address to Britain’s House of Commons, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said he would never capitulate to the invading Russians.
author: By Mark Landler and Marc Santora

header: As Fighting Gets Closer, a Kyiv Hospital Treats the War’s Atrocities
desc: As Russian bombings have grown more indiscriminate, hospitals in Ukraine have become perilous places to work.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: After a Week of Siege, Bloodied Mariupol Plans Mass Graves
desc: Under a relentless Russian barrage, there is no heat or electricity, and people are boiling snow for water. A 6-year-old died of dehydration, the authorities said.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Ukraine’s first lady emerges into the spotlight to condemn Russia’s invasion and plead for help.
desc: Olena Zelenska says in a letter that Russian forces are engaged in the “mass murder of civilians” and reiterates her husband’s call for a no-fly zone.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Battlefield reports are murky, but signs of Ukraine’s successes emerge.
desc: The Ukrainian military claims to have killed thousands of Russian soldiers and destroyed hundreds of tanks and aircraft. Verifying the figures is challenging.
author: By Marc Santora

header: W.H.O. condemns attacks on health care services in Ukraine and calls for safe passage for medical supplies.
desc: The organization has confirmed at least 16 attacks on the medical system, which is facing urgent supply shortages.
author: By Isabella Kwai

header: Moldovans Welcome Fleeing Ukrainians, but Some Pack Their Own Bags, Too
desc: Moldova has taken in more Ukrainians, per capita, than any other country. But the closer Russian troops get to Moldova, the more locals consider their own escape plans.
author: By Patrick Kingsley and Laetitia Vancon

header: Ukrainians Trying to Flee to U.K. Face a Confounding Path
desc: The government has offered a way for U.K. residents to bring over Ukrainian relatives fleeing the war. But families and rights groups say it’s a bureaucratic nightmare that makes it too difficult to get in.
author: By Megan Specia

header: Slowed on the Battlefield, Russia Widens Bombardment of Ukrainian Cities
desc: But military experts, citing previous Russian campaigns, say that strategy is unlikely to succeed without bloody urban fighting.
author: By Michael Levenson, Eric Schmitt and Neil MacFarquhar

header: Russia Batters and Encircles Ukrainian Cities, as Diplomacy Falters
desc: The first meeting during the war of the two countries’ foreign ministers yielded no cease-fire. The Russian side signaled that its invasion would not stop until Ukraine surrendered.
author: By Richard Pérez-Pena

header: How a Line of Russian Tanks Became an Inviting Target for Ukrainians
desc: A skirmish in an eastern suburb of Kyiv illustrated how close Russian forces have come as they continued to tighten a noose on the city, but also revealed their strategic vulnerabilities.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russian forces are laying siege to the northern Ukraine city of Chernihiv, the mayor says.
desc: Ukrainian forces are battling to keep some roads open, as Russia tightens its cordon around the battered city. “We are surrounded,” the mayor said.
author: By Marc Santora

header: ‘Free Ukraine Street’: Russian Embassies Get Pointed New Addresses
desc: Officials in many European cities are giving streets, squares and intersections in front of Russian missions names with pro-Ukraine themes.
author: By Isabella Kwai, Henrik Pryser Libell and Christina Anderson

header: Europe’s Trains Take Fighters to Ukraine, and Bring Back Refugees
desc: Built up over 150 years of conflicts that defined modern-day Europe, railways have played a central role in the continent’s peacetime integration. Now they’re back on a war footing.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Russian Sieges of Ukrainian Cities Provoke Bitter Recollections for Syrians
desc: “We feel for them and say, may God be with you,” said one Syrian who endured hunger and cold when his own government, backed by Russia, besieged Aleppo.
author: By Raja Abdulrahim

header: Harris Tells Americans They Will Have to Pay More for Gas to Punish Russia
desc: Vice President Kamala Harris, visiting NATO ally Romania, insisted that the higher costs of energy associated with sanctions imposed on Moscow over its war on Ukraine would be worth the pain.
author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs

header: Harris, in Poland, Seeks to Present United Front Against Russia
desc: Vice President Kamala Harris visited Warsaw a day after U.S. officials said they were blindsided by Poland’s offer to provide jet fighters to Ukraine. Washington rejected it, fearing it could escalate the conflict.
author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs

header: Biden will call for suspending normal trade relations with Russia.
desc: The move, expected to be joined by the G7 and the European Union, would result in higher tariffs on Russian products being sent to the United States.
author: By Ana Swanson and Katie Rogers

header: U.S. to Send Arms to Ukraine, as Russia Intensifies Campaign of Destruction
desc: A defiant mayor of a captured city was kidnapped by Russian troops, Ukrainian authorities say, an act that prompted hundreds to protest.
author: By Marc Santora, Michael Schwirtz and Michael Levenson

header: In a Kyiv Basement, 19 Surrogate Babies Are Trapped by War but Kept Alive by Nannies
desc: Some surrogate mothers are trapped by the fighting as their due dates near. And newborns face uncertain fates, with many biological parents now unable to travel to Ukraine.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Lynsey Addario

header: Russian Airstrike at NATO’s Doorstep Raises Fears of Expanded War
desc: Russian missiles hit a military base being used to train foreign volunteers who want to help Ukraine repel the invasion, killing a reported 35 people just 11 miles from the Polish border.
author: By Marc Santora, Jack Nicas and Eric Schmitt

header: Booms, Smoke and Fire Signal Horror of Russian Attack on Base
desc: Residents of a town near Poland’s border awoke to frightful sounds and an awareness they were no longer safe.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Yousur Al-Hlou

header: Pandemic Fears Give Way to a Rush for Bomb Shelters
desc: Since Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, European anxiety has shifted from Covid to nuclear annihilation. Bunkers, survival guides and iodine pills are flying off the shelves.
author: By Jason Horowitz

header: The base attacked in western Ukraine has been a hub for foreign militaries.
desc: The base outside Lviv that was attacked by Russian forces early on Sunday was a key link between Ukraine’s armed forces and Western militaries before the war.
author: By Austin Ramzy

header: With Bombings and a Funeral, the War Arrives in Ukraine’s West
desc: Western Ukraine has been a safe haven for Ukrainian refugees, as well as businessmen, journalists and diplomats. But attacks in two cities pierced the sense of security in the region.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Brent Renaud, an American journalist, is killed in Ukraine.
desc: An award-winning filmmaker and journalist, Mr. Renaud, 50, was killed while reporting in a suburb of Kyiv. Another journalist was wounded.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Shelling damages a revered monastery, and injures some seeking shelter there.
desc: The 16th-century monastery is one of the three most sacred sites in Ukraine for Orthodox believers.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Chaos of War in Ukraine Could Fuel New Covid Surge, Doctors Say
desc: War has pushed Covid out of people’s minds while forcing them into crowded and unsanitary conditions that are fertile ground for the coronavirus, polio and other pathogens.
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: Diplomacy Quickens to Halt Ukraine War or Stop Its Expansion
desc: Ukraine and Russia held a new round of talks and agreed to resume them on Tuesday, as the United States warned China about helping an increasingly isolated Kremlin and expanding the conflict.
author: By Mark Landler and David E. Sanger

header: China Sees at Least One Winner Emerging From Ukraine War: China
desc: The country’s leaders think it can shield itself from economic and diplomatic fallout and eventually be seen as a pillar of stability.
author: By Steven Lee Myers and Chris Buckley

header: ‘I’m Not Scared of Anything’: Death and Defiance in a Besieged Ukrainian City
desc: The port city of Mykolaiv is being shelled by Russian forces every day. Bodies are piled at the morgue. But residents refuse to succumb.
author: NA

header: European Leaders Brave Russian Bombardment in Visit to Kyiv
desc: The prime ministers of Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovenia made the trip as a show of solidarity, but it also bared divisions with other European Union members.
author: By Mark Landler and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Two Refugees, Both on Poland’s Border. But Worlds Apart.
desc: A young man fleeing war in Sudan and a young woman evacuating Ukraine crossed into Poland at the same time. They had very different experiences.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Monika Pronczuk

header: Impunity for War Crimes in Syria Casts a Grim Shadow Over Ukraine
desc: Syria, with Russian support, used many of the brutal tactics now seen in Ukraine — and its dictator stayed in power. That conflict offers lessons for Russia’s leader, analysts say.
author: By Ben Hubbard

header: A Chinese video blogger in Odessa challenges Beijing’s version of the war.
desc: Wang Jixian has become one of the boldest voices confronting the Chinese state-controlled media’s narrative, drawing hundreds of thousands of viewers.
author: By Chris Buckley

header: The U.S. warns China not to give Russia military or economic aid.
desc: The Kremlin denied the report, and the spokesman for the Chinese Embassy in Washington said he had never heard of the request.
author: By Richard Pérez-Pena and David E. Sanger

header: Kyiv’s Once-Busy Streets Empty as Russia Targets Capital
desc: With civilian areas coming under fire and an estimated half the population having fled, the avenues of the Ukrainian capital, under siege by Russian forces, are almost deserted.
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: Zelensky calls on Russian troops to surrender.
desc: The Ukrainian leader and the Pentagon have both said some Russian soldiers have surrendered or been captured.
author: By Jesus Jiménez

header: Ukrainian Forces Strike Back at Russia as Biden Sends More Firepower
desc: The attacks in Kyiv and Kherson were aimed at inflicting “maximum losses” against Russia but not regaining territory, while the U.S. pledged $800 million more in military aid.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Valerie Hopkins and Carlotta Gall

header: Why Vladimir Putin Invokes Nazis to Justify His Invasion of Ukraine
desc: The language of Russia’s invasion has been dominated by the word “Nazi” — a puzzling assertion about a country whose leader is Jewish.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Survivors Emerge From a Bombed Theater, but Ukraine’s Suffering Grows
desc: Russia continues to devastate cities and hit civilians, as Ukrainian forces strike back and peace talks drag on.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Michael Schwirtz and Eric Nagourney

header: UNESCO will send body armor to Ukrainian journalists.
desc: The U.N. agency said thousands of Ukrainian journalists with no protective equipment or training were now covering the war. At least four journalists have been killed.
author: By Jane Arraf

header: An American who traveled to Ukraine for his partner’s treatment is killed.
desc: NA
author: By Megan Specia and Michael Schwirtz

header: L.G.B.T.Q. activists in Ukraine share the fight against Russia’s invasion.
desc: A pro-Russian puppet government would be less supportive of gay rights, the activists say, and incidents of discrimination would be likely to rise, as they have in Russian-backed separatist regions.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Videos show a destroyed Mariupol theater that Ukrainian officials say sheltered hundreds of civilians.
desc: NA
author: By Christoph Koettl, Dmitriy Khavin and Valerie Hopkins

header: A Fox News journalist who was injured in Ukraine is now ‘safe.’
desc: Benjamin Hall was seriously injured in an incident that killed a Fox News cameraman and a young Ukrainian journalist.
author: By Michael M. Grynbaum

header: Putin’s War on Ukraine Is About Ethnicity and Empire
desc: Biden’s framework of ‘democracies versus autocracies’ misses the darker source of this war, which has deep roots in Russian history and thought.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: Oligarchs Got Richer Despite Sanctions. Will This Time Be Different?
desc: For nearly a decade, sanctions have been little more than names on a list for wealthy Russians. Governments are working to give them bite.
author: By Matt Apuzzo and Jane Bradley

header: Russia Targets Western Ukraine as Biden Warns Xi Not to Aid Moscow
desc: A scramble of diplomatic efforts bears little fruit as Russia intensifies its attacks, including with a bombardment into a relatively unscathed part of western Ukraine.
author: By Michael Levenson, Megan Specia and Edward Wong

header: Deadly Strike on Ukraine Barracks Punctuates Russian Military Gains
desc: Ukraine said it had temporarily lost contact with officials in the strategic port city of Mariupol, and a Russian rocket attack on a military site in Mykolaiv left dozens dead.
author: By Michael Levenson, Marc Santora and Valerie Hopkins

header: Defying China’s Censors to Urge Beijing to Denounce Russia’s War
desc: A persistent minority of Chinese scholars, journalists and citizens is warning Beijing against the risks of supporting the invasion of Ukraine.
author: By Chris Buckley

header: Kyiv’s Suburbs Become Unlikely Front Line of Ukraine War
desc: With savage artillery exchanges, the areas on the outskirts of the capital are the scenes of seesaw battles that have stalled the Russian advance for now.
author: By Carlotta Gall, Andrew E. Kramer, Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Brent McDonald, Mark Boyer and Benjamin Foley

header: Pope Deplores the War in Ukraine but Not the Aggressor
desc: Francis has raised his voice against “unacceptable armed aggression” without mentioning President Vladimir V. Putin or Russia. Some analysts say that he risks complicating his legacy.
author: By Jason Horowitz

header: The battle for Kyiv could be the biggest urban battle in decades.
desc: “There’s no talk of capitulation for Kyiv,” said Lt. Tetiana Chornovol, the commander of an anti-tank missile unit on the outskirts of the city.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Lynsey Addario

header: The Battle for Kyiv Looms as a Long and Bloody Conflict
desc: Ukraine’s capital is the biggest prize of all for the Russian military. If Russia tries to take control, it could lead to one of the biggest urban conflicts since World War II.
author: NA

header: Ukrainian tennis stars trade rackets for rifles in the fight for their country.
desc: Sergiy Stakhovsky, Andriy Medvedev and Alexandr Dolgopolov have gone to Kyiv to fight the invading Russian military.
author: By Megan Specia

header: Ukraine’s celebrities are dying in the war, adding an extra dimension to the nation’s shock.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ada Petriczko

header: As diplomacy drags on, peace seems far off in Ukraine.
desc: Western officials have little optimism that talks between Russia and Ukraine have reached a serious stage or have even confronted the most difficult issues.
author: By Steven Erlanger and Patrick Kingsley

header: Russians Pound Ukrainian Cities, as Biden Rallies Anti-Kremlin Alliance
desc: A powerful explosion ruined a shopping mall in Kyiv and claimed several lives, while Ukraine refused a Russian demand to surrender the devastated city of Mariupol.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russia Broadens Mariupol Assault as Signs of Stalemate Take Shape
desc: The battle for Mariupol has become a grim symbol of Russia’s superior firepower and its frustration in failing to subjugate Ukraine after more than three weeks of war.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Marc Santora and Catherine Porter

header: Ukraine War Threatens to Cause a Global Food Crisis
desc: A critical share of the world’s food and fertilizer is stuck in Russia and Ukraine, sending global prices soaring and foreshadowing a rise in world hunger.
author: By Jack Nicas

header: Truth Is Another Front in Putin’s War
desc: The Kremlin has used a barrage of increasingly outlandish falsehoods to prop up its overarching claim that the invasion of Ukraine is justified.
author: By Steven Lee Myers and Stuart A. Thompson

header: As Mariupol Is Bombed and Besieged, Those Trapped Fight to Survive
desc: For three weeks, the Ukrainian port city has been without water, heat, electricity and all communication under a merciless Russian assault. Here’s what its residents have been enduring.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: An Ancient City Transformed by War
desc: Simple rituals, like having coffee in a cafe in Lviv, Ukraine, take on a new and sometimes surreal meaning in a radically altered context.
author: By Marc Santora

header: ‘I Don’t Have the Right to Cry’: Ukrainian Women Share Their Stories of Escape
desc: In war, things can change quickly. A New York Times reporter wanted to capture — in whatever blurry way one can in a war — this moment in this war, three weeks in.
author: By Sabrina Tavernise

header: Biden warns the private sector that Russia is exploring options for cyberattacks.
desc: The president cited “evolving intelligence” and urged companies to strengthen their defenses immediately.
author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs

header: In Warsaw, a Network of Support Greets Those Crossing the Polish Border
desc: A sprawling expo center in the Polish capital has given some 25,000 refugees a safe place to recharge before journeying on.
author: By Megan Specia

header: Russian Soldiers Took Their City, Then Their Homes
desc: As Russian forces pushed toward Kyiv, they stormed an apartment complex in a nearby suburb and held residents hostage. Some of it was caught on camera.
author: By Brenna Smith and Masha Froliak

header: How Ukraine’s Outgunned Air Force Is Fighting Back Against Russian Jets
desc: Aerial dogfights. Top Gun-style duels. Ukraine’s fighter pilots are badly outnumbered but have so far kept Russia from controlling the skies.
author: By Maria Varenikova and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukrainians Try to Push Back Russian Forces Pummeling Their Cities
desc: Desperate fighting has shifted the front lines but neither side seems to have a decisive upper hand as Ukraine’s suffering deepens.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: As Russia Stalls in Ukraine, Dissent Brews Over Putin’s Leadership
desc: Military losses have mounted, progress has slowed, and a blame game has begun among some Russian supporters of the war.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Michael Schwirtz

header: As Biden Visits Europe Over Crisis, NATO Says It’s Doubling Eastern Flank Forces
desc: The alliance also said it would assist Ukraine because of chemical, biological and nuclear threats posed by Russia in the month-old invasion.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, David E. Sanger and Rick Gladstone

header: Putin’s climate envoy steps down from his Kremlin post, reportedly over the Ukraine war.
desc: The envoy, Anatoly Chubais, was reported to have become the senior-most Russian government official to quit over the invasion.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: A Town on Ukraine’s Edge, Determined to Escape Its Past
desc: Przemysl’s history has been intertwined with war. This time, like much of Poland, it wants to do things differently.
author: By Monika Pronczuk, Jeffrey Gettleman and Erin Schaff

header: Russia’s combat force has shrunk, a Pentagon official says, reflecting casualties and other struggles.
desc: The official said that Russian forces were “struggling on many fronts,” and that there were indications that some troops had been evacuated with frostbite.
author: By John Ismay

header: China Takes a Back Seat in International Diplomacy Over Ukraine
desc: Despite its economic and military might and close ties to Russia, China has balked at trying to press Vladimir Putin to stop the fighting.
author: By Steven Lee Myers and Chris Buckley

header: Ukraine War Ignites Israeli Debate Over Purpose of a Jewish State
desc: Most Ukrainians seeking refuge in Israel are non-Jews. Some Israelis see a moral imperative to take them in, but others see a threat to the country’s Jewish character.
author: By Isabel Kershner

header: Could a Crackdown on Kleptocrats Help Ukraine?
desc: Russian oligarchs helped boost Vladimir V. Putin’s influence in the West. Can sanctions turn that pressure back on him?
author: By Amanda Taub

header: Ukraine Tries to Seize Momentum With Claims of Counteroffensive
desc: The picture on the ground is muddy and it’s unclear how much territory Ukraine has gained back. But its announcement of a counteroffensive has enhanced the notion that it is taking the fight to the enemy.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russia Signals Redefined Goals in Ukraine War as Its Advances Stall
desc: The Russian Defense Ministry suggested its forces would concentrate on securing the eastern part of Ukraine, where Kremlin-backed separatists have long been fighting.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Michael D. Shear and Michael Levenson

header: Biden and his allies vow to take a tougher stance; Ukraine counteroffensive enters its second week
desc: In a day of summit meetings, President Biden and his counterparts faced the prospect of Russia using weapons of mass destruction. Mr. Biden said the United States would admit 100,000 Ukrainian refugees.
author: By Michael D. Shear and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Ukraine’s troops begin a counteroffensive that alters shape of the battle with Russia.
desc: Although their claimed gains in territory are hard to quantify or verify, this picture of Ukrainian progress is aiding the country’s messaging to its citizens and to the world.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: ‘A Frightening Repeat’: Ukrainian World War II Survivors Face Conflict Again
desc: Nearly 80 years after Ukraine emerged from a devastating world war that killed more than five million of its people, Russia’s invasion has stirred memories that the country had struggled to overcome.
author: By Emma Bubola

header: ‘Like a Weapon’: Ukrainians Use Social Media to Stir Resistance
desc: Photos and videos of the war’s horrors have spread quickly, searing into the global public consciousness and providing powerful ammunition in the information battle.
author: By Megan Specia

header: Ukrainian Refugee Wins Women’s Race at the Jerusalem Marathon
desc: Valentyna Vereteska fled from Mykolaiv, Ukraine, to Poland with her 11-year-old daughter a month ago.
author: By Nadav Gavrielov

header: Belarusian Exiles in Ukraine Join the Fight Against a Common Foe: Russia
desc: Eager, but ill equipped, some of Belarus’s exiles have formed a battalion in their host country, saying its fight against Vladimir Putin’s domination is the same as their homeland’s.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Long on Europe’s Fringe, Poland Takes Center Stage as War Rages in Ukraine
desc: Poland’s right-wing populist government has been embraced by both Brussels and Washington as a linchpin of Western solidarity and security.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: How One Month of War in Ukraine Ground to a Bloody Stalemate
desc: In four weeks, huge numbers of civilians have been bombed and displaced, but Russia has so far achieved almost none of its military objectives, analysts say.
author: By Marc Santora

header: As the war in Ukraine moves into its second month, fears grow of Mariupol’s fall to Russia.
desc: Ukraine’s top military intelligence officer suggested that Russia was changing its military focus to the south and east and might be trying to divide the country.
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: At the Edge of Kyiv, Ukrainians Show Off Their Counteroffensive
desc: Destroyed tanks and body parts are all that are left of a Russian advance, part of the larger battle to block the invaders’ attempt to enter or encircle the capital.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett

header: Zelensky Gives Interview to Russian Journalists. Moscow Orders It Quashed.
desc: The remarkable interview was still published by journalists outside of Russia, an episode that laid bare the extraordinary, and partly successful, efforts at censorship by Moscow.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: In a Fiery Speech, Biden Warns of a Battle Between ‘Liberty and Repression’
desc: The president warned Western nations that the fight against autocracy would be costly and could be lengthy.
author: By Michael D. Shear, David E. Sanger and Michael Levenson

header: A history of the tensions between Ukraine and Russia.
desc: Here is a look at some key events in the run-up to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukrainians say Russians are withdrawing through Chernobyl to regroup in Belarus.
desc: NA
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: Blinken to Press Mideast Allies for Stronger Support for Ukraine
desc: The countries, which have their own relationships with Russia, have provided some modest backing, but Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will ask for more.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: Missiles hit targets in Lviv, 50 miles from the Polish border.
desc: The major city in western Ukraine, Lviv had largely been spared from Russian bombardment. It has become the a haven for people fleeing the devastation farther east.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: In Lviv, New Russian Strikes Pierce the Sense of Security in West
desc: Residents in the western city of Lviv once ignored the air raid sirens. But Russian rocket attacks over the weekend have brought the war closer to their doorstep.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Afghan Refugees in U.K. Are Still in Limbo as Ukrainians Arrive
desc: Some 12,000 Afghans who fled to Britain have been living in hotels for months awaiting permanent housing. This has raised questions about the country’s ability to take in many more escaping Ukraine.
author: By Megan Specia

header: In Kyiv Suburb, Ukrainian Military Claims a Big Prize
desc: Ukrainian soldiers have essentially retaken, for now, the town of Irpin, the scene of fierce fighting in recent weeks. Its success shows the steep challenges Russia faces in trying to capture Ukraine’s capital.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Daniel Berehulak

header: Ukraine Claims Some Battle Successes as Russia Focuses on Another Front
desc: With the fighting raging and sputtering attempts at diplomacy continuing, diplomacy between the two sides was continuing, with talks planned in Istanbul on Tuesday.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Steven Erlanger

header: A Brutal Russian Playbook Reapplied in Ukraine
desc: The besieging of cities, the deliberate targeting of civilians — they are the tactics Russia used before, in Grozny. I saw it firsthand.
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: Peace Talks Produce Signs of Progress, but No End to War Is in Sight
desc: Russia said it would “drastically” reduce military activity around Kyiv, while Ukraine said it would be willing to accept neutrality and discuss territorial claims to resolve the conflict.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Germany’s New Muscular Foreign Policy ‘Lies in the Hands of Strong Women’
desc: Angela Merkel is no longer chancellor. But as war rages in Ukraine, a mere 10-hour drive from Berlin, female ministers oversee national security.
author: By Katrin Bennhold and Steven Erlanger

header: Orthodox leader calls the invasion of Ukraine ‘atrocious,’ but stops short of denouncing Putin by name.
desc: NA
author: By Sophie Downes

header: A video shows Russian prisoners of war in Ukraine being beaten and shot in their legs.
desc: NA
author: By Haley Willis

header: A Vow to Ease Bombing Is Too Late for Many in Ukraine City Near Kyiv
desc: Russia’s offer, if honored, will not help the thousands who have already fled Chernihiv.
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: Sanctioned Oligarch’s Presence Adds Intrigue to Ukraine-Russia Talks
desc: Roman Abramovich, sanctioned owner of the Chelsea Football Club, mysteriously showed up at the talks between Ukraine and Russia in Istanbul, and is said to be playing an unofficial role.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: How Russia Is Using Ukrainians’ Hunger as a Weapon of War
desc: Residents of Mariupol, Ukraine, described how they are surviving a monthlong siege of the southern port with little food and other necessities. “No roof, no food and no water,” survivors texted relatives.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Ben Hubbard and Gina Kolata

header: A Nation of Spy-Catchers: Fear of Saboteurs Has Ukrainians on Edge
desc: There are checkpoints, hotlines and apps for reporting suspicious activities. Ukrainians worry about saboteurs mixing among them, sowing mistrust and spreading misinformation.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: ‘Like Living in a Horror Movie’: A Ukraine Town Dying a Slow Death
desc: The war never stops in Huliaipole, a town on the front lines in eastern Ukraine. Most residents have fled. Those who remain listen to the Russian shelling and wonder: Where will the next one land?
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

header: In European Classrooms, Questions About a War So Close to Home
desc: As many in Europe have grappled with the shock of facing a war on their doorstep, teachers say they are facing tough questions posed about the conflict by worried children.
author: By Emma Bubola

header: Russia Steps Up Attacks Amid Reports of Rifts in Moscow
desc: Despite claims of de-escalation, Russian forces turned their fury on Chernihiv and the suburbs of Kyiv. U.S. officials say they believe Vladimir Putin’s aides are misleading him about the war.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Megan Specia and Julian E. Barnes

header: What is the Wagner Group?
desc: The private Russian military force, which has close ties to President Vladimir Putin and has been used in war zones across the world, is expanding its presence in Ukraine.
author: By Victoria Kim

header: U.S. intelligence suggests that Putin’s advisers misinformed him on Ukraine.
desc: One American official said that there “is now persistent tension” between the Russian president and his Defense Ministry.
author: By Julian E. Barnes, Lara Jakes and John Ismay

header: Buses sent to evacuate people from Mariupol are held up by Russian forces, a Ukrainian official says.
desc: NA
author: By Alyssa Lukpat

header: Syrian Mercenaries Deploy to Russia en Route to Ukrainian Battlefields
desc: A first contingent has arrived in Russia for military training including members of a Syrian unit that worked with Russian officers in Syria, backing President Bashar al-Assad.
author: By Ben Hubbard, Hwaida Saad and Asmaa al-Omar

header: A new satellite image shows food lines in Mariupol, as Russian forces push deeper into the city.
desc: The city has been under siege for weeks and is suffering from severe food and water shortages.
author: By Haley Willis and Sarah Kerr

header: More Mixed Signals From Russia as Ukraine War Enters Sixth Week
desc: Moscow appeared to adjust its position on humanitarian access to Mariupol, but there was little evidence to support Russian claims of a military pullback near Kyiv.
author: By Megan Specia, Anton Troianovski and Steven Erlanger

header: War in Ukraine Compounds Hunger in East Africa
desc: The conflict has driven up the cost of food in a region that depends heavily on crops from Russia and Ukraine and is facing what could be its worst drought in four decades.
author: By Abdi Latif Dahir

header: With Ukraine Invasion, Hungary’s Leader Softens His Embrace of Russia
desc: Facing an election on Sunday, Viktor Orban plays neutral peacemaker while campaigning against the “gender insanity” that he says is creeping in from the West.
author: By Andrew Higgins and Benjamin Novak

header: Russia in Broad Retreat From Kyiv, Seeking to Regroup From Battering
desc: A short drive from Kyiv in any direction turned up scenes of incinerated Russian vehicles, charred engine parts and chunks of armor. Attention is now shifting to the east, where Moscow says it is redirecting its forces.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Neil MacFarquhar

header: Mariupol Mass Evacuation Falters as Red Cross Judges It Too Dangerous
desc: Thousands are reported to have escaped the besieged city, and new signs emerged that Russian forces were retreating from areas outside of Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.
author: By Megan Specia, Anton Troianovski, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Julian E. Barnes

header: Shaken at First, Many Russians Now Rally Behind Putin’s Invasion
desc: Polls and interviews show many Russians now accept the Kremlin’s assertion that their country is under siege from the West. Opponents are leaving the country or keeping quiet.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Valeriya Safronova

header: Pope Francis alludes to Putin’s bringing ‘dark shadows of war’ to Ukraine.
desc: The pope also said in response to a reporter’s question on a papal flight to Malta that a possible visit to Kyiv was “on the table.”
author: By Jason Horowitz

header: Refuse to cooperate with the Kremlin’s war, Zelensky tells Ukrainians and Russians.
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine threatened retribution for people who collaborate with occupying forces and accused retreating Russians of planting mines and even booby-trapping corpses.
author: By Richard Pérez-Pena

header: A Ukrainian photojournalist who went missing near Kyiv is found dead.
desc: Maks Levin, 40, was a prominent freelancer who had spent years covering the conflict in Ukraine.
author: By Megan Specia

header: For Putin, Invasion Is the Latest in a Long String of Failures in Ukraine
desc: Beginning in 2004, the Russian leader’s repeated efforts to subjugate his neighbor have been defeated, frustrating his imperial ambitions.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: Pope Blames a ‘Potentate’ for Casting ‘Dark Shadows of War’ on Ukraine
desc: Francis’ remarks during a trip to Malta were the closest he has come to pinning the war in Ukraine on President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
author: By Jason Horowitz

header: Reports of atrocities emerge from Ukraine as Russia repositions its forces.
desc: As outrage grew, world leaders promised new sanctions, and it appeared that Russia’s gas industry, which Europe depends on heavily, may no longer be off the table.
author: By Carlotta Gall, Andrew E. Kramer and Natalie Kitroeff

header: Images of Russian Atrocities Push West Toward Tougher Sanctions
desc: President Biden called for Vladimir Putin to face trial for war crimes, and European officials will meet to consider possibly banning some Russian energy imports.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: ‘Sitting at Home and Trembling’: A Town Emerges After a Russian Retreat
desc: A local official said he was detained and interrogated by the Russians, and described what he called mock executions.
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: ‘This Is True Barbarity’: Life and Death Under Russian Occupation
desc: The town of Trostyanets was occupied by Russian forces for a month before the Ukrainian military liberated it. Residents described weeks of hunger and horror.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

header: In a Kyiv Suburb,‘They Shot Everyone They Saw’
desc: With Russian forces retreating, Ukrainians in Bucha are finding scores of bodies in yards and on the roads amid mounting evidence of intentional and indiscriminate killings of civilians.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Bristling Against the West, China Rallies Domestic Sympathy for Russia
desc: China’s Communist Party is mounting an ideological campaign aimed at officials and students. The message: The country will not turn its back on Russia.
author: By Chris Buckley

header: Russia strikes infrastructure on Ukraine’s southern coastline.
desc: Troops are in retreat from the capital, Kyiv, but they are still battering the coastline.
author: By Jane Arraf and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Atrocities in Bucha could complicate Russia-Ukraine talks.
desc: It was unclear what effect the killing of civilians outside Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, would have on negotiations.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: How to Avoid Sharing Misinformation on Ukraine
desc: Uncritically sharing posts about Ukraine can make you an accidental conduit for war propaganda. Here's what to watch for.
author: By Daniel Victor

header: Zelensky blasts Merkel and Sarkozy for denying Ukraine NATO membership.
desc: In a video address, he said that NATO’s decision in 2008 not to give Ukraine a path to membership helped lead to atrocities by Russian forces.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: Up-Close Ukraine Atrocity Photographs Touch a Global Nerve
desc: The apparent execution of Ukrainian civilians by retreating Russian forces, their bodies strewn in streets and yards, has focused attention on what constitutes crimes in war.
author: By Rick Gladstone

header: Civilians Flee Eastern Ukraine as Signs Point to Stepped-Up Russian Attack
desc: Alarmed by reports of atrocities near Kyiv, many residents of Ukraine’s east, now suffering the brunt of Russian force, are getting out while they can.
author: By Megan Specia, Cora Engelbrecht and Eric Schmitt

header: More Russians Consider Costs of War in Ukraine as Casualties Mount
desc: Many Russians have been in the dark about their country’s losses. As news of more Russian deaths arrives, the reactions range from anger at the Kremlin to parroting the state’s messaging that blames “Nazis’’ in Ukraine.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Valeriya Safronova

header: Traces of Lives Cut Short: Bread on a Park Bench, Blood Pooled Nearby
desc: The violence of war is often random. Those who suffer most are the civilians caught in the middle. Two recent deaths in Kharkiv, Ukraine, are a testament to that.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak

header: Zelensky Accuses Russia of Atrocities and Criticizes U.N.’s Inaction
desc: In a blistering address to the United Nations Security Council, Ukraine’s president asked what use the body was if it would not intervene to stop a war of aggression.
author: By Richard Pérez-Pena

header: The End of the (Pipe)line? Germany Scrambles to Wean Itself Off Russian Gas
desc: Dangerously dependent on Russian gas, Germany is still refusing to cut off President Putin, whose war it is effectively subsidizing to the tune of some $220 million a day.
author: By Katrin Bennhold

header: Some Ukrainian Refugees Are Returning Home, Despite the Risks
desc: A growing number of families, convinced the war could last for years, have decided that facing danger at home is better than life as a refugee.
author: By Jane Arraf

header: In South Korea, Ukraine War Revives the Nuclear Question
desc: Seoul abandoned a covert program in the 1970s, but some argue it is time for the country to embrace its nuclear ambitions and safeguard against a Russia-style invasion.
author: By Choe Sang-Hun

header: Why Tracking Putin’s Wealth Is So Difficult
desc: Amid speculation that oligarchs are holding cash and luxury assets for the Russian president, many of his extravagances can be traced elsewhere: the Russian state.
author: By Mike McIntire

header: Countries have expelled 120 Russian spies since the war in Ukraine started.
desc: Despite the purge of intelligence officers, former officials cautioned that Moscow would have other ways to collect information and that the efforts would have little impact on the war in Ukraine.
author: By Julian E. Barnes

header: ‘He Is a Child of War’: Giving Birth Amid Chaos in Ukraine
desc: As artillery shells fall, pregnant women are delivering prematurely, being shuttled in and out of bomb shelters or having babies in basements without even a midwife to help. Tens of thousands more are displaced.
author: NA

header: Missile Strike in Eastern Ukraine Kills 50 Awaiting Train to Escape
desc: Ukraine’s president blamed Russia for the latest atrocity in the six-week-old war, calling the Russian invasion force “an evil that has no limits.” Moscow denied responsibility.
author: By Megan Specia and Michael Levenson

header: Land Mines on a Timer, Scattered Over a Ukrainian Town
desc: Civilians near Kharkiv in northeastern Ukraine are discovering a new threat: munitions that eject up to two dozen small mines that explode at intervals.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and John Ismay

header: Russian Blunders in Chernobyl: ‘They Came and Did Whatever They Wanted’
desc: Tank treads ripped up the toxic soil, bulldozers carved trenches and bunkers, and soldiers spent a month camped in — and dug into — a radioactive forest.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Ivor Prickett

header: West Moves to Curb Russian Coal and Trade Over Ukraine War
desc: The United Nations also penalized Russia, suspending it from the Human Rights Council, as Russian forces moved to assault eastern Ukraine and more evidence emerged implicating them in atrocities against civilians.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Michael Levenson and Steven Erlanger

header: In Ukraine, Sudden Death on a Train Platform
desc: A railway station in eastern Ukraine had been a main departure point for people seeking to escape an expected Russian onslaught. A rocket assault left at least 50 dead.
author: By Megan Specia

header: Pink Floyd says it will release its first new track in decades to support Ukraine.
desc: The song, “Hey Hey Rise Up,” is a reworking of a protest song from World War I and features the Ukrainian rock star Andriy Khlyvnyuk of the band Boombox.
author: By Anushka Patil

header: A Russian attack hits a train station in Ukraine’s east where crowds had been evacuating.
desc: The strike in Kramatorsk, which had been a main point of evacuation for thousands of people trying to flee eastern Ukraine, left “dozens” dead and injured, according to a local official.
author: By Megan Specia

header: For Ukrainian Writer, War Evokes Scars of Time in Captivity
desc: Stanislav Aseyev, a 32-year-old journalist, had documented his abuse in a prison run by Russian-backed separatists. Now, the war reminds him of why Ukrainians are fighting for their lives.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Ukraine’s Eurovision entry goes on tour to help fund the war effort.
desc: Kalush Orchestra, a group that mixes rap and traditional Ukrainian music, was given special permission to leave the country and play internationally.
author: By Victoria Kim

header: Racing for safety, Ukrainians meet new perils.
desc: With Russian troops massing for a presumed new assault in the east, many civilians heeded warnings and headed west. Some did not make it.
author: By Cora Engelbrecht, David Zucchino and Jane Arraf

header: Russia Shuffles Command in Ukraine as Thousands Flee the East
desc: The Russian campaign will be consolidated under a veteran of the Syrian war, while Western nations pump additional arms into Ukraine.
author: By Eric Schmitt, Jane Arraf and Michael Levenson

header: A Stricken Ukrainian City Empties, and Those Left Fear What’s Next
desc: After the deadly strike on the train station in Kramatorsk, Ukraine, those who stayed behind are grim about the future: “We think we will be swept off the face of the earth.”
author: NA

header: Why Calls for War Crimes Justice Over Ukraine Face Long Odds
desc: If those in power act as if they are immune to the laws of war, it may be because they often are. But following through is not necessarily an empty exercise.
author: By Max Fisher

header: Spurred by Putin, Russians Turn on One Another Over the War
desc: Citizens are denouncing one another, illustrating how the war is feeding paranoia and polarization in Russian society.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: ‘Everything Was Destroyed’: War Hits Ukraine’s Farms
desc: The Russian invasion is pummeling Ukraine’s agriculture, threatening harvests in Europe’s breadbasket and contributing to a global food crisis.
author: By Emma Bubola, Valeriya Safronova and Maria Varenikova

header: Israel’s Ukraine Policy Prompts Scrutiny of Russian-Israeli Oligarchs
desc: Israel has expressed solidarity with Ukraine but avoided direct criticism of Russia, raising questions about Russian-Israeli businessmen close to the Kremlin.
author: By Patrick Kingsley

header: Ukraine’s Draft Dodgers Face Guilt, Shame and Reproach
desc: Thousands of Ukrainian men are avoiding military service, putting them on risky paths into Europe. Among Ukrainians, it’s stirring a complicated debate.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Monika Pronczuk

header: Japan dials up measures against Russia, aligning itself with the U.S. and Europe.
desc: The country has announced a ban on Russian coal and restrictions on imports including timber, vodka and machinery. It is also expelling eight Russian diplomats.
author: By Victoria Kim

header: An 85-year-old mother recalls a desperate struggle to save her daughter in eastern Ukraine.
desc: Lidiia, 85, fought through a night to free her disabled daughter from rubble after a Russian strike hit their house. She didn’t have the strength.
author: By Jane Arraf

header: Putin Calls Talks a ‘Dead End’ but Limits War Aim to Eastern Ukraine
desc: It was the first time that President Vladimir Putin himself had defined a more limited military goal: taking control of the Donbas region in the east of Ukraine — not the whole country.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Far From Defeated, Putin Intends to Escalate War in Ukraine
desc: Austria’s chancellor said after meeting with Mr. Putin that the Russian president had “totally adopted the logic of war.”
author: By Steven Erlanger and Anton Troianovski

header: No More ‘Have a Nice Day’: Lviv Learns to Live With War
desc: Ukraine’s cultural capital, the western city of Lviv, is trying to adjust to being on the fringes of war and at the center of massive displacement.
author: By Jane Arraf and Mauricio Lima

header: With India on the fence over Ukraine, Biden meets with Modi.
desc: India, heavily dependent on Russian weapons, has long tried not to take sides between Moscow and Washington. It has refrained from denouncing Russia’s invasion or imposing sanctions.
author: By Mujib Mashal

header: Ukraine War Pushes Germans to Change. They Are Wavering.
desc: In just six weeks since Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced a strategic shift for his country, already doubts are emerging about how real and deep it is.
author: By Katrin Bennhold and Steven Erlanger

header: Zelensky says Ukraine takes ‘as seriously as possible’ an apparent threat of Russian chemical weapon use.
desc: A Ukrainian unit in Mariupol claimed Russian forces had used chemical weapons there. Their report could not be independently confirmed.
author: By Jesus Jiménez

header: The U.N. Security Council focuses on the war’s toll on Ukraine’s women and children.
desc: NA
author: By Farnaz Fassihi

header: Western powers look into an unverified claim of possible use of a chemical agent in Mariupol.
desc: Ukrainian commanders said “a poisonous substance” caused respiratory difficulties and neurological symptoms in a handful of soldiers and civilians.
author: By Marc Santora, Megan Specia and Rick Gladstone

header: Ukraine says a political ally of Putin has been detained in a ‘special operation.’
desc: Viktor Medvedchuk, a wealthy Ukrainian politician seen as the Kremlin’s main agent of influence in Ukraine in recent years, had disappeared shortly after the start of the war.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Anton Troianovski

header: Name, phone, address: The writing on a child’s back is now a symbol of Ukrainian parents’ terror.
desc: A mother who wrote emergency contact information on her 2-year-old’s back has become a voice for countless Ukrainian parents forced to do the same.
author: By Anushka Patil

header: Hiding in Plain Sight, a Soviet-Era Air Defense System Arrives in Ukraine
desc: Encouraged by the United States, Slovakia “donated” a bulky but effective S-300, hoping to challenge Russian domination of the skies in the war next door.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: ‘Clear Patterns’ of Russian Rights Abuses Found in Ukraine, Report Says
desc: Momentum is building to try to bring war crimes charges tied to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
author: By Marc Santora, Erika Solomon and Carlotta Gall

header: Despite Russian Warnings, Finland and Sweden Draw Closer to NATO
desc: The invasion of Ukraine has heightened security fears, pushing even formally nonaligned countries toward the Western alliance.
author: By Steven Erlanger and Johanna Lemola

header: The Ukrainian Refugee Crisis Is a Women’s Crisis
desc: A wave of displaced women and children into Poland is forcing the country to address its lack of protections for working women.
author: By Amanda Taub

header: A Russian warship is ‘seriously damaged’ in the Black Sea. Conflicting explanations emerge.
desc: Ukraine claimed it was the same vessel that was famously and obscenely told off by Ukrainian troops in February.
author: By Anushka Patil and Alan Yuhas

header: On Poland-Ukraine Border, the Past Is Always Present. It’s Not Always Predictive.
desc: For a Jewish reporter with Eastern European roots, one of the hardest challenges covering the war is reconciling the horrors of the Holocaust with the Poland and Ukraine of today.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: The U.S. is considering sending a high-level official to Kyiv.
desc: No American official has publicly visited Ukraine since Russia launched its invasion in late February.
author: By Michael D. Shear

header: Pencil Cases and Air-Raid Sirens: School at War for Ukraine’s Children
desc: The country’s teachers are doing their best to provide lessons for the millions of school-age children whose education has been interrupted.
author: By Megan Specia and Maria Varenikova

header: Tensions Over the Ukraine War Deepen the Chill Near the North Pole
