desc: The war and the comments of a Russian diplomat have strained relations on an archipelago in Norway where Russians, Ukrainians and Norwegians have lived peacefully for decades.
author: By Jeré Longman and Erin Schaff

header: Russians planted thousands of land mines and booby-traps to ‘kill or maim’ civilians, Ukrainians say.
desc: Departing Russian soldiers have laced large swaths of the country with buried mines and jury-rigged bombs, some hidden inside homes, to terrorize returning civilians.
author: By Cora Engelbrecht

header: Russia Fires Missile Barrage at Ukrainian Cities and Military Targets
desc: The strikes seemed aimed at hampering Ukraine’s war fighting capacity as the conflict shifts to eastern Donbas region, and at responding to the sinking of a Russian warship.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Girding for New Battle, Russia Warns U.S. on Advanced Weapons for Ukraine
desc: The warnings were regarded as a sign that American military assistance to Ukraine was compounding problems for the Russians in their two-month-old invasion.
author: By David E. Sanger, Helene Cooper and Anton Troianovski

header: Putin’s Ukraine Gamble Pivots to a Very Different Battlefield
desc: After Russian forces were mauled in cities and towns in northern Ukraine, Vladimir V. Putin is shifting the focus of his invasion to the flatlands of Donbas, in the east.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Eric Schmitt, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Michael Schwirtz

header: ‘Thank You for Not Killing Us’
desc: An ordeal at a mental health facility in Ukraine illuminated the horrors of the Russian occupation in the areas around Kyiv.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Oleksandr Chubko and David Guttenfelder

header: The Moskva’s sinking inspires one of Ukraine’s most popular rockers.
desc: Vadym Krasnooky, whose band Mad Heads had stopped performing when the war began, said his new song is meant to ‘channel all this hate.’
author: By Jane Arraf

header: Russia’s Black Sea flagship was hit by 2 Ukrainian missiles, a U.S. official says.
desc: Moscow claimed the sinking was an accident, but U.S. intelligence reports say the cruiser went down after Ukraine struck it with Neptune missiles.
author: By Helene Cooper

header: Anticipating the need for coastal defense, Ukraine asked for anti-ship missiles, U.S. officials say.
desc: NA
author: By Julian E. Barnes

header: Where Russians Turn for Uncensored News on Ukraine
desc: Telegram is the platform of choice for Russians seeking to escape Moscow’s propaganda web. But can it last?
author: By Valeriya Safronova, Neil MacFarquhar and Adam Satariano

header: Why Ukraine War Crimes Trials Could Take Many Years
desc: Long after the fighting ends, any prosecutions and trials arising from it could be barely beginning. Here is a look at the complexities of bringing aggressors to justice.
author: By Rick Gladstone and Farnaz Fassihi

header: A reporter covering the war reflects on the legacy of the Holocaust.
desc: In eastern Poland, perceptions of Russia and Ukraine are shaped by a traumatic past.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: Ukraine Says Russia Begins Assault in the East After Raining Missiles Nationwide
desc: The president of Ukraine and a top national security aide said the Russian offensive, anticipated for weeks, had finally begun after a Russian missile barrage that included the first deadly strike on the western city of Lviv.
author: By Jane Arraf, Ivan Nechepurenko and Mark Landler

header: In the besieged and broken city of Mariupol, Ukrainians vow a ‘fight to the end.’
desc: Defying a Russian demand to surrender or be “eliminated,” Ukrainian forces in a sprawling steel plant are making a last stand for the strategic city.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Jack Nicas and Neil MacFarquhar

header: Ukraine War Divides Orthodox Faithful
desc: Around the world, national churches, parishes and even families are reassessing relations with Patriarch Kirill of Moscow, who has encouraged Russia’s aggression.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Sophia Kishkovsky

header: Atrocities in Ukraine War Have Deep Roots in Russian Military
desc: Like the shelling of cities, the seemingly pointless, close-up killing of individuals recalls wars in Chechnya. Do they reflect intent, or only indifference, propaganda and a military culture of violence?
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Bleak assessments of the Russian economy clash with Putin’s rosy claims.
desc: While Vladimir Putin boasts that Russia is holding up under Western sanctions, his central bank chief and the mayor of Moscow warned that the worst was yet to come.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Patricia Cohen

header: To Push Back Russians, Ukrainians Hit a Village With Cluster Munitions
desc: The New York Times verified that Ukraine’s forces appeared to fire at least two of these internationally banned weapons in a neighborhood, putting Ukrainian civilians at extreme risk.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and John Ismay

header: Top Ukrainians say Russia’s eastern offensive is underway, but some analysts warn it has barely begun.
desc: NA
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Ivan Nechepurenko, Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: ‘They Are Gone, Vanished’: Missing Persons Haunt Ukrainian Village
desc: In a Russian-occupied village, five men went off to feed cattle. Their relatives and neighbors are wondering what happened to them.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

header: What is the Neptune, the Ukrainian-made missile that sank Russia’s warship?
desc: The missile is part of a coastal defense system designed to hide below enemy radar and evade counterattacks.
author: By John Ismay

header: A Russian strike hits Lviv, a city relatively untouched by violence.
desc: Hundreds of thousands of displaced people from other parts of Ukraine have fled to, or through, Lviv to escape the fighting. Then it landed on their doorstep.
author: By Jane Arraf

header: The U.S. Races to Arm Ukraine With Heavier, More Advanced Weaponry
desc: Washington and its allies are scouring Central Europe and the world to get Ukraine the weapons it needs for the next phase of the war.
author: By Steven Erlanger, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes

header: More Cautious, Russia Embarks on New Phase of Ukraine War
desc: Despite the Kremlin’s new methodical approach focusing on eastern Ukraine, the Russian military still faces some of the same problems that hampered it after the war began.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Michael Schwirtz and Eric Schmitt

header: A Ukrainian Town Goes Underground as Russia Assaults the East
desc: As Ukrainian forces dig into trenches and residents flee into basements, Russia’s artillery attacks have intensified. “They can’t get through the front lines and so they’re starting simply to destroy the city,” a Ukrainian official said.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Warning Ukraine’s Friends to ‘Think Twice,’ Putin Tests Advanced Missile
desc: Vladimir Putin said Russia’s test-firing of its new I.C.B.M. sends a message, as his forces prepare for a broad offensive in eastern Ukraine.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: Despair in Mariupol’s last stronghold: ‘They’re bombing us with everything’
desc: A huge Soviet-era steel mill is where the last Ukrainian defenders of Mariupol have taken refuge as Russia’s battle to take full control of the city appeared to be entering its final stages.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Cora Engelbrecht and Andrew E. Kramer

header: He Was a Penniless Donor to the Far Right. He Was Also a Russian Spy.
desc: An investigation in Slovakia has exposed how Russian clandestine operations are trying to sow discord in Europe and create sympathy for Moscow over Ukraine.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: The U.S. is bolstering Ukrainian artillery and air power.
desc: Weeklong training for Ukraine’s soldiers on howitzers is taking place outside of their country, a U.S. defense official said. Additionally, new spare parts have allowed Kyiv to get more than 20 warplanes back in service.
author: By John Ismay

header: Ukraine’s War Efforts Gain an Unlikely Source of Funding: Memes
desc: A campaign using internet memes and merchandise has rallied international public support for Ukraine in its war with Russia.
author: By Jane Arraf

header: Ukraine’s profane stamp that has become a symbol of resistance sells out.
desc: NA
author: By Jane Arraf

header: Calls to Give Heavy Weapons to Ukraine Divide Germany’s Government
desc: Weeks after Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced a paradigm shift in military strategy, his government is struggling to balance domestic politics, how to help Ukraine and anxiety over provoking Russia.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: Russians Seize 42 Towns in Eastern Ukraine as Fighting Intensifies
desc: Ukrainian military officials vowed to reverse Russia’s territorial gains in what was turning into a grinding back-and-forth struggle along a front stretching more than 300 miles.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Michael Levenson

header: Calling Off Steel Plant Assault, Putin Prematurely Claims Victory in Mariupol
desc: With casualties mounting and progress slow in his war on Ukraine, Vladimir V. Putin is eager to present it to the Russian people as a success.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: Ukraine needs up to $7 billion in support per month, Zelensky says.
desc: Ukraine has suffered $550 billion in losses from the war, President Volodymyr Zelensky told the World Bank on Thursday.
author: By Jesus Jiménez

header: With sunken warship, Russian disinformation faces a test.
desc: Families of missing crew members say the Russian authorities are giving them the runaround after a flagship sank last week in the Black Sea.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Alina Lobzina

header: Dug in on the front lines, Ukrainian soldiers fight to repel the Russian onslaught.
desc: After near-annihilation, and a marriage proposal, a Ukrainian unit has become a group of hardened veterans, dug in and determined.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Pope Francis condemns the war in Ukraine (again), but doesn’t name Putin (again).
desc: In a wide-ranging interview with an Argentine newspaper, Francis defended his decision not to call out Mr. Putin, but said he was ready to do “everything” to prevent more deaths.
author: By Elisabetta Povoledo

header: One Ukrainian War Casualty: The World’s Largest Airplane
desc: Mriya, the world’s largest aircraft, was destroyed in a pivotal battle at the start of the war. It was a beloved symbol for all of Ukraine but perhaps no one misses it more than its first pilot.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: People who escaped from Mariupol describe the flight from its ruins: ‘The city is gone.’
desc: After a harrowing, all-night drive through Russian-controlled territory, evacuees said most of the city was pulverized by weeks of Russian shelling.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Satellite images show what appears to be a growing mass grave near Mariupol.
desc: NA
author: By Cora Engelbrecht and Christiaan Triebert

header: Biden announces $800 million in new military aid and questions Russia’s hold of Mariupol.
desc: President Biden said President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia would “never succeed in dominating” Ukraine.
author: By David E. Sanger

header: As Western Arms Pour Into Ukraine, Zelensky Promises Victory
desc: “The day when they will be forced to leave Ukraine is approaching,” the Ukrainian president said of the Russians, in a sharp change of tone.
author: By Marc Santora, Michael Schwirtz and Michael Levenson

header: U.S. Officials Make Top-Secret Visit to Ukraine
desc: The American government refused to comment on reports that Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III had traveled to Ukraine to meet with its leaders.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Natalie Kitroeff

header: Rattled by Ukraine War, Moldova Strives to Dodge Russia’s Long Shadow
desc: Moldova’s destiny has been intertwined uncomfortably with Russia’s for years, and the Ukraine invasion has accelerated its efforts to break free from Moscow.
author: By Monika Pronczuk and Jeffrey Gettleman

header: In a Ukrainian School, 12 People Await the War’s End, or Their Own
desc: In the basement of a battered school in Kharkiv, a dozen residents have taken shelter. In a neighborhood not far away, life has returned to some sense of normalcy. But they choose to stay.
author: NA

header: With Us or With Them? In a New Cold War, How About Neither.
desc: Old geopolitical foes are facing off after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, but much of the world is refusing to take sides.
author: By Hannah Beech, Abdi Latif Dahir and Oscar Lopez

header: Blinken and Austin meet in Kyiv with Zelensky.
desc: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III met Sunday with President Volodymyr Zelensky, the first senior U.S. officials known to have visited Ukraine since the invasion.
author: By Eduardo Medina and Michael Crowley

header: Biden nominates an ambassador in Kyiv, aiming to fill a void in the U.S.-Ukraine relationship.
desc: President Biden nominated Bridget Brink, the current U.S. ambassador to Slovakia, as ambassador to Ukraine. The position has been empty for more than a year.
author: By Anushka Patil and Edward Wong

header: Ukrainians in Mariupol’s steel mill are holding on, despite intensifying attacks, a commander tells The Times.
desc: Capt. Svyatoslav Palamar says he and others would give up the factory if they could leave safely.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: The Former Chancellor Who Became Putin’s Man in Germany
desc: Gerhard Schröder, who is paid almost $1 million a year by Russian-controlled energy companies, has become a pariah. But he is also a symbol of Germany’s Russia policy.
author: By Katrin Bennhold

header: Ukrainians lean on Easter traditions in the shadow of a devastating war.
desc: In Lviv, residents had laid bouquets of flowers at the feet of a statue of the Virgin Mary, next to piles of white sandbags protecting the statue from bombings.
author: By Jane Arraf, Marc Santora and Emma Bubola

header: As Diplomacy Hopes Dim, U.S. Marshals Allies to Furnish Long-Term Military Aid to Ukraine
desc: Germany said it would send Ukraine dozens of armored antiaircraft vehicles, a major shift for a country that has been reluctant to escalate the conflict with Russia.
author: By John Ismay, Christopher F. Schuetze and Michael Levenson

header: Emboldened by Ukraine’s Grit, U.S. Wants to See Russia Weakened
desc: Hours after the American secretaries of defense and state met with Ukraine’s president in Kyiv, Russia hit at least five Ukrainian railway stations in rocket attacks.
author: By Marc Santora, John Ismay and Rick Gladstone

header: Standing in the path of war, a small Ukrainian town braces as Russians advance.
desc: In Orikhiv, near the front lines, most residents have fled and those who remain endure constant shelling and the fear of what comes next.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Lynsey Addario

header: Fires rip through Russian oil depots not far from the Ukrainian border.
desc: Russian state television reported two separate explosions, but officials acknowledged only one.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Austin Ramzy

header: A new U.S.-led international group will meet monthly to focus on aiding Ukraine.
desc: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III announced the formation of the Ukraine Contact Group, with more than 40 member nations, to coordinate military and humanitarian assistance.
author: By John Ismay

header: How Zelensky Tamed Ukraine’s Fractious Politics and Stood Up to Putin
desc: Ukrainian politics were known for sharp-elbowed infighting. But as he defends his country against the Russian invasion, President Volodymyr Zelensky has his government presenting a unified front.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Explosions rattle a breakaway region in Moldova, raising fears of a broader war.
desc: The blasts in Transnistria, a region bordering Ukraine that is run by Russia-backed separatists, have fueled talk of Moldova being dragged into the war.
author: By Monika Pronczuk

header: Putin congratulates Emmanuel Macron on his election victory in France.
desc: Mr. Macron’s opponent, Marine Le Pen, was seen in Russia as a potential game-changing option, amid the threat of new sanctions over the war in Ukraine.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Roughly 15,000 Russian troops have died since the start of the war, the U.K. estimates.
desc: NA
author: By Anushka Patil

header: Americans’ support for admitting refugees is at a record high, Gallup finds.
desc: Gallup reported the record high after its new poll found that 78 percent of adults in the United States approve of allowing up to 100,000 Ukrainian refugees into the country.
author: By Anushka Patil

header: Ukraine War Impact Widens: Russia Cuts Gas Flow and Vows More Reprisals
desc: New explosions across Ukraine’s borders, Russia’s shut-off of natural gas to two European nations and Moscow’s warning of additional “counterstrikes” pointed to escalating hostilities.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Neil MacFarquhar, Shashank Bengali and Megan Specia

header: They Flooded Their Own Village, and Kept the Russians at Bay
desc: The waters that poured into Demydiv were one of many instances of Ukraine wreaking havoc on its own territory to slow Russia’s advance. Residents couldn’t be happier. “We saved Kyiv,” one said.
author: NA

header: Touring wreckage near Kyiv, the top U.N. official declares the war ‘an absurdity.’
desc: António Guterres’ goals include securing evacuation routes for besieged civilians and supporting the prosecution of war crimes.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Maria Varenikova

header: European gas prices jump after Gazprom cuts natural gas to Poland and Bulgaria.
desc: The market reaction underscored that a dreaded moment in the war had arrived: the severe disruption of Russian natural gas exports to the E.U.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Russian intelligence was behind an attack on the editor of Novaya Gazeta, a U.S. official says.
desc: Dmitri Muratov was on a train preparing to leave Moscow at the time of the attack, which caused chemical burns to his eyes.
author: By Julian E. Barnes

header: Russia Releases Former U.S. Marine in Prisoner Swap
desc: Trevor Reed had been detained since 2019, after he was accused of assaulting and endangering the lives of two police officers.
author: By Michael D. Shear and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Explosions are reported in three Russian regions bordering Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Victoria Kim

header: Explosions and downed drones suggest Ukraine is striking targets deeper inside Russia.
desc: NA
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: Political leaders shift rhetoric as they prepare for a protracted struggle in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: In a strategy shift, Russia is making slower advances in eastern Ukraine, analysts say.
desc: NA
author: By Cora Engelbrecht

header: Kremlin Deploys New Troops to Ukraine as Both Sides Gird for a War of Attrition
desc: Moscow is hitting fuel refineries and imperiling critical harvests, while Ukrainian forces are being buoyed by an influx of heavy weapons.
author: By Marc Santora, Jane Arraf and Michael Levenson

header: Amid Hardening Western Resolve, Signs of Russia’s Stalling in Eastern Ukraine
desc: Pentagon officials say the Russian drive in Donbas is being hampered by poor logistics and stiff Ukrainian resistance.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: A Body Bag and a Sister in Denial
desc: The war in Ukraine is so big that it has shaken the world. But for a sister looking for her missing older brother, it was reduced to a visit to a morgue.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

header: They Survived the Holocaust. Now, They Are Fleeing to Germany.
desc: A complex operation is underway to evacuate Holocaust survivors from Ukraine. For rescuers and evacuees alike, it means confronting the past.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: Ukraine singles out Russian soldiers for atrocities in Bucha.
desc: In the first detailed set of allegations since the invasion, Ukrainian officials published the names and photos of Russian soldiers they say tortured civilians in a suburb of Kyiv.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: The death of an American fighting for Ukraine is confirmed by his family.
desc: Willy Joseph Cancel Jr., 22, died in combat earlier this week, according to his uncle. He is believed to be the first American killed while fighting in Ukraine.
author: By John Ismay and Dave Philipps

header: Ukrainian Official Outlines Intentional Ambiguity on Strikes Inside Russia
desc: The strikes have been one of the most intriguing, and opaque, new elements of the recent fighting. But when it comes to confirming their origins, “we don’t say yes and we don’t say no,’’ said the official.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukrainian officials said they found the bodies of three men in Bucha, with signs they had been ‘tortured.’
desc: A police chief said that victims’ bodies were discovered in a forest, and showed signs of mutilation.
author: By Esha Ray

header: Ukraine says Russia looted ancient gold artifacts from a museum.
desc: According to Ukrainian officials, Russian soldiers, aided by a mysterious expert, broke into a museum and spirited away priceless artifacts from the Scythian empire.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Oleksandr Chubko

header: Sunflower Oil ‘Vanishes’ as Ukraine War Grinds On
desc: Several British supermarkets have joined other chains around the world in asking shoppers to limit their cooking oil purchases, as supplies dwindle and prices rise.
author: By Christine Hauser

header: Painful Stories Emerge From Mariupol, While Combat Rages to the East
desc: With its forces making only slow progress and enduring heavy losses, Russia now plans to annex eastern parts of Ukraine after a sham election, the U.S. says.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Michael Levenson

header: Pelosi Visit to Ukraine Signals Growing U.S. Resolve Against Russia
desc: In Mariupol, the scene of intense fighting, civilians who had taken refuge at a steel plant were at least able to begin evacuating.
author: By Steven Erlanger, Jane Arraf and Marc Santora

header: They Fell Deeply in Love in Bucha. One Russian Bullet Ended It All.
desc: Over nearly two decades, Iryna Abramova and her husband, Oleh, built a life of love and happiness. Now, she says, she wishes the Russian soldiers had shot her, too.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Daniel Berehulak

header: Russian Tycoon Criticized Putin’s War. Retribution Was Swift.
desc: Oleg Tinkov spoke out against his country’s war in Ukraine. Now he is in hiding. In an exclusive interview he said, “I don’t believe in Russia’s future’’ under Vladimir Putin.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Ukraine acknowledges that the ‘Ghost of Kyiv’ is a myth.
desc: The legend of a pilot who shot down numerous Russian aircraft was one of the more successful pieces of propaganda in Ukraine’s information war.
author: By Emma Bubola

header: A U.S. diplomat says Russia is planning to annex parts of Ukraine with ‘sham’ elections.
desc: The official said that Russia may also try to take over parts of Ukraine by imposing “puppets and proxies” in local governments and forcing out democratically elected officials.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: Deaths of foreign fighters draw renewed attention to the military volunteers in Ukraine.
desc: At least three foreigners have been killed fighting with Ukraine’s International Legion. One analyst said many would-be volunteers underestimated the danger from Russian forces.
author: By Jane Arraf

header: Russia’s top officer visited the front line to change the offensive’s course, U.S. and Ukraine officials say.
desc: The presence of such a high-ranking official on the front lines is highly unusual and comes amid what Western military analysts describe as increasing disarray within Russian forces.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Eric Schmitt

header: In Kyiv, residents cautiously return and embrace a renewed sense of normalcy.
desc: A month after the Ukrainian Army defeated the Russian forces that had partly encircled Ukraine’s capital, tension is slowly seeping out of the city.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Zelensky says around 100 civilians are being evacuated from the Mariupol steel factory.
desc: The Ukrainian president said that civilians were being evacuated from the Azovstal steel factory and are headed to a “controlled area.”
author: By Marc Santora

header: As Victory Day Looms in Russia, Guesswork Grows Over Putin’s Ukraine Goals
desc: The Russian holiday celebrating the Soviet triumph over Nazi Germany is viewed by Ukraine and NATO as a stage for the Russian president to proclaim a turn in the war.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Michael Levenson

header: Russia’s War Has Been Brutal, but Putin Has Shown Some Restraint. Why?
desc: Western officials are debating the Kremlin’s calculations in not trying harder to halt weapons shipments in Ukraine. Analysts wonder whether a bigger mobilization by Moscow is on the horizon.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Julian E. Barnes

header: Evacuees From Mariupol’s Steel Plant Tell of Horrors and Survival
desc: Nearly 130 people reached relative safety after sheltering for weeks in dark bunkers under the Azovstal plant, under constant bombardment, with dwindling food.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Missiles hit power stations in Lviv and along crucial railways in central and western Ukraine.
desc: Altogether, six electrical substations were struck along the railways in central and western Ukraine, according to a top rail official. The rail system is the country’s lifeline for humanitarian and military supplies.
author: By Jane Arraf

header: Saving Ukrainian Art, and Helping Artists, One NFT at a Time
desc: Lika Spivakovska, the owner of two art galleries in Kyiv, Ukraine, has partnered with an NFT gallery in Puerto Rico to auction off pictures of art damaged and created during the war. The money will go to Ukrainian artists and other humanitarian aid.
author: By Eduardo Medina

header: Sensing a Stalled Russia, West Adds Support and Arms for Ukraine
desc: ‘You have exploded the myth of Putin’s invincibility,’ Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain told Ukrainian lawmakers, one of several Western sources of cheerleading on Tuesday.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Jason Horowitz

header: For an organist from Kharkiv, performance is ‘a prayer’ in a time of despair.
desc: NA
author: By Finbarr O’Reilly

header: Invoking Churchill, Boris Johnson says the war is ‘Ukraine’s finest hour.’
desc: In the first address by a foreign leader to Ukraine’s Parliament, Britain’s prime minister burnished his credentials as a supporter of the resistance to Russia.
author: By Mark Landler

header: European Union Takes a Leap With a Russian Oil Embargo
desc: The ban, once seen as unlikely, is a significant tightening of the squeeze on Russia’s economy, and a financial blow to Europe, too.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Putin-Linked Superyacht May Elude Sanctions, by Setting Sail
desc: The Italian police are in a race to finish investigating a $700 million vessel thought to be the Russian president’s — before it’s out of their reach.
author: By Gaia Pianigiani and Michael Forsythe

header: Turning Tables on Russia With West’s Arms, Ukraine Goes on Offense
desc: Ukrainian forces are seeking to drive back Russian invaders from two key cities in northeast Ukraine and achieve a breakthrough in what has become a grinding battle.
author: By Marc Santora, Cora Engelbrecht and Michael Levenson

header: Putin’s Forces Battle in East Ukraine to Feed His Hunger for a Victory
desc: The fighting has intensified ahead of Russia’s May 9 Victory Day holiday commemorating the Soviet Union’s triumph over Nazi Germany.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: One Village at a Time: The Grinding Artillery War in Ukraine
desc: The advances by the Ukrainian army in the north have been modest, but they are emblematic of both sides’ strategy: maneuvering artillery to gain territory.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

header: NASA satellites meant to detect wildfires offer a peek at Ukraine’s front lines.
desc: NA
author: By Victoria Kim

header: In Lviv, a hidden work by a master is discovered.
desc: During the renovation of a former Catholic church, a mural by the Polish painter Jan Henryk de Rosen was uncovered.
author: By Jane Arraf

header: Italy seizes a superyacht tied to Putin.
desc: Italian police boarded the yacht, the Scheherazade, late on Friday, ending what appeared to be preparations to set sail.
author: By Gaia Pianigiani

header: Jill Biden embarks on a trip to Eastern Europe to visit Ukrainian refugees.
desc: The first lady is also scheduled to tour the Slovakian border with Ukraine, becoming the latest high-profile Biden administration official to come close to the conflict zone.
author: By Katie Rogers

header: Anti-Putin Russians Are Leaving, With a Push From the Kremlin
desc: Many Russians who are designated “foreign agents” by the government view it as another form of repression that makes living in the country, or returning to it, untenable.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: Ukraine is on heightened alert before Russia’s Victory Day celebrations.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: One village at a time: The grinding artillery war in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

header: Russian Pullback Seen Near Kharkiv, Despite Victory Day Push for Gains
desc: Advances by Ukrainian forces in the northeast appeared to have forced Russians to move back toward the border, blowing up bridges behind them and contradicting the Kremlin narrative.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Cora Engelbrecht and Megan Specia

header: Russia’s Grave Miscalculation: Ukrainians Would Collaborate
desc: Besides their military failures, the Russians entered the war believing they could persuade Ukrainians in the east to join their side. Those efforts have failed spectacularly.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Both Sides Harden Positions on Anniversary of Nazi Defeat in Europe
desc: The war in Ukraine was marked by posturing and signaling, with each side ramping up its rhetoric as the battle ground on.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: A bomb-sniffing dog named Patron received state honors from Zelensky.
desc: Patron has found more than 200 explosives, President Zelensky said. The dog has gone viral as Ukraine wages an information war.
author: By Anushka Patil

header: Dozens are feared dead after a Russian airstrike hits a school building, officials say.
desc: Initial reports suggested that as many as 60 people were trapped inside the building, which officials said was being used as a shelter for civilians.
author: By Marc Santora

header: ‘What kind of military target is this?’ Russian bombs strike homes and a bakery in Malotaranivka.
desc: NA
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Jill Biden makes an unannounced visit to Ukraine, and meets with Zelensky’s wife.
desc: The first lady became the latest high-profile person close to President Biden to travel to Ukraine, visiting a school close to the western border.
author: By Katie Rogers

header: May 9 Is a Revered Day in Russia. For Many, Putin Has Hijacked It.
desc: Under President Vladimir V. Putin, Victory Day, marking the defeat of Nazi Germany, has come to celebrate modern Russian military might. The war in Ukraine is shifting its meaning further.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Two Europes Confront Each Other Over the Glory, or Shame, of War
desc: On Monday, Vladimir Putin will mark Russia’s Victory Day by extolling the virtues of force. France’s leader, Emmanuel Macron, will honor a very different anniversary.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: Jill Biden met with Ukrainian mothers and children in Romania. Several told her they wanted to return home.
desc: NA
author: By Katie Rogers

header: Russia’s invasion upends a shared World War II history with Ukraine.
desc: The war has complicated relationships between Russians and Ukrainians.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Ukraine War’s Geographic Reality: Russia Has Seized Much of the East
desc: Despite many stumbles and setbacks, the Russian military has gained near total control of the Donbas region, giving the Kremlin huge leverage in any future talks.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Marc Santora and Michael Levenson

header: In Speech, Putin Shows Reluctance in Demanding Too Much of Russians
desc: The Russian president, in a much-anticipated speech on his country’s most important holiday, did not proclaim an escalation of the fight in Ukraine.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Readers ask: How are public services operating in Ukraine?
desc: Our reporters answer readers’ questions about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Many of you asked about schools and hospitals.
author: By Megan Specia

header: Biden signs bill to allow lending arms to Ukraine, which will speed up shipments.
desc: The law will waive time-consuming requirements on the provision of arms to Ukraine considered critical to its defense against Russian forces.
author: By Peter Baker

header: Leonid Kravchuk, First President of an Independent Ukraine, Dies at 88
desc: Days after his election, he signed a multinational agreement that formally declared the dissolution of the Soviet Union.
author: By Anushka Patil

header: Crowdfunding a War: How Online Appeals Are Bringing Weapons to Ukraine
desc: A campaign to crowdfund donations and weapons is producing millions of dollars as well as a bounty of smaller weapons and other military equipment for the Ukrainian military.
author: By Jane Arraf

header: In Photos: Russia Celebrates Victory Day Holiday With Parade in Red Square
desc: President Vladimir V. Putin used his speech on Russia’s most important secular holiday to rally support for the country’s invasion of Ukraine.
author: By The New York Times

header: How much of Ukraine does Russia hold?
desc: Although Russian forces failed to take Kyiv, they have captured large chunks of the south and east, giving Moscow a chance to strangle the country economically.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Ukraine struggles to combat Russian dominion on the Black Sea.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: In the Trenches of Eastern Ukraine, Combat Becomes a Vicious Dance
desc: In some villages along the front, Ukrainian and Russian soldiers face off at close quarters, sometimes within eyesight of one another.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Lynsey Addario

header: Finland Moves to Join NATO, Upending Putin’s Ukraine War Aims
desc: Neutral Finland’s leaders unequivocally said they intended to seek membership in the alliance, with Sweden expected to do the same, inviting new threats from Moscow.
author: By Steven Erlanger and Norimitsu Onishi

header: The Ukraine War’s Economic Toll Is Testing the West’s Unity Against Russia
desc: Russia’s president is calculating that Western leaders will tire before he does of a protracted struggle in Ukraine, especially if the price is turbocharged inflation and energy shortages.
author: By Mark Landler

header: Nearly a third of Ukraine’s jobs have been lost amid the war, U.N. labor agency says.
desc: The report highlights the grim economic toll of Russia’s aggression and the challenges that lie ahead for Ukraine and other nations.
author: By Liz Alderman

header: Rand Paul holds up $40 billion in aid for Ukraine.
desc: Mr. Paul had sought to alter the bill to include requiring that an inspector general monitor the spending.
author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Emily Cochrane

header: Life in a Ukrainian Unit: Diving for Cover, Waiting for Western Weapons
desc: Analysts say the outcome of fighting now is riding on the accuracy, quantity and the striking power of long-range weapons. Ukraine is pleading for more.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: As the war grinds on, its global economic toll is growing.
desc: NA
author: By Alyssa Lukpat

header: Once Best Friends, Bulgaria Takes a Stand Against Russia
desc: Bulgaria has imposed economic sanctions on Russia, offered to repair broken military equipment for Ukraine and expelled Russian diplomats.
author: By Andrew Higgins, Boryana Dzhambazova and Nanna Heitmann

header: In a first, a Russian soldier will stand trial in Ukraine on war crimes charges.
desc: A 21-year-old Russian soldier is accused of following orders to shoot an unarmed cyclist four days into Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
author: By Anushka Patil

header: Why do Finland and Sweden appear headed toward swift NATO membership while Ukraine is not?
desc: The previously nonaligned countries could potentially join NATO in less than a year, but Ukraine’s prospects of joining the alliance any time soon — if ever — are very unlikely.
author: By Dan Bilefsky and Steven Erlanger

header: West Increases Pressure on Putin, Including Sanctions on Reputed Girlfriend
desc: The Russian leader was challenged by the prospect of an enlarged NATO, plans to get Ukrainian grain exports past a Kremlin blockade, and sanctions on his purported mistress.
author: By Marc Santora, Mark Landler and Michael Levenson

header: Russia is pulling back from Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-largest city.
desc: NA
author: By Alyssa Lukpat

header: Vladimir Putin, Family Man
desc: As Western nations place sanctions on people close to the Russian leader, including family members, the strict secrecy surrounding his private life is being punctured.
author: By Jason Horowitz

header: For Putin, a Nordic Nightmare Is Springing to Life
desc: With Finland and Sweden likely to request NATO membership, and Ukraine counterattacking in the east, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is facing more setbacks.
author: By Marc Santora and Natalie Kitroeff

header: An American diplomat offers a stark assessment of Russian detention camps.
desc: NA
author: By Alyssa Lukpat

header: India bans most wheat exports, adding to concerns of global food insecurity.
desc: The ban could compound a worldwide shortfall worsened by the war in Ukraine and exacerbate an already dire forecast for global hunger.
author: By Sameer Yasir and Victoria Kim

header: Ukraine begins a trial of a Russian soldier accused of a war crime, a first since the conflict began.
desc: Sgt. Vadim Shysimarin is accused of shooting a 62-year-old man on a bicycle in a village in the Sumy region, about 200 miles east of Kyiv.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Amid war and destruction, Ukraine is favored to win the wildly popular Eurovision Song Contest.
desc: The exclusion of Russia from the contest has underlined the country’s estrangement from the west, including in popular culture.
author: By Dan Bilefsky and Anushka Patil

header: After 200 Years of Neutrality, Sweden Weighs Joining NATO
desc: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine created new fears, and the Swedes, dragged along by Finland, are expected to apply, reluctantly, to join the alliance and its collective defense.
author: NA

header: At a German Hideaway, Oligarch Villas Challenge a ‘Silent Contract’
desc: Tegernsee, a luxury getaway in Bavaria, is known for quietly hosting the superrich. But war in Ukraine has divided locals about whether the authorities should go after the assets of their wealthy Russian neighbors.
author: By Erika Solomon and Laetitia Vancon

header: Russia Planned a Major Military Overhaul. Ukraine Shows the Result.
desc: Russia wanted to build a leaner, more flexible fighting force and eliminate waste, bureaucracy and corruption. But entrenched, Soviet-era practices endure.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: Ukraine’s Eurovision winner releases a music video filmed in the rubble.
desc: NA
author: By Alyssa Lukpat

header: Estonia’s Tough Voice on Ukraine Urges No Compromise With Putin
desc: Kaja Kallas, the prime minister, remembers the repression of life under Soviet rule and sees the same brutality in occupied Ukraine, which she believes is fighting for all of Europe.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: Deadly artillery strikes are battering the key eastern city of Sievierodonetsk, a local official says.
desc: NA
author: By Alyssa Lukpat

header: NATO Leaders Say They Will Speed Finland and Sweden Membership Bids
desc: In another setback for Moscow, top officials from alliance nations met over the weekend in Berlin to discuss admitting Finland and Sweden and supporting Ukraine.
author: By Edward Wong and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: In Rebirth for NATO, Europe Unites in Face of Putin’s Ambition
desc: Sweden’s and Finland’s embrace of NATO after decades of neutrality is a clear statement that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has ended an era of European illusions about Moscow.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: A Mini-Russia Gets Squeezed by War
desc: The self-declared republic of Transnistria, on the Ukraine border, has been steered by Moscow for decades. During a rare visit, a reporter and photographer get an inside look into how it operates, and hear from Transnistrians their fears of war.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Cristian Movila

header: Growing evidence of a military disaster on the Donets pierces a pro-Russian bubble.
desc: As the news of the losses at the river crossing started to spread, some Russian bloggers did not hold back in their criticism of what they said was incompetent leadership.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Marc Santora

header: The Ukrainian authorities declare an end to the combat mission in Mariupol after weeks of Russian siege.
desc: More than 250 fighters were evacuated from the besieged Azovstal complex after holding out and sheltering civilians for weeks under near-constant Russian bombardment.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Ivan Nechepurenko and Marc Santora

header: Further Russian Retreat Seen in East Ukraine, Another Setback for Putin
desc: Russia appeared to shrink its already narrowed goals to take the Donbas region, as NATO and its two newest applicants, Sweden and Finland, practiced war games near Russia’s border.
author: By Marc Santora, Anton Troianovski, Rick Gladstone and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukrainian Holdouts in Mariupol Surrender to an Uncertain Fate
desc: The government’s order for hundreds of remaining fighters to stand down offers Russia a propaganda victory, but prospects for a prisoner swap seem unclear at best.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Rick Gladstone

header: Russia Uses Surrender in Mariupol to Portray Ukrainians as Terrorists
desc: Many soldiers who surrendered from Mariupol’s Azovstal steel plant belong to the Azov battalion, a group with far-right roots, and the Kremlin may now put them on trial just as Ukraine is prosecuting Russians for war crimes.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Neil MacFarquhar, Ivan Nechepurenko and Michael Levenson

header: In Ukraine, Gruesome Injuries and Not Enough Doctors to Treat Them
desc: Operating with skeleton crews, doctors and nurses race to save limbs, and lives. It’s a grim routine for medical personnel often working around the clock. And not all limbs can be saved.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Lynsey Addario

header: A Shelter for Displaced Artists in Ukraine
desc: On the outskirts of Lviv, displaced artists shunning government shelters have found a home in an abandoned factory. They recently opened up their space.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: With Ukraine Taking Firmer Stance, Peace Talks Grind to a Halt
desc: The impasse is mainly driven by Russia’s insistence on controlling large areas of Ukrainian territory. But Ukraine is also emboldened by successes on the battlefield and angry over Russian atrocities.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Valerie Hopkins

header: Readers ask: How do Ukrainians see the Western response to the war?
desc: Our reporters are answering readers’ questions about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Many of you have asked about sentiments in Ukraine about the West.
author: By Jane Arraf

header: Around Kharkiv, Ukrainians Emerge to Find Lives in Ruin
desc: After sheltering underground since February, residents of the beseiged city have finally been able to to assess the damage the Russians left behind. The discoveries have been grisly.
author: By Finbarr O’Reilly

header: Life Returns to Bucha
desc: In Bucha, Ukraine, our correspondent saw a city overshadowed by death coming back to life.
author: By Jane Arraf

header: Biden endorses Finland and Sweden’s bids to join NATO.
desc: Mr. Biden’s pledge is far short of a treaty, or even an executive agreement committing the United States to come to the aid of both countries.
author: By David E. Sanger

header: Ukraine’s Eurovision winners don’t regret flouting the rules with a plea for Mariupol.
desc: The winning band’s lead singer said he still feared for the fighters who had been holed up beneath the Azovstal steel plant.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: Moscow Moves to Russify Seized Ukraine Land, Signaling Annexation
desc: The territory occupied by Russian forces so far in the three-month-old invasion deserves “a worthy place in our Russian family,” a Kremlin official who toured the region said.
author: By Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Norimitsu Onishi

header: Russia Hustles to Recruit Soldiers and Halts Gas Supplies to Finland
desc: The war has evolved into something of a stalemate that has seriously depleted Russia’s conventional war capabilities, even as it has made some gains.
author: By Katrin Bennhold, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Andrew E. Kramer

header: In Hungary, Cheap Russian Oil Fuels Right-Wing Culture Wars
desc: Prime Minister Viktor Orban has resisted a proposed E.U. embargo of Russian oil, saying it would devastate his country’s economy, but it would also cut off a source of funds for his political allies.
author: By Andrew Higgins and Benjamin Novak

header: Russia fortifies its control over parts of southeastern Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Alyssa Lukpat

header: A Russian rock singer was charged after condemning the Ukraine war at a concert.
desc: The singer made the comments less than three months after Russia enacted a law that would punish spreading “false information” about its invasion.
author: By Alyssa Lukpat

header: A Russian official tours occupied southern Ukraine.
desc: The official, Marat Khusnullin, Russia’s deputy prime minister for infrastructure, outlined plans to take control of vital infrastructure.
author: By Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Anton Troianovski

header: The incoming U.S. ambassador to Ukraine has experience in countries shaped by Soviet domination.
desc: Bridget Brink has worked in Slovakia, Uzbekistan and Georgia. She is filling a role that has been empty for three years.
author: By Dan Bilefsky

header: Ukrainian oligarch seeks to distance himself from Russia by mulling sale of superyacht.
desc: The richest man in Ukraine has committed to building back his country. But he is also constructing a luxury ship that would rival a yacht that the U.S. government believes may belong to Vladimir Putin.
author: By Michael Forsythe

header: The U.N. warns that Russia’s blockade could harm global food security.
desc: NA
author: By Alyssa Lukpat

header: A Russian gymnast was given a one-year ban for wearing the pro-war ‘Z’ symbol at a competition.
desc: The gymnast, Ivan Kuliak, wore the symbol while standing at the podium next to the Ukrainian gold medalist.
author: By Anushka Patil

header: The Russian Orthodox Leader at the Core of Putin’s Ambitions
desc: Patriarch Kirill I has provided spiritual cover for the invasion of Ukraine, reaping vast resources for his church in return. Now, in an extraordinary step, the E.U. is threatening him with sanctions.
author: By Jason Horowitz

header: Russian forces are attempting another crossing of a river where they suffered a major blow, Ukraine’s military says.
desc: The 650-mile-long Seversky Donets River originates in Russia and meanders southeast through the Donbas region before re-entering Russian territory.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: As Biden Signs $40 Billion Aid Package for Ukraine, Calls Grow for a Cease-Fire
desc: But a diplomatic resolution to the war still looks remote, amid searing questions about what would constitute a “victory” for Kyiv.
author: By Steven Erlanger, Andrew E. Kramer and Katrin Bennhold

header: Russia Renews Assault on Key Eastern City as Advances by Both Sides Slow
desc: The battle for Sievierodonetsk in eastern Ukraine represents another crucial point in the war, as both sides engage in a grueling war of attrition.
author: By Carlotta Gall, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Maria Abi-Habib

header: ‘Such Bad Guys Will Come’: How One Russian Brigade Terrorized Bucha
desc: A particularly fearsome unit of Moscow’s invading army arrived in the Kyiv suburb in mid-March. The soldiers’ reputation preceded them.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Daniel Berehulak

header: A destroyed village, a war crimes trial, a funeral: Images from Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By The New York Times

header: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Shashank Bengali

header: The Polish president visits Kyiv and says Ukraine alone should determine its future.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: This is what the $40 billion U.S. aid for Ukraine includes.
desc: NA
author: By James C. McKinley Jr.

header: Zelensky says more weapons for Ukraine could help tame global food prices.
desc: NA
author: By Austin Ramzy

header: ‘Please, God, Let Him Live’: Russian Forces Pummel Ukraine’s East
desc: With enemy forces massed on three sides, the residents of Sievierodonetsk are at the heart of the battle.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Finbarr O’Reilly

header: ‘They basically got everything wrong’: A Russian diplomat speaks out on the war.
desc: Boris Bondarev, a Russian official who resigned over the war in Ukraine, said his colleagues were focused more on pleasing their superiors than on delivering accurate information to Moscow.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Powerful American Artillery Enters the Fight in Ukraine
desc: The most lethal weapons the West has provided so far to Ukraine are now deployed in combat. Will they make a critical difference for Ukraine’s military in a war that has mostly become an artillery battle?
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Ivor Prickett

header: Addressing Davos, Zelensky invites global businesses to Ukraine.
desc: The Ukrainian leader pledged to root out corruption to make his country more attractive to investors, and urged for tougher penalties against Moscow.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Ukraine charges 8 Russian soldiers and mercenaries in the killings of a small-town mayor and her family.
desc: The bodies of the mayor, her husband and her son were found after Russian forces retreated in early April.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Ukraine makes its pitch to the world elite where Russia once held court.
desc: The Russia House, where oligarchs sipped vodka and talked with politicians and corporate chiefs during the World Economic Forum, has been rebranded “Russian War Crimes House.”
author: By Mark Landler and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: War Raises Famine Fears as Russia Chokes Off Ukraine’s Farms and Exports
desc: World leaders say there is no easy way to bypass a Russian blockade without a military clash, and accuse Vladimir V. Putin of using global hunger as a weapon.
author: By Mark Landler, Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Erika Solomon and Patricia Cohen

header: Russia’s Shrinking War
desc: The goals of Russia’s invasion keep getting smaller. But its depleted military is still failing to make major advances, and time is on Ukraine’s side.
author: By Josh Holder, Marco Hernandez and Jon Huang

header: Zelensky Urges Even Harder Line on Russia as Allies Work to Remain United
desc: A midlevel Russian diplomat broke ranks and resigned with a scathing statement on the war, and President Volodymyr Zelensky called on world leaders to turn up the pressure.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Anton Troianovski and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: Kissinger suggests that Ukraine give up territory to Russia, drawing a backlash.
desc: The former secretary of state argued that ceding land could bring an end to the war. Critics called the idea reckless and unrealistic.
author: By Dan Bilefsky

header: A Doomed River Crossing Shows the Perils of Entrapment in the War’s East
desc: Encirclement is a tactic used by both sides in the war between Russia and Ukraine, but it can carry big risks.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Ivor Prickett

header: As Russia Diverges From the Global Economy, Soviet-Style Scarcity Looms
desc: With soaring prices and shortages of basic goods, the Russian people and businesses large and small are feeling the pinch.
author: By Patricia Cohen, Eshe Nelson, Valeriya Safronova and Michael Levenson

header: Putin visits the wounded at a military hospital in Moscow, in a first since the Ukraine invasion.
desc: The Russian leader also announces new social welfare measures and military benefits in an apparent effort to show Russians he is aware times are tough.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Putin fast-tracks Russian citizenship for residents of Ukrainian areas under Russian control.
desc: NA
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: Two Russian soldiers plead guilty in the second war crimes trial in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: A grain shortfall will be felt by July, Ukraine’s agriculture minister warns.
desc: NA
author: By Erika Solomon

header: Zelensky rebukes Kissinger and The New York Times for suggesting that Ukraine should cede territory to Russia.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Eshe Nelson and Shashank Bengali

header: A young Ukrainian escapes a war to protest for peace.
desc: NA
author: By Somini Sengupta

header: Hungary’s Viktor Orban declares state of emergency, citing the Ukraine war to expand his power.
desc: NA
author: By Benjamin Novak

header: Ferocious Russian Attacks Spur Accusations of Genocide in Ukraine
desc: The country is at “imminent” risk of genocide, a new report says, as Russia turns to ultrapowerful conventional weapons.
author: By Victoria Kim, Megan Specia, Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson

header: Drones. Crutches. Potatoes. Russians Crowdfund Their Army.
desc: A grass-roots movement to get basic supplies to soldiers fighting in Ukraine reflects the growing recognition among Russians that their military was unprepared for major conflict.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Ukrainian Orthodox Church Breaks With Moscow Over War
desc: The Council of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church said that it disagreed with the Moscow Patriarch’s position on the war.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: In hopes of returning home, displaced Ukrainians learn how to detect mines.
desc: Courses in western Ukraine, meant for volunteer defenders, are now open to Ukrainian civilians whose villages have been blighted by war.
author: By Erika Solomon and Diego Ibarra Sanchez

header: Russia Edges Closer to Seizing Key City in Eastern Ukraine
desc: Russian and Ukrainian forces were locked in street-by-street fighting in Sievierodonetsk, Kyiv’s last foothold in Luhansk Province.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Neil MacFarquhar and Patrick Kingsley

header: Sounds of bombardment drown out the ‘last bell’ for the final day of school in Ukraine.
desc: On what is usually a day of festivities and fun, many of Ukraine’s students ended the academic year amid the sounds of war or from abroad.
author: By Victoria Kim

header: He left Russia to fight Putin. Now he leads Ukrainian soldiers in combat against his former compatriots.
desc: “The hottest place to fight against the regime was in Ukraine,” says a unit commander who has been a volunteer soldier for his adopted country on and off since 2015.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Finbarr O’Reilly

header: Long-range weapons take on new import in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By The New York Times

header: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: ‘It destroys bunkers’: Russia systematically uses thermobaric warheads in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Europe agrees to ban most Russian oil imports.
desc: A draft of the agreement allows pipeline imports, in a nod to Hungary’s complaints, but would be the toughest action yet over Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: Ukraine Battle Expands as Kyiv Launches Counteroffensive
desc: “Hold on, Kherson, we’re coming!” the Ukrainian military declared as it pushed to retake territory in a key southern city.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Jason Horowitz

header: Tending Russia’s Dead as They Pile Up in Ukraine
desc: Ukrainians hope that if they safeguard Russia’s war dead, they will be more likely to get back their own.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: For Russian-Speaking Ukrainians, Language Clubs Offer Way to Defy Invaders
desc: Many Ukraine citizens speak Russian as their first language. Volunteer organizations are helping them improve their Ukrainian and abandon “the occupiers’ language.”
author: By Erika Solomon

header: A French journalist is killed by shrapnel in eastern Ukraine.
desc: “The newsroom is in mourning,” said a manager at the TV channel where the 32-year-old journalist worked.
author: By Aurelien Breeden and Carlotta Gall

header: As Ukraine Fights, Does the E.U. Owe It Membership?
desc: Brussels supports Kyiv’s battle against Russia, but gaining full membership to the bloc could take years. Is there another way to bind Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia to Europe?
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: An explosion in the Russian-occupied city of Melitopol appears to target a pro-Kremlin leader.
desc: Pro-Kremlin authorities in the city blamed Ukrainian partisans for the blast, which they said had injured two people.
author: By Marc Santora and Neil MacFarquhar

header: Eurovision Winners Auction Off Trophy to Support Ukraine’s Army
desc: Millions of people have viewed a video of the band Kalush Orchestra that was filmed in the rubble of Ukraine. Its members have urged fans to help the Ukrainian army.
author: By Emma Bubola

header: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Traci Carl

header: Ukraine says it’s counterattacking in south as new weapons arrive.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: A whistle, then a deadly barrage. Ukraine’s soldiers are under relentless fire.
desc: The attention on Russia’s battle casualties has obscured the heavy losses of Ukraine’s fighters in Donbas — often ill-trained volunteers.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Even as Russia Bears Down in the East, Some Ukrainians Stay Behind
desc: The Russian offensive grinds on, but not everyone is leaving the eastern Donbas region.
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: Forces Battle for Ukraine City, as E.U. Ratchets Up Responses
desc: As Russian forces advanced into Sievierodonetsk, Ukraine’s allies promised increased aid, a sharp drop in Russian oil imports and efforts to ship Ukrainian grain out of the country.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: 2 Russian Soldiers Sentenced in Ukrainian War-Crimes Trial
desc: The soldiers, an artillery driver and a gunner, had been found guilty of shelling the town of Derhachi in northeastern Ukraine.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: ‘We Are About to Lose a Lot More Lives and Limbs’: Ukraine Girds for a Wave of Amputees
desc: The war in Ukraine is pushing the country to expand its prosthetics industry amid fears of looming shortages.
author: By Erika Solomon and Diego Ibarra Sanchez

header: As Food Shortages Loom, a Race to Free Ukraine’s Stranded Grain
desc: An operation to bring grain out from Ukraine through Lithuania, with considerable political hurdles, is just one option being considered amid warnings of mass starvation around the world.
author: By Andrew Higgins and Erika Solomon

header: From Ukraine’s Front Lines, Bravery and Wreckage
desc: Amid the roar of artillery and bone-rattling explosions, New York Times photographers have borne graphic witness to the fight to survive. These are their stories and images.
author: NA

header: The Middlemen at the Heart of an Oligarch-Industrial Complex
desc: They oversee the flow of billions of dollars from Putin-connected Russians to companies involved in superyachts and villas. They’ve drawn the attention of a U.S. task force.
author: By Michael Forsythe, Gaia Pianigiani and Julian E. Barnes

header: Hungary’s oil embargo exemption is the latest sign of its leader’s affinity for Russia.
desc: Prime Minister Viktor Orban has spoken admiringly of President Vladimir Putin and expressed sympathy for his security demands to NATO.
author: By Victoria Kim

header: Germany promises to send Ukraine a missile defense system and radar equipment.
desc: The announcement came as Chancellor Olaf Scholz faced pressure over when the government would deliver on previous weapons pledges.
author: By Christopher F. Schuetze and Niki Kitsantonis

header: 100 Days of War: Death, Destruction and Loss
desc: The grinding conflict in Ukraine has rocked the global order, wrought destruction that “defies comprehension” and shows little sign of ending soon.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Neil MacFarquhar, Steven Erlanger and Michael Levenson

header: As War Rages Into Its 100th Day, Russia Now Controls a Fifth of Ukraine
desc: While President Volodymyr Zelensky acknowledged Russian gains, Ukrainian forces pressed a counteroffensive in the south.
author: By Marc Santora, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Michael Levenson

header: Russian and African leaders meet, one needing allies, the other grain.
desc: A meeting between President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and the head of the African Union, President Macky Sall of Senegal, showed that Africa is not prepared to cut ties to Russia.
author: By Elian Peltier

header: African Union Head Has Plea for Putin: Release Ukraine’s Grain.
desc: Amid fears of a global food crisis, the president of Senegal is to meet with the president of Russia at a Black Sea resort on Friday. Aides say he will speak of the risk of famine in Africa.
author: By Elian Peltier

header: In a Museum Show, Ukraine Tells the Story of a War Still in Progress
desc: The exhibition, called “Crucified Ukraine,” is one of several ways that the country’s government is highlighting the devastation that its people have endured.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Thousands Swept Up as Kremlin Clamps Down on War Criticism
desc: The arrests are a stark gauge of how the Kremlin has intensified repression of critics. At least 50 people now face years-long prison sentences.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Alina Lobzina

header: Dolphins Dying in Black Sea, and May Be Casualties of War, Scientists Say.
desc: The washing up of dolphins on the coasts of Bulgaria, Romania, Turkey and Ukraine is raising concerns that the war in may be interfering with marine life. But more research is needed, scientists say.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Ukraine accuses Russia of forcibly deporting more than 200,000 children.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Victoria Kim

header: The day’s military theme comes as Britain is supporting Ukraine in its war.
desc: NA
author: By Mark Landler

header: A Farmer Holds On, a Fraying Lifeline for a Besieged Corner of Ukraine
desc: Most farmers have fled the Russian advance, but Oleksandr Chaplik has stayed, despite the lethal risks and a lack of workers, water and power.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Finbarr O’Reilly

header: Russia Seeks Buyers for Plundered Ukraine Grain, U.S. Warns
desc: American diplomats have alerted 14 countries, most in Africa, that Russian ships filled with stolen Ukrainian grain could be headed their way, posing a dilemma to countries facing dire food shortages.
author: By Declan Walsh and Valerie Hopkins

header: Struggling in Ukraine’s East, Russian Forces Strike in Kyiv
desc: Vladimir Putin threatened “to strike targets we haven’t hit before” if Western nations proceed with plans to send long-range missiles to Ukraine.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Steven Erlanger

header: As Battles Rage, Ukraine Rejects Macron Plea Not to ‘Humiliate’ Russia
desc: Amid reports of battlefield gains by Ukraine, an official angrily rejected Mr. Macron’s advice, saying it “can only humiliate France.”
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Jason Horowitz

header: Ukraine aims to restart soccer leagues on its own soil in August.
desc: In an interview with The Associated Press, the leader of Ukraine’s soccer federation said President Volodymyr Zelensky had approved the decision.
author: By Victor Mather

header: Fire engulfs wooden temple at a revered monastery in eastern Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Cora Engelbrecht

header: Russia and Ukraine exchange the bodies of 320 fallen soldiers after talks.
desc: Ukrainian officials said the transfer of the dead took place on Thursday, in the Zaporizhzhia region.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Four foreign soldiers were killed fighting for Ukraine, the international legion says.
desc: NA
author: NA

header: Ukraine rebuffs Macron’s call to ‘not humiliate Russia.’
desc: NA
author: By Alan Yuhas

header: Ukraine’s strategic dilemma in Sievierodonetsk: Stand and fight, or pull back?
desc: Sievierodonetsk, now site of the most intense combat, is “dead,” President Volodymyr Zelensky said, but letting it go might be worse than shedding blood to hold it.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Potent Weapons Reach Ukraine Faster Than the Know-How to Use Them
desc: Soldiers desperate for advanced arms to match their Russian enemies have resorted to Google Translate to decipher the instructions for their sophisticated new tools.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak

header: Battered by Russian Shells, a Monastery Remains Loyal to Moscow
desc: The monks and nuns cloistered in a monastery complex in eastern Ukraine absorb daily bombardments from Russian artillery. And yet they remain loyal to the Russian Orthodox Church.
author: NA

header: Bodies of Soldiers Killed Defending Mariupol Are Returned to Ukraine.
desc: In the first official confirmed exchange of war dead, Russia and Ukraine each received about 160 bodies.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Goodbye, Tchaikovsky and Tolstoy: Ukrainians look to ‘decolonize’ their streets.
desc: Across the country, officials are evaluating and rechristening roads, parks and other sites bearing Russian names.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: High-tech Western Weapons Pose Challenge for Untrained Ukrainian Soldiers
desc: Ukrainian fighters are getting increasingly sophisticated weaponry from abroad. Some have been reduced to Googling instructions.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak

header: Guerrilla Attacks Signal Rising Resistance to Russian Occupation
desc: Fueled by brutal Russian repression and worsening humanitarian conditions, Ukrainian partisans appear to be striking deep inside Russian-controlled territory.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Fiji hands over a superyacht that the U.S. says is tied to a Russian oligarch.
desc: The handover of the Amadea is the latest development in a global effort to seize the assets of oligarchs with ties to Russia’s president.
author: By Mike Ives

header: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora and Shashank Bengali

header: Russia Is Racing to Cement Its Control in Southern Ukraine
desc: The Kremlin says it has rebuilt rail and road links to Crimea, while appointing proxy officials in an effort to create facts on the ground.
author: By Marc Santora, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Anton Troianovski and Michael Levenson

header: ‘Dead Cities’ Become the Flashpoint for the Fierce War in the East
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky has framed the battle in Sievierodonetsk as pivotal to the broader fight for the Donbas. Amid relentless Russian attacks, Ukraine holds on and waits for Western weapons.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Ivor Prickett

header: A Plea From German Brewers: Bring Back Your Empties
desc: A nation of beer lovers is facing a shortage of bottles, partly because of the war in Ukraine. Breweries are looking to drinkers for a rescue.
author: By Melissa Eddy

header: Satellite Imagery Shows Ukrainian Water Flowing Again to Crimea, as Russia Nears Big Objective
desc: Ukraine blocked a freshwater to canal to the Crimean Peninsula after Russia occupied it 2014. Moscow has fully restored the flow, easing its path to a “land bridge” with Russia, images show.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Malachy Browne

header: The Treasury Department bars Americans from buying Russian stocks.
desc: The measure seemed likely to have a greater impact on members of the Russian elite than on Russia’s ability to fund the war in Ukraine.
author: By Alex Traub

header: Angela Merkel says she ‘won’t apologize’ for her Russia diplomacy.
desc: Ms. Merkel has come under fire for pushing German-Russian business interests during her tenure as chancellor.
author: By Erika Solomon and Emma Bubola

header: Russia Opens 1,100 Cases Against Ukrainian P.O.W.s, Raising Fears of Show Trials
desc: Announcing the invasion in February, Vladimir Putin said Ukrainians would be prosecuted for “blood crimes.” Moscow is now making good on that vow.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: As Russia tries to solidify its ‘land bridge,’ Ukraine attempts to push back in the south.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: 3 Foreign Fighters in Ukraine’s Army Sentenced to Death in Russian-Held Territory
desc: Legal experts said the death sentences appeared calculated to discourage foreign volunteers from joining Ukraine’s military.
author: By Dan Bilefsky and Valerie Hopkins

header: Evacuating the Vulnerable Amid the Terror of War
desc: As Russian forces bear down on eastern Ukraine, a small army of volunteers is racing to bring to safety those unable to care for themselves.
author: By Ivor Prickett and Maria Varenikova

header: Shortage of Artillery Ammunition Saps Ukrainian Frontline Morale
desc: Shells for Soviet-era weapons are running short, and powerful Western weapons are not arriving fast enough to make up the difference, giving Russia a big advantage in artillery.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Andrew E. Kramer and Natalia Yermak

header: Ukraine’s banks say they are weathering the war ‘surprisingly well,’ if for now.
desc: NA
author: By Emma Bubola

header: Behind Enemy Lines, Scouts Help Ukrainians Execute Deadly Strikes
desc: A nascent insurgency made up of civilians or former soldiers provided information that aided Ukraine’s attack on two Russian bases, according to a senior Ukrainian military official.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Marc Santora

header: Momentum in Ukraine Is Shifting in Russia’s Favor
desc: With the Ukrainians running short of guns and ammunition, and pressures growing on Western governments, Moscow’s fortunes may be rising.
author: By Marc Santora and Roger Cohen

header: McDonald’s Is Back, Moscow Style, as Russian Economy Stumbles On
desc: The reopening of the fast-food stores under Russian ownership (and with a new logo) illustrates the economy’s surprising resilience in the face of intense sanctions, though tough times lie ahead.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: ‘We Are Still in Shock’: A Month Trapped in a Basement by Russian Forces
desc: More than 300 Ukrainians, 77 of them children, were imprisoned in a dank and airless school basement for nearly a month. Ten of them died.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Nicole Tung

header: A new cultural center in Lithuania for Ukrainians seeks to ‘preserve the nation’s vitality.’
desc: NA
author: By Nancy Ramsey

header: Ukraine counterattacks in the southern Kherson region, making small gains.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Behind enemy lines, scouts help Ukrainians execute deadly strikes.
desc: NA
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Marc Santora

header: Ukraine reiterates pleas for more weapons from the West.
desc: NA
author: By Jesus Jiménez

header: Tough Questions for West as Ukraine Cities Teeter
desc: Sievierodonetsk is nearly encircled. Lysychansk may be next. The momentum of the war has shifted, and Ukraine’s allies may soon start rethinking their goals.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: As China Rattles Sabers, Taiwan Asks: Are We Ready for War?
desc: Ukraine’s stubborn resistance to invasion, and the help that has poured in as a result, has both inspired Taiwan and made it rethink its own military strategy.
author: By Amy Qin, Amy Chang Chien and Lam Yik Fei

header: The Corpse of a Russian Soldier, and the Cold but Human Urge to Look
desc: Why does war’s wreckage — the downed helicopters, the destroyed tanks and the dead — draw crowds? A former Marine ponders the question as he stands before the badly burned body of a Russian fighter.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: On Russia, Europe Weighs Competing Goals: Peace and Punishment
desc: Arming Ukraine is not turning the tide. Is the answer vastly more weapons, as Ukraine says, or a bitter truce?
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: The battle for Ukraine’s Donbas will be remembered for its brutality, Zelensky says.
desc: NA
author: By Anushka Patil

header: Attacked at home, Boris Johnson is honored in Ukraine with a pastry in his image.
desc: A croissant is the latest homage in Ukraine to the British prime minister, who has also had a road named after him in a town near Odesa.
author: By Dan Bilefsky

header: A top Ukrainian official says urgency is missing in the West’s response to the war.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Valerie Hopkins

header: Control of Luhansk, and the wider Donbas region, could hinge on the battle for Sievierodonetsk.
desc: Russian-backed forces already control an estimated 80 to 90 percent of the Donbas, which is a prize for President Vladimir V. Putin.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: Zelensky seeks backing for Ukraine to join the European Union.
desc: NA
author: By Austin Ramzy

header: An outgunned Ukraine is adding to the pressure on Europe.
desc: NA
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: U.S. and Allies Pledge Additional Arms for Ukraine, but Kyiv Wants More
desc: Some NATO countries are wary of sending heavy weapons, hoping for a negotiated truce, but the alliance insists publicly that it is committed to helping Ukraine defeat Russia.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: A Link to Besieged Ukrainians Is Cut, as Allies Question Strategy
desc: The last bridge to the city of Sievierodonetsk fell as street battles raged, and some Western officials questioned Ukraine’s ability to keep resisting the Russian onslaught.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Eric Schmitt

header: North of Kyiv, the Russians Retreated. But the War Never Left.
desc: In the Ukrainian villages near the Russian border, shells still explode and checkpoints and trenches dot the landscape. And wary civilians live in fear the enemy will return.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: A brutal urban artillery battle sends civilians running in eastern Ukraine.
desc: Heavy volleys between Russian forces taking control of Sievierodonetsk and Ukrainian forces in a neighboring city are leaving wreckage and growing desperation for the residents stuck there.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak

header: In Ukraine, a Minority Group Feels Ambivalence About the War
desc: After Moscow’s invasion, some Ukrainians worry that divided loyalties within the country’s small ethnic Hungarian minority might make it susceptible to pro-Russia propaganda from Hungary.
author: By Erika Solomon and Diego Ibarra Sanchez

header: U.S. and NATO allies send more military aid to Ukraine to counter Russia.
desc: After announcing a major new wave of long-range weaponry for Ukraine, Western leaders will turn their sights toward other potential threats to NATO from Russia and China.
author: By Steven Erlanger, Michael D. Shear and Dan Bilefsky

header: Two U.S. veterans fighting in Ukraine have gone missing, family members say.
desc: The two men, who are both from Alabama, were last seen in combat on June 9.
author: By Alex Traub, Maham Javaid and Anushka Patil

header: The U.S. says it won’t pressure Ukraine to negotiate an end to the war.
desc: NA
author: By Eric Schmitt

header: The loss of a final bridge to Sievierodonetsk may hurt Ukraine’s ability to hold its ground.
desc: The last bridge linking the eastern city with Ukrainian-controlled territory to the west has been destroyed.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: The battle for Mariupol came down to a single factory. Will Sievierodonetsk go the same way?
desc: The United Nations says that hundreds of civilians are trapped with besieged Ukrainian forces at a chemical plant and “are suffering and experiencing constant shelling and bombardment.”
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Europe Offers Ukraine a Hope of Joining the E.U., but Not a Vast Arsenal
desc: In their first wartime visit to Kyiv, the leaders of France and Germany countered doubts about their commitment to Ukraine defeating Russia, but did not promise the weapons Ukrainians have called for.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson

header: Russians Breached This City, Not With Troops, but Propaganda
desc: As they batter towns and cities in Ukraine with artillery, the Russians are also bombarding them with messaging aimed at eroding Ukrainians’ trust in their military and their government.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

header: A Defiant Putin Says Russia Will Flourish Without the West
desc: In a speech at an economic forum, he called the U.S. a fading power and said sanctions on Russia, not the Ukraine war, are hurting Western economies.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson

header: Eurovision rules out Ukraine as host of next year’s song contest.
desc: The Eurovision Song Contest’s organizers said on Friday that Russia’s invasion meant Ukraine could not stage next year’s event, even though it won this year’s contest.
author: By Alex Marshall

header: The war in Ukraine revives an old practice: train diplomacy.
desc: With Ukraine’s airspace closed to civilian traffic since Russia’s invasion, European leaders had to take a train to Kyiv to visit President Volodymyr Zelensky.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Foreign fighters in Ukraine, many in motley groups, face perils if captured.
desc: Thousands of foreign fighters have gone to fight for Ukraine, but not all join its International Legion. Russia has maintained that some of foreign fighters it has captured are mercenaries.
author: By Jane Arraf and James C. McKinley Jr.

header: Internal challenges like corruption pose challenges in Ukraine’s bid to join the E.U.
