desc: The rules for joining the European Union require candidate nations crack down on corruption, a problem that Ukraine has struggled to address, including since President Volodymyr Zelensky took office.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: After past cease-fire deal failures, Ukraine casts a wary eye on Europe’s intent.
desc: The failed Minsk accords have become shorthand in Ukraine for appeasement of Russia. But European leaders today reiterated that any peace timeline would be in Ukraine’s hands.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: The State Department says a third American fighter may be missing in Ukraine.
desc: A State Department spokesman did not provide specifics. Earlier reports that two U.S. veterans had been captured by Russian forces remain unconfirmed.
author: By Anushka Patil

header: Ukraine’s path to the E.U. will be long and arduous.
desc: A recommendation to grant Ukraine candidate status has important symbolism. But the country faces a difficult road ahead, including more than 80,000 pages of rules and regulations.
author: By Dan Bilefsky

header: Russian Forces Tighten Noose Around Important Cities in Ukraine’s East
desc: The area around Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk is about three-quarters encircled by Russians, leaving only a slender gap there for Ukrainian troops to maneuver.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Vivian Yee, Andrew E. Kramer and Natalia Yermak

header: Zelensky Visits War-Torn Mykolaiv and Odesa in Southern Ukraine
desc: The president’s trip aimed to highlight Ukraine’s grip on the area and to lift the spirits of an embattled populace.
author: By Megan Specia

header: What Hundreds of Photos of Weapons Reveal About Russia’s Brutal War Strategy
desc: A New York Times analysis of visual evidence from Ukraine showed widespread use by Russia of cluster weapons banned under certain international treaties.
author: By Danielle Ivory, John Ismay, Denise Lu, Marco Hernandez, Cierra S. Queen, Jess Ruderman, Kristine White, Lauryn Higgins and Bonnie G. Wong

header: The metric of the war: Deaths.
desc: NA
author: By Jason Horowitz

header: Odesa Opera House Reopens, Defying Putin’s Barbarism
desc: War is not far away, but a city that has always lived for the moment proclaims that culture will help Ukraine prevail.
author: By Roger Cohen and Laetitia Vancon

header: Ukraine bans some Russian music and books.
desc: The Ukrainian Parliament voted to ban some Russian media and sent two bills to President Zelensky to sign.
author: By Carly Olson

header: Western leaders warn that the war in Ukraine could last years.
desc: Jens Stoltenberg said that Ukrainian forces were fighting bravely, and that with the arrival of more modern weaponry, they would be able to push Russian troops out of the eastern Donbas region.
author: By Austin Ramzy

header: Zelensky visits war-torn Mykolaiv and Odesa in southern Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Megan Specia

header: Russia launches strikes against targets across eastern Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukraine rushes troops to reinforce its faltering defense of Sievierodonetsk.
desc: NA
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Linchpin of Ukrainian Defiance, a Southern City Endures Russian Barrage
desc: Without its Black Sea coast, a landlocked Ukraine would struggle. Mykolaiv is determined that won’t happen.
author: By Roger Cohen and Laetitia Vancon

header: A Shopping Trip for Apples, Over the Last Bridge in Lysychansk
desc: Bridges are critical in the battle for Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk, separated by a river. Shelling has mostly destroyed them, but that didn’t stop one woman from walking across to buy some basics.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

header: Garland, Visiting Ukraine, Names Prosecutor to Investigate Russian War Crimes
desc: In an unannounced trip, the U.S. attorney general met with prosecutors and said perpetrators of atrocities have “no place to hide.”
author: By Glenn Thrush

header: Russia’s blockade of Ukraine’s food exports is a ‘war crime,’ says the E.U.’s foreign policy chief.
desc: The war is contributing to global food shortages and rising prices, and the United Nations warns of possible famine. Ukraine is usually a major grain exporter.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: The Kremlin says two captured American fighters are ‘soldiers of fortune’ not protected by the rules of war.
desc: Moscow says the Americans who fought for Ukraine are not regular soldiers who would be covered by the Geneva Conventions, calling their conduct criminal.
author: By Dan Bilefsky

header: Ukraine urges civilians to flee the occupied south ahead of a promised counteroffensive.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Western Move to Choke Russia’s Oil Exports Boomerangs, for Now
desc: With China and India buying the Russian oil shunned by the West in an effort to force an end to the Ukraine invasion, Moscow is earning more now than it did before the war.
author: By Victoria Kim, Clifford Krauss and Anton Troianovski

header: Russia’s Blockade of Ukraine Is ‘War Crime,’ Top E.U. Official Says
desc: The remarks by the official, Josep Borrell Fontelles, were among the strongest language from a Western leader in describing the Kremlin’s tactics to subjugate Ukraine.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Andrew Higgins, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Rick Gladstone

header: Ukraine bans some Russian music and books as a global culture war grows.
desc: Russian culture is being been shunned across the world as a protest against the invasion. But some critics argue that canceling Russian culture risks playing into the hands of President Vladimir V. Putin.
author: By Dan Bilefsky

header: The U.S. confirms the death of an American presumed to be the second killed on the battlefield in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Victoria Kim

header: Amid backlash, Eurovision’s organizers defend why Ukraine cannot host next year’s song contest.
desc: Eurovision officials cited the need to guarantee the security of all those involved in the contest, robbing Ukraine, this year’s winner, of the chance to be an international showcase.
author: By Maham Javaid and Dan Bilefsky

header: The arrival of Western weapons begins to reshape the battle off Ukraine’s coast.
desc: The Ukrainian military said it was attacking Russian infrastructure on Snake Island.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Marc Santora

header: European leaders are meeting today to decide on granting Ukraine E.U. candidate status.
desc: Their approval would allow Ukraine to be a candidate to join the bloc, starting what could be a long road.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk

header: As Russian forces fortify a Ukrainian nuclear power plant, employees are fleeing repression, local officials say.
desc: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, Europe’s largest, lies in southern Ukraine in a strategically important spot.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Russia Gains in the East, Threatening to Overrun Luhansk
desc: The seizure of three strategic villages confronts Ukrainian commanders with a grim choice: fight on and risk encirclement or retreat and lose the last major centers in the region.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Alan Yuhas

header: In Warsaw Park, Ukraine’s Teen Refugees Hang Out and Hang On
desc: Some fled to Poland’s capital alone. All feel deeply uneasy about the future. For the young Ukrainians packing into Poland’s capital, a park offers a place where they can try to cope, together.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: First Step Toward Ukraine Joining E.U. Signals Solidarity Amid War
desc: As Russia’s brutal offensive squeezes defenders in eastern Ukraine, Europe’s leaders, in a rebuke to Moscow, made a move they would have rejected before the invasion.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Michael Levenson

header: European leaders give Ukraine coveted E.U. candidate status.
desc: Candidacy signals that a nation is in position, if certain conditions are met, to begin a painstaking and yearslong process of changes and negotiations with the bloc, with a view to eventually joining.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk

header: The U.S. announces an additional $450 million in military aid for Ukraine.
desc: The latest announcement brings the total amount of military aid from the United States to Ukraine to $6.8 billion since the beginning of the Biden administration.
author: By John Ismay

header: Finding Alternative Route for Ukraine’s Grain Exports Isn’t So Simple, Experts Say
desc: Proposed alternatives include exporting into Poland or transporting it into Romania and out through the Black Sea port of Constanta.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukraine Retreats From Embattled City, as Russia Grinds On
desc: With the withdrawal from Sievierodonetsk, the fighting shifts to neighboring Lysychansk, the last city in the Luhansk region still under Ukrainian control.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Marc Santora and Michael Levenson

header: Ukraine says it is withdrawing from the city of Sievierodonetsk.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Russia Unleashes a Missile Barrage, While Inching Ahead in Eastern Ukraine
desc: Some of the missiles were launched from Belarus, whose leader is meeting Saturday with the Russian president.
author: By Marc Santora, Megan Specia and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Ukrainian insurgents kill a Kremlin-backed politician in occupied Kherson, part of a wave of attacks.
desc: A growing guerrilla movement appears to have been fueled by public anger over worsening economic, security and humanitarian conditions.
author: By Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Ukraine’s foreign minister sees E.U. candidacy as a crucial step toward joining a ‘liberal empire.’
desc: “History has been made,” he said of Ukraine’s being accepted as a candidate for E.U. membership.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Coal Dust and Methane Below, Russian Bombs Above
desc: The war has added a new threat to the dangerous lives of miners in eastern Ukraine.
author: By Finbarr O’Reilly

header: For a Kyiv techno collective, ‘now everything is about politics.’
desc: “This war has destroyed the statement that art could be outside politics,” the group’s booking and communications manager said.
author: By Tom Faber

header: Belarus’s Leader, ‘Europe’s Last Dictator,’ Burnishes Links to Russia
desc: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met with President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus on Saturday amid questions over how far Minsk will allow itself to be drawn into the war.
author: By Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Mayor of Embattled Southern Ukrainian City Urges All Residents to Leave
desc: The request by the Mykolaiv official was somewhat surprising, given that the city’s combative, never-say-die spirit has become a symbol of Ukrainian resistance.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: Russia begins occupying Sievierodonetsk and barrages Ukraine from the north and south.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora, Megan Specia and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Russian Strike on Kyiv Looms Over G7 Summit
desc: On the first day of their gathering, Group of 7 leaders moved to increase the economic pressure on Russia, but a missile attack on the Ukrainian capital made clear that Moscow is not backing down.
author: By Jim Tankersley

header: U.S. Urges New Tactic to Curb Putin’s War Machine and Lower Fuel Prices
desc: Group of 7 leaders meeting in Germany were receptive to a Biden administration plan to cap the price of Russian oil in world markets, limiting Kremlin revenue.
author: By Jim Tankersley

header: After a weekend of strikes, sirens bring anxiety even in Ukraine’s safest cities.
desc: The dozens of the missiles launched by Russian forces into Ukraine over the weekend have raised anxiety in Lviv, even in the relative peace of the country’s northwest.
author: By Megan Specia

header: Civilians should immediately evacuate a Ukrainian city that is under fire, a regional official warned.
desc: Residents of Lysychansk, across the river from a city that fell to Russian control last week, should leave over “the real threat to life and health,” the region’s military governor said.
author: By Megan Specia and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: At a Boarding School in Ukraine, Displaced Children Long for Home
desc: Many left their parents behind when they were evacuated from the country’s east. Now they wrestle with the trauma of a conflict that has consumed much of their young lives.
author: By Megan Specia

header: A missile strike hits a crowded shopping center in central Ukraine.
desc: Videos of the site, near the railway station in the central city of Kremenchuk, showed a fire raging as emergency workers frantically attempted to extinguish the flames.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Ivan Nechepurenko, Megan Specia and Dan Bilefsky

header: After Monday’s mall airstrike, shocked residents grapple with the destruction, the dead and the missing.
desc: “The worst thing is that this is a shopping mall,” said a town official. “Any of us could have been here.”
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Missile Strike in Kyiv Rattles Residents After Weeks of Quiet
desc: The strike on Sunday morning shook many out of the relative sense of security that has prevailed in Ukraine’s capital since the Russians were pushed out of its periphery in early April.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Ukraine War’s Latest Victim? The Fight Against Climate Change.
desc: As leaders of the Group of 7 gather in Germany, the scramble to replace Russian fossil fuels is raising concerns that hard-won climate targets will be missed.
author: By Katrin Bennhold and Jim Tankersley

header: The U.S. and Britain will ban imports of gold from Russia.
desc: President Biden announced the decision before the start of a G7 summit meeting in Germany.
author: By Jim Tankersley and Austin Ramzy

header: On Front Lines, Communication Breakdowns Prove Costly for Ukraine
desc: The Ukrainian Army has tried to modernize, but still falls short in coordination among units, so they often fight independently of one another — with sometimes deadly results.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak

header: A More Muscular NATO Emerges as West Confronts Russia and China
desc: It is a fundamental shift for a military alliance born in the Cold War and scrambling to respond to a newly reshaped world.
author: By Steven Erlanger and Michael D. Shear

header: Ukraine announces largest prisoner exchange yet, including Mariupol fighters.
desc: Officials said 144 Ukrainian soldiers, many of them seriously injured, were released in an exchange for the same number of Russian and proxy forces.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: ‘It is not at all safe’: Cities across Ukraine suffer a steady stream of civilian casualties.
desc: Despite a Russian claims to focus on military infrastructure, civilian sites have increasingly been destroyed.
author: By Megan Specia

header: Why do Finland and Sweden appear headed toward swift NATO membership while Ukraine isn’t?
desc: The imperative to seek NATO membership is written into Ukraine’s Constitution. But even President Volodymyr Zelensky has said that it may never happen.
author: By Dan Bilefsky and Steven Erlanger

header: ‘We hoped we would be safe here’: The death toll from a strike on a mall rises to 18.
desc: Ukraine’s top prosecutor arrived with a team of investigators to collect evidence about what she said constituted a “war crime” under Ukrainian law and a crime against humanity.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: G7 Leaders Promise $4.5 Billion to Address Global Hunger Caused by War in Ukraine
desc: The planned commitment, more than half of it from the U.S., reflects worldwide alarm at shortages in wheat and sunflower oil caused by Russia’s invasion.
author: By Michael D. Shear

header: ‘This is our 1937 moment,’ the U.K.’s new army chief says of the war.
desc: Gen. Patrick Sanders, alluding to Western Europe’s failure to confront Nazi Germany, said that Britain must not allow Russia’s military action to expand into NATO territory.
author: By Euan Ward and Stephen Castle

header: A cap on the price of Russian oil comes with many questions.
desc: The idea is to limit how much Russia can earn from the oil it sells while still keeping markets well supplied.
author: By Stanley Reed

header: ‘I Was Flying Headfirst’: A Shopping Trip Shattered by a Missile
desc: Survivors of the Russian strike that hit a busy mall in central Ukraine, killing at least 18, described the moment that tore their lives apart.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Ill Prepared for Combat, Volunteers Die in Battles Far From Home
desc: Many of the fighters for Ukraine’s western territorial defense units were assigned benign tasks away from the fighting when they first joined. Then they were called to the front to fight.
author: By Megan Specia

header: The U.K. pledges to nearly double its military funding for Ukraine.
desc: Britain, the second-largest donor to Ukraine after the United States, promised a further 1 billion pounds as Ukraine struggles to finance its war effort.
author: By Marc Santora

header: At a boarding school in Ukraine, displaced children long for home.
desc: The children are navigating a strange new reality.
author: By Megan Specia

header: Missile Strikes on Ukraine Kill at Least 21 Near Odesa
desc: The strikes hit a residential tower and a recreational center in a coastal town southwest of the Black Sea port city of Odesa.
author: By Eduardo Medina and Victoria Kim

header: Biden Vows to Back Ukraine ‘as Long as It Takes’ Despite Economic Toll
desc: NATO leaders concluded a summit with new commitments to a united front against Russian aggression, but they face the challenge of persuading their own people that it’s worth the cost.
author: By Steven Erlanger, Jim Tankersley, Michael D. Shear and Alan Yuhas

header: Vitaliy Kim, Master Motivator and Symbol of Ukraine’s Resistance
desc: Applying the lessons of taekwondo, the regional military leader has rallied the embattled southern city of Mykolaiv.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: ‘Long Live the Theater’: Mariupol’s Drama Company to Perform Again
desc: Thirteen members of the Mariupol Drama Theater have reconvened in western Ukraine where they are rehearsing a new play about a Ukrainian dissident who died in a Russian prison camp in the 1980s.
author: By Megan Specia

header: From the Early Morning Sky, Shards of Hot Metal
desc: Ukrainians reacted in fury to a Russian missile strike near Odesa, the latest in a string of attacks on civilian targets.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: As the war’s effects ripple, India seeks a middle ground.
desc: The changing tone reflects the middle path that India is carving out for itself in this crisis.
author: By Emily Schmall and Suhasini Raj

header: Missing From Biden’s Europe Trip: An Endgame for War and Cheaper Gas
desc: The G7 and NATO meetings this week underscored the pressure on Western leaders caused by soaring energy costs resulting from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
author: By Jim Tankersley and Michael D. Shear

header: As City Falls, Ukraine’s Last Hope in Luhansk Falls With It
desc: Lysychansk managed to hold out for a week after its twin city, Sievierodonetsk, was captured. But on Sunday a pro-Russian flag flew there, as well.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Kamila Hrabchuk and Vivian Yee

header: Ukraine dreams of rebuilding the world’s largest airplane. Can Richard Branson help?
desc: A Virgin Group spokesperson said the effort would turn to finding ways the international community could support the project.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: Ukrainian students are hopeful and defiant as they graduate amid war.
desc: For these students, this coming-of-age moment amid the war is especially poignant.
author: By Megan Specia and Emile Ducke

header: How the Russian Media Spread False Claims About Ukrainian Nazis
desc: An analysis of nearly eight million articles about Ukraine from Russian websites shows that references to Nazism have spiked to unprecedented levels during the war.
author: By Charlie Smart

header: This regional leader is a symbol of Ukrainian defiance.
desc: Vitaliy Kim is the head of the regional military administration in the embattled southern city of Mykolaiv.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: Investigators of War Crimes in Ukraine Face Formidable Challenges
desc: International agencies are joining Ukrainian prosecutors in what may be the biggest effort ever to hold war criminals to account. But the difficulties and dangers they face are exceptional, too.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Russia Repeatedly Strikes Ukraine’s Civilians. There’s Always an Excuse.
desc: The Kremlin’s explanations have sometimes satisfied the Russian people, but they fall apart under closer scrutiny abroad.
author: By Daniel Victor and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Russia Steps Up Pace of Missile Attacks on Residential Targets
desc: The Russians’ growing use of imprecise Soviet-era missiles to terrorize civilians reflects the daunting outlook of its offensive despite incremental gains, analysts say.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Women who were raped by Russian soldiers yearn for justice.
desc: Rapes were among the many atrocities Russian troops inflicted on Ukrainian civilians during weeks of occupation in the Kyiv suburbs and elsewhere. But the challenges of prosecuting the assaults are daunting.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Australia’s new prime minister promises increased aid during visit to Ukraine.
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky described the visit as the first by an Australian prime minister to his country during their history of diplomatic relations.
author: By Alex Traub

header: As Russia Moves on Another Province, Ukrainians Leave Ghost Towns Behind
desc: Vast stretches of eastern Ukraine are now largely devoid of people and industry. If Ukraine is ever to have a vibrant postwar future, it is unlikely to sprout from these ruins.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and The New York Times

header: Russia Advances Behind Brutal Barrage, but Will Its Strategy Keep Working?
desc: The Russian and Ukrainian armies have both been badly mauled, raising questions about how long they can keep fighting as they have, particularly the outgunned Ukrainians.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: ‘Get the Stretcher!’ Life and Death on Ukraine’s Front Line
desc: On another day of scorched-earth artillery barrages in the east, a team of Ukrainian medics did their best to stabilize and assure the survivors, with the din of war all around.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

header: How War in Ukraine Roiled Russia’s ‘Coolest Company’
desc: The decline of Yandex, the Russian version of Google, is emblematic of the economic and cultural troubles spawned by the invasion.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: Investigating war crimes in Ukraine, as the war rages on, poses formidable challenges.
desc: NA
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Ukrainian jewelers are determined to do more than survive.
desc: NA
author: By Victoria Gomelsky

header: Ukraine’s prime minister says rebuilding will cost $750 billion.
desc: World leaders are mapping out the monumental effort to restore a war-battered nation.
author: By Dan Bilefsky and Nick Cumming-Bruce

header: As losses mount, defiant Ukrainians have little appetite for compromise.
desc: NA
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Maria Varenikova

header: In Putin’s Russia, the Arrests Are Spreading Quickly and Widely
desc: One by one, Russians deemed insufficiently patriotic are being snatched up by security forces as the Kremlin tightens the noose.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Ukraine’s allies sign accord to help the war-ravaged country rebuild.
desc: NA
author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce

header: Ukraine’s Herculean Task: Helping Millions Whose Homes Are in Ruins or Russia’s Hands
desc: Millions of Ukrainians have fled their homes as Russia has slowly advanced in the east. Many may not have a home to go back to when the war is over.
author: By Emma Bubola and Megan Specia

header: For Foreign Fighters in Ukraine, a War Unlike Any They’ve Seen
desc: Small groups of Western combat veterans are on the front lines, but many more with fewer skills are left trying to find a role to play.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Valerie Hopkins and Jane Arraf

header: A team of Ukrainian medics navigates life and death on the battlefield.
desc: NA
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

header: At Europe’s Largest Port, Russia Sanctions Meet Their Toughest Test
desc: The Dutch port of Rotterdam and its staff are at the front line of enforcing the European Union’s restrictions on trade with Russia. It’s no easy task.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Zelensky calls Johnson ‘a true friend’ to Ukraine.
desc: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has visited Ukraine’s capital twice since Russia invaded, had countless phone calls with its president, Volodymyr Zelensky, and helped deliver weapons and aid.
author: By Megan Specia

header: Ukraine says a Russian ship carrying stolen grain has left Turkey.
desc: NA
author: By Maham Javaid and Safak Timur

header: Brittney Griner pleads guilty to drug charges in Russia.
desc: Her plea came hours after a Russian diplomat said that publicity around the basketball player’s case was not helping her interests.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: The U.S. intelligence chief laid out three scenarios in Ukraine. Here’s a look at each.
desc: NA
author: By David Leonhardt

header: Ukraine retreated from an eastern city in ‘moment of vulnerability,’ a former defense minister says.
desc: NA
author: By Jane Arraf

header: U.S. senators in Kyiv say they will push to send more arms to Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: Desperate for Recruits, Russia Launches a ‘Stealth Mobilization’
desc: Leery of a national draft for the Ukraine war, the Kremlin is offering cash bonuses and employing strong arm tactics.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: Ukraine dismisses its ambassador to Germany after controversial remarks.
desc: Andriy Melnyk, an outspoken advocate for weapons for Ukraine, denied the role of a Ukrainian nationalist leader in the Holocaust, stoking outrage in Germany.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: For Ukraine, Boris Johnson’s Resignation Means Loss of a Personal Ally
desc: Boris Johnson may be a polarizing figure in Britain, but in Ukraine he is widely adored for his unstinting support since the conflict with Russia.
author: By Megan Specia

header: Families of civilian soldiers worry and wait in Ukraine.
desc: Many of the fighters have no previous military experience.
author: By Megan Specia

header: Behind Russia’s ‘pause’ are signs of a troubled effort to regroup.
desc: The weapons and personnel Russia may be turning to, analysts say, suggest that Moscow’s next assault may not be as fierce as it promised.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: As Russia Looms, a Ukrainian City’s Loyalties Divide
desc: Most residents have fled the eastern city of Sloviansk before an expected Russian assault. About half of the 23,000 remaining are eager to welcome the invaders.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Mauricio Lima

header: Blinken Presses China’s Top Diplomat on Ukraine but Stresses Cooperation
desc: At a G20 meeting, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken sought to cool tensions with Beijing in an effort to further isolate Russia. He met resistance.
author: By Michael Crowley, Steven Erlanger and Catherine Porter

header: ‘It’s Like Parallel Realities’: Rituals of Life and Death Blur in a Vibrant Ukrainian City
desc: In Lviv, babies are born in a hospital just steps away from the military cemetery where Ukraine’s young soldiers are laid to rest.
author: By Megan Specia and Emile Ducke

header: Russia’s Lavrov Is Pariah at Group of 20 Event, but Only for Some
desc: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and other Western foreign ministers refused to meet with the Russian diplomat, but for many others it was business as usual.
author: By Michael Crowley

header: The U.S. and its allies face a test of endurance in Ukraine as weariness grows.
desc: NA
author: By Peter Baker and David E. Sanger

header: Russia Steps Up Attacks on Civilian Areas, Even With Advance Paused
desc: Russian forces in eastern Ukraine are regrouping, with a new offensive expected, but they continue to rain death and destruction on cities and towns.
author: By Carlotta Gall, Kamila Hrabchuk and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: The war could have you paying more for hummus.
desc: Russia and Ukraine are two of the biggest exporters of chickpeas, and the global supply is expected to decline this year.
author: By Maham Javaid

header: Ukrainian Medic’s Months in Russian Cell: Cold, Dirty and Used as a Prop
desc: Yulia Paievska was already well known in Ukraine when she was captured, but the trauma she describes has made her a symbol of bravery and sacrifice.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Putin extends a fast-track Russian citizenship process to all Ukrainians.
desc: The move indicated that Russia might seek to establish permanent control of Ukrainian territories currently occupied by Moscow’s forces.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: A hail of Russian strikes brings terror to Ukraine’s east.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Carlotta Gall

header: In Eastern Ukraine, Attacks Intensify as Russia Readies New Offensive
desc: The civilian toll has risen sharply in recent days as rockets and shells strike residential areas in the likely path of Russia’s coming push into Donetsk Province.
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: A Ukrainian medic describes spending months in a cold, dirty Russian cell.
desc: NA
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Ukrainian entrepreneurs have switched to producing goods to help wage war.
desc: NA
author: By Erika Solomon

header: A survivor emerges from the rubble of an apartment complex.
desc: NA
author: By Carlotta Gall and Kamila Hrabchuk

header: ‘Like parallel realities’: Rituals of life and death blur in a vibrant Ukrainian city.
desc: NA
author: By Megan Specia and Emile Ducke

header: Ukraine says its forces hit a Russian ammunition depot in the Kherson region.
desc: A pro-Russia official said the weapon used was a High Mobility Artillery Rocket System, or HIMARS. The truck-mounted, multiple-rocket launchers are the most advanced weapons so far supplied by the United States to Ukraine.
author: By Euan Ward

header: Priests Once Aligned With Russia Come Under Suspicion in Ukraine
desc: The Ukrainian Orthodox Church was once a dominant force in the country, but now officials suspect that some priests may be collaborating with Russia.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Oleksandr Chubko and Vera Mironova

header: After Ukraine-Russia Meeting, U.N. Sees ‘a Ray of Hope’ to Free Grain
desc: Negotiators did not reach a deal to allow grain to flow from blockaded Ukrainian ports and ease a global food crisis, but the U.N. secretary general said they made progress.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Michael Schwirtz

header: History Haunts Ukraine’s Undiplomatic Voice in Berlin
desc: Debate over a Ukrainian nationalist leader’s role in the Holocaust has exposed how views of the past shape European allies’ relationships with Kyiv.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: Putin, Looking for Allies, Plans to Meet Leaders of Turkey and Iran
desc: In his second diplomatic push since Russia invaded Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin will travel to Tehran to build bridges between leaders at odds over Syria, oil and the West.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Ukraine’s pleas for more weapons run into the concerns of the U.S.
desc: NA
author: By Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes

header: The U.N. will investigate the deaths of children in Ukraine.
desc: The “Children and Armed Conflict” report highlights the impact of war on a vulnerable population.
author: By Carly Olson

header: Putin’s Oil War With the West Comes at His Allies’ Expense
desc: Russia’s use of energy as a weapon in its standoff with the West is redrawing the geopolitical map, but it could strain ties with allies like Iran and Venezuela.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Farnaz Fassihi

header: The U.S. accuses Russia of war crimes, alleging hundreds of thousands of Ukrainian deportations.
desc: Ukrainian officials have long sounded the alarm on Russia’s deportations, but U.S. officials had previously been vague about their scale.
author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka

header: Stress on workers at an occupied nuclear plant elevates risks, experts say.
desc: Three problems at the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, in a city close to territory held by Ukraine, have caused particular worries.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: In a Flash of Fire and Shrapnel, a Smiling 4-Year-Old’s Life Is Snuffed Out
desc: A toddler with Down syndrome was happily pushing a stroller through a Ukraine park before a Russian missile landed. “I want to shout out to the whole world,” an anguished survivor of the attack cried.
author: By Maria Varenikova and Andrew E. Kramer

header: A strike on the Ukrainian city of Vinnytsia kills at least 23 people, officials say.
desc: Dozens were wounded in the rocket attack on the city, according to emergency officials.
author: By Maria Varenikova and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Gaps in Arms Supplies to Ukraine Point to Countries’ Divergent Strategies
desc: Beyond logistical issues, the uneven flow of arms to Ukraine hints at differences among allies about whether Russia should be punished or eventually accommodated.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: Strikes on Civilians Deep in Ukraine Show Russia’s Lethal Reach
desc: Missiles struck Vinnytsia, hundreds of miles from the front lines, and other cities, claiming dozens of lives, as Russia keeps up pressure despite pausing its eastern offensive.
author: By Maria Varenikova and Michael Levenson

header: ‘Putin’s War Must Be a Strategic Failure,’ Biden Says in Israel
desc: Ukraine policy has been a point of friction between Israel and the United States.
author: By Patrick Kingsley

header: The many parties involved complicate war crimes investigations.
desc: Russian attacks on civilians have underscored the need to hold war crimes to account. But the prosecutor of the International Criminal Court warned against a “stampede” of investigations.
author: By Dan Bilefsky and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Putin Aims to Shape a New Generation of Supporters, Through Schools
desc: Sweeping changes in the curriculum will soon cast the Russian president as a pivotal historical figure and mark an end of openness to the West.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: An American living in Ukraine has been detained in Russian-occupied territory, his family says.
desc: The man was taken into custody last month, according to his brother, and says he is being held in the same jail as two other Americans.
author: By Carly Olson

header: Long ties to Russia stir suspicions about Ukraine’s Orthodox Church, and its priests.
desc: NA
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Oleksandr Chubko and Vera Mironova

header: The rash of fighting in Donetsk Province counters the notion of a military ‘pause.’
desc: NA
author: By Alan Yuhas and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: On Donetsk’s Front Line, Small Gains and Losses Impose a Heavy Toll
desc: Ukrainian soldiers say they live under almost constant Russian bombardment but dismiss any suggestion that they cede land.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Mauricio Lima

header: Reunited in Bucha, a Ukrainian Family Comes to Terms With War’s Traumas
desc: As flowers bloom amid the wreckage, the Kyiv suburb synonymous with atrocity feels almost normal again. But the lives of the people there may never be.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Moscow Signals a Shift to a More Aggressive Phase of Ukraine War
desc: After a brief pause, the Russian military is ramping up activity “in all operational sectors” in the Donbas region, the defense minister said.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Steven Erlanger

header: A Young Woman’s Wartime Task: Persuading People to Leave Their Homes
desc: In phone calls, doorstep conversations and public speeches, Yana Muravinets has tried to convince people that it’s time to leave villages around the embattled southern city of Mykolaiv.
author: By Emma Bubola

header: Ukrainian Plane Carrying Serbian Munitions Bound for Bangladesh Crashes in Greece
desc: Eight Ukrainian citizens were killed when the cargo plane transporting 11.5 tons of weapons crashed in a field in Greece.
author: By Niki Kitsantonis and Cora Engelbrecht

header: Family Members Mourn a 4-Year-Old Girl Killed in Russian Missile Attack
desc: The death of Liza Dmytriyeva, a 4-year-old with Down syndrome, encapsulated the brutality of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
author: By Eduardo Medina

header: Italy’s Crisis Redoubles European Foreboding
desc: Europe is being tested, not only in its united front to Russia, but in the very resilience of its democracies, as nationalist forces sympathetic to Russia remain untamed.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: A heat wave in Europe threatens crops as grain from Ukraine remains blocked.
desc: NA
author: By Maham Javaid

header: ‘It’s tense’: Under constant fire, Ukrainian soldiers dismiss any suggestion that they cede land.
desc: NA
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: A series of deadly strikes on civilian targets across Ukraine leaves officials urging people to heed air raid sirens.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Jane Arraf

header: Zelensky Takes Aim at Hidden Enemy: Ukrainians Aiding Russia
desc: In firing his intelligence chief and top prosecutor, President Volodymyr Zelensky signaled a more aggressive approach to a fifth column undermining Ukraine’s war effort.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Valerie Hopkins

header: Kharkiv Tried to Return to Normal. Russian Shelling Wouldn’t Let It.
desc: Ukraine repelled the effort to capture its second-largest city, but the artillery attacks did not stop. Many residents who left have returned but fear that a new offensive is imminent.
author: NA

header: Putin Finds a New Ally in Iran, a Fellow Outcast
desc: A three-way summit meeting in Tehran between the leaders of Russia, Iran and Turkey sent a clear signal that Vladimir Putin is pushing back against ostracism from the West.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Farnaz Fassihi

header: As Putin visits Iran, he meets with Turkey’s leader, a middleman in Ukraine diplomacy.
desc: NA
author: By Ben Hubbard

header: Long-range artillery supplied by the United States has started to alter Ukraine’s battlefield dynamics.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: An assault renews concerns about a nuclear power plant on the war’s front line.
desc: Russian forces have controlled the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant since March, but its location could make it a focus of any effort by Ukraine to regain lost territory.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Russia plans to annex territory it controls in Ukraine, a U.S. official says.
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson

header: Ukraine’s first lady meets with Jill Biden (and receives flowers from President Biden).
desc: NA
author: By Jim Tankersley

header: E.U. bans Russian gold and reimburses countries for weapons sent to Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Russia fines Google for failing to remove news it calls ‘fake.’
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson

header: Ukraine Tries to Make the Case That It Can Win, Citing Recent Strikes
desc: Pushing back against skepticism that Western weapons will allow them to turn the tide against Russia, Ukrainians point to successful attacks using new long-range rocket systems.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: With Russian Cutoff Feared, Europeans Are Told to Curb Natural Gas Use
desc: The European Union’s executive branch says member countries must cut consumption by 15 percent between now and the springtime to stave off a major crisis as Russia weaponizes its exports.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Russia Signals That It May Want a Bigger Chunk of Ukraine
desc: A top Russian official said Moscow may extend its territorial claims to include not just the east of Ukraine but also parts of the south.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Eric Nagourney

header: Putin is ‘entirely too healthy,’ the C.I.A. director says.
desc: There is no evidence that the Russian president is unwell, Western intelligence officials said, after the Kremlin denied rumors about his health.
author: By Maham Javaid

header: Russia’s territorial aims in Ukraine have expanded, the foreign minister says.
desc: Mr. Lavrov said that Russia’s objectives could expand further if Western countries deliver more long-range weapons to Ukraine.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Seeking ‘Axis of Good’ Against U.S., Russia Taps Allies of Convenience
desc: A trilateral meeting of the leaders of Iran, Russia and Turkey seemed to suggest a new anti-American alliance. But there are major fissures between the countries, too.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: Ukraine steps up attacks on key Russian targets in the south.
desc: Attacks on a strategically important bridge and other Russian positions in the Kherson Province over the last two days raise a question: Is Ukraine preparing a larger counteroffensive?
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Turkey says a deal between Ukraine and Russia to unblock grain exports will be signed on Friday.
desc: NA
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Farnaz Fassihi, Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Safak Timur and Anton Troianovski

header: Ukraine’s first lady tells the U.S. Congress that ‘Russia is destroying our people.’
desc: In a rare appearance by a foreign first spouse before Congress, Olena Zelenska asked for more weapons to defend against Russian aggression.
author: By Dan Bilefsky, Stephanie Lai and Jim Tankersley

header: Russia Restarts Gas Shipments Through Pipeline, but Keeps Germany Guessing
desc: Russia is again sending natural gas through the Nord Stream 1 pipeline to Germany, but nobody knows how much and how long the fuel will flow.
author: By Melissa Eddy

header: Russia Agrees to Let Ukraine Ship Grain, Easing World Food Shortage
desc: Ukraine and Russia signed a deal to lift Russia’s blockade of Ukrainian ports, which has worsened a global food crisis — their most important agreement since the war began.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Last Stand at Azovstal: Inside the Siege That Shaped the Ukraine War
desc: For 80 days, at a sprawling steelworks, a relentless Russian assault met unyielding Ukrainian resistance. This is how it was for those who fought, and for those trapped beneath the battlefield.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Russia Strikes Odesa Port, Stirring Doubts on Deal to Export Grain
desc: The string of explosions in Ukraine’s most important port came less than 24 hours after the two countries struck a deal on grain shipments, and prompted accusations from Ukrainian leaders that Russia could not be trusted.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Erika Solomon

header: Boats and a bridge: Control of waterways will be key in Ukraine’s looming counteroffensive.
desc: The Biden administration is sending aid to help in the effort to recapture Kherson.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: The price of wheat falls on news of a deal to allow Ukrainian exports.
desc: NA
author: By Joe Rennison

header: The Biden administration will send another $270 million in military aid to Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Michael Crowley

header: Spouses of world leaders to join Ukraine’s first lady in a discussion on postwar lives.
desc: NA
author: By Maham Javaid

header: Draghi’s Fall Reverberates Beyond Italy
desc: The downfall of Italy’s prime minister has raised concerns across Europe about the power of populist movements and whether they will erode unity against Russian aggression.
author: By Jason Horowitz

header: Here’s how the grain deal between Ukraine and Russia will work.
desc: The process requires the collaboration of the two warring nation, along with Turkey and the United Nations.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Russia and Ukraine trade attacks as fighting shifts to the south.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Victoria Kim

header: Eyeing a City Captured by Russia, Ukraine Prepares an Ambitious Counterattack
desc: With soldiers, artillery and subversives, Ukraine has been laying the groundwork to retake Kherson, which Russia has held for months. But a counterattack would require huge resources, and could come at a heavy toll.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Daniel Berehulak

header: U.K., Eurovision Runner-up to Ukraine, Will Host Song Contest in 2023
desc: Organizers had ruled out Ukraine from hosting next year because of safety concerns from Russia’s invasion.
author: By Daniel Victor

header: A U.S. intelligence report finds that Russia’s use of ‘filtration centers’ to detain and deport Ukrainians has intensified.
desc: A newly declassified U.S. analysis found that Ukrainians detained in the centers may face deportation or imprisonment.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Fears rise for a rights activist captured while fighting for Ukraine.
desc: Russian propaganda has demonized Maksym Butkevych, a former journalist and campaigner who was taken prisoner in the eastern city of Sievierodonetsk.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: ‘We Survived Another Night’: In Ruined Suburb, Solace in a Small Community
desc: In a largely abandoned apartment complex on the outskirts of Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-biggest city, the people who stayed behind find comfort in their surroundings and each other.
author: By Jane Arraf and Emile Ducke

header: ‘An abyss of fear’: A report accuses Russia of further abuses against civilians.
desc: Human Rights Watch cataloged a litany of torture, inhumane treatment, arbitrary detention and disappearances in southern Ukraine and said that the atrocities could amount to war crimes.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Kyiv Nightlife Comes Back Amid Urge for Contact. ‘This Is the Cure.’
desc: Frenzied raves. Crowded bars (with free therapy). And of course, cuddle parties. Nightlife is returning to Ukraine’s capital. But revelers still have to reckon with guilty feelings. Plus curfew.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Laura Boushnak

header: An American killed in Ukraine was moved to volunteer by his heritage, a friend says.
desc: Joining the fight “was something that he needed to do,” a close friend said of Luke Lucyszyn.
author: By Eduardo Medina

header: Bryan Young, an American volunteer who died fighting in Ukraine, felt called to help.
desc: After resettling in the Republic of Georgia, Young traveled to Ukraine to enlist as a volunteer fighter.
author: By Carly Olson

header: Ukraine presses on with a plan for much-needed grain shipments after a Russian attack.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Eric Nagourney

header: The Hunt Is On for ‘War Trophies’ in Ukraine
desc: Collectors across the country are seeking pieces of shrapnel, bits of bombs and even the uniforms of dead Russians. It’s part of an urge to feel more directly connected to the cause.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: Navigating mines and threatened by war, ships laden with grain are expected to leave Odesa soon.
desc: Such voyages would be the first since the signing of a deal to allow a resumption of Ukraine’s grain exports, which have been blocked since Russia’s invasion five months ago.
author: By Maria Varenikova and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Britain’s Power Grid Warns of a Tight Energy Supply This Winter
desc: Unlike many European countries, Britain produces substantial amounts of its own gas, but it has still faced skyrocketing energy prices in recent months.
author: By Alex Traub

header: Ukraine hits a key bridge in Kherson as Russia steps up missile strikes across the south.
desc: The bridge is a critical part of Russia’s resupply route for the forces charged with holding the port city.
author: By Maria Varenikova and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Looming Question for Putin Opponents: Can You Change Russia From Jail?
desc: For opposition figures choosing to stay in Russia after President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, imprisonment looks like a matter of time. It’s also a subject for fierce debate.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Facing ‘Putin’s Energy Blackmail,’ Europe Agrees to Cut Russian Gas Use
desc: Holding together despite some nations’ dependence on Russia, the European Union agreed to make voluntary savings mandatory if the Kremlin suddenly decides to turn off the taps over its invasion of Ukraine.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: A joint center to monitor grain shipments from Ukraine opens in Istanbul.
desc: NA
author: By Safak Timur and Maria Varenikova

header: The war has sent prices in Ukraine soaring.
desc: NA
author: By Liz Alderman

header: A special military group in Germany keeps the West’s weapons flowing into Ukraine.
desc: A little-known group at U.S. European Command in Germany fills Ukraine’s battlefield requests with donations from more than 40 countries.
author: By Eric Schmitt

header: Macron criticizes the ‘hypocrisy’ of some African leaders on the Ukraine war.
desc: President Emmanuel Macron of France, visiting West Africa, said some countries had failed to condemn Russia’s invasion of Ukraine because of “diplomatic pressures.”
author: By Elian Peltier and Aurelien Breeden

header: Explosion Kills Dozens of Ukrainian Captives at Russian-Held Prison
desc: At least 50 captured fighters died in a blast at a prison in eastern Ukraine, with no clarity on exactly what happened and each country blaming the other.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Valerie Hopkins and Cora Engelbrecht

header: Why does Ukraine fight? So it can exist, Zelensky says.
desc: Ukraine is celebrating its Day of Statehood, a holiday that both celebrates its independence and sends an unmistakable message to a neighbor with territorial ambitions.
author: By Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora

header: Blinken and Lavrov Discuss Griner in Their First Call of the War
desc: Ukraine said it was ready for Black Sea grain shipments to resume, while the top Russian and American diplomats talked about a prisoner swap involving the basketball star Brittney Griner.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Michael Crowley and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: Russians, Risking Isolation in the South, Build Up for Ukrainian Attack
desc: Russia is moving “maximum” forces to the south, which presents a role reversal from the eastern Donbas region: Ukraine is on the offensive and Russians holding a key city risk being cut off.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Marc Santora, Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Maria Varenikova and Michael Levenson

header: Lethal missile strikes in Kharkiv hit sites related to Ukraine’s military, a new pattern.
desc: NA
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: Lebanon says it is investigating Ukraine’s claim that a docked ship contains plundered grain.
desc: The Laodicea, a Syrian cargo ship, arrived in Tripoli, Lebanon, on Wednesday carrying about 10,000 tons of wheat and barley.
author: By Hwaida Saad

header: A Ukrainian appeals court reduces the life sentence of a Russian soldier tried for war crimes.
desc: NA
author: By Dan Bilefsky

header: A strike kills dozens of Ukrainian prisoners of war. Russia and Ukraine blame each other.
desc: NA
author: By Cora Engelbrecht and Michael Schwirtz

header: Iran Ramps Up Drone Exports, Signaling Global Ambitions
desc: Tehran has quietly stepped up the sale of drone technology to countries outside the Middle East as it seeks to become a player in the international market.
author: By Euan Ward and Farnaz Fassihi

header: Ukraine’s harvest is underway, swelling its grain backlog and adding to farmers’ troubles.
desc: NA
author: By Liz Alderman

header: Using Nuclear Reactors for Cover, Russians Lob Rockets at Ukrainians
desc: Russia has turned Europe’s largest nuclear power plant into a fortress, stymying Ukraine’s forces and unnerving locals who fear both shelling and a radiation leak.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: How the Kremlin Is Forcing Ukrainians to Adopt Russian Life
desc: In Russian-occupied regions in Ukraine, local leaders are forcing civilians to accept Russian rule. Next come sham elections that would formalize Vladimir V. Putin’s claim that they are Russian territories.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Valerie Hopkins, Marc Santora and Michael Schwirtz

header: One of Ukraine’s richest businessmen is killed in the port city of Mykolaiv.
desc: Oleksiy Vadaturskyi, whose company built storage facilities and infrastructure necessary for exporting grain, was killed with his wife in a missile strike.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Marc Santora

header: As Ukraine defends in the east and south, a U.S. official says Russia’s war effort is failing.
desc: A senior U.S. Defense Department official said there was growing evidence that steep Russian losses had left some units ill-prepared to fight.
author: By Marc Santora

header: As Ukraine Orders Civilians to Evacuate the East, Residents Face a Grim Choice
desc: The president’s announcement is the broadest government directive issued thus far in the war, coming after months of relentless Russian bombardment.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Erika Solomon

header: Ukraine Calls for Investigation Into Prisoner Deaths as Outrage Grows
desc: Ukrainian authorities gathered evidence that they said showed Russia had orchestrated an explosion that killed at least 50 of their soldiers.
author: By Marc Santora, Maria Varenikova and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: The Red Cross says it still doesn’t have access to the prison camp where dozens of Ukrainians died.
desc: The Russian Defense Ministry had said it would allow the United Nations and the Red Cross to visit the site.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: ‘Fill the silence with your music’: A visit to Ukraine reaffirmed what culture can do at its best.
desc: NA
author: By Jason Farago

header: Vessels await word that they can carry the first grain shipments out of Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Ukrainian officials compile evidence that they say shows Russia was behind prison camp blast.
desc: Dozens of Ukrainian soldiers being held in a Russian prisoner of war camp were killed when a blast tore through their barracks.
author: By Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora

header: Ukraine Ships Grain at Last. It Will Take Far More to Slow Global Hunger.
desc: The departure of a grain-filled vessel from Odesa was hailed as a victory against global hunger. But experts say the crisis is so big that no single advance can reverse it.
author: By Declan Walsh

header: Here’s what we know about the deadly blast at a prisoner camp in eastern Ukraine.
desc: An explosion at a detention camp killed at least 50 Ukrainian prisoners of war, in what Ukrainians are calling a war crime.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Maria Varenikova

header: A ship loaded with Ukrainian grain leaves the Port of Odesa for the first time since the war began.
desc: NA
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: In Ukraine, Devastation Spreads as Russia Regroups for New Offensive
desc: The U.S. has announced $550 million in additional arms for Ukraine as it gears up to defend its eastern regions, which Ukrainian officials have asked civilians to flee before winter.
author: By Marc Santora, Peter Baker and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: Living Side by Side, Ukrainian and Russian Sailors Are Tested by War
desc: Sailors are accustomed to not discussing politics at sea, but the war between the two countries has made that more difficult.
author: By Jenny Gross and Emma Bubola

header: First Cargo Ship Passes Russia’s Black Sea Blockade Under Grain Deal
desc: For the first time since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, a ship loaded with corn sailed out of Odesa, part of a deal officials hope will help ease food shortages around the world.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Zelensky says Ukraine’s government may allow civil partnerships for same-sex couples.
desc: The Ukrainian president said the constitution’s ban on same-sex marriage could not be changed during the war. Calls for equal rights have grown as L.G.B.T.Q. soldiers have joined the fight against Russia.
author: By Michael Levenson

header: War Spurs Ukrainian Efforts to Legalize Same-Sex Marriage
desc: The role of gay soldiers, the lack of legal rights for their partners, and the threat of Russia imposing anti-L.G.B.T. policies have turned the war into a catalyst for change in Ukraine.
author: By Maham Javaid and Dan Bilefsky

header: Ukraine wages a ‘deep war’ to degrade Russian forces as Moscow continues its scorched-earth campaign.
desc: An attack on a train over the weekend was the latest in a series of strikes that have disrupted Russian logistical efforts and inflicted grave losses.
author: By Marc Santora

header: The U.S. imposes a new round of sanctions on Russians, including a woman close to Putin.
desc: Many of the targets are already under sanctions imposed by the European Union and Britain. One is Alina Kabaeva, a former Olympic gymnast believed to be the romantic partner of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
author: By Michael Crowley

header: Taiwan and Ukraine: Two crises, 5,000 miles apart, are linked in complex ways.
desc: The fear since the start of the war in Ukraine has been that Moscow and Beijing will be driven closer as the United States casts both issues as a struggle between authoritarianism and democracy.
author: By Marc Santora and Steven Erlanger

header: Three more ships carrying grain depart from Ukraine.
desc: The ships are carrying a total of about 64,000 tons of corn from Ukraine’s desperately needed stores.
author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Sophie Downes

header: Ukraine is building a case that a deadly prison camp explosion was a Russian war crime.
desc: Officials outlined evidence to suggest that Russian forces appeared to be preparing for mass casualties in the days before the July 29 explosion.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Christiaan Triebert, Kamila Hrabchuk and Stanislav Kozliuk

header: Ukraine Builds a Case That Killing of P.O.W.s Was a Russian War Crime
desc: At a Russian-held prison, graves were dug days before the explosion that killed at least 50 Ukrainian troops held there, Ukrainian officials said.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Christiaan Triebert, Kamila Hrabchuk and Stanislav Kozliuk

header: Mines, Fires, Rockets: The Ravages of War Bedevil Ukraine’s Farmers
desc: A deal allowing ships to start carrying grain from Ukraine solved a logistical problem, but it left a more pressing one for Ukrainian farmers: growing and reaping crops in a war zone.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and David Guttenfelder

header: Taiwan and Ukraine: Two crises, 5,000 miles apart, are linked in complex ways.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora and Steven Erlanger

header: Amnesty International says Ukraine’s tactics have endangered civilian lives, drawing a fierce rebuke.
desc: NA
author: By Ruth Maclean and Maria Varenikova

header: Russia is preparing its forces for an attack on the southern battlefront, Ukraine says.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russian Court Sentences Griner to 9 Years, Raising Pressure on Biden
desc: Amid the hostility over the war in Ukraine, a court imposed nearly the maximum possible sentence on the American basketball star Brittney Griner, intensifying calls to win her release.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: A ship that Ukraine claims is carrying stolen grain has been allowed to depart Lebanon.
desc: NA
author: By Hwaida Saad

header: Driven by its first lady, Ukraine raises $5.4 million for off-road ambulances.
desc: Olena Zelenska has recently become more visible in advocating for humanitarian causes.
author: By Carly Olson

header: Fighting Around Ukrainian Nuclear Plant Heightens Safety Fears
desc: A series of blasts Friday at the plant, which the Russian military is using as cover for artillery attacks, renewed concerns of a radiation catastrophe.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: A Time for War, a Time for Play
desc: Summer for Ukraine’s children means sunshine and swimming, but also long hours in bomb shelters and mine-safety training. A photographer captured their days in Kyiv for The New York Times.
author: By Laura Boushnak

header: Putin and Erdogan find more room to cooperate at a meeting in Sochi, Russia.
desc: The Turkish and Russian leaders sat face-to-face for the second time in less than three weeks, solidifying Turkey’s role as a bridge to the West and a mediator between Russia and Ukraine.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: U.S. and Russia Ready to Negotiate Griner’s Release
desc: The countries’ top envoys made separate announcements after a meeting where they sat close together — without talking.
author: By Edward Wong, Neil MacFarquhar and Natalie Kitroeff

header: Ukrainian Grandmaster Bids to Unseat Russian Head of World Chess Body
desc: Hoping to end Russia’s domination of the International Chess Federation, Andrii Baryshpolets is running for the presidency of the powerful governing organization.
author: By Jane Arraf and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Facing Energy Crisis, Germans, Warily, Give Nuclear a Second Look
desc: For three decades, nuclear power was one of Germany’s most divisive debates. But with Russia cutting gas, Germans are revisiting their political energy taboos.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: In Ukraine, young lives are shaped, or ended, by the ravages of war.
desc: Children have seen their families are torn apart, their schools blown up. But humanitarians say there is still time to prevent the legacies of trauma that can last for generations.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: Russia and Ukraine trade accusations of terrorism after blasts at a giant nuclear complex.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Cora Engelbrecht

header: A time for war, a time for play: Ukraine’s children bear the burdens of the conflict.
desc: NA
author: By Laura Boushnak

header: In My Homeland, the Smell of Death on a Summer Afternoon
desc: In Ukraine, tragedies are a backdrop to everyday existence, piling up in numbers that seem inconceivable, an inescapable reality that feels like the very air in your lungs.
author: By Natalia Yermak

header: Rumors spread quickly in wartime Ukraine.
desc: While seemingly harmless, these tales may have their origins in Russian propaganda, according to analysts monitoring Russian disinformation campaigns in Ukraine.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: Amnesty International Assessment That Ukraine ‘Put Civilians in Harm’s Way’ Stirs Outrage
desc: The human rights group accused the Ukrainian military of establishing bases and weapons systems in schools and hospitals.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Four more grain ships leave Ukrainian ports.
desc: The ships, the largest caravan to depart Ukraine since the Russian invasion began, were headed for China, Iran, Italy and Turkey.
author: By Emma Bubola

header: In a Summer of Feints, Russia and Ukraine Try to Predict Enemy’s Next Move
desc: Ukraine says that announcing a planned offensive on the southern front has paid off in the eastern Donbas region, as both sides deploy forces based on guessing each other’s next moves.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and David Guttenfelder

header: The U.S. Will Send Another $1 Billion in Aid to Ukraine.
desc: The latest round of aid includes rockets credited with destroying Russian command posts and ammunition depots.
author: By John Ismay

header: After Rockets Strike Near Nuclear Plant, Ukraine and Russia Trade Blame
desc: Moscow accused Ukraine of striking near spent-fuel storage at the Zaporizhzhia power plant, while Ukrainian intelligence said it was a move by Russia to destroy infrastructure.
author: By Vivian Yee

header: When home is a ferry ship: An influx from Ukraine strains Europe.
desc: NA
author: By Patricia Cohen

header: For Ukrainians Abroad, War Has Also Meant a Flowering of Identity
desc: Italy already had the biggest Ukrainian community in Western Europe before the war, but in recent months the diaspora has taken on new prominence and visibility.
author: By Emma Bubola

header: In War-Torn Mykolaiv, Ukrainians Search for Informers
desc: As the city emerged from a 54-hour lockdown, the governor of the Mykolaiv region declared the operation a success, saying that five people had been arrested.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Contradicting Kremlin’s Account, Crimean Officials Detail Explosions’ Extent
desc: Blasts at an air base in the Russian-occupied territory damaged 62 apartment buildings and forced hundreds into shelters. Satellite imagery showed destroyed fighter jets.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Alan Yuhas and Christiaan Triebert

header: From the Workshop to the War: Creative Use of Drones Lifts Ukraine
desc: While Russia lacks an effective long-range strike drone, Ukraine’s experimentation has produced an array of inexpensive, plastic aircraft, jury-rigged to drop grenades or other munitions.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and David Guttenfelder

header: Explosions Rip Through Russian Base on Crimea
desc: A senior Ukrainian official said his country’s forces were responsible, which Ukraine did not publicly confirm or deny. Russian officials said only that munitions had detonated.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Biden signs measures giving U.S. approval to Sweden and Finland’s bids to join NATO.
desc: The expansion of NATO has received overwhelming support among Democrats and Republicans in a deeply divided Washington.
author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs

header: Hungary Settles Russia’s Bill With Ukraine to Restore Oil Flows
desc: Hungary’s energy conglomerate, MOL, paid Russia’s transit fees to Ukraine, ensuring that oil keeps flowing through an overland pipeline that remains crucial for Central Europe.
author: By Melissa Eddy

header: Ukraine’s experimentation with drones gives it a technological advantage.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and David Guttenfelder

header: Russia wants to divert electricity from a nuclear plant to Crimea, says a Ukrainian official.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: In parts of Russia-occupied Ukraine, Moscow controls the internet. Here’s how.
desc: NA
author: By Adam Satariano

header: Canada and Sweden join a British-led effort to train Ukrainian forces.
desc: NA
author: By Cora Engelbrecht

header: For Ukrainians abroad, the war has also meant a flowering of identity.
desc: NA
author: By Emma Bubola

header: Shelling of Ukraine Nuclear Plant Raising Fears and Outrage
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky accused Russia of “nuclear blackmail” as the two sides traded blame.
author: By Marc Santora and Jason Horowitz

header: A U.N. ship will carry Ukrainian grain directly to countries worst affected by shortages.
desc: It is the first ship hired to carry the grain to countries badly affected by food shortages since a deal between Ukraine and Russia allowed shipments to resume.
author: By Carly Olson

header: Shelling Threatens Ukrainian Nuclear Plant, and U.N. Pleads for Access
desc: The chief U.N. nuclear monitor called for an immediate stop to fighting that risks a radiation disaster, as Russians and Ukrainians blamed each other for strikes dangerously close to the reactors.
author: By Alan Yuhas and Shashank Bengali

header: Rhythm of War: A Thunderous Blast, and Then a Coffee Break
desc: This is a war fought in a cycle of opposites: bursts of chaos from outgoing and incoming shelling, and then long lulls in which soldiers undertake the most routine activities.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Shelling at the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant Is Raising Fears of an Accident. Here’s a Look at the Risks.
desc: Repeated shelling inside the plant’s complex over the past seven days has stirred new concerns of a nuclear accident.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Russian attack in eastern Ukraine kills 2 civilians, regional military leader says.
desc: A video showed damaged homes and some areas that had been turned into ruins.
author: By Jesus Jiménez

header: Serbia’s Leader Rejects ‘Little Putin’ Label Amid Fears of Russian Meddling
desc: President Aleksandar Vucic’s ties to Moscow raise awkward questions as the Kremlin appears to be stirring unrest in the Balkans to deflect attention from the war in Ukraine.

author: By Marc Santora and Shashank Bengali

desc: NA

desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Russia replaces the commander of its damaged Black Sea Fleet.
desc: NA
author: By Dan Bilefsky, Ivan Nechepurenko, Steven Erlanger and Julian E. Barnes

desc: The daughter of a prominent ultranationalist, herself a hawkish commentator, was killed by a car bomb deep in Russian territory.

header: People are paying to have personal messages painted on Ukrainian artillery shells.
desc: The messages have become an inventive, if macabre, way to raise money for resistance to Russia’s invasion.

header: Thousands swarm to Kyiv’s display of captured Russian tanks, placed to mark Ukraine’s Independence Day.

header: A Russian spy agency blames Ukraine in the bombing death of Daria Dugina.
desc: Kyiv has denied involvement in the death of Ms. Dugina, the daughter of a nationalist ideologue who backed Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

header: Defiant Under Russian Strikes, Ukrainians Celebrate a Nation ‘Reborn’

header: Putin has called Ukrainian statehood a fiction. History suggests otherwise.
desc: NA
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Maria Varenikova and Rick Gladstone

author: By Marc Santora

header: Ukraine presses its offensive in the south.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Under Liz Truss, Britain is expected to double down on support for Ukraine.

header: With Boris Johnson’s departure, Ukraine loses a friend.
desc: If there is one place where appreciation for Mr. Johnson is undimmed, it is Ukraine, where he has been seen as a genuine friend since Russia’s invasion in February.

header: Hints of Ukrainian progress, and Russian confusion, emerge from a southern counteroffensive.

author: By Farnaz Fassihi

author: By Steven Erlanger
