header: Russia Holds First Elections Since Ukraine Invasion, but Opposition Is Mostly Absent
desc: Voters are choosing local and regional governments, but the ranks of opposition candidates have been severely depleted by jail and exile.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Anton Troianovski and Alina Lobzina

header: Conditions at Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant Are ‘Unsustainable,’ U.N. Watchdog Warns
desc: Cut off from the country’s electric grid, the plant is relying on an emergency measure that it is not designed to keep up for long, while shells continue to rain down.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Rebuilding Ukraine will cost at least $349 billion, a new report estimates.
desc: NA
author: By William Lamb

header: The body of a British aid worker captured by Russian proxies showed signs of torture, a Ukrainian official says.
desc: Paul Urey was charged with mercenary activities by a pro-Russian separatist group, which claimed he died in July from illness and stress.
author: By Cora Engelbrecht

header: As Crises Mount, Europe Turns Once Again to Big Spending
desc: The standoff with Russia over Ukraine and rising energy prices are rapidly overturning European economic orthodoxy, with barely a peep of dissent.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Ukrainian Offensive Seen as Reshaping the War’s Contours
desc: The fall of the strategically important city of Izium, in Ukraine’s east, is the most devastating blow to Russia since its humiliating retreat from Kyiv.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Marc Santora

header: Ukraine Routs Russian Forces in Northeast, Forcing a Retreat
desc: Russia acknowledged that it had lost nearly all of the northern region of Kharkiv after a blitzkrieg thrust by Ukrainian fighters.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Andrew Higgins

header: Russia’s Retreat in Ukraine Pokes Holes in Putin’s Projection of Force
desc: Russia’s military setbacks may be weakening President Vladimir V. Putin’s reputation at home as a savvy geopolitical strategist.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: As Russians Retreat, Putin Is Criticized by Hawks Who Trumpeted His War
desc: Russian bloggers reporting from the front line provide a uniquely less-censored view of the war. But as Russia’s military flails, these once vocal supporters are exposing its flaws, lies and all.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Ukraine says Russia is retaliating by hitting critical infrastructure, causing blackouts.
desc: Kyiv condemned the strikes as an act of revenge as Russian forces retreat in the northeast.
author: By Carly Olson

header: As Ukraine advances, a reticent Germany faces more pressure to help.
desc: Many weapons Germany promised Kyiv have yet to arrive. Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s government has not fully explained the delays.
author: By Katrin Bennhold

header: Ukraine begins to shut down the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant as a safety measure.
desc: External power has been restored to the plant, allowing engineers to move its reactors into a safer state, Ukraine’s nuclear regulator said.
author: By Marc Santora and David E. Sanger

header: Russia says that a senior Chinese official expressed support for the invasion of Ukraine.
desc: The comments are the clearest sign of support from China, which has preferred to stay on the sidelines and maintain ties with both Russia and Europe, without alienating either.
author: By Austin Ramzy

header: How Ukraine Gained Momentum Against Russia and Took a Critical Hub
desc: For months, Russia used the city of Izium as a way station to resupply and reinforce its troops in their campaign to seize the eastern Donbas region. With a northern offensive, Ukraine has retaken the city.
author: By Marc Santora

header: The southern counteroffensive has been a battle of river crossings. So far, Ukraine has advanced.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine’s Sudden Gains Prompt New Questions for Commanders
desc: Ukraine’s military is gauging how far its forces can press the attack, at risk of their ability to hold the new lines. Russian leaders are trying to regroup after a dramatic, demoralizing rout.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: In Reclaimed Towns, Ukrainians Recount a Frantic Russian Retreat
desc: Residents of towns recently retaken by Ukraine described a chaotic flight by disorganized Russian troops, suggesting morale and inexperience remain major problems for Russia.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Jeffrey Gettleman

header: As Russian Losses Mount in Ukraine, So Does Criticism Back Home
desc: Ukraine’s recent battlefield successes are emboldening Vladimir Putin’s critics and sending his supporters in search of someone else to blame.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Ukraine’s Sudden Success Could Bolster Europe’s Support — and Morale
desc: “It’s not for nothing.” Ukraine’s backers say that an offensive over the weekend shows Western military aid is helping, and that it’s time to supply more sophisticated weaponry.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: The U.N. watchdog says there are active discussions to end fighting around the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant.
desc: The nuclear complex in southern Ukraine has been imperiled by frequent shelling, raising fears of a nuclear catastrophe.
author: By Marc Santora and David E. Sanger

header: A new draft in Russia ‘is not being discussed,’ the Kremlin says.
desc: Russian commentators have been calling on President Vladimir V. Putin to bolster the army with recruits and to target Ukrainian infrastructure.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: How Russia’s war in Ukraine has unfolded, month by month.
desc: A timeline of Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine, which began one year ago.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Losses in Ukraine Prompt Something New on Russian TV: Debate
desc: The divergence of views, even on tightly-controlled state television networks, highlighted how Moscow’s narrative had quickly shifted.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Ukraine’s backers say the offensive shows Western aid is ‘not for nothing.’
desc: The Ukrainian military’s recent successes will most likely increase the pressure on countries like Germany to give more sophisticated weapons.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: Russia’s retreat in Ukraine pokes holes in Putin’s projection of force.
desc: Russia’s military setbacks may be weakening President Vladimir V. Putin’s reputation at home as a savvy geopolitical strategist.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Zelensky Visits a City Just Miles From the Front, Underscoring Ukraine’s Gains
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky’s trip to a city reclaimed days ago demonstrated Ukraine’s growing boldness in the wake of Russia’s frantic retreat from the country’s northeast.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora

header: War May Be Distant in Moscow, but in One Russian Border City, It’s Real
desc: In Belgorod, 25 miles from Ukraine, recent losses by Russia’s military have brought home the reality of the war in a way not present elsewhere in the country.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Putin Nods to Xi’s ‘Concerns,’ and the Limits of Their Cooperation
desc: The discordant messages of China’s president, Xi Jinping, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia suggested that despite an earlier pledge of “friendship,” Moscow does not have an unconditional ally in Beijing.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Keith Bradsher

header: Fearing flooding, Ukrainian officials call for evacuations after Russia damaged a dam.
desc: Pedestrian bridges were washed away and water rose along river banks in the city of Kryvyi Rih in southern Ukraine, where Kyiv’s forces are carrying out a counteroffensive.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: Pope Francis Says Arming Ukraine Can Be ‘Morally Acceptable.’
desc: The pontiff said that it is acceptable for countries to provide weapons to Ukraine so that the country can defend itself, but stressed that communication channels with Russia should remain open.
author: By Elisabetta Povoledo

header: The U.S. will send $600 million in additional military supplies to Ukraine.
desc: The new shipment continues the Pentagon’s recent trend of sending ammunition that Ukraine needs to carry out heavy fighting in the country’s south, east and northeast.
author: By Eric Schmitt

header: Germany offers a special fund for Ukrainian Holocaust survivors.
desc: The $12 million emergency fund, part of a larger $1.2 billion reparations package, will be disbursed to 8,500 Jewish survivors in Ukraine.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: Retreat in Ukraine’s Northeast Leaves Other Russian Territory Vulnerable
desc: Ukraine’s success in the northeast raised the possibility that it would seek to reclaim territory in the eastern Donbas region, where Russia has supported separatist uprisings since 2014.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: An Eastern City Under Attack Wonders How Far Ukraine’s Offensive Can Go
desc: Bakhmut residents who have endured relentless shelling by the Russians watch the Ukrainian forces’ recent victories and weigh whether to stay or to flee.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

header: Germany Offers One of the Largest Holocaust Reparations Packages, and a Special Fund for Ukrainians
desc: The country will pay $1.2 billion, including emergency aid for Holocaust survivors in Ukraine and, for the first time, remembrance education.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: The ‘Wild Field’ Where Putin Sowed the Seeds of War
desc: In one small town in the Donbas region, everything suddenly fell apart. It was part of Vladimir Putin’s grand plan, and it helped lay the groundwork for the invasion of Ukraine. Now things are heating up again.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: At Mass Grave Site in Ukraine’s Northeast, a Sign of Occupation’s Toll
desc: Russian troops held the city of Izium, in northeastern Ukraine, for six months. One burial site found this week could hold the remains of more than 400 people, investigators said.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora and Nicole Tung

header: As India Joins China in Distancing From Russia, Putin Warns of Escalation
desc: After India’s prime minister said that now is not the time for war, an increasingly isolated Mr. Putin threatened “more serious” actions in Ukraine while insisting he was ready for talks.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Mujib Mashal and Julian E. Barnes

header: Amid Russia’s growing international isolation, India’s leader tells Putin that today is no time for war.
desc: Mr. Modi was speaking on the s
author: By Dan Bilefsky and Mujib Mashal

header: Biden Warns Russia, Facing Losses, Against Using Unconventional Weapons
desc: Some officials worry that the more cornered Vladimir Putin feels, particularly with recent setbacks from Ukraine’s counteroffensive, the greater the chance that he might turn to an unconventional weapon.
author: By Marc Santora and Norimitsu Onishi

header: Russia continues attacking in Ukraine’s east despite recent setbacks.
desc: NA
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak

header: Fire and Fear in South Ukraine
desc: The perilous life of a city under Russian attack, and the firefighters who save it
author: By Daniel Berehulak and Michael Schwirtz

header: Russia and Ukraine trade blows in the south.
desc: NA
author: By Oleksandr Chubko

header: Video Reveals How Russian Mercenaries Recruit Inmates for Ukraine War
desc: In a video posted on social media on Tuesday, the de facto leader of a Russian mercenary group explained to Russian convicts how they could earn their freedom by fighting in Ukraine.
author: By Christiaan Triebert

header: Ukraine is consolidating its gains, but Russia is shoring up its defensive lines, a Pentagon spokesman said.
desc: NA
author: By John Ismay

header: Strike Near Another Ukrainian Nuclear Plant Escalates Fears of Disaster
desc: A powerful Russian missile hit 300 yards from the plant far from the front lines, Ukraine said, a reminder that despite its recent retreat, Russia can still threaten nuclear sites.
author: By Marc Santora

header: The Singular Offense of the Mass Grave
desc: Violent loss is even more devastating when the dead are disposed of without identification. When Russians pull out in Ukraine, they leave a trail of anonymous death.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: One Big Problem for Ukraine Is Clear: Glass
desc: Russian bombs. Soaring energy costs. Severed trade links. It’s getting hard to fix all the shattered windows in Ukraine, and winter is coming.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: Russia Deploys Iranian Attack Drones, Ukrainian Military Says
desc: A Ukrainian colonel said attacks that took out howitzers and armored vehicles were carried out by Iranian-made drones that had not previously been used outside of the Middle East.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Forces Face Mobilized Inmates and Drones
desc: Ukraine has been pushing a counteroffensive in the east and south, applying greater pressure to Russian forces, but there is no indication of any mass Russian withdrawal.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russian Pop Music Icon Comes Out Against the War in Ukraine
desc: Alla Pugacheva, whose stardom has spanned from the Soviet era to after the Cold War, said the invasion of Ukraine had turned Russia into a “pariah.”
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: In One Corner of Kosovo, Cheers Still Ring Out for Putin
desc: Many ethnic Serbs, nursing grievances against NATO for a 1999 bombing campaign that broke Serbia’s grip on the territory, see President Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia as a potential savior.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Ukrainian officials try to build pressure to hold Russia accountable for war crimes.
desc: NA
author: By Ron DePasquale and Juston Jones

header: The strike increases concerns about nuclear safety in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Ukraine’s first lady attends Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral.
desc: NA
author: By Cora Engelbrecht

header: Russia Signals Annexation of Parts of Ukraine, Raising Stakes in Fighting
desc: Kremlin-backed officials in four partially occupied regions announced referendums on joining Russia, as Moscow tightens its grip and hints at escalation.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Putin Raises Stakes in the War, With Direct Challenge to the West
desc: The Russian leader announced a call-up of troops and hinted at using nuclear weapons, accusing the West of trying to “destroy our country” and vowing that Russia would defend itself.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Valerie Hopkins

header: Russia’s Invasion Shadows U.N. Assembly Amid ‘Colossal Global Dysfunction’
desc: Presidents Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey and Emmanuel Macron of France used the gathering as a stage to cast themselves as would-be peacemakers in the war in Ukraine.
author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Alan Yuhas

header: Biden Condemns Russia as Threat to the World in U.N. Speech
desc: President Biden portrayed Russia as the chief threat to global peace and renewed warnings that “a nuclear war cannot be won.”
author: By Jim Tankersley, David E. Sanger and Farnaz Fassihi

header: Erdogan says Russia should return all captured Ukrainian territory.
desc: Erdogan has positioned himself as a mediator between Ukraine and Russia and hosted preliminary peace talks in Istanbul in March.
author: By Cora Engelbrecht and Carlotta Gall

header: As fighting intensifies in Ukraine’s east, a frontline town is cut off from the world.
desc: After the Ukrainian military’s sweeping victory in the northeast last week, the fate of Siversk, in the Donbas region, appears once more undecided.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Dimitry Yatsenko

header: A volunteer group working on behalf of Ukraine says it hacked Wagner Group.
desc: NA
author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor

header: 10 imprisoned foreign fighters, including Americans, are released as part of a Russia-Ukraine exchange, Saudi Arabia says.
desc: Alex Drueke, a former U.S. Army staff sergeant who served two tours in Iraq, and Andy Tai Ngoc Huynh, a former U.S. Marine, were released.
author: By Carly Olson and Dan Bilefsky

header: Can Ukraine Break Through Again?
desc: A surprise advance this month exposed deep vulnerabilities in Russia’s overstretched military. As Russia calls for more troops, can Ukraine keep gaining ground?
author: By Marco Hernandez and Denise Lu

header: Russia releases 215 fighters, including Mariupol commanders, in a prisoner exchange.
desc: The exchange, the war’s largest, included Viktor Medvedchuk, a Ukrainian oligarch and close friend of the Russian president.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Ukraine War Comes Home to Russians as Putin Imposes Draft
desc: As Vladimir Putin’s “special military operation” enters a new chapter, Russians are being plucked from villages around the country for training and military service.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Valerie Hopkins, Ivan Nechepurenko and Alina Lobzina

header: As freed Ukrainian soldiers return, joy and relief ripple across the country.
desc: After the largest prisoner exchange of the war, Ukrainians celebrated while anger coursed through the ranks of Russian mercenaries and military bloggers.
author: By Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora

header: Staged voting is happening amid international condemnation.
desc: Huge numbers of people have fled the areas that Russia controls, the process has been rushed and referendums are taking place against a backdrop of oppression.
author: By Marc Santora

header: In Seized Parts of Ukraine, Moscow Stages Balloting on Joining Russia
desc: Under coercive conditions, with most residents gone and war still raging, Russia is putting on what it calls referendums on annexation but Ukraine and its allies call an illegal farce.
author: By Marc Santora

header: On a Corpse’s Wrist, an Emblem of Ukrainian Fortitude
desc: When they pulled Serhiy Sova’s body from a grave in Izium, his wrist bore a bracelet in Ukraine’s colors, given to him by his children. The image has transfixed the nation.
author: By Marc Santora and Anna Lukinova

header: Putin’s Draft Draws Resistance in Russia’s Far-Flung Regions
desc: Villagers, activists and some elected officials asked why the conscription drive seemed to be hitting poor, remote areas hardest, while pro-war hawks criticized it as chaotic.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: ‘One man chose this war.’ Harsh words fly at a U.N. Security Council meeting.
desc: Insults, accusations and talk of war crimes and nuclear holocaust dominated the world’s premier diplomatic stage on Thursday.
author: By Farnaz Fassihi

header: Putin confidant Viktor Medvedchuk is the most prominent captive released in a prisoner swap.
desc: The Ukrainian politician and oligarch had acted as the Kremlin’s primary agent of influence in Ukraine for years.
author: By Victoria Kim

header: Some men flee Russia, fearing they could be called up to fight.
desc: Since the announcement of a new troop mobilization, civilians have realized they could not count on staying out of their country’s invasion of Ukraine.
author: By Ben Hubbard and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Berlusconi draws a backlash for appearing to defend Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
desc: Italy’s former prime minister said that the Russian president was “pushed” to invade Ukraine, remarks that drew fierce criticism days before an election.
author: By Gaia Pianigiani

header: Russia Begins Mobilizing Ukrainians to Fight Against Their Own Country
desc: Panic and fear flooded the occupied territories as Russian forces rounded up men to fight and forced residents to vote in a staged referendum on joining Russia, Ukrainian officials and rights groups said.
author: By Marc Santora

header: In Ukraine’s South, Fierce Fighting and Deadly Costs
desc: The offensive in the south was the most highly anticipated military action of the summer. Ukraine is making gains, but the fighting is grinding, grueling and steep in casualties.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: Ukraine warns of growing attacks by drones Iran has supplied to Russia.
desc: As Moscow finds itself isolated internationally, and as its arsenal has been depleted in Ukraine, it has turned for military support to countries including Iran.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Roger Waters Concert in Poland Called Off After Ukraine Views Prompt Anger
desc: In online exchanges with Ukraines first lady, the Pink Floyd co-founder said Ukraine should seek peace with Russia and blamed the United States for encouraging the conflict.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukraine Fights to Reclaim Territory as Russia Holds Annexation Referendums
desc: Ukraine’s president has urged citizens to resist the Russians in occupied territories, where voting is underway in what Western officials have called “sham” referendums on joining Russia.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Valerie Hopkins and Ben Hubbard

header: Germany’s Chancellor Has ‘a Lot’ for Ukraine. But No Battle Tanks.
desc: Military assistance to Kyiv has become something of a litmus test of Olaf Scholz’s ability to lead Europe through its most significant security crisis since World War II.
author: By Katrin Bennhold

header: Defying travel warnings, Hasidic Jewish pilgrims flock to Ukraine.
desc: Tens of thousands of Hasidic Jews traditionally travel to Uman to mark Rosh Hashana with a visit to the burial site of a revered 18th-century rabbi.
author: By Isabel Kershner

header: At least 745 people are detained in protests across Russia.
desc: Demonstrations against President Vladimir V. Putin’s “partial mobilization” policy continued, despite the Kremlin’s crackdown on dissent.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Ukraine makes gains in the south, but the costs are steep.
desc: The offensive in the south was the most highly anticipated military action of the summer. Ukraine is making gains, but the fighting is grinding, grueling and steep in casualties.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: Ukraine strips Iran’s ambassador of accreditation over drone sales to Russia.
desc: NA
author: By Matt Surman and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Two Cities, Two Armies: Pivot Points in the Fight in Ukraine’s East
desc: The battle for the critical Donbas region in Ukraine is centered on two strategically important cities: Lyman, held by the Russians, and Bakhmut, held by Ukraine. The fighting over the cities is fierce as both armies race to claim new ground.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

header: As Russians Flee, Some Find Draft Notices Waiting at the Border
desc: The Kremlin dispatched federal security forces to frontier border crossings packed with Russian men trying to escape the draft by entering countries like Georgia, Kazakhstan and Mongolia.
author: By Marc Santora, Andrew E. Kramer and Eric Nagourney

header: Ukrainian Soldier Whose Bracelet Made Him a Symbol Gets Posthumous Honors
desc: Serhiy Sova, 36, was honored as a Hero of Ukraine by President Volodymyr Zelensky. His body was found in a mass grave in Izium.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Foreign minister denies Iran has sent arms to Russia to use against Ukraine.
desc: The minister, Hossein Amir Abdollahian, said Iran was committed to not giving arms to either side in the war but also was honoring an separate agreement with Russia that had “nothing to do with the war.”
author: By Alan Yuhas

header: For a Deaf Family in Ukraine, the Bombs Came Without Warning
desc: People with disabilities in the country are often isolated and poor, and for those like Antonina Andriyenko and her daughter, Tanya, the fear and confusion of trying to stay safe is a constant struggle.
author: By Jane Arraf

header: Victorious Meloni Faces Early Test of Italy’s Resolve on Russia
desc: The hard-right leader Giorgia Meloni has been a full-throated supporter of Ukraine, but her coalition partners have sounded like apologists for Vladimir V. Putin.
author: By Jason Horowitz

header: Leaks in undersea gas pipelines from Russia to Germany after blasts raise suspicions of sabotage.
desc: The authorities in Germany, Denmark and Sweden are investigating the cause of leaks in two gas pipelines under the Baltic Sea that caused an abrupt drop in pressure on Monday.
author: By Melissa Eddy and Victoria Kim

header: A recruitment officer was wounded in the latest attack on a Russian draft office.
desc: A gunman opened fire at a draft office in a Siberian town, in what is believed to be the first attack on a military recruitment center since February to result in serious injury.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Shashank Bengali

header: Russia Admits to Draft Problems as Anger Flares Into Violence
desc: The Kremlin’s spokesman tried to shift blame for errors in the call-up to regional agencies on Monday, the same day a gunman attacked a draft office in Siberia.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Shashank Bengali and Alan Yuhas

header: Putin is expected to annex parts of Ukraine after referendums end on Tuesday.
desc: The staged votes earned broad international condemnation, and world leaders vowed not to recognize the announced results.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russian Proxies in Ukraine Push Moscow to Annex Occupied Regions
desc: The requests lent an air of formality to a process condemned by the West. They followed sham referendums in four regions in Ukraine that purported to put voters’ stamp of approval on joining Russia.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora and Eric Nagourney

header: Sabotaged Pipelines and a Mystery: Who Did It? (Was It Russia?)
desc: An attack on gas lines under the Baltic Sea exposes the vulnerability of an already jittery Europe. Some officials suggested Moscow was to blame, but with little evidence, others urge caution.
author: By Katrin Bennhold and David E. Sanger

header: Russia-backed officials ask Putin to annex Ukrainian regions after referendums widely dismissed as sham.
desc: The appeals from Moscow-backed leaders set in motion formalities intended to give Russia’s plans a sheen of legitimacy.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russia Beat and Denied Food to Prisoners of War, Ukraine Says
desc: Evidence of Russian abuses of captives has fueled outrage and added to a litany of reports of Russian war crimes.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Zelensky’s Answer to Escalating Russian Threats: Defiance
desc: In a nightly address, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine told Russian soldiers: “If you want to live, run.”
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: With Annexation Plans, Putin Escalates Battle of Wills With the West
desc: There was no sign that any other country would recognize Russia’s move, but Mr. Putin may try to use the plans to shift attention away from his losses on the battlefield.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Russia plans to illegally annex lands it invaded, even as its military falters.
desc: Even though Russia has failed to fully control the four territories it seeks to annex, the Kremlin is preparing a show designed to present a sheen of legitimacy to its illegal takeover.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Putin concedes that some men were wrongly drafted.
desc: The Russian president’s remarks came after anger with the draft spilled over into street protests across Russia.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: What to Know About Russia’s Annexation of Four Ukrainian Provinces
desc: The Kremlin is using pageantry and a show of adhering to Russian legal formalities to give the move a veneer of legitimacy.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: The E.U. proposes a fresh round of sanctions against the Kremlin over ‘sham’ referendums.
desc: NA
author: By Monika Pronczuk

header: With Bluster and Threats, Putin Casts the West as the Enemy
desc: Declaring that Russia would annex four regions of Ukraine, which the West rejects as illegal, the Russian president accused the U.S. and its allies of “despotism’’ and “Satanism.’’
author: By Anton Troianovski and Valerie Hopkins

header: In Washington, Putin’s Nuclear Threats Stir Growing Alarm
desc: In a gathering Cold War atmosphere, American officials are gaming out responses should Russia resort to battlefield nuclear weapons.
author: By David E. Sanger, Anton Troianovski and Julian E. Barnes

header: Moscow Pounds Regions in Eastern Ukraine, Then Declares Them Part of Russia
desc: The strikes killed a total of 30 civilians and wounded 107 in one of the bloodiest attacks in recent weeks.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine Forces Retake Lyman, a Strategic City, as Russians Retreat
desc: Russia’s withdrawal from the city comes one day after Moscow illegally annexed the surrounding region.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Andrew E. Kramer, Anton Troianovski and Catherine Porter

header: Biden Declares West Will Not Be Intimidated by Putin’s Actions
desc: The president also said that Mr. Putin should not dare to take his fight into NATO territory, underscoring the unity among the alliance.
author: By Alan Rappeport

header: Ukraine submits an application to join NATO, with big hurdles ahead.
desc: Ukraine’s desire to join the alliance has long been a source of conflict with Russia, which sees the eastward expansion of NATO as a existential threat.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Dan Bilefsky

header: Ukraine says 30 people are dead in an attack on a civilian convoy in Zaporizhzhia.
desc: Russia launched a flurry of strikes, creating scenes of destruction inside Ukraine as the Kremlin planned an elaborate, and widely dismissed, annexation ceremony.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russia’s withdrawal from Lyman comes a day after Putin said he was annexing the region.
desc: It also appeared to illustrate that for all of Mr. Putin’s nuclear saber-rattling, Ukraine remained unbowed and defiant, and the fronts in the war had not altered.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Europe and allies condemn Russia’s illegal annexation of Ukrainian territory.
desc: NA
author: By Dan Bilefsky

header: Intercepted calls reveal the Russian army in disarray.
desc: NA
author: By Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak and Evan Hill

header: I Lived in Russia? Annexation Is News to Key City Reclaimed by Ukraine.
desc: Without access to electricity, radios or the internet, residents of Lyman said they were unaware of President Vladimir V. Putin’s grandiose celebration of an illegal land grab.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Nicole Tung

header: In Retreat on Ukrainian Fronts, Russia Shows Signs of Disarray
desc: Confusion and recriminations marked the Russian efforts to call up draftees and claim sovereignty over Ukrainian territory, as well as the Russian response to battlefield setbacks.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Carlotta Gall and Anton Troianovski

header: The Ukrainian first lady says the war is like something out of the ‘Middle Ages.’
desc: Olena Zelenska told CBS News that Russian attacks on schools, hospitals and residential areas have been a form of terrorism.
author: By Juston Jones

header: A Frontline Mystery: Was He Scouting for Firewood, or for Russia?
desc: Outside the city of Lyman, Ukrainian troops ran across a 69-year-old Soviet veteran. He was placed in an improvised blindfold. All were enveloped in the fog of war.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Nicole Tung

header: Ukrainian Troops Hunt Demoralized Russian Stragglers in Seized City
desc: A major Russian newspaper said the Russian troops, facing defeat in Lyman, had fled with “empty eyes” after barely escaping with their lives.
author: NA

header: The Pentagon plans to set up a new command to arm Ukraine, officials say.
desc: The mission in Germany would streamline a training and assistance system that the United States and its allies created on the fly after Russia’s invasion, officials said.
author: By Eric Schmitt

header: Elon Musk weighs in on how to end the war in Ukraine.
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky swiftly dismissed the entrepreneur’s suggestion on Twitter, and the Kremlin’s spokesman called it a “very positive” development with caveats.
author: By Carly Olson

header: The head of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant has been released from detention, the U.N. nuclear agency says.
desc: The detention by Russia of Ihor Murashov had stoked concerns about the security of Europe’s largest nuclear plant.
author: By Dan Bilefsky

header: Nine NATO nations express support for Ukraine’s membership bid.
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson

header: Putin’s claims to Donetsk are news to the residents of newly liberated Lyman.
desc: Russia’s president decreed on Friday that four regions of Ukraine including Donetsk, where Lyman is located, would be absorbed into Russia.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine Expels Some Russian Troops in South, Expanding Campaign
desc: Moscow’s retreat has pulled back the curtain on a panorama of ruined towns and empty villages left in its wake.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Putin signs annexation laws, plowing ahead with a parallel reality as Russia loses ground in Ukraine.
desc: Russian state television trumpeted the news, while playing down or ignoring the fact that Moscow’s forces are in retreat in multiple parts of the front line.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: In Retreat at the Front, Russia Strikes Deep Into Ukraine
desc: In an attack in central Ukraine, Russian forces used what Ukrainians said were Iranian-made drones acquired by Moscow as its own arsenal dwindles.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Anton Troianovski and Eric Nagourney

header: Ukraine’s top diplomat tries to counter Russia’s narrative on Africa tour.
desc: “I arrived here and I hear, ‘Russia and Ukraine are one people,’” Ukraine’s foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, said in Senegal on the first stop of his 10-day trip across Africa.
author: By Elian Peltier and Mady Camara

header: A new package of U.S. military aid will speed more mobile rocket launchers to Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By John Ismay

header: She’s a Doctor. He Was a Limo Driver. They Pitched a $30 Million Arms Deal.
desc: New brokers are cashing in as the Biden administration quietly encourages private weapons sales to Ukraine. Oversight is scant in these shadows.
author: By Justin Scheck

header: North Korea supports Russia’s illegal claim to Ukrainian land.
desc: Russia has found a lone ally in North Korea, which on Tuesday said it was backing Moscow’s annexation of four Ukrainian provinces after widely discredited referendums.
author: By John Yoon

header: The E.U.’s plan faces a new hurdle, as oil producers led by Saudi Arabia aim to keep global prices high.
desc: The cap, championed by the United States, would deprive the Kremlin of tens of billions of dollars annually. Experts warn that implementation will be difficult.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Russians Fleeing the Draft Find an Unlikely Haven
desc: Tens of thousands of men have ended up in places like Kyrgyzstan, a former Soviet territory, that normally see few refugees but are willing to take them.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Three months after a defeat, Ukraine is poised at the doorstep of Donbas.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Blunt Criticism of Russian Army Signals New Challenge for Putin
desc: An official in a Russian-occupied region of Ukraine suggested Russia’s defense minister should shoot himself because of his army’s failings, an unusually blunt and public rebuke of Kremlin leadership.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Neil MacFarquhar

header: Nobel Peace Prize Winners Share a Past Shadowed by Russian Abuses
desc: Democracy advocates from Belarus, Russia and Ukraine were jointly awarded the world’s most prestigious peace prize, an implicit condemnation of the Kremlin’s war in Ukraine and repression at home.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Megan Specia and Andrew Higgins

header: Ukrainian police have found the bodies of 534 civilians and evidence of torture in recaptured territory.
desc: The police have discovered 22 locations that they suspect were used as torture chambers in areas recently reclaimed from Russian control, a Ukrainian official said.
author: By Oleksandr Chubko and Carlotta Gall

header: In Ukraine, the sharing of the prize prompts some backlash.
desc: Some saw the decision to group a Ukrainian organization with human rights defenders from Russia and Belarus — two of the country’s aggressors — as an affront.
author: By Megan Specia and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Russia Lashes Out in Ukraine, Raising Question of What’s Next
desc: Facing battlefield setbacks and domestic criticism, the Kremlin has escalated its war, claiming ownership of a nuclear plant and launching more attacks on Ukrainian cities.
author: By Richard Pérez-Pena, Carly Olson and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Putin’s 70th birthday is hailed in Russia and derided in Ukraine.
desc: Russian newspapers lauded Mr. Putin’s leadership, comparing him to Peter the Great and Leonid Brezhnev. Some Ukrainians said they hoped the birthday would be his last.
author: By Valeriya Safronova and Megan Specia

header: ‘They Are in a Panic’: Ukraine’s Troops Size Up the Enemy
desc: Ukrainian soldiers are exulting in their smashing of Russian lines in the northeast. They engaged enemy troops up close, and gained confidence from it.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett

header: Its Army in Retreat, Russia Strikes Multiple Ukrainian Cities
desc: On Vladimir V. Putin’s 70th birthday, his faltering military continued to show that it could use its advantage in long-range munitions to rain death and destruction far from the battlefield.
author: By Megan Specia and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: With Ukraine War, Europe’s Democratic Project Takes on New Urgency
desc: Panelists at the Athens Democracy Forum said Putin’s invasion has provided a striking example of the importance and power of the democratic idea.
author: By Celestine Bohlen

header: Two Russians who braved miles of open sea arrive on an Alaskan island and request asylum.
desc: The men, apparently part of an exodus of more than 200,000 since Putin announced a new draft, traveled on a vessel from Russia and reached St. Lawrence Island in the Bering Sea.
author: By Dan Bilefsky and Carly Olson

header: Ukrainians Fear Russian Reprisals for Crimea Bridge Attack
desc: Bitter over a strike against a vital bridge, Moscow hit civilian areas of Ukraine with a barrage of rockets, and some Ukrainians feared worse to come.
author: By Megan Specia, Michael Schwirtz and Neil MacFarquhar

header: Blast on Crimean Bridge Deals Blow to Russian War Effort in Ukraine
desc: Any impediment to traffic on the bridge could affect Russia’s ability to wage war in southern Ukraine, where Ukraine’s forces have been fighting an increasingly effective counteroffensive.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Andrew E. Kramer

header: An American in Ukraine Finds the War He’s Been Searching For
desc: For an unconventional former Marine colonel, Ukraine represents the morally just war that eluded him his entire career. But how much can he and his military start-up help?
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: ‘Happy birthday, Mr. President’: Ukrainians celebrate the bridge blast with memes.
desc: The bridge has both practical and symbolic resonance.
author: By Megan Specia

header: As Ukraine Forces Press Offensive, Front Line Is Shifting Fast
desc: Evidence of killings and torture is discovered in a forest camp outside the village of Borova as Ukrainian soldiers recapture territory.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett

header: Putin blames Ukraine for the Crimea bridge blast.
desc: The Russian president’s remarks were his first about Saturday’s explosion on the Kerch Strait Bridge.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: Russian shelling has again forced the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant offline, Ukrainian officials say.
desc: NA
author: By Megan Specia

header: Ukraine wants a long-range American missile. The U.S. is holding it back.
desc: NA
author: By John Ismay

header: Russia names a new commander for the war in Ukraine.
desc: General Surovikin, 55, had been leading troops in Ukraine’s south, where Kyiv’s forces have been waging a counteroffensive to reclaim territory from Russia.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Cassandra Vinograd

header: Russian soldiers, fleeing southern Ukraine, leave haunting mementos.
desc: In a Ukrainian village in the southern Kherson region, residents reflect on the occupation, and the aftermath.
author: By Nicole Tung and Evelina Riabenko

header: Pressure Grows on the West to Speed Air-Defense Systems to Ukraine
desc: After Russia bombarded civilian targets, G7 leaders pledged “undeterred and steadfast” financial and military support for Kyiv.
author: By Steven Erlanger, Eric Schmitt, Michael Schwirtz and Eric Nagourney

header: With Attacks on Ukraine, Putin Gives Hard-Liners What They Wanted
desc: A sharp shift toward deadly strikes signaled that domestic pressure over Russia’s flailing war effort had escalated to the point where Vladimir Putin felt a decisive show of force was necessary.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Anton Troianovski

header: Putin Unleashes Barrage of Missiles on Ukrainian Civilian Areas
desc: The Russian president tied the attack to a bombing of the bridge to Crimea, and vowed that more strikes would follow if Russian targets were hit again.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Andrew E. Kramer, Megan Specia and Eric Nagourney

header: The Hunt to Arm Ukraine Leads to Difficult Choices
desc: The U.S. and NATO are scouring the world for new sources of old weapons to send to Ukraine. But it risks as much peril for some nations as it does promise for Kyiv.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: Here is the latest on Russia’s attacks across Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Megan Specia and Austin Ramzy

header: In Southern Ukraine, Signs of Low Russian Morale Amid Retreat
desc: The Ukrainians are making gains in the south, an area where Russian soldiers are dug in more securely and where their retreat has been less chaotic than in the north.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: The attacks come two days after an explosion damaged Russia’s bridge to Crimea.
desc: Ukrainians had been bracing for a severe Russian response after the main bridge linking Russia to Crimea was damaged over the weekend.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Here’s what Russia’s attacks may indicate about its weapons stockpile.
desc: Russia’s assault on Ukraine on Monday raised questions about the capacity of Moscow’s forces to carry out President Vladimir V. Putin’s military calculations.
author: By Mike Ives

header: Multiple Russian Strikes Wreak Havoc in Ukraine
desc: President Vladimir Putin ordered a series of missile strikes against cities across Ukraine, killing at least 14 people. It was the broadest aerial assault against civilians and critical infrastructure since the early days of Moscow’s invasion.
author: By Nikolay Nikolov

header: In Kyiv, the strikes shattered what had become a relative sense of calm.
desc: Russia’s attacks on Ukraine’s capital on Monday came after months in which the fighting had shifted to other parts of the country.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Western Nations Rush Defensive Systems to Ukraine to Counter Russian Missiles
desc: Even with Soviet-era defensive weapons, the Ukrainians have been more than holding their own, but this week’s barrage prompted calls to better equip them.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt

header: Civilians fleeing Kherson are advised to travel to Russia or Crimea.
desc: The announcement seemed timed to deflect attention from Russian forces who, since Monday, have killed more than three dozen Ukrainians in a barrage of missile strikes on towns and cities.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukraine Offensive Will Push Through Winter, U.S. Defense Chief Says
desc: The “deliberate cruelty” of Russia’s latest bombardment has made the West more determined to help Ukraine, Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said.
author: By John Ismay

header: Death Toll Rises as Russia Bombards Ukraine’s Cities for a Fourth Day
desc: Prompted by the expanded strikes, European countries made plans to develop joint air defenses and to train Ukrainian soldiers on European Union soil.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Eric Nagourney

header: Russian shellfire cuts power to Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant for a second time in five days.
desc: The electricity supply was affected after Russian forces shelled a substation that provides power to the nuclear plant, Ukraine’s state energy company said.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: A strike outside Kyiv adds to concerns over Russia’s use of ‘kamikaze’ drones.
desc: The weapons are causing havoc in a region that had been largely spared since the early months of the war.
author: By Megan Specia and Victoria Kim

header: Mourners Gather in Bucha for Soldier’s Funeral
desc: About 150 people attended the funeral for a Ukrainian soldier who died from injuries sustained in combat earlier this month. Among the mourners was his mother, who wept beside his casket before the burial.
author: By Finbarr O’Reilly For The New York Times

header: Zelensky says Ukraine needs $57 billion to rebuild and pay its bills.
desc: NA
author: By Ben Shpigel

header: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By John Ismay, Steven Erlanger, Eric Schmitt and Dan Bilefsky

header: The U.S. commitment to providing arms to Ukraine is open-ended, the defense secretary signals.
desc: NA
author: By John Ismay

header: Three Women of Bucha: Their Deaths and Lives
desc: New reporting illuminates the fortitude of three women — a former public servant, an animal lover, a grandmother — who were victims of Russian brutality.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko

header: Elon Musk says SpaceX can’t fund internet service in Ukraine ‘indefinitely,’ stirring controversy.
desc: Starlink terminals have been critical in allowing the Ukrainian military to coordinate on the battlefield, including in recent offensives.
author: By Cade Metz, Cassandra Vinograd and Helene Cooper

header: Elon Musk backtracks, saying his company will continue to fund internet service in Ukraine.
desc: The service has been crucial for communications in Ukraine’s army as it advances into territory occupied by Russia.
author: By Cade Metz

header: Despite Its Barrage of Missiles, Russia Still Loses Ground in Ukraine
desc: “They use their expensive rockets for nothing, just to frighten people,” a member of Ukraine’s Parliament said of Russian attacks on the country’s cities and infrastructure.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Putin Moves to Cement Annexations in Ukraine
desc: Moscow is pressuring nuclear engineers to sign contracts with a Russian agency while pushing Ukrainians fleeing Kherson to go to Russia.
author: By Ben Hubbard and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Can Russia Keep Firing Missiles at Cities? And What Defenses Does Ukraine Need?
desc: Efforts to help Ukraine shield its cities may depend on the scarcity of both Russian missiles and Western air defense systems.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: Belarus Wavers as Putin Presses It to Join Ukraine War
desc: The country’s strongman, Aleksandr Lukashenko, finds himself in a bind. He survives with support from Russia, but entering the fight could be “political suicide.”
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Biden authorizes an additional $725 million in military aid to Ukraine.
desc: An air defense system is still not a part of the package, but that may be on the way soon.
author: By Helene Cooper

header: France pledges to train up to 2,000 Ukrainian soldiers and offers air defense missile system.
desc: NA
author: By Constant Méheut

header: An orchestra conductor has been killed after refusing to cooperate with Russian occupiers, Ukrainian officials say.
desc: The conductor, Yurii Kerpatenko, was fatally shot after he refused to take part in an online day of music organized by Russian-backed local officials, Ukraine’s culture ministry said.
author: By Megan Specia

header: ‘Coffins Are Already Coming’: The Toll of Russia’s Chaotic Draft
desc: Newly mobilized recruits are already at the front in Ukraine, a growing chorus of reports says, fighting and dying after only days of training.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: Strikes Hit Staging Ground for Troops in Russia’s Border Region
desc: Explosions rocked Belgorod and the city of Donetsk on Sunday, signaling that the mayhem unleashed by Russia’s invasion is spreading far beyond the front lines.
author: By Andrew Higgins, Megan Specia and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Resilient Kyiv Patches Up After Attacks, but Some Things Can’t Be Fixed
desc: After a barrage of Russian missile and drone strikes on the Ukrainian capital, its residents show a resolve to clean up and press on.
author: By Megan Specia and Brendan Hoffman

header: Drones Embody an Iran-Russia Alliance Built on Hostility to the U.S.
desc: Authoritarian regimes in Moscow and Tehran have in common international isolation, domestic crisis and conflict with the West.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: What is known about the Iranian-made drones that Russia is using to attack Ukraine.
desc: Russia has used the drones to strike on the battlefield and in Ukrainian cities. Their use may be a sign that Moscow is running low on precision-guided weapons.
author: By Austin Ramzy

header: How Ukraine’s Surrogate Mothers Have Survived the War
desc: When Russia invaded, Ukraine’s once-booming surrogacy industry seemed at risk of collapsing. But surrogate mothers and agencies have managed to continue deliveries, and clients are arriving again to pick up their children.
author: By Maria Varenikova, Andrew E. Kramer and Lynsey Addario

header: Generators briefly switch back on at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant after a strike knocks out external power again.
desc: A Russian strike again disconnected the embattled plant from the national power grid, forcing it to move to backup power, officials said.
author: By Shashank Bengali

header: Russia Unleashes More Drones on Kyiv, Sowing Fear and Bringing Death
desc: “What a horror,” said a Ukrainian retiree, as plumes of smoke rose from a central Kyiv street. “Again!” she said. “This is now happening all the time.”
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Megan Specia, Maria Varenikova and Eric Nagourney

header: Ukraine and Russia exchange prisoners, many of them women.
desc: NA
author: By Dan Bilefsky

header: Russia threatens to block an extension of the Ukraine grain deal.
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson

header: Putin Declares Martial Law in 4 Illegally Annexed Ukrainian Regions
desc: The Russian leader also imposed restrictions in over two dozen areas in Russia, signaling an attempt to crack down on dissent at home.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Neil MacFarquhar

header: Russian Barrage Targets Power, Water and Heat for Ukraine’s Civilians
desc: The stepped-up attacks on cities, including through the heavy use of Iranian-made exploding drones, threaten a new sort of humanitarian crisis for Ukrainians this winter.
author: By Megan Specia and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Where Have All the Men in Moscow Gone?
desc: Across the capital, there are noticeably fewer men at restaurants, stores and social gatherings. Many have been called up to fight in Ukraine. Others have fled to avoid being drafted.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

header: Russia Shrinks Forces in Syria, a Factor in Israeli Strategy There
desc: Moscow withdrew a key air defense system and some troops to bolster its war in Ukraine, officials said, potentially altering Israel’s calculations about striking Syria or arming Ukraine.
author: By Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman

header: As Ukraine intensifies pressure in the south, Russian missile strikes rain down across the country.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Kyiv should cut diplomatic ties with Iran, Ukraine’s foreign minister says.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Russian forces detain two more senior officials at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, Ukraine says.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: The E.U. agrees to place sanctions on Iran for supplying Russia with drones.
desc: Iran has denied supplying Russia with drones for use in Ukraine.
author: By Monika Pronczuk

header: Martial law will allow Russia to impose tighter restrictions in occupied Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: Ukraine’s advances have limited Russia’s options for a smooth pullback.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: In Shattered Homes, Ukrainians Brace for a Cold Winter
desc: In cities and towns battered by the war, residents worry about how to heat their homes as temperatures drop. But even in places spared from the worst of the fighting, Russian strikes on infrastructure have raised new fears.
author: By Megan Specia and Brendan Hoffman

header: ‘It Was Horror’: Ukrainians Share Grim Tales of Russian Occupation
desc: With Russian soldiers pushed out of parts of the Kharkiv region, Ukrainian investigators have been overwhelmed with accounts of detentions, torture and missing relatives, as well as collaboration and property theft.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett

header: Using Adoptions, Russia Turns Ukrainian Children Into Spoils of War
desc: Thousands of Ukrainian children have been transferred to Russia. “I didn’t want to go,” one girl told The New York Times from a foster home near Moscow.
author: By Emma Bubola

header: As Inflation Stalks Europe, Leaders Shudder
desc: The downfall of Britain’s prime minister served as a warning to all of the political peril that awaits those who fail to address the erosion of living standards, no matter the cause.
author: By Jason Horowitz

header: Russian errors prompted the deployment of Iranian drone personnel to Ukraine, a U.S. official says.
desc: John Kirby, a National Security Council official, also warned that Russia may try to buy advanced missiles from Iran.
author: By Julian E. Barnes and John Ismay

header: Russian Troops in Belarus Spur Debate Over the Threat to Ukraine
desc: The United States and its allies are playing down the dangers posed by the deployment of thousands of Russian soldiers to Belarus, but the intelligence assessments come with a dose of uncertainty.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: The E.U. and the U.K. place sanctions on Iran for supplying Russia with drones.
desc: The sanctions will target the company that manufactures Shahed-136 drones, diplomats said, as well as three individuals.
author: By Monika Pronczuk

header: Zelensky accuses Russia of deliberately slowing grain shipments.
desc: The U.N. confirmed a backlog of 150 ships waiting to fulfill contracts to transport Ukrainian food products, a delay that comes as a deadline to renew a grain deal nears.
author: By James C. McKinley Jr.

header: Berlusconi, Caught on Tape Gushing Over Putin, Heightens Anxiety About Italy
desc: Silvio Berlusconi, the former Italian leader and linchpin of the incoming right-wing government, blames Ukraine’s president for pushing President Vladimir V. Putin to invade.
author: By Jason Horowitz

header: Ukraine Rations Power and Warns of Lethal Winter, Despite Battle Gains
desc: Russia may be preparing to retreat from the southern city of Kherson, Western analysts say, but Ukraine’s president warned of possible destruction of a dam upstream.
author: By Megan Specia, Monika Pronczuk and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: ‘We Heard It, We Saw It, Then We Opened Fire’
desc: With an intense, hastily assembled effort, the Ukrainian military is pioneering successful techniques in the difficult art of anti-drone warfare.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: As Russia and Ukraine Seek Gains on Front Line, U.S. and Allies Warn Moscow
desc: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III held a call with Russia’s defense chief to discuss President Vladimir Putin’s nuclear threats.
author: By Carlotta Gall, Helene Cooper and Eric Nagourney

header: Russia Hits Ukraine’s Power Infrastructure With Some of the Biggest Strikes in Recent Weeks
desc: Ukrainian officials confirmed missile strikes in at least half a dozen regions, and the country’s state energy company imposed restrictions in several areas.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukraine War Amputees Find Camaraderie in Recovery
desc: It did not take long for amputees to begin coming off the Ukrainian battlefield. Our photographer captured their fight to lead ordinary lives again.
author: By David Guttenfelder and Eric Nagourney

header: More Ukrainian officials accuse Russia of intentionally slowing grain shipments.
desc: A U.N.-brokered deal ended a five-month Russian blockade of Ukrainian ports and freed millions of tons of agricultural products for a 120-day period.
author: By Carly Olson and James C. McKinley Jr.

header: In shattered homes, Ukrainians brace for a cold winter.
desc: In cities and towns battered by the war, residents worry about how to heat their homes as temperatures drop. But even in places spared from the worst of the fighting, Russian strikes on infrastructure have raised new fears.
author: By Megan Specia

header: Russian attacks are seen as an attempt to stretch Ukraine’s resources.
desc: NA
author: By Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko

header: In a call, U.S. and Russian officials discuss Russia’s escalating threats against Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Helene Cooper

header: Russian-installed authorities tell civilians to ‘immediately’ leave Kherson, a key southern city.
desc: Kherson, which was captured by Russia early in the war, is a major industrial port city and the capital of the one of the four regions Russia has illegally annexed.
author: By James C. McKinley Jr.

header: Using adoption, Russia turns Ukrainian children into spoils of war.
desc: NA
author: By Emma Bubola

header: Where Russians Retreated, Ukrainians Find Devastation
desc: Returning to liberated towns, Ukrainians find destruction on a staggering scale, vital services cut, and the prospect of a lethal winter ahead.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett

header: Amid Backlash, Liberal House Democrats Retract Call to Pursue Ukraine Ceasefire
desc: One day after issuing a letter urging President Biden to seek direct diplomatic talks with Russia, progressives withdrew that appeal. The move reflected deepening divisions over the conflict.
author: By Catie Edmondson

header: Ukraine shoots down Russian attack helicopters, making a dent in Moscow’s fleet.
desc: Kyiv’s forces have shot down at least 23 Ka-52 Russian attack helicopters since the invasion, according to the British military’s defense intelligence agency.
author: By Marc Santora

header: On Ukraine and on Energy, Germany Is Upsetting Its Allies in Europe
desc: The government has dismissed criticism of its refusal to provide modern tanks to Ukraine and its massive energy subsidy for its own citizens. But its friends are bridling.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: House progressives urge the Biden administration to engage in direct talks with Russia.
desc: Thirty Democrats called on the Biden administration to “seek a realistic framework for a cease-fire” that is acceptable to Ukraine.
author: By Catie Edmondson

header: Russian Officials Flee Kherson as Russian Troops Dig In for a Battle
desc: In Kherson, the first Ukrainian city to fall after the Russian invasion, occupation forces appear to be preparing to fight advancing Ukrainian troops.
author: By Marc Santora and Eric Nagourney

header: A senior Ukrainian official said Russia’s occupation administration in Kherson is leaving.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Italy’s New Right-Wing Government Seeks to Affirm Support for Ukraine
desc: Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani expressed support for Ukraine, trying to dispel concerns that Italy could undercut Europe’s opposition to the Russian invasion.
author: By Gaia Pianigiani

header: European leaders in Berlin pitch a ‘Marshall Plan’ for Ukraine.
desc: Berlin hosted a one-day conference to begin coordinating reconstruction, billed by Germany’s chancellor as a “task for generations.”
author: By Erika Solomon

header: In a stretch of southern Ukraine, the Russians have left, but their bombs remain.
desc: NA
author: By Finbarr O’Reilly

header: Why Russia Stole Potemkin’s Bones From Ukraine
desc: The 18th-century military commander and lover of Catherine the Great helped conquer Ukraine and looms large in the version of history the Kremlin uses to justify the war.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Putin Wants to Divide Ukrainians. Mykolaiv Is a Test Case.
desc: In a battered city on Ukraine’s southern coast, salt water runs from the taps and electricity is sporadic. Residents curse Russia, but also express frustration with their own leaders.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Finbarr O’Reilly

header: Playing to Western Discord, Putin Says Russia Is Battling ‘Strange’ Elites
desc: Ahead of U.S. elections, the Russian leader sounded like some right-wing Westerners, saying his fight is not with those in the West who hold “traditional values.”
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Reports of Looting in Kherson as Ukrainians Battle to Retake the City
desc: As Russia pressures local residents to leave, a hydroelectric dam outside the city may prove to be a major point of contention.
author: By Marc Santora and Eric Nagourney

header: New U.S. sanctions target Russian efforts to manipulate the politics in Moldova, a neighbor of Ukraine.
desc: Moldova, like its neighbor Ukraine, wants closer relations with the West but has long battled Russian political interference and intimidation.
author: By Michael Crowley

header: The C.I.A. director visited Ukraine this month.
desc: NA
author: By Julian E. Barnes

header: Ukrainian authorities receive the body of a U.S. Army veteran who volunteered to help fight Russia.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukraine says it has moved forces north in case of aggression from Belarus.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: With Economy Reeling From Ukraine War, Egypt Secures $3 Billion I.M.F. Loan
desc: The local currency had tumbled against the dollar, and food and energy prices soared in the wake of Russia’s February invasion of Ukraine, adding to the struggles of millions of Egyptians.
author: By Vivian Yee

header: The Kremlin’s intensified propaganda against Ukraine is aimed at Russians, U.S. analysts say.
desc: NA
author: By Julian E. Barnes

header: With Western Weapons, Ukraine Is Turning the Tables in an Artillery War
desc: In the southern Kherson region, Ukraine now has the advantage in range and precision guidance of artillery, rockets and drones, erasing what had been a critical Russian asset.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russia Withdraws From Grain Deal After Drone Attack on Black Sea Fleet
desc: The Russian move jeopardized a rare case of wartime coordination aimed at lowering global food prices and combating hunger.
author: By Marc Santora

header: The U.S. announces more military aid for Ukraine, including guided rockets and artillery ammunition.
desc: NA
author: By John Ismay

header: Amid the Slog of Mud Season, the Ukrainian Military Keeps Advancing
desc: Fall rains have turned the earth to sludge, slowing advances at least until the winter freeze, in conditions that have hampered military movement for centuries.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Scarred by War, Ukraine’s Children Face Years of Trauma
desc: For countless Ukrainian children, the war has brought long-term physical and psychological injuries. Those who have suffered serious physical harm or the loss of a parent now face a challenging path forward.
author: By Megan Specia and Brendan Hoffman

header: Here’s how the grain deal between Ukraine and Russia worked.
desc: The process required the collaboration of the two warring nations, along with Turkey and the United Nations.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Some four million Ukrainians face restrictions on power use.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Ukraine accuses Russia of violating international law by placing Ukrainian children in Russian families.
desc: The transfer of Ukrainian children from occupied territories to Russia and their adoption by Russian families is a potential war crime.
author: By Emma Bubola

header: A U.S. program aims to keep sensitive weapons in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Lara Jakes and John Ismay

header: Ukraine and Russia exchange more than 100 prisoners of war, officials say.
desc: NA
author: By April Rubin

header: Oleg Tinkov, Former Banking Tycoon, Renounces Russian Citizenship Over Ukraine
desc: The multimillionaire said on Instagram that he “can’t and won’t be associated with a fascist country.”
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Moldova condemns Russian strikes after missile debris lands in its territory.
desc: Parts of a Russian missile intercepted by Ukrainian air defenses landed in a Moldovan border village on Monday.
author: By Maria Varenikova and Monika Pronczuk

header: Russian Missiles Deliver New Woe to Kyiv, Knocking Out Tap Water
desc: Moscow kept up its campaign to destroy civilian infrastructure, in an apparent bid — so far unsuccessful — to break Ukrainian morale by making cities unlivable.
author: By Marc Santora and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Russia Is Urged to Rejoin Grain Deal as Hunger Warnings Mount
desc: Moscow dismissed accusations that it was using food as a weapon and said Ukraine was to blame for its decision to suspend an agreement that allowed for grain shipments.
author: By Shashank Bengali, Abdi Latif Dahir and Natalie Kitroeff

header: Africa faces immediate pain from the grain deal’s suspension, but the impact on Ukraine could be delayed.
desc: NA
author: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: The war in Ukraine is slowing the recovery in global employment, a U.N. agency says.
desc: NA
author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce

header: A sea drone attack on a Russian fleet puts the focus on expanded Ukrainian arms.
desc: NA
author: By Lara Jakes

header: The U.S. says Russia is ‘weaponizing’ food by halting grain shipments.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora and Juston Jones

header: Kyiv loses water, forcing residents to line up at the city’s wells.
desc: Before the latest round of assaults on Ukrainian infrastructure, a buzz had returned to the capital.

header: ‘Too scary to stay’: Ukrainians along the front line in Kherson are fleeing as fighting escalates.

author: By Oleksandr Chubko and Carlotta Gall

header: Where Russian Fire Pours Down, His Men Sneak Forward
desc: The commander of a Ukrainian reconnaissance unit spearheading the counterattack in the southern region of Kherson explained how his team helped breach defenses he described as frighteningly dense.

header: Russia Rejoins Grain Deal, but Warns It Could Pull Out Again
desc: The agreement allows Ukraine, a major food producer, to export grain by sea, easing the threat of famine in other countries.

desc: Ukrainian officials said that Moscow was trying to clear out civilians to provide places for newly mobilized Russian troops to occupy.

author: By Marc Santora

header: Kyiv says it is preparing 425 shelters in case of a Russian nuclear attack.
desc: Worries that the Kremlin might turn to its nuclear arsenal have deepened since President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia raised the specter of using such weapons to hold on to territorial gains.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Three more grain ships set sail from Ukraine amid questions about their safety.
desc: NA
author: By Dan Bilefsky, Anton Troianovski and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Cheap drones and Western weapons help Ukraine turn the tide in the south.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: As winter approaches, Ukraine braces for the worst.
desc: NA
author: By Dan Bilefsky and Andrea Kannapell

header: These charts help show how Russia pays for the war in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: NA

header: Russian military bloggers criticize the Kremlin for rejoining the Ukraine grain deal.
desc: NA
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: The U.N.’s nuclear watchdog finds no evidence for Russia’s claim that Ukraine is readying a ‘dirty bomb.’
desc: The International Atomic Energy Agency said its inspections had found no evidence of illegal nuclear activity at three sites that figured in Russia’s claims.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Russia’s flag appears to be gone from Kherson’s administrative building. A fight for the city may still loom.
desc: Ukrainian officials have warned that Moscow could be trying to create the illusion of a pullback to draw Ukrainian forces into a trap.
author: By Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Michael Schwirtz

header: The Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant returns to relying on generators after shelling.
desc: It is at least the fourth time the facility has lost connection to outside power since Russian forces began occupying it early in the war.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Kherson Braces for Battle as Russian Administration Evacuates
desc: Evidence points to both sides preparing for a pitched battle for the southern city, and Ukrainians say hints of a Russian military withdrawal are mere deception.
author: By Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Russia Sends Ill-Trained Draftees Into Combat Amid Losses, Analysts Say
desc: Ukraine’s military and Western analysts say Russian forces are making fruitless attacks in eastern Ukraine and taking heavy losses after a hastily arranged draft added over 300,000 troops.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Frustrating and Often Fruitless: The Search for Missing Russian Soldiers
desc: Russian families searching for loved ones say the system for finding missing soldiers is as disorganized as Vladimir Putin’s military effort, which has been marked by dysfunction from the beginning.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Alina Lobzina

header: The Defense Department says it will support Ukraine for ‘as long as it takes.’
desc: The Pentagon’s resolution to supplying Ukraine with weaponry and the new command are clear signals that the U.S. expects the threat from Russia to Ukraine and its neighbors to persist for years, officials said.

header: A New Refugee Crisis Stirs Uncomfortable Issues for Europe
desc: The war in Ukraine has sent the numbers of refugees seeking shelter in Europe soaring, pushing those from other conflicts to the end of the line.
author: By Erika Solomon and Monika Pronczuk

header: U.S., Allies Vow to Protect Ukraine’s Infrastructure From Russian Attacks
desc: Top diplomats from the Group of 7 nations discussed sending more air defense equipment to Ukraine and agreed to coordinate on rebuilding its infrastructure.
author: By Edward Wong

header: Poland’s ability to handle refugees from Ukraine is under strain, but more keep arriving.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: These Men Fled War in Syria to Ukraine. Now They’ve Fled Again.
desc: Two men displaced from Syria as civil war gripped their country spent a decade living in limbo in Ukraine. But when war came to them again, they were forced to leave, eventually making their way to London.

header: Could India Help Broker Peace in Ukraine?
desc: India has good relations with both Russia and the West, and seeks a more muscular role in geopolitics. The biggest obstacle is that Ukrainians and Russians don’t want to talk.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Mujib Mashal

header: Russia Looks to Private Militia to Secure a Victory in Eastern Ukraine
desc: Wagner Group forces launched attacks from several directions on the city of Bakhmut, though analysts said seizing it would yield little strategic value.
author: By Andrew Higgins and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Kyiv Planning for Total Evacuation if It Loses Electricity
desc: The city is also establishing 1,000 heating centers for its 3 million residents, as Russia pounds away at civilian targets.
author: By Marc Santora and Ben Hubbard

header: The U.S. and Europe seek to assure Ukraine of support.
desc: NA
author: By Dan Bilefsky, Andrew E. Kramer, Eric Schmitt, Helene Cooper and Edward Wong

header: Republican gains in Congress would pressure Biden on Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Michael Crowley

header: Southeast Asia is a case study in Russia’s declining prospects as an arms exporter.
desc: Analysts say Russia’s performance in Ukraine, coupled with Western sanctions, is likely to hurt its ability to sell weapons abroad. Southeast Asia is a case in point.

header: External power is restored again to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, easing risk of an accident.
desc: NA
author: By James C. McKinley Jr.

header: A judge who sentenced volunteer fighters to death in occupied Ukraine is shot in an apparent assassination attempt.
desc: NA
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Ukraine says Russia is blowing up civilian ships in Kherson to stop the Ukrainian military from using them.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Even as Challenges Mount, Europeans Stick by Ukraine
desc: Inflation and anxiety over nuclear weapons may be eating into some popular support for the war, but key governments remain insulated from the pressures for now.

header: Why Control of Kherson City Is Important to Russia and Ukraine
desc: The forced withdrawal of troops is a significant setback to Moscow’s campaign to control southern Ukraine.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Marc Santora

header: Aerial War Over Ukraine Heats Up as Russia Pounds Cities
desc: Ukraine, beefing up its air defenses, says Russia has bought ballistic missiles from Iran to replace the precision weapons it is firing at services vital to civilians.
author: By Marc Santora, Shashank Bengali and Andrew E. Kramer

header: As Ukraine Bears Down, Life Worsens in Occupied Areas
desc: Those fleeing speak of the growing dangers of bombardment and of Russian forces commandeering homes and sheltering among civilians.

header: Why Kherson, Bracing for Battle, Matters So Much to Russia and Ukraine
desc: Both sides have given great weight to what happens in Kherson, a city of symbolic and strategic value, where conditions are increasingly dire for the thousands of people who remain.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Marc Santora and Carly Olson

header: Zelensky warns the U.N. climate gathering that Russia’s war is undercutting any possible collective action.
desc: Reports from the ground and research on previous armed conflicts suggest that the ecological impact of the conflict could be enormous.
author: By Dan Bilefsky

header: Ukraine wants Russia to return territory and pay damages.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Shashank Bengali

header: India hopes to play peacemaker, if Russia and Ukraine talk.
desc: NA
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Mujib Mashal

header: Civilians struggle to escape as a bigger battle looms in southern Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko

header: Russia and Ukraine push for weapons to fight an escalating aerial war.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Ukraine Moves Forward in South, With Little Resistance From Russia
desc: A day after Russia said it was withdrawing from Kherson City in the south, Ukraine’s forces moved into villages without a fight, indicating the Russians were, indeed, retreating.

header: Russia Orders Retreat From Kherson, a Serious Reversal in the Ukraine War
desc: Russia’s position had grown perilous in Kherson, a strategic city and one of the biggest prizes seized in its Ukraine invasion, but Russian hawks reacted angrily to the withdrawal.

header: Phantom Retreats and Stolen Bones: The War of Deceit in Ukraine
desc: Both Russia and Ukraine are using confusion as well as artillery on the battlefield. The latest question: Is Russia really retreating from the strategic city of Kherson, as its defense minister says, or is it laying a trap?
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russia and Ukraine each have suffered over 100,000 casualties, the top U.S. general says.
desc: Gen. Mark Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, called the coming winter months an opportune time for the two sides to hold peace talks, though that prospect appears dim.
author: By Helene Cooper

header: In Wake of U.S. Election, Ukrainian Lawmakers Will Reach Out to Washington
desc: Officials are optimistic that Washington will continue to support the war effort. But a delegation is planning a trip to meet lawmakers of both parties.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: ‘Go ahead with the pullout of troops,’ Russia’s defense minister says.
desc: NA
author: By Dan Bilefsky, Marc Santora, Andrew E. Kramer and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Tough Lines on Ukraine and China: Seeing Policy Fallout From U.S. Election
desc: With the MAGA star dimmed, analysts expect continued support in Washington for Ukraine and NATO, and perhaps greater pressure on China.
author: By Steven Erlanger and Alexandra Stevenson

header: Putin’s top security official visits Iran as Russia seeks precision weapons.
desc: The visit comes as Western and Ukrainian officials warn that Russia is trying to secure high-tech Iranian missiles and drones to deploy on the battlefield.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Marc Santora

header: Some Russian war bloggers express anguish over the Kherson order, while others see its pragmatism.
desc: “This betrayal is now carved up on my heart for centuries,” one military blogger wrote online. Another blogger lauded the move as a way to preserve the army.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: The U.S. unveils another $400 million in military aid for Ukraine.
desc: The package encompassed more missiles for HAWK air defense systems and more ammunition for the high-tech HIMARS rocket launchers that Ukraine has used against Russian forces to devastating effect.
author: By Dan Bilefsky and John Ismay

header: Ukraine Signals It Will Stay on the Offensive, Despite Talk of a Lull
desc: Many analysts and diplomats have suggested there could be a pause in major combat, and even peace talks, over the winter, but after pushing the Russians out of Kherson, Ukraine has no desire to stop.

header: Ukrainian Soldiers Sweeping Into Kherson Are Greeted With Jubilation
desc: After months of Russian occupation, residents said the moment recalled being liberated from the Nazis in World War II. But there was also fear about further Russian attacks.

header: Ukrainian Forces Enter Kherson, a Strategic Prize, in a Blow to Putin
desc: Jubilant crowds poured into the streets, greeting Ukrainian soldiers and waving flags. But officials said the city was not out of danger, warning of potential Russian reprisals.

header: As Ukraine Makes Gains, Mykolaiv Bears Fierce Russian Attacks
desc: The Ukrainian city keeps getting bombed by the Russians just as nearby Kherson appears to be falling back into the hands of Ukraine.

header: Zelensky says dozens of towns and villages in the Kherson region have been retaken.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Dan Bilefsky

header: When It Comes to Bearing Bad Tidings, Putin Is Nowhere to Be Found
desc: Big decisions about Ukraine are President Vladimir V. Putin’s to make, but the Kremlin and state media are distancing him from the setback in Kherson and downplaying its seriousness.

header: Amid Joy in Kherson, a Humanitarian Disaster Looms
desc: Ukrainian forces encountered a city without heat, water, electricity or cellphone service, with Russian artillery digging in just miles away.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora and Katie Rogers

header: Banksy Unveils Mural in War-Torn Ukrainian Town
desc: The anonymous artist appeared to confirm his latest creation in Borodyanka, a town that was among the first to be hit by Russian airstrikes.
