header: Joy over the Russian pullout spreads in Ukrainian communities at home and abroad.
desc: NA
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: ‘Let me hug you’: Ukrainian soldiers receive a hero’s welcome in Kherson.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russia Tried to Absorb a Ukrainian City. It Didn’t Work.
desc: In Kherson, national songs were banned, speaking Ukrainian could lead to arrest, and students were told they were Russian. Cue the resistance.

header: The Pentagon will pay Lockheed Martin more than $520 million to replace guided rockets sent to Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By John Ismay

header: Accounts of Torture Emerge From Kherson, Ukraine’s ‘City of Fear’

header: Winter will be a major factor in the war in Ukraine, officials say.
desc: NA
author: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes

header: Russia’s War Hawks Step Up Criticism of the Military Over Kherson Withdrawal

header: Leaders at the G20 summit urge an end to the Russia-Ukraine war.

header: The C.I.A. director meets with his Russian counterpart to warn against the use of nuclear weapons in Ukraine.

header: Reports of atrocities in Kherson follow similar accusations in other reclaimed areas of Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson and Marc Santora

desc: Some military analysts said that the recapture of Kherson might enable Ukraine to shift forces as well as artillery east to Donetsk.

desc: NA
author: By Steven Erlanger

desc: Though the battle for Ukraine remains largely a grinding artillery war, new advances in technology and training there are being closely monitored for the ways they are starting to shape combat.

header: In Poland, a Warm Welcome for Ukrainian Refugees Wobbles
desc: Poland took in millions of people fleeing the war in Ukraine. But a vocal minority is trying to stoke tensions as Russian attacks threaten to prompt a new surge.

header: A reopened rail route to Mykolaiv restores some order amid war.
desc: On Monday night, the first train from Kyiv departed for the Black Sea city, which had been pummeled for months by Russian attacks.

header: In a Polish Village, Renewed Fears of War Spilling Over From Ukraine
desc: When missiles landed a few miles from the Ukrainian border, residents say they reignited fears that had largely calmed since the war’s early weeks.

header: Here’s what we know about the S-300 missile, which was involved in the Poland blast.
desc: Both Russia and Ukraine have depended on the S-300 systems, which are built by Russia, as protection against incoming air assaults during the ongoing war.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: NATO envoys gather as the explosion in Poland alarms the alliance.
desc: NA
author: By Richard Pérez-Pena and Shashank Bengali

header: For Ukraine, Keeping the Lights On Is One of the Biggest Battles

header: Russian attacks on Ukraine’s power grid are endangering nuclear plants, a U.N. agency warns.

desc: The disaster claimed 298 civilian lives, and came in the midst of a conflict that foreshadowed Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine.

header: Words Were Once His Harshest Weapon. Now He Carries an Assault Rifle.

header: Deal allowing Ukraine to export grain is extended 120 days, easing food crisis.
desc: Ukraine, Turkey and the United Nations, three of the parties to the agreement, announced the extension of the deal on Thursday.

header: Ukraine works to keep the lights on.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Ukraine attacks deeper into Russian-held territory.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Russian forces pummel Ukraine with missile strikes.
desc: NA

header: Zelensky expresses skepticism that a Ukrainian missile hit Poland, putting him at odds with the West.
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson

header: At least 437 children have been killed in the war since February, Ukraine says.

header: As the War Rages, Ukraine Wages a Daunting Battle to Rebuild

header: Battered School Holds Memories of Collective Trauma in a Ukrainian Village

header: Train service between Kyiv and Kherson is restored after nine months.
desc: A train, carrying 200 passengers, made the 11-hour journey for the first time since Ukraine retook the city, a senior official said.

header: Videos Suggest Captive Russian Soldiers Were Killed at Close Range
desc: Videos circulating online and reported on by Russian state media have raised questions about whether Ukrainian soldiers committed a war crime.

header: How did Russia manage to launch its biggest aerial attack yet on Ukraine?
desc: NA
author: By Lara Jakes and Marc Santora

header: A Ukrainian film critic is drafted into a real-life war.
desc: NA
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn

header: Russia and Ukraine again trade blame for shelling at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant.
desc: The United Nations’ nuclear watchdog agency called the strikes “extremely disturbing.”

header: From The Times Magazine: How Ukraine’s vast rail system has helped it withstand Russia’s invasion.
desc: NA
author: By Sarah A. Topol

header: For Ukraine, So Much Unexpected Success, and Yet So Far to Go

header: ‘I want to escape’: Russian shelling brings terror and death to Kherson, even after the retreat.
desc: NA
author: By Lynsey Addario

header: Ukraine Raids Holy Site Amid Suspicion of Orthodox Church Tied to Moscow
desc: The security services said they searched for spies and weapons at the Monastery of the Caves in Kyiv. Dozens of priests have been arrested since the war began on charges of aiding Russia.
author: By Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Ukraine raids an Orthodox monastery in Kyiv to prevent ‘subversive’ activities.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Ukraine has defied the odds, but its objectives in the war remain distant.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Shelling kills a social worker at an aid station, Ukraine says.

header: The U.S. bolsters Ukrainian air defenses and long-range artillery.

header: Pope Francis compares Russia’s war against Ukraine to a devastating Stalin-era famine.
desc: The comparison to Stalin’s decision to let millions in Ukraine starve represents one of the pope’s strongest condemnations yet of the Russian invasion.

header: A U.S.-Made Missile Went Astray in Ukraine, Injuring Civilians
desc: An air-launched AGM-88B missile, built to destroy enemy radars, apparently missed its target and hit an apartment building in Kramatorsk in September.

desc: NATO is determined to help Ukraine battle Russia, but wants no direct part of the war. A new promise of air defense weapons for Poland may make that more complicated.

header: ‘Every hour is getting harder’: Surgeons in Ukraine struggle to operate when the power goes out.
desc: The scene in a Kyiv hospital was a vivid illustration of the cascading toll Russia’s attacks are having on civilians far from the front lines.

header: A Russian missile strikes a maternity ward, killing a newborn, Ukraine says.
desc: “Grief fills our hearts,” a regional official said.

header: Russian citizens were found in raids on Orthodox churches, Ukraine’s security service says.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: A U.S.-made missile went astray in Ukraine in September and injured civilians.
desc: NA
author: By John Ismay

desc: The West thought an artillery and tank war in Europe would never happen again and shrank weapons stockpiles. It was wrong.

desc: The Holodomor commemoration came as President Vladimir V. Putin was accused of degrading Ukraine’s power grid to freeze the country into submission.

header: Under a Cross Atop a Shallow Grave, He Found His Father
desc: The full extent of Russian war crimes in the city of Kherson and surrounding areas is just coming into focus. These were two of them.

header: Merkel says she lacked the power to influence Putin ahead of his invasion of Ukraine.
desc: Recounting her last state visit to Moscow in August of 2021, Angela Merkel noted that President Vladimir V. Putin would not meet with her alone, as he had done in the past.

header: A battered school holds memories of collective trauma in a Ukrainian village.
desc: NA
author: By Megan Specia

header: As a dark winter descends on Ukraine, Europe tries to help keep the lights on.
desc: NA
author: By Euan Ward

header: Ukraine says its nuclear power plants are back online.
desc: NA
author: By Victoria Kim and Marc Santora

header: Putin holds a highly choreographed meeting with mothers of Russian servicemen.

header: After losing Kherson, Russia bombards the city from afar.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora and Enjoli Liston

header: Ukraine warns of a new wave of Russian strikes.
desc: Officials urged Ukrainians to continue conserving energy, as analysts said that deteriorating weather was one factor slowing Ukraine’s battlefield progress.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: The U.S. and NATO scramble to arm Ukraine and refill their own arsenals.
desc: The West thought an artillery and tank war in Europe would never happen again and shrunk weapons stockpiles. It was wrong.
author: By Steven Erlanger and Lara Jakes

header: Why the Ukrainian flag is flying everywhere in Maine.
desc: Like people in other states, Mainers want to show their solidarity with Ukraine. But it’s more than that.
author: By Hannah Beech

header: In snow and slush, Ukraine’s forces practice how to take new territory.
desc: NA
author: By Brendan Hoffman

header: Belarus’s architect of Western outreach dies suddenly, state media reports.
desc: Vladimir Makei served 10 years as the foreign minister of Belarus, a key geopolitical battleground between Russia and the West.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Andrew Higgins

header: Ministers from seven northern European nations meet with Zelensky in Kyiv.
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson

header: When the Lights Go Out, Kyiv Keeps Going — With Some Ingenuity
desc: Survival kits in elevators, alternative menus in cafes, flashlights and generators everywhere: This is life under Russian bombardment, when power can fail at any moment.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Russian Retreat Reveals Signs of an Atrocity in a Ukrainian Village
desc: In the southern Kherson region, the pattern seen in eastern Ukraine is repeating: The withdrawal of Russian forces yields evidence of possible war crimes.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly

header: NATO foreign ministers begin two days of meetings with a show of unity in support of Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Edward Wong

header: A letter bomb delivered to the Ukrainian Embassy in Madrid explodes.
desc: An employee was slightly injured. Ukraine ordered all Kyiv’s embassies to strengthen security after the attack.
author: By José Bautista and Carly Olson

header: Poland says it will ask Ukrainian refugees to pay some housing and food costs next year.
desc: Poland has taken in more Ukrainians fleeing the war than any other European country and by the end of the year will have also spent more on services for them.
author: By Carly Olson

header: U.S. Pledges $53 Million to Help Fix Ukraine’s Electrical Grid
desc: American officials said they hoped the commitment would spur allies to make similar donations, as many Ukrainians head into winter without power or water.
author: By Edward Wong and Steven Erlanger

header: A ‘Bridge to the West’ Dies in Belarus, as Moscow Seeks More Help in Ukraine
desc: Vladimir Makei, a former foreign minister who led failed efforts to improve relations with the West, died over the weekend. His death comes as Russia presses Belarus to send troops to Ukraine.
author: By Andrew Higgins and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Kyiv’s mayor expresses resolve as Russian attacks aim to make his city unlivable.
desc: Vitali Klitschko says of Moscow: “They want to destroy the country from inside.”
author: By Marc Santora

header: As Macron Pays State Visit to U.S., Ukraine Tests an Old Alliance
desc: The French president goes to Washington with differences over how to end the war in Ukraine, and how to share its burdens, at the heart of talks with President Biden.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: Special Court Needed for Russian Crimes in Ukraine, E.U. Chief Says
desc: The idea reflects frustration with the difficulty in holding anyone accountable in the war, and actually reaching trials in a new court is likely to be very hard.
author: By Carly Olson and Matt Surman

header: As Macron Loses His Sheen at Home, Harmonious U.S. Visit Is ‘Regenerative’
desc: President Emmanuel Macron, dealing with a difficult start to his second term, can return to France feeling buoyed by a warm reception and unity on Ukraine.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: Ukrainian embassies receive packages containing animal eyes, the Foreign Ministry says.
desc: The packages arrived several days after six letter bombs were mailed to offices in Spain, including those of Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez and the American and Ukrainian Embassies.
author: By Cora Engelbrecht

header: Lavrov defends strikes on civilian infrastructure as six million in Ukraine remain without power.
desc: Russia’s foreign minister defended the strikes against Ukraine’s civilian infrastructure, which the United Nations has said could amount to war crimes.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Marc Santora

header: Brace for Bombs, Fix and Repeat: Ukraine’s Grim Efforts to Restore Power
desc: Even as Ukrainian workers race to restore basic services like electricity, heat and water, new Russian airstrikes send them back to the starting line.
author: By Marc Santora, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Zelensky Proposes Barring Orthodox Church That Answers to Moscow
desc: Ukraine’s president called for legislation to prevent an ancient branch of the Orthodox Church, led by a Putin ally, from operating in his country, but it remains unclear how that would work.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Germany’s leader, in a call with Putin, vows continued support for Ukraine.
desc: The call, which the Germany chancellery said lasted an hour, was the first between the two leaders since September.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: Zelensky proposes preventing Orthodox churches ‘affiliated’ with Moscow from operating in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Amid Ukraine’s calls to ban his church, the Russian Orthodox leader reiterates his support for the war.
desc: NA
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: U.S. and Ukrainian Embassies Targeted by Letter Bombs in Spain
desc: One of the six packages containing “pyrotechnic material” was also sent to the prime minister’s office in Madrid, prompting the authorities to increase security.
author: By José Bautista, Isabella Kwai and John Ismay

header: A Zelensky aide says that up to 13,000 Ukrainian troops have been killed.
desc: NA
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: In Forests Full of Mines, Ukrainians Find Mushrooms and Resilience
desc: These misty and damp parts of the country have long beckoned to mushroom hunters with the promise of plenty, but now peril, too, lies beneath the earth’s surface.
author: By Maria Varenikova and Brendan Hoffman

header: He Returned a Dazed Soldier to the Russians. Ukraine Calls It Treason.
desc: No one knew what to do with a lost Russian pilot who suddenly appeared in the occupied city of Kherson. The case has revealed the blurred line between pragmatism in a war zone and collaboration with the enemy.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly

header: Ukraine Calls for Evacuations From a Russian-Controlled Area, Signaling a New Offensive
desc: A Ukrainian official urged civilians to leave the eastern bank of the Dnipro River, across from the city of Kherson, warning of the “possible intensification of hostilities” there.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Security guarantees for Russia are an ‘essential’ part of any peace talks, Macron says.
desc: Ukraine reacts an
author: By Roger Cohen

header: The Kremlin’s defiance adds to questions over whether the price cap will work.
desc: The Pre
author: By Matt Stevens, Ivan Nechepurenko and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: With a raised flag, Ukraine hints at a continued push in the south.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukraine Targets Bases Deep in Russia, Showing Expanded Reach
desc: Launching drones at air bases 300 miles from its own territory, Ukraine changed the geography of the war. It said it had developed drones with a range of over 600 miles.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Michael Schwirtz and Marc Santora

header: Ukraine’s Philharmonic Plays On
desc: As Ukraine battles to protect its power grid from Russia’s assault, its national philharmonic continues to perform in the dark.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Ukraine will auction a yacht seized from a Putin ally.
desc: A Kyiv government agency is planning to sell a confiscated vessel linked to Viktor Medvedchuk, a prominent politician who was seen as a key conduit of Russian influence in the country.
author: By Emma Bubola and Anastasia Kuznietsova

header: Ukraine Strikes More Boldly, Seeing Little Room for Russia to Escalate
desc: The third apparent drone attack in two days on a Russian air base indicates a new phase of the war for Ukraine as it develops longer-range weapons.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ecstasy Gives Way to Despair in a Liberated Ukrainian City
desc: Kherson has been whipsawed by occupation, liberation and now dread. It’s a lonely place. And cold.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: War and Sanctions Threaten to Thrust Russia’s Economy Back in Time
desc: While Russia’s economy has not collapsed, an exodus of Western companies is eroding hard-won progress, and experts say the worst may be yet to come.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Putin inspects a bridge linking Russia and Crimea, two months after a damaging explosion.
desc: When the bridge opened in 2018, it was a powerful symbol of the connection the Kremlin was attempting to forge between Russia and Crimea, a Ukrainian region illegally annexed by Moscow.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Ukraine attacks military bases hundreds of miles inside Russia.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Michael Schwirtz and Marc Santora

header: Latvia Hosted Russian Journalists in Exile. Then Their Loyalties Were Questioned.
desc: A news host’s comment about helping troops prompted the Latvian authorities to revoke the license of TV Rain, a major independent outlet, putting a focus on the public role of Russians who fled.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: A timeline of attacks on Russian territory or assets during the war in Ukraine.
desc: Ukraine has often celebrated the attacks but has not officially confirmed involvement in any of them.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: The sounds of war mark time in one battered town.
desc: In Bakhmut, in eastern Ukraine, rumbles and blasts are just background noise, until they aren’t.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak

header: A Gray Area of Loyalties Splinters a Liberated Ukrainian Town
desc: “Friends are not friends anymore,’’ said one woman in the town of Sviatohirsk, which remains divided not by trench lines and artillery, but by where people’s allegiances lie: with Moscow or Kyiv.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

header: Zelensky is named Time’s person of the year.
desc: Ukraine’s president was propelled onto the world stage with Russia’s invasion of his country.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: News Analysis: In Brittney Griner Deal, Putin Used Pain, a Familiar Lever
desc: By seizing the basketball star, the Russian president made things so painful for the U.S. that it capitulated and turned over a convicted arms dealer. Can the same tactic work in the war in Ukraine?
author: By Anton Troianovski and Valerie Hopkins

header: Ukraine escalates its offensive in Luhansk, aided by a winter freeze, officials say.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Russian Anti-War Activists Seek Common Goals (When They’re Not Bickering)
desc: Almost 300 activists, many young and from the diaspora, gathered to try to forge a common path, beyond struggling against Vladimir Putin and the war in Ukraine.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: Putin Warns Russians to Prepare for Protracted Ukraine War
desc: Vladimir Putin appeared to acknowledge that subduing Russia’s neighbor was taking longer than expected, but said there was no need for another draft now.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Sevastopol’s mayor says Russia’s Black Sea Fleet shot down a Ukrainian drone.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Photos show that Russia is building a barrier in Belgorod, near its border with Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukrainian officials investigating Russian spies raid 13 Orthodox monasteries and churches.
desc: NA
author: By Anushka Patil

header: Spat Over Patriot Missiles Reveals Deepening Rifts in Europe Over Ukraine
desc: Relations between Warsaw and Berlin, never warm, have deteriorated since the start of the Ukraine war, damaging unity in both NATO and the European Union.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: NATO’s secretary general warns that a ‘full blown war’ with Russia is ‘a real possibility.’
desc: “If things go wrong, they can go horribly wrong,” Jens Stoltenberg said in an interview published on Friday.
author: By Anushka Patil

header: At Nobel Ceremony, Russian Crimes and ‘Imperialism’ Take Center Stage
desc: The three recipients of this year’s Peace Prize emphasized the urgency of fighting today’s authoritarian states to secure human rights and democracy.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Russia and Iran are strengthening their defense partnership, the Biden administration warns.
desc: The National Security Council spokesman, John Kirby, said that the U.S. was “concerned that Russia intends to provide Iran with advanced military components.”
author: By Anushka Patil

header: A Chatty Putin’s Underlying Message: I’m Still in Charge
desc: In a string of appearances, it wasn’t so much what the Russian leader said, much of it false, as it was his apparent need to demonstrate that he is healthy, alert and in control.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Brittney Griner Swap Puts Spotlight on Americans in Russia
desc: Westerners in Russia have to weigh the risks of living and working in the country against professional and financial opportunities there.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Jonathan Abrams

header: The Kremlin plays down Putin’s claim of territorial gains in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Ukraine details Russian attacks against its energy grid over the last two months.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Zelensky catalogues Russian crimes, as Putin suggests that he’ll continue striking Ukraine’s energy grid.
desc: war
author: By Marc Santora

header: Ukrainians leave Kherson as Russia bombards the area.
desc: NA
author: By David Guttenfelder

header: War Next Door Brings Energy Crunch, and Paid Protests, to Moldova
desc: The tiny country, starved of natural gas and electricity because of the conflict in neighboring Ukraine, is confronting street rallies bankrolled by a pro-Russian politician to target its pro-Western government.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Russia Is Using Old Ukrainian Missiles Against Ukraine, General Says
desc: The missiles, returned to Russia in the 1990s under an agreement aimed at assuring Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity, have shown up in rubble.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Ukraine says it struck a hotel where members of Russia’s Wagner security force had gathered.
desc: The claim could not be independently verified, and there was no immediate comment or confirmation from the Wagner Group.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukraine Faces More Outages and Strikes Russian-Controlled Melitopol
desc: The attack on Melitopol signals the importance of longer-range weapons in Ukraine’s campaign to recapture land in the south.
author: By Mark Landler, Matt Stevens and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Putin Skips Annual News Conference, Avoiding Possible Questions on War
desc: The December event has offered reporters rare — albeit stage-managed — chances to pose hard questions. With the war going poorly for Russia, that could have been awkward.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: Russia is using old Ukrainian missiles against Ukraine, an official says.
desc: The missiles, returned to Russia in the 1990s under an agreement aimed at assuring Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity, have shown up in rubble.
author: By Marc Santora

header: The E.U.’s foreign ministers agreed to give Ukraine 2 billion euros in military aid.
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: The diplomatic push follows Russian strikes that have damaged critical Ukrainian infrastructure.
desc: NA
author: By Yan Zhuang

header: The G7 nations agree to set up a donor platform to funnel money to Ukraine.
desc: The plans are the first concrete steps to be taken in long nebulous efforts to devise a system for funding Ukraine’s financial survival and reconstruction.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: The strike on Melitopol signals the importance of longer-range weapons in Ukraine’s campaign to recapture land in the south.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Pope Francis calls for people to celebrate a more ‘humble’ Christmas and donate to Ukraine.
desc: “Let us not forget Christmas,” the pope said at the end of his weekly general audience, “but with the people of Ukraine in our hearts, and let us offer concrete signs of help for them.”
author: By Elisabetta Povoledo

header: Defenses Carved Into the Earth
desc: Russia is building a vast network of trenches, traps and obstacles to slow Ukraine’s momentum. Will it work?
author: By Marco Hernandez and Josh Holder

header: Banksy’s works near Kyiv have inspired Ukraine. But did one activist go too far?
desc: The removal of a Banksy mural sparks a debate about the future of a handful of his works scattered in and around Ukraine’s capital.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Plan for More Donors and Faster Aid Yields $1 Billion for Ukraine Repairs
desc: A French-led effort to involve dozens of countries aims to help Ukraine survive a harsh winter with quick repair of vital electrical, heating, water and health care systems.
author: By Catherine Porter and Liz Alderman

header: Russia warns that it would ‘undoubtedly’ target U.S. Patriot air defense systems in Ukraine.
desc: Moscow said that Washington’s plans to supply Kyiv with its most advanced air defense system raised the risk of drawing the U.S. directly into the war.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Eric Schmitt and John Ismay

header: Belarus says it is checking its army’s combat readiness. Analysts see little chance it will join Russia’s fight.
desc: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus is a close ally of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, and Belarus relies on Moscow for finance, fuel and security assistance.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Russia Launches a Wave of Iranian-Made Drones at Kyiv After a Lull
desc: Analysts had surmised that Russia was having trouble with the drones, but if a problem has been fixed, it remains unclear how long the Kremlin can sustain such attacks.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora

header: Zelensky says Russian and Belarusian athletes shouldn’t be allowed at the 2024 Olympics.
desc: In recent days, international Olympic officials have been unclear about whether the athletes will be allowed to compete in the Paris Summer Olympics.
author: By Carly Olson

header: Targeting One Southern City, Ukraine Hints at Next Front in the War
desc: Using missiles and saboteurs, Ukraine is focusing on the city of Melitopol, a vital Russian link to Crimea, ahead of an expected southern offensive.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Paris hosts a vast gathering to coordinate urgent aid for Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Catherine Porter and Liz Alderman

header: In Subfreezing Cold, Waves of Russian Missiles Batter Ukraine
desc: Dozens of missiles knocked out heat and electricity systems around the country including in Kyiv, where two-thirds of its residents had no heat or water.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora

header: The Infrared Hunt for Russian Troops in the Battle for Bakhmut
desc: On a frigid December night, The New York Times accompanied members of a surveillance team for the Ukrainian Army as they used a thermal sight to find enemy positions miles away.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Tyler Hicks

header: U.S. Will Train More Ukrainian Troops, Adding Advanced Battle Tactics
desc: Western instruction since Russia’s invasion has focused on basic training or the use of sophisticated weapons systems. Officials say “combined arms” tactics could be a key next step.
author: By Eric Schmitt and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Zelensky calls for the United Nations to send observers to energy infrastructure targeted by Russian strikes.
desc: The Ukrainian leader says that he has spoken with António Guterres, the U.N. secretary general, and they are working on organizing ‘missions with an international mandate’ to such sites.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: A Russian Missile, a Sudden Death, and Unspeakable Grief
desc: In the immediate aftermath of an attack, the horrors of the Ukraine war, the random death and the lives upended take on a deeper meaning when seen close-up.
author: By David Guttenfelder and Oleksandr Chubko

header: Expanded U.S. training aims to fill a gap in Ukraine’s military capabilities.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine fears Russia will try again to take Kyiv.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: The U.S. plans to more than double the number of Ukrainian troops it trains in Germany.
desc: NA
author: By Eric Schmitt and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russian forces shell Kherson, in the south, as Ukraine’s troops bombard Donetsk, in the east.
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson

header: Missiles knock out heating systems in towns and cities amid freezing temperatures.
desc: It was the ninth large-scale wave of missiles to be aimed at Ukrainian infrastructure this fall. Officials said 76 missiles had been fired, and all but 16 were shot down.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora and Victoria Kim

header: Overnight drone attacks target Kyiv and two other regions of Ukraine.
desc: Ukraine said that it had shot down 20 of 35 drones that Russia had launched, though those that evaded air defenses had hit power plants, electrical systems and other civilian targets.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine Says Russia Is Training Soldiers for Possible New Offensive
desc: An adviser to President Volodymyr Zelensky urged Western allies to take seriously the threat of a new Russian onslaught, which could include mass infantry attacks.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Putin Makes Rare Visit to Ukraine War Headquarters
desc: The meetings with his top brass seemed to signal a shift from his largely hands-off public posture to one conveying a more active role in war planning.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Eight Takeaways From The Times’s Investigation Into Putin’s War
desc: Secret Russian battle plans, intercepts, and interviews with Russian soldiers and Kremlin confidants revealed new details of how Vladimir Putin botched his invasion of Ukraine.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Counting Russia’s War Dead, With Tips, Clips and a Giant Spreadsheet
desc: Amid doubts about Moscow’s true war losses, Russian data journalists and volunteers use news articles, tombstone photographs and other open-source information to tally the Russian toll from the war in Ukraine.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: Ukrainians Focus on Resilience a Day After Major Russian Strikes
desc: The mayor of Kyiv said that water was back on and that the city’s subway service had resumed. President Volodymyr Zelensky urged businesses to help set up more “invincibility centers” for the public.
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: The Year in Pictures 2022
desc: Photographers captured historic moments of war, grief and wonder that defined the year.
author: By The New York Times

header: Zelensky’s visit to Bakhmut aims to show Ukraine’s resolve.
desc: Despite months of Russian bombardments and waves of assaults, the city has remained in Ukrainian control.
author: By Marc Santora and Anton Troianovski

header: In a bomb shelter-turned-TV set, Ukraine selects its Eurovision contestant.
desc: The electronic music duo Tvorchi won with the song “Heart of Steel,” which the singers said was inspired by the courage of Ukrainian soldiers defending Mariupol.
author: By Carly Olson

header: Inside a high-tech Ukrainian operation in the battle for Bakhmut.
desc: NA
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Surrender to a Drone? Ukraine Is Urging Russian Soldiers to Do Just That.
desc: Capitalizing on reports of low Russian morale, Ukraine has begun offering enemy troops detailed instructions on how to make their way over the battlefield and lay down their arms.
author: By Marc Santora

header: The Pentagon says it has helped Ukraine thwart Russian cyberattacks.
desc: Russia has struggled to see military gains from its cyberattacks in the world’s first sustained cyberspace battle between two sophisticated militaries.
author: By Julian E. Barnes

header: Congress’s sprawling spending bill includes more than $44 billion for Ukraine.
desc: The new aid would push U.S. investment in the war against Russia to more than $100 billion, and sets aside funds for inspector generals to scrutinize how the money is being spent.
author: By Emily Cochrane

header: Putin Visits Belarus, Stirring New Concern on Future of Ukraine War
desc: Belarus has resisted being drawn more centrally into the war. But the visit raised worries that a new Russian ground offensive could aim again at Kyiv, near the Belarusian border.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson

header: Zelensky is expected to make a trip to Washington to meet Biden and address Congress on Wednesday.
desc: NA
author: By Emily Cochrane, Carl Hulse, Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora, Michael D. Shear and Annie Karni

header: Lauding Their Soldiers, Putin and Zelensky Signal Long Fight Ahead
desc: As the 10-month mark of the war nears, the leaders of Ukraine and Russia handed out medals and pledged not to back down.
author: By Marc Santora, Anton Troianovski and Michael Levenson

header: The U.S. will give Ukraine Patriot missiles for the first time.
desc: NA
author: By Helene Cooper

header: Putin Concedes Military Failings, but Insists Russia Will Fight On
desc: Nodding to criticism that his army lacked the basic necessities to wage war, the Russian leader said his government was providing “everything that the army asks for.’’
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Belarus’s leader tries to play down suggestions that recent military moves were aimed at Ukraine.
desc: Some Ukrainian officials have warned that a military exercise involving Russia could be a precursor to a new offensive aimed at Kyiv.
author: By Cora Engelbrecht

header: Zelensky flies the flag of Ukraine’s enduring defiance with a crew neck and cargo pants.
desc: The outfit offered an immediate visual reminder of the Ukrainian president’s purpose to his people, his fighters, his allies — and, not least, his foe in the Kremlin.
author: By Vanessa Friedman

header: Ukraine Buoyed by Hero’s Welcome for Zelensky in Washington
desc: Ukrainians, many left in the dark and cold by Russian airstrikes, drew solace from President Volodymyr Zelensky’s speech to Congress.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Zelensky’s Message: Ukraine Is Fighting for Good Over Evil
desc: One of the Ukrainian leader’s overriding aims is to prevent support for the war from becoming a partisan issue.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Frontline City’s Final Food Stand Finds a Way to Keep the Pizza Coming
desc: Despite all the shelling, and with no electricity, one snack shop is still serving the soldiers and citizens who have stayed in Bakhmut, Ukraine, a pivotal battleground in the war.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

header: A Putin ally meets with China’s top leader, highlighting ties as Russia’s isolation grows.
desc: China has remained a significant, if largely silent, counterweight to the international censure of Russia.
author: By Victoria Kim and Anton Troianovski

header: Washington says North Korea is delivering arms to the Wagner Group for Russia’s use in Ukraine.
desc: The paramilitary group has played a central role in Russia’s efforts to storm the city of Bakhmut in Donetsk Province, which borders Luhansk.
author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs

header: Zelensky’s U.S. trip lifts spirits during a cold winter for Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: The U.S. military aid flowing to Ukraine now includes very sophisticated weapons.
desc: NA
author: By Helene Cooper

header: When Putin called the conflict a ‘war,’ he wasn’t reversing course.
desc: The Russian leader was repeating the propaganda line that it was the West and Ukraine that started a “war” against Russian speakers in eastern Ukraine.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Threat of Invasion From Belarus Low, Says Ukraine Spy Chief
desc: In a wide-ranging interview on the state of the war, Kyrylo Budanov also spoke about Russia-Iran relations and Moscow’s obsession with taking the city of Bakhmut.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: At Least 10 Killed in Kherson Shelling, Fueling Anger Over Christmas Strikes
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine had urged vigilance after the military noted the presence of Russian ships carrying cruise missiles in the Black Sea.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: Russian shelling hits Ukraine’s south and east as Zelensky returns to Kyiv.
desc: At least five civilians were killed and 18 injured in Russian attacks on Thursday and into Friday morning, an official said.
author: By The New York Times

header: Ukraine’s spy chief says Russian activity in Belarus is an attempt to divert Ukraine’s forces.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: The nearly $50 billion Congress approved for Ukraine consists mostly of military support.
desc: NA
author: By Lauren McCarthy

header: Ukraine’s president defiantly predicts victory after trip to Washington.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew Higgins, Cora Engelbrecht, Andrew E. Kramer and David E. Sanger

header: Christmas is still coming to Ukraine, with a few adjustments.
desc: NA
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: A Christmas staple from Ukraine marks the 100th anniversary of its first American performance.
desc: “Carol of the Bells” started as a song about a little bird and was first performed in the United States in 1922.
author: By Rob LeDonne

header: The Senate passes a spending bill that includes nearly $50 billion in aid for Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Emily Cochrane

header: Russian Air Base Is Attacked, as Ukraine Discounts Escalation Threat
desc: Russia said falling wreckage from a Ukrainian drone had killed three servicemen at the base, some 300 miles from Ukraine, which would be the third such long-range attack this month.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: How Citizen Spies Foiled Putin’s Grand Plan for One Ukrainian City
desc: A partisan cell in Kherson spied on, undermined and even hunted down Russian soldiers. Now that Vladimir V. Putin’s forces are gone, people feel free to talk — and to brag a little.

header: Putin Insists He Is Open to Talks, as Air-Raid Sirens Sound Across Ukraine
desc: Ukrainians appeared intent on celebrating Christmas, even if scarce power left some cities darkened, save for generator-powered holiday light displays.

header: In Ukraine, Christmas Lights Defy Darkness of War, and Children Ask for Peace
desc: One town is protecting a statue of St. Nick with sandbags, another is putting its Christmas tree underground and others are cranking up noisy generators to keep the holiday spirit alive.

header: In Christmas Address, Pope Bemoans ‘Grave Famine of Peace’
desc: Pope Francis urged the tens of thousands of faithful in St. Peter’s Square to pray for Ukraine and for others suffering in conflicts around the world.
author: By Jason Horowitz

header: In Nord Stream Mystery, Baltic Seabed Provides a Nearly Ideal Crime Scene
desc: As investigators piece together clues, Russia has quietly taken steps to begin expensive repairs on the giant gas pipeline, complicating theories about who was behind September’s sabotage.
author: By Rebecca R. Ruiz and Justin Scheck

header: The president of Belarus is in Russia amid concerns of a new offensive in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: In Ukraine, Christmas lights defy the darkness of war.
desc: NA
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: There was no holiday from fighting on the eastern front line.
desc: NA
author: By Tyler Hicks

header: Ukraine is offering Russian soldiers detailed instructions on how to surrender to its drones.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Hard-Line Positions by Russia and Ukraine Dim Hope for Peace Talks
desc: Both Moscow and Kyiv say they are ready to talk, but their terms for sitting down at a negotiating table suggest otherwise.
author: By Shashank Bengali

header: Russian City Mourns Its Lost Soldiers, but Doesn’t Resent Putin’s War
desc: Ryazan, not far from Moscow, regularly sends young men off to fight. Some are now buried in the local cemetery, but there is no surge of outrage against Russian leaders.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

header: Ukraine’s difficulties on the bond markets leave it more reliant on foreign aid.
desc: Unable to roll over debt accumulated before the war, Ukraine has paid investors more than it has collected this year, the Central Bank says.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine and Russia Battle for a Gateway City in the East
desc: Recapturing Kreminna, in eastern Ukraine, would be a step further in Ukraine’s campaign to retake major cities that Russia seized after it invaded.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Alan Yuhas

header: Ukrainian forces edge closer to a heavily guarded city in the east.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Lukashenko and Putin Affirm Close Ties Without Addressing Ukraine
desc: Their meeting could add to fears that Moscow will try to draw Belarus, Ukraine’s northern neighbor, more directly into the war.
author: By Shashank Bengali and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Russia rejects a new Ukrainian proposal for peace talks.
desc: NA
author: By Shashank Bengali

header: France’s defense minister visits Kyiv to discuss further military support.
desc: NA
author: By Constant Méheut

header: A Russian tycoon and his travel companion are found dead in India.
desc: The body of the millionaire Pavel Antov, who had reportedly criticized the Russian shelling of civilians in Kyiv, was found outside his hotel.
author: By Anushka Patil and Suhasini Raj

header: In a city a few hours from Moscow, mothers grieve their sons but don’t resent Putin’s war.
desc: NA
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

header: Russian Missile Barrage Staggers Ukraine’s Air Defenses
desc: Cruise missiles and exploding drones from Iran swept across the skies of Ukraine, wreaking havoc and once again knocking out power.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine Defeats Russian Drone Swarm, as NATO Head Says Kyiv Needs More Arms
desc: In a war where the vital weapons and tactics have changed repeatedly, Ukraine relies more than ever on air defenses to fend off barrages aimed at its energy systems and cities.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: In Battered Ukrainian City, the Latest Battle is Against Winter
desc: Firefighters in Lyman, in Ukraine’s east, contend with land mines, freezing temperatures, damaged buildings, awful cell service and a lack of water.
author: By Natalia Yermak and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Critics say a new media law signed by Zelensky could restrict press freedom in Ukraine.
desc: Lawmakers who passed the bill said it would help meet European Union conditions for membership, but journalists have denounced it as a move toward censorship.
author: By Anushka Patil

header: Moscow on the Med: A Faraway War Transforms a Turkish Resort Town
desc: Tens of thousands of Russians and Ukrainians have settled in Antalya, on Turkey’s southern coast, hoping to avoid the fallout of Russia’s war in Ukraine and start new lives.
author: By Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur

header: 100 Years Since the Birth of the Soviet Union, in Pictures
desc: It is the disintegration of the U.S.S.R. that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia says he wants to remedy by waging war against Ukraine; it is the legacy of Moscow’s dominance that Ukrainians hope to free themselves of by defeating Moscow.
author: By The New York Times

header: Ukraine gives an optimistic update on its power grid, but concern grows about coming holidays.
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson

header: Belarus says it shot down a Ukrainian missile, the type Ukraine uses for air defense.
desc: NA
author: By Shashank Bengali

header: NATO’s chief argues that giving more weapons to Ukraine is the fastest path to peace talks.
desc: NA
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: Washington condemns the latest Russian attacks in Ukraine as ‘barbaric.’
desc: NA
author: By Eric Schmitt

header: Deadly Russian Strikes Hammer Ukraine on New Year’s Eve
desc: Explosions hit the capital, Kyiv, and other cities on the final day of a year shaped by Russia’s invasion. Flanked by soldiers, Vladimir V. Putin called the invasion a “sacred duty” of Russians.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Anton Troianovski

header: Russian Airstrikes Leave Ukrainians Few Options but to Endure
desc: Ten months into the war, Ukraine has turned the tide in ground combat, but its cities are still facing relentless waves of missiles and exploding drones.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Clergymen or Spies? Churches Become Tools of War in Ukraine
desc: Ukrainian officials are cracking down on a branch of the Russian Orthodox Church that they describe as a subversive force doing the Kremlin’s bidding.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: With Speeches to Ukraine, and the World, Zelensky Shapes Narrative of the War
desc: In a New Year’s Eve addresses to his people , the president delivered a message meant to rouse his people and rally Ukraine’s allies.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: ‘I just don’t have words.’ Kyiv residents express fury at New Year’s Eve attacks.
desc: The year ended much the same way it had gone for months, with air raid sirens, explosions and families rushing to find shelter.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russia’s War Could Make It India’s World
desc: The invasion of Ukraine, compounding the effects of the pandemic, has contributed to the ascent of a giant that defies easy alignment. It could be the decisive force in a changing global system.
author: By Roger Cohen and Mauricio Lima

header: Ukraine at war: 2022 in photos.
desc: NA
author: By Andrea Kannapell

header: Zelensky’s New Year’s Eve addresses have a strong following among Ukrainians.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Shashank Bengali

header: Putin and Zelensky will give dueling addresses today with no end to fighting in sight.
desc: Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will share their New Year’s messages as the war grinds on toward its one-year anniversary.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russia says its officials and officers in Ukraine don’t have to declare income.
desc: NA
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Deadly Strike on Russians in Ukraine Exposes Moscow’s Military Failings
desc: A Ukrainian attack with U.S.-made rockets may have left hundreds of casualties, and pro-war Russians accused their military commanders of repeating fatal errors.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: In Romania, U.S. Troops Train Close to Russia’s War, in Signal to Moscow
desc: The deployment to a NATO country near the conflict in Ukraine is seen as a model of deterrence for a U.S. military that has recently stepped back from direct fighting.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: Ukraine Keeps Downing Russian Drones, but Price Tag Is High
desc: When costly missiles take out cheap drones, the real winner over time may be the country that spends less.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Activist who removed Banksy mural from Kyiv suburb could face prison, police say.
desc: The mural, showing a woman in a bathrobe wearing a gas mask and holding a fire extinguisher, was one of seven artworks painted by Banksy on war-ravaged buildings in and around Kyiv.
author: By Javier C. Hernández

header: Putin Prepares Russians for a Long Fight Ahead
desc: The Russian leader has dropped the pretense that life goes on as normal despite the war, evident in the Kremlin’s quick acknowledgment of mass casualties inflicted by Ukraine last weekend.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Defending against Russian drones is expensive, but Ukraine sees the cost as worth it.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Julian E. Barnes, Shashank Bengali and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukrainian prosecutors identify a Russian torture site, adding to a list of more than 50.
desc: NA
author: By Andrea Kannapell

header: A U.S.-made long-range rocket system has helped give Ukraine momentum in the war.
desc: Washington delivered the first batch of truck-mounted, multiple-rocket launchers, known as HIMARS,
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Eric Schmitt

header: Deadly strike on Russians in Ukraine exposes Moscow’s military failings.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: Away from the spotlight, Ukraine and Russia trade border fire in rural villages.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: ‘Fear Still Remains’: Ukraine Finds Sexual Crimes Where Russian Troops Ruled
desc: Investigators have uncovered widespread evidence of abuse by Moscow’s forces, including rape and forced nudity. Kremlin officials have repeatedly denied accusations of rights violations.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Laura Boushnak

header: For Russian Troops, Cellphone Use Is a Persistent, Lethal Danger
desc: Ukrainian artillery targets Russian soldiers by pinpointing their phone signals. Despite the deadly results, Russian troops keep defying a ban on cellphone use near the front.
author: By Alan Yuhas, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Yousur Al-Hlou

header: More than 60 percent of Bakhmut has been destroyed, a Ukrainian official says.
desc: Russia has continued to press an offensive aimed at capturing the eastern city, after suffering a string of setbacks elsewhere in Ukraine in recent months.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: Lacking precision missiles, Russia is increasing its use of drones, Ukraine says.
desc: NA
author: By Shashank Bengali

header: France promises Ukraine armored vehicles as the U.S. weighs doing the same.
desc: President Emmanuel Macron pledged to provide AMX-10 RC armored vehicles, though Mr. Macron’s office did not specify how many of the vehicles would be delivered or when.
author: By Aurelien Breeden

header: Ukraine Claims Heavy Russian Losses in Waves of Missile Strikes
desc: Kyiv says its forces have killed or wounded hundreds of Russian soldiers in a series of pinpoint attacks. Russia has confirmed only one of three waves of strikes.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Christiaan Triebert

header: Putin Calls a 36-Hour Cease-Fire, but Ukraine and U.S. Are Skeptical
desc: The cease-fire would coincide with the Eastern Orthodox Christmas on Saturday, but Kremlin adversaries and some analysts call it a ploy for military and political advantage.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Russia issues the first pardons to prisoners who fought in Ukraine, state media reports.
desc: Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of the Wagner paramilitary group, is seen in a video congratulating men for completing their military contracts.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Alina Lobzina

header: Ukraine moves toward charging 2 Russian commanders accused of ordering strikes that killed civilians.
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson

header: Ukraine recorded its largest annual fall in G.D.P. in over 30 years, a top minister says.
desc: NA
author: By Jason Karaian and Enjoli Liston

header: Attacks Continue in Ukraine Despite Russia’s Supposed Cease-Fire
desc: Ukraine never accepted Russia’s unilateral Christmas truce, dismissing it as a hollow ploy, and Russian shelling was as intense as ever in a hotly contested city.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: New Armored Vehicles Will Help Ukraine Take the Fight to Russia
desc: The Western allies’ provision of infantry fighting vehicles signals their support for new offensives in coming months, analysts said.
author: By Steven Erlanger and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: The U.S. announces a $3 billion package of military aid to Ukraine, including armored fighting vehicles.
desc: Karine Jean-Pierre, the White House press secretary, said the administration would also send $682 million to countries on NATO’s eastern flank.
author: By Michael D. Shear and John Ismay

header: In a Ukraine Workshop, the Quest to Build the Perfect Grenade
desc: A Ukrainian unit is tinkering with tape, a scale, a 3-D printer and other items to turn a fragmentation grenade into a tank-killer. It’s a steep and risky challenge.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak

header: Battered and Strained by War, Ukraine’s Economy Adapts to Survive
desc: After 10 months of Russian destruction, Ukraine’s economy shrank by 30 percent. But companies have packed up and moved, switched products and found support abroad.
author: By Liz Alderman

header: Ukrainians Celebrate Orthodox Christmas at a Holy Site Long Linked to Moscow
desc: The sermon, a deeply symbolic moment after months of tension with the Moscow-led branch of the church, came as a cease-fire failed to materialize.
author: By Megan Specia

header: Ukraine says recent pledges show that key weapons are no longer ‘taboo’ for its allies.
desc: The foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, welcomed pledges this week from France, Germany and the United States of military aid that his government had been seeking for months.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: Continued shelling backs up Ukraine’s doubts about Putin’s cease-fire.
desc: NA
author: By Megan Specia

header: ‘Fear still remains’: Ukraine finds sexual crimes where Russian troops ruled.
desc: Russian officials have denied abuses against civilians despite widespread evidence of sexual violence by Russian troops documented by Ukrainian and international investigators.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Laura Boushnak

header: The U.S. imposes sanctions on more Iranians over the drones Russia is using in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Julian E. Barnes

header: Now Fighting for Ukraine: Volunteers Seeking Revenge Against Russia
desc: Chechens, Crimean Tatars and people from the former Soviet republics, all with deep historical grievances against Moscow, are eagerly taking up arms for Kyiv.
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: Without Hesitation, Ukraine Goes Toe to Toe With Russia in Bakhmut
desc: Earlier in the war, Ukraine’s leadership was more equivocal about pitched battles with high casualties. There’s no second-guessing this time. Some analysts say it makes sense strategically.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Nicole Tung

header: Putin’s Efforts to Divide the West Over Ukraine Fall Flat
desc: A cease-fire proposal seemingly aimed at splintering Western unity has instead been met with Western escalation, underscoring Moscow’s diplomatic struggles.
author: By Max Fisher

header: The House Is in Ruins, but the Holiday Feast Goes On
desc: Orthodox Christmas came under harsh circumstances in Ukraine this year. For families like the Kovtuns, living next to the remains of their shell-struck home, celebration was an act of defiance.
author: By Megan Specia

header: Ukraine rejects Russia’s claim of a deadly strike on troops in the east.
desc: Russia’s Defense Ministry said it had carried out a strike that “killed 600 people,” but no evidence has emerged to support the claim.
author: By Megan Specia

header: The pace of offensives has been slower in the east.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Shifting strategy, Ukraine goes toe to toe with Russia in Bakhmut.
desc: Earlier in the war, Ukraine’s leadership was more equivocal about pitched battles with high casualties. There’s no second-guessing this time. Some analysts say it makes sense strategically.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: A Russian strike on a market killed two women, Ukraine says.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: In the bitter cold, a Ukrainian team searches ‘not for bodies, but for souls.’
desc: NA
author: By Nicole Tung and Evelina Riabenko

header: The invasion of Ukraine has contributed to the ascent of India, a giant that defies easy alignment.
desc: NA
author: By Roger Cohen and Mauricio Lima

header: Russia Replaces Commander for Ukraine War, as Signs of Dissension Grow
desc: Allies of President Vladimir V. Putin contradicted each other about battlefield progress, as a war command shake-up put another Kremlin loyalist in charge.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Ukraine strips a wealthy pro-Russian politician of his citizenship.
desc: Viktor Medvedchuk, a Ukrainian politician who is close to the Russian president, was handed over to Moscow in September as part of a prisoner swap while awaiting trial on treason charges.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: What Does It Mean to Provide ‘Security Guarantees’ to Ukraine?
desc: A postwar Ukraine will want to ensure that Russia does not attack again. But is there anything short of full NATO membership that will satisfy Kyiv and deter Moscow?
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: Russian Mercenary Group Says It Has Taken Contested Ukrainian Town
desc: With a harsh winter putting sweeping offensives on hold, the war has shifted back to bloody battles of attrition like the one for the small city of Bakhmut and the smaller town of Soledar.
author: By Megan Specia, Ivan Nechepurenko and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Come On In, the Internet Is Fine: Kyiv Workers Get Online in Unlikely Spots
desc: Sporadic power outages have people resorting to makeshift office spaces in the Ukrainian capital. Stores have set up power hubs, and workers are getting comfortable doing their jobs in home furnishing displays.
author: By Megan Specia

header: Russia posts a $47 billion budget deficit for 2022, its second highest in the post-Soviet era.
desc: The budget gap reached 3.3 trillion rubles, or 2.3 percent of the size of the Russian economy, according to the country’s finance minister.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Britain is considering sending tanks to Ukraine, in what would be a first.
desc: The British Challenger II could become the first Western-made main battle tank to be provided to Ukraine since Russia invaded almost a year ago.
author: By Lara Jakes and Stephen Castle

header: Poland says it’s willing to provide Ukraine with German-made tanks, adding pressure on Berlin to agree.
desc: NA
author: By Anushka Patil

header: Foreign volunteers seeking revenge against Russia bolster the ranks of Ukraine’s Army.
desc: NA
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: Putin’s efforts to divide the West over Ukraine are falling flat.
desc: NA
author: By Max Fisher

header: Western Tanks Appear Headed to Ukraine, Breaking Another Taboo
desc: The West has sent an array of weapons once seen as too provocative, and it looks like tanks will be next. With a new Russian offensive expected, officials see an urgent need to shift the balance.
author: By Lara Jakes and Steven Erlanger

header: Russia’s Claim to Seize a Ukrainian Town Exposes Rifts Among Forces
desc: After Russia’s Defense Ministry said its troops had taken Soledar, a leader of the Wagner mercenary group accused the military of stealing credit. Ukraine said its forces were still fighting there.
author: By Alan Yuhas, Megan Specia and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Gen. Valery Gerasimov, the new head of Russia’s war effort, is the Kremlin’s top military commander.
desc: In a statement announcing the appointment, the Russian Defense Ministry hinted at a renewed campaign in Ukraine.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: The transfer of an Israeli missile-warning system to Ukraine is delayed, ambassador says.
desc: NA
author: By Isabel Kershner

header: Western tanks appear to be headed to Ukraine, breaking another taboo.
desc: The West has sent an array of weapons once seen as too provocative, and it looks like tanks will be next. With a new Russian offensive expected, officials see an urgent need to shift the balance.
author: By Lara Jakes and Steven Erlanger

header: A funeral near Kyiv bears witness to the toll of fierce fighting in Ukraine’s east.
desc: Neither Russia nor Ukraine divulges its battle losses, but both have said the other is paying a heavy price in lives. The loss of one Ukrainian commander offers one small window on the cost of the battle for the east.
author: By Photographs and Text by Lynsey Addario

header: As Poland and Britain weigh sending tanks to Kyiv, pressure on other allies mounts.
desc: U.S. and European defense officials have long held concerns that giving Ukraine tanks could prompt Russia to escalate the war.
author: By Anushka Patil

header: The internet is a lifeline in Ukraine. Keeping it running is a key government focus, a minister says.
desc: NA
author: By Megan Specia

header: A worldwide recession might be averted, the I.M.F. chief says, but the war in Ukraine is a caveat.
desc: NA
author: By Alan Rappeport

header: How Western Goods Reach Russia: A Long Line of Trucks Through Georgia
desc: With Western sanctions barring many imports, a lot of what Russia needs now travels a slow, crowded truck route through the Caucasus Mountains from Georgia.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: As Russians Steal Ukraine’s Art, They Attack Its Identity, Too
desc: Russian forces have looted tens of thousands of pieces, including avant-garde oil paintings and Scythian gold. Experts say it is the biggest art heist since the Nazis in World War II, intended to strip Ukraine of its cultural heritage.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn

header: Dead, Alive or Devastated After Russian Strike on Apartments
desc: Rescue workers were still digging through the ruins of a residential building in the central Ukrainian city of Dnipro on Sunday, a day after a Russian missile attack.
author: By Megan Specia and Nicole Tung

header: Russia unleashes dozens of missiles on Ukraine.
desc: Russian forces have targeted Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, and other cities with missile and drone attacks off-and-on for months, devastating the power grid and forcing rolling blackouts.
author: By Megan Specia

header: Britain Says It Will Give Ukraine Tanks, Breaching a Western Taboo
desc: Western countries have balked at giving Ukraine tanks and other powerful weapons. As increased spring fighting looms, that seems to be changing.
author: By Megan Specia and Ben Hubbard

header: ‘I’m Sorry, We’re From Moscow.’ In Bali, Warring Sides Learn to Cohabitate
desc: Thousands of Russians and Ukrainians have fled their homelands for Bali. But even in a tropical paradise, the war is ever-present.
author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Nyimas Laula

header: Rescuers rush to save people buried in rubble of a building destroyed by a Russian missile.
desc: A 15-year-old girl was among the 14 people killed. The search for survivors continues.
author: By Nicole Tung, Megan Specia and Cassandra Vinograd

header: For Families and Detainees in Russian-Occupied Areas, a Grim Wait
desc: After Russia’s retreat from Kherson city, Ukrainians in other occupied areas of the south had expectations of quickly regaining their freedom. But those hopes have been dashed.
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: A United Europe Weathers Crises, but Deeper Challenges Remain
desc: Differences on NATO and E.U. enlargement, energy and climate, and relationships with the United States, China, Russia and Ukraine will prime Davos talks.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: The U.K. says it aims to give tanks to Ukraine, a move long resisted by allies.
desc: NA
author: By Lara Jakes

header: As Humanitarian Crises Escalate, So Do Demands to End Them
desc: David Miliband, head of the International Rescue Committee, says the global refugee crisis “is manageable, not insoluble.”
author: By Claudia Dreifus

header: Ukraine’s first lady urges leaders at Davos to use their influence to help her country.
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Megan Specia

header: Death Toll of Russian Strike in Dnipro Rises to 40, Ukraine Says
desc: The authorities said 34 people remained missing after three days of searching for the living and the dead at an apartment building struck by a Russian missile in Dnipro.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Megan Specia

header: What 70 Years of War Can Tell Us About the Russia-Ukraine Conflict
desc: Despite some postmodern features, the fighting resembles a type of conflict from decades past: wars fought between nations in which one does not conquer the other outright.
author: By Max Fisher

header: A Wagner fighter defects to Norway, promising to expose Russian war crimes in Ukraine.
desc: The rare defection by a former member of the notorious Russian paramilitary force could aid investigations into Moscow’s atrocities.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Henrik Pryser Libell and Michael Schwirtz

header: At a Pivotal Moment in Ukraine, U.S. and Allies Will Decide on Sending Arms
desc: Ukraine has a narrow window of time to retake more territory ahead of an expected Russian spring offensive, but to do that it needs weapons like armored vehicles.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: The Australian Open bans Russian and Belarusian flags.
desc: Tennis has struggled with its response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, which Belarus has supported.
author: By Natasha Frost

header: Germany’s defense minister resigns after criticism over her handling of the war.
desc: The minister was repeatedly attacked over public blunders and her handling of the war in Ukraine. She is the most senior member of Olaf Scholz’s government to resign.
author: By Erika Solomon and Christopher F. Schuetze

header: The U.N. confirms civilian deaths in Ukraine have surpassed 7,000, but says the real toll is far higher.
desc: The total includes only those that U.N. investigators have been able to corroborate, and does not include the dozens killed in Saturday’s strike on Dnipro.
author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce

header: The war in Ukraine upended energy markets. What does that mean for the climate?
desc: Almost a year after Russia launched its invasion, assessing the impact on the oil industry and greenhouse gas goals is not so simple.
author: By David Gelles

header: School Is in Session, Power or Not
desc: In Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, Russian strikes and power outages are part of the school day. Teachers and students press on with resolve.
author: By Megan Specia and Laura Boushnak

header: Ukraine says it will take time to determine the cause of a helicopter crash that killed 14 people.
desc: The helicopter came down near a kindergarten and a residential building outside Kyiv, killing the interior minister and others and causing severe damage.
author: By Ben Shpigel and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukraine Minister Killed in Helicopter Crash Oversaw Some Security Forces
desc: Denys Monastyrsky was the highest-ranking Ukrainian government official to die since Russia’s invasion began in February last year.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine’s Allies Pledge to Send Major Infusion of Military Aid
desc: As representatives from dozens of countries prepared to attend a war-planning meeting in Germany, the talk was of missiles, air defense and — above all — tanks.
author: By Steven Erlanger, Eric Schmitt, Lara Jakes and Erika Solomon

header: Why Tanks Are Tripping Up the West
desc: Western nations are amping up offensive military power for Ukraine in almost every category except the one Kyiv says it needs the most. Here’s why.
author: By Lara Jakes and Erika Solomon

header: Helicopter Crash Kills Ukrainian Minister in Blow to Wartime Leadership
desc: The crash in a suburb of Kyiv killed at least 14 people, officials said, including the interior minister, a top adviser to President Volodymyr Zelensky, who oversaw Ukraine’s domestic security.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Megan Specia

header: ‘Tragedies are outpacing life’: In a video address at Davos, Zelensky mourns the dead and pleads for help.
desc: At the start of his address, the Ukrainian president called for a minute of silence to honor the country’s minister of internal affairs.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Tinkering with tape, a scale and a 3-D printer, one Ukrainian unit is on a quest to build the perfect grenade.
desc: NA
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak

header: C.I.A. Director Visited Kyiv for Meeting With Zelensky
desc: The director, William J. Burns, has made periodic visits to Ukraine to meet with intelligence officials and to exchange information with the country’s president.
author: By Julian E. Barnes

header: South Africa to Hold Naval Drill With Russia and China Amid Ukraine War
desc: The 10-day naval exercises are a show of diplomatic independence for South Africa, which is part of an alliance with Brazil, Russia, India and China — known as BRICS.
author: By Lynsey Chutel and John Eligon

header: Ukraine allies announce new military aid ahead of a key meeting of defense ministers.
desc: NA
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: Allies Fail to Agree on Sending Tanks to Ukraine
desc: Officials tried to play down the rift. But Germany is still insisting it will not be the country to take the first step alone, for fear of incurring Moscow’s wrath.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: Safe at Home in Dnipro, Until a Russian Missile Struck
desc: Despite the ever-present danger of war, life in Ukraine proceeds almost normally at times. Then, suddenly, it all changes, as it did in Dnipro last weekend after a missile struck an apartment complex.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: A Hit French Novel Tries to Explain Putin. Too Well, Some Critics Say.
desc: A popular novel, “The Wizard of the Kremlin,” presents a sympathetic portrait of the Russian leader, critics say, raising concerns that it might influence national policy toward the Ukraine war.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Amid Mounting Frustration With Germany, Ukraine Holds Out Hope It Will Get Tanks
desc: While Germany has not yet made a decision on whether to send Leopard 2s to Ukraine, a Kyiv official said his country’s soldiers would begin training on them.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: What are Stryker vehicles? And why is the Pentagon sending them to Ukraine?
desc: The vehicles weigh about 20 tons and have eight wheels. They move quickly while carrying soldiers and can be armed with a variety of weapons.
author: By John Ismay

header: A Navy SEAL who deserted in 2019 has been killed in Ukraine.
desc: The man, Daniel W. Swift, was the latest American to be killed in Ukraine, where hundreds of international volunteers have gone to fight in Ukraine’s defense.
author: By Anushka Patil

header: Multiple factors make providing Western tanks to Ukraine problematic.
desc: NA
author: By Lara Jakes and Erika Solomon

header: The Biden administration is warming to helping Ukraine target Crimea.
desc: NA
author: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes

header: A Russian missile lands outside a kindergarten in eastern Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: The U.S.’s top general says it would be ‘very, very difficult’ to eject Russian forces from Ukraine this year.
desc: NA
author: By Ben Shpigel

header: In Moscow, a Quiet Antiwar Protest With Flowers and Plush Toys
desc: Amid Russia’s crackdown on resistance to the war in Ukraine, some have dared to lay bouquets and other offerings at a statue of a Ukrainian poet, protesting the recent Russian strike on civilians in Dnipro.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

header: Germany’s Reluctance on Tanks Stems From Its History and Its Politics
desc: A post-Nazi aversion to war and a commitment to promoting peace through engagement combines with an old fixation on Russia and a deep aversion to leading militarily.
author: By Steven Erlanger and Erika Solomon

header: Zelensky vows action against corruption after a minister is fired for embezzlement.
desc: The Ukrainian leader said the dismissal should serve as notice to officials whose actions “violate the principle of justice.”
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: Zelensky Urges Ukrainians to Remain Unified
desc: On a day meant to mark the unification of Ukraine in 1919, the country’s leader said it was vital for Ukrainians of all regions to bind together.

desc: After Russia’s retreat from Kherson city, Ukrainians in other occupied areas of the south had expectations of quickly regaining their freedom. But those hopes have been dashed.

header: Germany’s reluctance to send tanks to Ukraine stems from its history and politics.
desc: NA
author: By Steven Erlanger and Erika Solomon

header: Analysis: The NATO alliance is holding strong on Ukraine, but fractures are emerging.
desc: NA
author: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

header: Poland says permission from Germany is ‘a secondary issue’ with Leopard tanks.
desc: NA
author: By Ron DePasquale

header: In Kyiv, one tour guide aims to change attitudes about Soviet-era architecture.
desc: NA
author: By Brendan Hoffman

header: In Dnipro, a seemingly ordinary Saturday turned tragic in an instant.
desc: NA
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Poland asks Germany’s permission to send its Leopard tanks to Ukraine.
desc: Germany says it will decide shortly on whether to send advanced tanks to Kyiv, which has been pleading for such equipment for months.

desc: A deputy defense minister was among those removed from their posts, as was a deputy prosecutor general who caused a scandal by taking a wartime vacation to Spain.

header: Germany and U.S., Dropping Resistance, Will Send Battle Tanks to Ukraine
desc: Although welcomed by Kyiv as a critical weapon to expel Russia’s invasion, the Leopard 2 tanks from Germany and Abrams tanks from the United States are unlikely to arrive soon.

header: Western Tanks Are Coming to Ukraine, but Will They Be Enough?
desc: Western allies have pledged to send at least 105 tanks, far less than Ukraine says it needs, and it may be months before they join the battle.

desc: Ukraine’s military acknowledged a gain for Russian forces that brings them closer to encircling the strategic eastern city of Bakhmut.

header: Two British men went to Soledar. Neither came back.
desc: Andrew Bagshaw, 47, and Chris Parry, 28, were part of an ad hoc cohort of foreigners who have gone to Ukraine despite little to no experience with combat situations.

header: Russia’s War Breathes New Life Into a Cold War Symbol
desc: Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, a news network originally set up as a C.I.A. operation early in the Cold War, is experiencing a renaissance and making a case for its independence.

desc: A 74-year-old Spanish man made and sent all of the six letter bombs himself, the authorities alleged, though the “participation or influence of other people” was not ruled out.

header: The M1 Abrams, headed to Ukraine, is the main U.S. battle tank.
desc: NA
author: By John Ismay

header: In Wave of Strikes, Russian Missiles Kill 12 Across Ukraine

header: Russia Outlaws a News Site and a Rights Group, Stifling Critical Voices
desc: The Kremlin stepped up efforts to banish independent sources of news. Prosecutors labeled Meduza, a popular news site, “undesirable,” so anyone who aids or promotes it can be prosecuted.

header: As Ukraine awaits promised tanks from the West, the fighting continues.
desc: NA
author: By Lauren McCarthy

header: Russia says it will switch four occupied Ukrainian regions to Moscow time.
desc: Russia, which has many time zones, is seeking to integrate the regions after illegally annexing them in September.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Russian shelling kills eight civilians in Donetsk Province in eastern Ukraine.
desc: Some military experts and Ukrainian military leaders have said they expect that Moscow will launch a new offensive in the Donbas region in the coming weeks or months.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: White House officials tell senators that Ukraine is committed to anti-corruption.
desc: The firing of several top members of the government in Kyiv had stirred concern over how U.S. aid was being used.
author: By Michael Crowley

header: Ukraine shot down 47 Russian missiles, the country’s air force said.
desc: NA
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: The war is shifting the balance of power from ‘Old Europe’ to newer nations of the east.
desc: NA
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: After securing tanks, Ukraine turns to the next weapon on its wish list: Fighter jets.
desc: NA
author: By Shashank Bengali

desc: Petr Pavel, a political novice, defeated Andrej Babis, a populist business tycoon and former prime minister, in the first of several important European elections this year.

header: The I.M.F. says the war poses a risk to a resilient global economy.
desc: NA
author: By Alan Rappeport

header: Ukraine used banned land mines in the formerly occupied city of Izium, a new report claims.
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson

header: France increases its aid to Ukraine with 12 more Caesar howitzers and stepped-up training.
desc: NA
author: By Aurelien Breeden

header: British volunteers killed in Ukraine are mourned at a service in Kyiv.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky is eager to highlight his crackdown on corruption, ahead of E.U. accession talks and possible Western investigations of war aid.

header: Putin uses a World War II anniversary to vow victory in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Ukraine keeps up the pressure to exclude Russian and Belarusian athletes from the 2024 Olympics.
desc: NA
author: By Anushka Patil

header: A missile strike on Kramatorsk kills at least 3 as Russia steps up its eastern campaign.
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson

desc: NA
author: By Anushka Patil

desc: NA
author: By Jin Yu Young

desc: NA
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: What weapons is Ukraine getting, and will they arrive in time?
desc: Kyiv has been promised scores of tanks and other armor, and the longest range munitions yet. But with a looming Russian offensive, a race is on to get the matériel to the battlefield.

header: The Ukrainian military reports attacks at dozens of points across the eastern front.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

desc: NA

header: Ukraine may no longer have a troop advantage, but Russia’s bolstered forces are still struggling.
desc: NA
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: As Ukraine awaits more Western weapons, it wants to stop Iran from bolstering Russia’s arsenal.

author: By Marc Santora

header: Western allies will support Ukraine in a spring offensive against Russia, the U.S. defense chief says.
desc: NA
