desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson

header: Wagner’s founder is confounding Moscow by dabbling in politics alongside waging war in Ukraine.
desc: NA

header: New Jersey’s governor makes an unannounced trip to Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Lauren McCarthy

author: By David Pierson

header: Biden Accuses Putin of Atrocities and Urges World to Rebuke Him
desc: In sharply opposed speeches, President Biden said Vladimir V. Putin bore sole responsibility for the war, while Mr. Putin said Russia had invaded in self-defense. But they agreed the war would not end soon.
author: By David E. Sanger, Michael D. Shear and Anton Troianovski

header: Putin and Biden Shore Up Alliances in Dueling Appearances
desc: On the surface, it looked like a reversion to the Cold War era. The reality was even more complicated.
author: By Michael D. Shear, David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski

header: Ukraine Hits Russian Positions Deep Behind Enemy Lines
desc: Nearly a dozen explosions rang out in the Russian-held Ukrainian port city of Mariupol, site of one of the best-known battles of the war.
author: By Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine prepares itself for the possibility of Russian aggression via Moldova and Belarus.
desc: Military analysts doubt Russia’s ability to sustain a new front, but Ukrainian and Western officials have warned that Moscow could try to divert Ukrainian resources.
author: By Marc Santora

header: In Kyiv, Italy’s prime minister condemns Russia and pledges further support to Ukraine.
desc: The prime minister, Giorgia Meloni, reiterated her backing amid dissension within her coalition government on the issue.
author: By Elisabetta Povoledo

header: In Northern Ukraine, a Different Sort of War Game
desc: Russian forces are shelling border areas there to tie up thousands of Ukrainian troops that might otherwise defend against attacks farther south.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova

header: Russia’s Top Paramilitary Chief Accuses Army Command of Treason
desc: Caustic accusations by the head of the Wagner mercenary group, Yevgeny Prigozhin, suggest that his vaunted access to Vladimir Putin may be on the wane.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Inside Putin’s Celebration of War
desc: A concert and rally in Russia’s largest stadium romanticized the invasion of Ukraine, as Vladimir V. Putin and his government seek to normalize the country’s war footing.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

header: Protests and Defiance Mark a Year of Russia’s War on Ukraine
desc: On the anniversary of the invasion, Volodymyr Zelensky held a marathon news conference and vowed victory if Ukraine’s allies remained united like a fist.
author: By Marc Santora and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: Bulgarian Factories and Secret Task Forces: How the West Hunts for Soviet Arms
desc: Ukraine has long relied on Russian weapons for its armed forces. Now it is scrambling to get Soviet-era ammunition for those weapons, with the help of manufacturers even in rural corners of Eastern Europe.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Justin Scheck and Boryana Dzhambazova

header: Russia, Ukraine and the West Vow to Fight On, in a War With No End in Sight
desc: Moscow and Kyiv face daunting challenges in moving forward, with no clear sense of what an attainable victory might look like.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Steven Erlanger and Marc Santora

header: The U.S. says it will spend another $2 billion on new drones and weapons for Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Eric Schmitt

header: China repeats its call for a cease-fire in Ukraine and for peace talks.
desc: A new policy paper was not the blueprint or bold initiative that some in European capitals appeared to expect.
author: By Chris Buckley

header: Lethal Threat or Tolerable Risk? Ukrainians Must Judge Constantly.
desc: After a year of war, people in Ukraine have become adept at telling which threats are probably not deadly, leaving room for a little enjoyment, and even hope.
author: By Marc Santora

header: China Reprises Old Themes in Ukraine Plan, Casting Itself as Neutral
desc: A year after Russia’s invasion, Beijing released a paper declaring its position on the war: It called for an end to the fighting but avoided demands that could hurt its ties with Russia.
author: By Chris Buckley, Steven Erlanger and Edward Wong

header: Zelensky answers reporters’ questions for hours, expressing confidence in Ukraine’s eventual victory.
desc: On the anniversary of Russia’s full-scale invasion, Mr. Zelensky offered a broad overview of where the war stood, the challenges Ukraine faced and the opportunities in the months ahead.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Six ways the war changed the world.
desc: The ripple effects of Russia’s invasion have reordered lives and upended economies. Here are some of the consequences.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Our Photographers in Ukraine on the Images They Can’t Forget
desc: In a year of war, New York Times photographers have reported from the front line, from cities and villages and in the footsteps of refugees. These pictures stayed with them.
author: By The New York Times

header: War in Ukraine Has Changed Europe Forever
desc: No event has transformed the continent more profoundly since the end of the Cold War, and there is no going back now.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: Deadly Russian Artillery Strikes Reported in Ukraine’s East and South
desc: Officials said at least five civilians were killed in the attacks, as President Vladimir V. Putin repeated his claim that the war is part of a U.S.-led effort to destroy Russia.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Anton Troianovski

header: China to Welcome Belarusian Leader, Raising Concerns Over Ukraine
desc: A state visit next week by Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus comes as the U.S. has accused China of preparing to send lethal aid to Russia.
author: By Marc Santora and Chris Buckley

header: Tempered in a Crucible of Violence, Zelensky Rises to the Moment
desc: In much of the world, President Volodymyr Zelensky, once brushed off as a political lightweight, has become a household name, representing Ukraine’s tenacity and underdog victories against Russia.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Macron says he will visit China and praises Beijing’s efforts on a peace plan.
desc: NA
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: Across the Globe, the Russian Diaspora Finds Ways to Protest Putin’s War
desc: From Berlin to Chicago, crowds gathered to express solidarity with Ukraine and to underscore that not all Russians support Vladimir Putin’s war.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: A half-hour air alarm across Ukraine is a reminder that Russian attacks aren’t stopping.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: After new E.U. sanctions package, Ukrainian officials say ‘tougher’ action is needed.
desc: NA
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: Ukraine’s allies will watch Lukashenko’s visit to China for signs of military and technology cooperation.
desc: NA
author: By Chris Buckley and Marc Santora

header: Here’s what to know as the war enters its second year.
desc: NA
author: By James C. McKinley Jr. and Matt Surman

header: Biden Deploys High-Powered Aides, Plus More Aid, to Bolster Ukraine
desc: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen traveled to Kyiv the day before Secretary of State Antony Blinken was to visit Central Asia in a show of American solidarity with Ukraine in its battle with Russia.
author: By Marc Santora and Alan Rappeport

header: Scrounging for Tanks for Ukraine, Europe’s Armies Come Up Short
desc: The struggle to deliver on promises to provide Leopard 2 tanks for use against Russian forces has exposed just how unprepared European militaries are.
author: By Erika Solomon, Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze

header: Russian officials accuse Ukraine of launching several attack drones over its territory.
desc: The Ukrainian government publicly follows a policy of deliberate ambiguity about strikes on Russian territory.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Neil MacFarquhar

header: Russia’s New Offensive Sends Conscripts Into the Teeth of Ukraine’s Lines
desc: A month into the campaign, Russian forces have barely budged despite forays by small units in fields, pine forests and ruined towns.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Tyler Hicks

header: In Central Asia, Blinken Will Urge Distance From Russia, and Ukraine War
desc: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken is making the first trip by a Biden administration cabinet official to the former Soviet republics of Central Asia.
author: By Edward Wong, Anton Troianovski and Stanley Reed

header: Zelensky says the situation in Bakhmut is ‘getting more and more difficult.’
desc: The eastern city, which had a prewar population of around 70,000 people, has become a focus of the fighting, with both sides pouring in troops and taking significant losses.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Satellite imagery shows possible damage to a Russian surveillance plane in Belarus.
desc: The British Ministry of Defense said that the loss of the plane would be significant if confirmed, “as it is critical to Russian air operations for providing an air battle space picture.”
author: By Christoph Koettl

header: Blinken Finds Receptive Leaders in Central Asia, Where Russia Seeks Aid
desc: The U.S. secretary of state’s diplomatic mission is part of a broader Biden administration effort to strengthen support for Ukraine, or at least push neutral nations to refrain from aiding Russia.
author: By Edward Wong and Andrew Higgins

header: Ukraine War Squeezes Street Snack in Uganda
desc: The price of a rolex — eggs rolled up in flatbread — has almost doubled in the last year.
author: By Abdi Latif Dahir

header: China Welcomes Belarusian Leader Amid Concerns About Ukraine
desc: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko’s visit comes shortly after the United States accused Beijing of preparing to give arms and ammunition to Russia to help its war on Ukraine.
author: By David Pierson

header: In First Wartime Meeting, Blinken Confronts His Russian Counterpart
desc: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said he told Sergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, that Moscow must end its war against Ukraine and return to a nuclear arms control treaty.
author: By Edward Wong

header: Russian partisans with ties to Ukraine say they briefly took control of a village in Russia.
desc: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia canceled a trip to be briefed on the incursion near the border with Ukraine. He described the incident as a “terrorist” attack.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Marc Santora

header: Ukraine is sending reinforcements after the Russians surrounded Bakhmut on three sides.
desc: In recent weeks, Russian forces have been rushed to the front line, helping Moscow seize more villages and towns.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: A Ukrainian Mayor Disappeared, but Questions of His Loyalty Did Not
desc: Traitor or hero? A decision by the former mayor of Kherson to remain in his post under Russian occupation has divided opinion, even after he vanished.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Ivor Prickett

header: In an Epic Battle of Tanks, Russia Was Routed, Repeating Earlier Mistakes
desc: A three-week fight in the town of Vuhledar in southern Ukraine produced what Ukrainian officials say was the biggest tank battle of the war so far, and a stinging setback for the Russians.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Incursion in Russian Border Town Puts Kremlin on Emergency Footing
desc: An armed group said it briefly took control of a border town in Russia’s Bryansk region, but what actually took place there was shrouded in conflicting claims.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Marc Santora and Alan Yuhas

header: Here are the basics of the feud between Russia’s top mercenary chief and the Kremlin’s military leaders.
desc: NA
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Russia steps up attacks in Bakhmut as Ukraine pledges reinforcements.
desc: NA
author: By Daniel Victor

header: At U.S. Base in Germany, Ukraine’s Military Conducts War Games
desc: The exercises come as Ukraine is emerging from a winter that was expected to offer a lull in fighting. Ukraine’s president appeared to signal recently that the country is preparing for a major offensive.
author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt

header: Ukraine Reinforces Embattled Bakhmut, but Mission Is Unclear
desc: Amid persistent rumors of Ukrainian withdrawal from the war’s most prolonged battle, officials said nothing about the size or purpose of the reinforcement.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Edward Wong

header: Whirring Into Action in Ukraine’s Skies
desc: Against the odds, Ukraine’s helicopter brigades are not only still operational, but are an inspirational component of its war effort.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Daniel Berehulak

header: The U.S. will send $400 million in new military aid to Ukraine, including precision-guided rockets.
desc: Western leaders have warned of a looming artillery shortage for Ukraine as its troops burn through thousands of shells each day in trying to push back Russian forces.
author: By Lara Jakes and Helene Cooper

header: As fighting intensifies, Ukraine says its forces are still holding Bakhmut.
desc: The city of Bakhmut, in eastern Ukraine, has taken on a deep symbolic resonance for both sides, which have incurred staggering numbers of casualties.
author: By Marc Santora and Natalia Yermak

header: As Ukraine Clings to Bakhmut, What’s Its Strategy and What’s at Stake?
desc: Ukraine is determined to hold the eastern city as long as it can. How high a price is it willing to pay? What might force its withdrawal? And what would a retreat look like — and mean?
author: By Marc Santora

header: The E.U. Offered to Embrace Ukraine, but Now What?
desc: The European Union and NATO have promised a path to membership for the embattled country. But real partnership will hold risks and benefits for both sides.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: A Visit to One of the War’s Most Violent Front Lines
desc: I recently traveled to the Donetsk region, where I got to know some of the soldiers. Here’s what they told me.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: The U.S. attorney general meets with Zelensky during a surprise visit to Ukraine.
desc: A major topic of talks was how to hold Russia accountable for any war crimes committed over the past year.
author: By Glenn Thrush

header: With Ukraine Under Pressure in Bakhmut, Fight Becomes a Battle Over Roads
desc: Ukraine’s military said that Russia was inching ahead in its efforts to encircle the city but that it had beaten back several attacks on supply routes.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Nobel Prize Is No Defense Against Jail for a Winner in Belarus
desc: Ales Bialiatski, last year’s Nobel Peace Prize laureate, has been sentenced by Belarus to 10 years in prison, on charges that rights advocates have dismissed as politically motivated.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Germany’s Scholz Visits Washington Amid Worries Over Ukraine ‘End Game’
desc: Chancellor Olaf Scholz arrives Friday for a quiet working visit with President Biden, sparking speculation that they will discuss tough questions on how to end the war.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: Ukrainian Soldiers, Nearly Encircled, Push Russians Back
desc: The battle for Bakhmut is not over — at least not yet. Ukrainian assault brigades offered Moscow a bloody reminder of that over the weekend.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Daniel Berehulak

header: They’re Exporting Billions in Arms. Just Not to Ukraine.
desc: As traditional weapons suppliers like the U.S. face wartime production shortages, South Korea has stepped in to fill the gap, while trying not to provoke Moscow.
author: By Choe Sang-Hun

header: He Heeded Russia’s Call to Enlist. Five Months Later, He Was Dead.
desc: Pvt. Ivan Ovlashenko was one of at least 16,000 Russians who have died in Ukraine, more than in the Soviets’ Afghan war. It’s getting hard for the Kremlin to cover that up.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva

header: A video shows the apparent execution of a Ukrainian prisoner of war.
desc: Ukrainian officials said they had opened a war crimes investigation.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: Russian Forces Attack Bakhmut From Three Directions
desc: Russian troops and Wagner mercenaries are still waging a fierce battle to encircle the eastern Ukrainian city, officials said.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Vivek Shankar and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine Signals It Will Keep Battling for Bakhmut to Drain Russia
desc: Gradual Russian advances and high Ukrainian casualties have fueled talk of a retreat from the eastern city, but Ukrainians say Russian losses are worse, a reason to keep them fighting.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine Claims a Drone Strike on a Military Target Inside Russia
desc: The claim was a rare public acknowledgment of a cross-border attack in Russian territory.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Estonia Election Delivers Vote of Confidence for Ukraine Aid
desc: The party of Prime Minister Kaja Kallas, who has pushed the West to send more weapons to Kyiv and impose tougher penalties on Moscow, took about double the tally of the second-place finisher.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: This Is What Trench Warfare on the Front Line Is Like
desc: The Ukrainian military calls it the zero position, where Russian soldiers are close enough to see, and where an old war tactic takes a horrific toll.
author: By Tyler Hicks and Marc Santora

header: Seeking Stability at Yoga Classes in Kyiv
desc: Air-raid sirens might disrupt the calm, but yoga classes in Kyiv continue to find eager participants. Here’s who I met.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: Conditions at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant have deteriorated, Ukraine says.
desc: The International Atomic Energy Agency last week warned that the situation at the plant, which Moscow seized soon after its invasion in February, was “precarious.”
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: A wide range of pro-Ukrainian groups operate in the shadows of the war.
desc: The new intelligence suggesting the involvement of such a group in explosions that damaged the Nord Stream pipelines last year is extremely vague.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukrainian incursions into Russia have usually been kept quiet, until now.
desc: At the funeral for four fighters killed in Russia and finally returned to Ukraine, fellow soldiers talked openly about the mission.
author: By Marc Santora and Oleksandr Chubko

header: Ukraine Claims Bakhmut Battle Is Wagner’s ‘Last Stand’
desc: Ukrainians say Russia’s Wagner mercenary group is running low on fighters recruited from prisons, used in attacks on Bakhmut, where Ukraine has also endured heavy losses.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: At War: Images From an Expanding Ukraine Conflict
desc: A photographic chronicle of the second year of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
author: NA

header: Germany treads a careful line over reports that a pro-Ukrainian group sabotaged the Nord Stream pipeline.
desc: Defense Minister Boris Pistorius said Germany was waiting for further investigations, after reports in The New York Times and other news outlets.
author: By Christopher F. Schuetze

header: Ukraine Needs Shells, and Arms Makers Want Money. Enter the E.U.
desc: Ukraine is firing artillery shells faster than manufacturers can make them. Brussels is working on a plan to increase production by guaranteeing big advance purchases.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: Russia Lacks Firepower to Keep Advancing, U.S. Intelligence Chief Says
desc: While both Ukrainians and Russians say the pitched battle for the city of Bakhmut could determine whether Russia can pursue more of an offensive, Western officials are skeptical.
author: By Julian E. Barnes, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: The Background on the Protests in Georgia
desc: Demonstrators worry that Georgia is reneging on commitments to foster closer ties with Europe and moving toward closer ties with Russia.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Shashank Bengali

header: A Russian Editor Evades Putin’s Censorship
desc: Galina Timchenko, founder of the dissident news site Meduza, has adapted as the information noose has tightened since the invasion of Ukraine.
author: By Alison Smale

header: Russia Blasts Ukrainian Cities, Including Biggest Use of Advanced Missiles
desc: Of 81 missiles fired, six were hypersonic weapons, among Russia’s newest and most advanced, which are all but impossible to shoot down.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Latvia is sending cars seized from drunken drivers to Ukraine.
desc: The first batch of cars will start making their way on Friday, the head of a charity helping deliver them said, and will go to the military and hospitals.
author: By Emma Bubola

header: A U.S.-developed rocket system becomes one of Ukraine’s most lethal weapons.
desc: A New York Times team was given rare access to witness an M270 in operation near the front line.
author: By Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Evelina Riabenko

header: Satellite images show widespread destruction after heavy fighting in Bakhmut
desc: New satellite pictures of the eastern Ukrainian city, where a brutal battle has been raging for months, showed bridges over a strategically important river had been destroyed.
author: By Elena Shao and Marco Hernandez

header: The E.U. and NATO promised Ukraine a path to membership. But real partnership holds risks.
desc: NA
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: Crowds gather to mourn ‘Da Vinci,’ a young Ukrainian soldier killed near Bakhmut.
desc: Dmytro Kotsiubailo, better known as “Da Vinci,” was killed near Bakhmut on March 7.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Changing His Tune for Mother Russia
desc: As the Kremlin seeks to remake Russia’s institutions to comport with its militaristic worldview, cultural figures are picking a side. One singer made his choice — and is growing rich.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Georgy Birger

header: Questions surround Russia’s use of hypersonic missiles in its latest attack.
desc: Moscow on Thursday fired the largest number of the air-launched weapons used in a single wave since the war began a year ago.
author: By John Ismay, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine highlights its desire for air defense weapons after Russia’s latest strikes.
desc: NA
author: By Shashank Bengali

header: The leaders of Britain and France met in Paris with Ukraine on the agenda.
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson

header: Front Line Shifts in Russia’s and Ukraine’s Battle for Bakhmut, Analysts Say
desc: Britain’s defense intelligence agency said that Russian forces had taken control of most of Bakhmut’s east, but advances farther west might be challenging.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: Ukraine Steps Up Calls for Evacuation of Kupiansk Under Relentless Russian Shelling
desc: Attacks on the northeast town in the Kharkiv region of Ukraine continued on Sunday.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko

header: In Fields Sown With Bombs, Ukraine’s Farmers Risk Deadly Harvest
desc: Some who till the breadbaskets of Ukraine have already lost three seasons of planting to war. With mines and cluster bombs widely scattered, normal harvests seem far in the future.
author: By Michael Schwirtz, Stanislav Kozliuk and Ivor Prickett

header: War in Ukraine Puts Centuries of Swiss Neutrality to the Test
desc: The Alpine state makes arms that Western allies want to send to Kyiv. Swiss law bans this, driving a national debate about whether its concept of neutrality should change.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: From ‘Hitler’ to ‘Sharing One Fate’: Saudi-Iran Pact Could Transform the Middle East
desc: Both countries as well as the broader region have much to gain from the reset in relations — if the agreement truly holds.

header: China’s Role in Iran-Saudi Arabia Deal Shows Xi’s Global Goals
desc: Brokering a rapprochement between the Middle Eastern rivals underscores the Chinese leader’s ambition of offering an alternative to a U.S.-led world order.
author: By David Pierson

header: An Activist’s Flight Reveals Widening Repression in Algeria
desc: Four years after a popular uprising fueled hopes for change and real democracy, the country’s government is using vaguely defined statutes to round up hundreds.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: As Russian Shelling Intensifies, True Liberation Eludes Ukrainian City
desc: Months after Ukrainian forces pushed out Russian occupiers, the city of Kherson remains very much a war zone.
author: By Marc Santora and Eric Nagourney

header: The Black Sea is a crucial theater in the war between Russia and Ukraine.
desc: Long dominated by Russia’s navy, the Black Sea has been the scene of Ukrainian defiance. It’s also been a rare point of agreement between the two countries.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Russian Attacks Along a Wide Arc of Ukraine Yield Little but Casualties
desc: Moscow’s forces have stepped up artillery and infantry assaults across eastern Ukraine, trying to improve their position before either side attempts a major breakthrough.
author: By Marc Santora, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: Zelensky names a soldier whose death was captured on video a Hero of Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Randy Pennell

header: Grain deal, Bakhmut and more: What to watch for this week.
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson

header: International Court to Open War Crimes Cases Against Russia, Officials Say
desc: The cases before the International Criminal Court would accuse Russia of abducting Ukrainian children and of deliberately targeting civilian infrastructure.
author: By Marlise Simons

header: ‘Navalny’ wins the Oscar for best documentary as the dissident’s wife issues a defiant message.
desc: The film followed Aleksei Navalny, a prominent critic of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, as he investigated his own near-fatal poisoning in 2020.
author: By Daniel Victor

header: ‘Russia Outside Russia’: For Elite, Dubai Becomes a Wartime Harbor
desc: In the exclusive neighborhoods and palatial shopping malls of the United Arab Emirates’ biggest city, wealthy Russians can build a new life without having to cut ties to their home country.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Andrea DiCenzo

header: He heeded Russia’s call to enlist. Five months later, he was dead.
desc: NA
author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva

header: Bakhmut remains of ‘paramount strategic importance’ to Ukraine, its top general says.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Ukraine Burns Through Ammunition in Bakhmut, Putting Future Fights at Risk
desc: The military is using thousands of artillery shells a day as it tries to hold the eastern city, which could jeopardize a planned springtime campaign.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt

header: Ukraine’s allies are set to discuss the dwindling ammunition supply.
desc: NA
author: By Anushka Patil

header: Ukraine’s Allies Promise Weapons for Spring Counteroffensive
desc: Ukraine and Russia are both running low on ammunition, and both are scrambling to replenish their stocks and gain a competitive edge.
author: By Marc Santora, Eric Schmitt, Valerie Hopkins and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Poland Says It Will Arm Ukraine With Warplanes, Raising Stakes
desc: The Polish leader said he would send jets designed by the Soviet Union to help Ukraine fend off Russian forces. It was unclear if other allies might follow suit.
author: By Andrew Higgins and Lara Jakes

header: Putin claims the West is trying to ‘pull apart’ Russia.
desc: NA
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Why the Black Sea Is a Flashpoint Between Russia and the West
desc: It has long been a theater of competition between Russia and the West, a dynamic supercharged by the Ukraine war.
author: By Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman

header: What We Know So Far About the Downed American Drone
desc: The incident was the first known physical contact between the Russian and American militaries since the war in Ukraine began.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: In describing the drone incident, U.S. officials stick to specific language.
desc: “Intercepts” are common, but statements issued after the encounter in the Black Sea this week suggest that Russia’s actions were unusual.
author: By Eric Schmitt

header: Salvaging the drone that crashed in the Black Sea presents big obstacles, experts say.
desc: The operation could take weeks and cost tens of millions of dollars, and just locating the drone might not be easy.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Poland says it foiled a Russian spy ring seeking to sabotage arms shipments to Ukraine.
desc: The sabotage, the Polish interior minister said, was planned “at the request of Russian intelligence” and “aimed at paralyzing the supply of equipment, weapons and aid to Ukraine.”
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Arrest Warrant From Criminal Court Pierces Putin’s Aura of Impunity
desc: A highly symbolic move by the International Criminal Court, which accused President Vladimir V. Putin of war crimes, carries moral weight.
author: By Mark Landler

header: More MIG fighters will help Ukraine, but what Kyiv really wants are F-16s.
desc: Ukrainian officials and military analysts do not expect the MIG jets pledged so far by Poland and Slovakia to fundamentally alter the battle in the skies.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Slovakia follows Poland in pledging warplanes for Ukraine, but most of its jets are in disrepair.
desc: The news came after Poland’s president said that his country would send MIG-29 jets, a move that appeared intended to open the door to more advanced warplanes from NATO allies.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: As Dreams of Peace Wither, Nightmares Flourish in Ukraine’s Sleep
desc: A survey asked hundreds of wartime Ukrainians what they dreamed about. Many replied: the war.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: In Stoic Ukraine, Stony Faces Are Starting to Crack and to Cry
desc: Although Ukrainians excel at putting up a brave front, a tremendous amount of suffering is being kept bottled up and sometimes bursts out.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: Russia Signals It Will Take More Ukrainian Children, a Crime in Progress
desc: The International Criminal Court’s arrest warrant for President Vladimir V. Putin highlights a practice that the Kremlin has not concealed and says will continue.
author: By Marc Santora and Emma Bubola

header: China’s Leader Will Visit Putin Under Shadow of War-Crimes Warrant
desc: Global divisions over Russia’s actions in Ukraine widened as China said Xi Jinping would go to Russia to help make peace, in a move widely seen as a stark sign of support for President Vladimir V. Putin.
author: By Alan Yuhas

header: Defiant Putin Visits Mariupol, a City Razed by Russian Forces
desc: The trip was the Russian leader’s first to territory his forces captured since the full-scale invasion of Ukraine, and came shortly after an international court issued a warrant for his arrest for war crimes.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Ivan Nechepurenko and Andrés R. Martínez

header: Who is Maria Lvova-Belova?
desc: As Vladimir V. Putin’s commissioner for children’s rights, she has led Russia’s efforts to deport thousands of Ukrainian children.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Here’s what to know about the I.C.C.’s arrest warrant for Putin.
desc: The International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant for President Vladimir V. Putin and a Russian official for war crimes. Here’s a look at the warrant and what it could mean for Russia’s leader.
author: By Marlise Simons, Charlie Savage and Anushka Patil

header: Putin and Xi Celebrate Ties Unbroken by Russia’s War in Ukraine
desc: President Vladimir V. Putin welcomed Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, to Russia, briefly noting Beijing’s peace plan for Ukraine but stressing Moscow and Beijing’s enduring partnership.
author: By Valerie Hopkins, Chris Buckley and Anton Troianovski

header: An explosion in Crimea destroyed Russian cruise missiles, Ukrainian officials say.
desc: Kremlin-appointed authorities in Crimea denied the claim saying that all the drones had been “aimed at civilian objects.”
author: By Carly Olson and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: The White House Authorizes $350 Million in Military Aid for Ukraine
desc: The latest infusion of aid is aimed at giving Ukraine much needed ammunition ahead of a planned spring offensive.
author: By Carly Olson

header: Inch by Bloody Inch in Ukraine War, Russia Is Closing In on Bakhmut
desc: Sending unarmed “diggers” into the front lines and near certain death, Russian troops are making slow but inexorable progress.
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: E.U. Officials Agree to Supply More Artillery Shells to Ukraine
desc: European leaders adopted a plan to provide Ukraine with badly needed shells, while replenishing their own national stocks.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: Xi heads to Russia saying little about Ukraine.
desc: China is calling Xi Jinping’s visit a “trip for peace,” but he is unlikely to risk straining the country’s ties with Russia and President Vladimir V. Putin.
author: By Chris Buckley and Anton Troianovski

header: Besides China, Russia Maintains Warm Relations With These Countries
desc: India and South Africa are among the nations that have not criticized Russia for invading Ukraine. Some others have supplied military aid.
author: By Daniel Victor

header: Why China and Russia Are Closer Than Ever
desc: This week’s meeting between the leaders of China and Russia marks another key moment in the deepening relationship between the two powers.
author: By Nicole Hong

header: Xi refrains from mentioning Ukraine in Moscow, instead focusing on generalities.
desc: NA
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: To Ukraine, Xi’s push for peace seems at odds with the battlefield reality.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Xi and Putin Bind China and Russia’s Economies Further, Despite War in Ukraine
desc: On the second day of the Chinese leader’s state visit in Moscow, Xi Jinping and Vladimir V. Putin declared an enduring economic partnership, in an effort to insulate their countries from punitive Western measures.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Chris Buckley

header: In a Brother Act With Putin, Xi Reveals China’s Fear of Containment
desc: Instead of focusing on a solution to the war in Ukraine, the Chinese leader’s visit to Moscow reinforced China and Russia’s shared opposition to American dominance.
author: By Chris Buckley

header: Its Forces Under Siege, Ukraine Hits Distant, Russian-Held Crimea
desc: The Crimean Peninsula, which Russia seized in 2014, has been a staging ground for other attacks and an increasingly attractive target for Ukraine.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Japan’s Prime Minister Becomes Latest G7 Leader to Visit Ukraine
desc: Fumio Kishida, who has been seeking a more active role for his country in international affairs, made an unannounced trip to meet with Ukraine’s president.
author: By Ben Dooley and Victoria Kim

header: Ukrainian Soldiers Speed Through U.S. Training on Patriot Missiles
desc: At the end of a 10-week crash course at a U.S. Army base in Oklahoma, the Ukrainians are essentially running their own training in preparation for the front lines.
author: By Eric Schmitt

header: She Posted Online About the War in Ukraine. Then She Faced a Prison Term.
desc: The case of Olesya Krivtsova, a Russian student who ended up on the Kremlin’s official terrorist list, has underscored the perils of using social media to criticize the Kremlin’s war in Ukraine.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Zelensky Makes Morale-Boosting Trip to Bakhmut
desc: The Ukrainian leader also condemned a deadly Russian missile attack against an apartment building in Zaporizhzhia.
author: By Marc Santora, Valerie Hopkins, Enjoli Liston and Victoria Kim

header: The Monks in the Middle of Russia’s War in Ukraine
desc: A war-fueled rift between the living clerics loyal to Moscow and those loyal to Kyiv is coming to a head.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Canada extends the deadline for Ukrainians to apply for a temporary visa program.
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson

header: Britain’s Prince William thanks Poland’s president for supporting Ukraine.
desc: He met with President Andrzej Duda on the second day of his visit to Poland.
author: By Anushka Patil

header: A Refuge for Russians and Ukrainians, Bali Rethinks Its Open-Door Policy
desc: After multiple accounts of tourists behaving badly, its governor wants Russia and Ukraine to lose access to Indonesia’s visa-on-arrival program.
author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono

header: Stolen Valor: The U.S. Volunteers in Ukraine Who Lie, Waste and Bicker
desc: People who would not be allowed anywhere near the battlefield in a U.S.-led war are active on the Ukrainian front, with ready access to American weapons.
author: By Justin Scheck and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Slovakia Makes Its First Delivery of Pledged Soviet-Era Fighter Jets to Ukraine
desc: The arrival of the aging MIG-29s is not expected to significantly change battlefield dynamics, and the planes will most likely be used for spare parts for Ukraine’s own Soviet-era jets.
author: By Anushka Patil

header: ‘Give Me an Abrams!’ Ukrainian Tank Commanders Grow Impatient.
desc: For now, they are holding on with inferior Soviet-era tanks, but relish the idea of taking on the Russians with modern Western battle tanks.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Daniel Berehulak

header: From Combat in Ukraine to Rehab in Minnesota, With No Time to Waste
desc: War has forced Ukraine to become skilled at treating amputees, but there are too many for its overtaxed medical workers. Some are finding their way to a prosthetics clinic in Minnesota.
author: By David Guttenfelder and Eric Nagourney

header: As Zelensky Visits Kherson, World Bank Says Ukraine Needs $411 Billion to Rebuild
desc: The bank released a significantly higher figure as European Union leaders approved plans to provide Kyiv with one million artillery shells over the next 12 months.
author: By Enjoli Liston, Victoria Kim and Monika Pronczuk

header: No Letup in Bakhmut as Ukraine and Russia Brace for Battles Elsewhere
desc: Both sides expect a Ukrainian offensive while the Bakhmut fight continues, but the head of the Wagner mercenary group said Russia must be clearer about its goals.
author: By Shashank Bengali and Anton Troianovski

header: A conference to help locate Ukraine’s abducted children is being organized, the E.U.’s top official says.
desc: NA
author: By Monika Pronczuk

header: Spain’s prime minister plans to visit Beijing for talks on China’s contentious peace proposal.
desc: China has been trying to build support for its proposal to start peace talks, but Ukraine’s allies hold that its call for an immediate cease-fire would only help Russia consolidate territorial gains.
author: By José Bautista

header: Ukraine pushes for phone talks between Zelensky and China’s leader.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Bakhmut Battle ‘Could Be Stabilized,’Ukrainian General Says, but Fighting Remains Intense
desc: The battle for the city has been the most violent of recent months, creating an increasingly dire humanitarian crisis for the few remaining civilians.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Victoria Kim

header: They Left Town as Convicts. Will They Be Buried as Heroes?
desc: As thousands of ex-prisoners fight and die in Ukraine, honoring their memory is becoming a patriotic imperative in Russia. But some committed crimes their old neighbors cannot forget.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: Putin Says He Could Put Tactical Nuclear Weapons in Belarus by Summer
desc: The proposal from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, talked of since last year, would be provocative without changing the West’s battlefield calculus in Ukraine.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Vivek Shankar and Andrew Higgins

header: An Anxious Asia Arms for a War It Hopes to Prevent
desc: Doubts about both China and the United States are driving an arms race in the Indo-Pacific with echoes of World War II and new levels of risk.
author: By Damien Cave and Chang W. Lee

header: Before 12:01 A.M., Migrants on Foot Dashed Into Canada to Beat Deadline
desc: A freer era of migration into Canada ended on Saturday when officials stopped accepting asylum petitions from people who walk in at unofficial crossings.
author: By Jane Gottlieb and Ian Austen

header: Who Will Take Care of Italy’s Older People? Robots, Maybe.
desc: The Western world’s oldest population is facing a crisis of caregivers. Some are looking for a little helping, plastic, hand.
author: By Jason Horowitz

header: Restoring a Giant Plane: Ukrainian Resilience or Folly?
desc: Ukraine, with far more pressing needs, plans to rebuild the colossal Mriya cargo plane, a symbol of pride that was destroyed last year in a battle for its airfield.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Amid Ruins and Explosions, Some Ukrainians Refuse to Leave Home
desc: In Avdiivka, as in Bakhmut and other devastated places on the front lines, most residents left long ago, but there are holdouts.
author: By Yousur Al-Hlou and Masha Froliak

header: A Plan to Lift the Fog of War in Ukraine? It’s in the Cards.
desc: To help soldiers quickly distinguish friend from foe, the Pentagon is issuing playing cards with pictures of 52 different NATO weapons systems.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: The Ukrainians hold on with old tanks, but relish the idea of advancing with modern Western battle tanks.
desc: NA
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: Torture and Turmoil at Ukrainian Nuclear Plant: An Insider’s Account
desc: The former director of Europe’s largest nuclear facility describes abuse of Ukrainian workers and careless practices by the Russians who took control of the plant.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Over 4,300 Ukrainian children have been deported to Russia or Russian-occupied areas, a Ukrainian official says.
desc: NA
author: By Carly Olson

header: U.N. Official Heads to Ukrainian Nuclear Plant as Safety Fears Grow
desc: The official met with President Volodymyr Zelensky to discuss the Zaporizhzhia plant, amid worries that a Ukrainian offensive could raise the already-high risk of disaster.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Promised tanks arrive in Ukraine from Germany and Britain.
desc: The deliveries of advanced equipment are expected to assist Kyiv with a potential spring offensive.
author: By Carly Olson

header: Blinken warns that calls for a cease-fire in Ukraine by Russia’s partners may be ‘a very cynical trap.’
desc: NA
author: By Edward Wong

header: Ukraine claims to shoot down 12 of 12 Russian drones over Kyiv.
desc: NA
author: By Daniel Victor

header: Ukrainians in a Hidden Command Post See Bakhmut Going Their Way
desc: Ukrainian commanders said that Russia exhausted all its reserves on the eastern city, though soldiers said the cost in lives had been steep.
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: Ukraine Goes Dark: Images From Space Drive Home the Nation’s Anguish
desc: A satellite operated by NASA and NOAA bares how Russia’s drones and missiles knocked out the nation’s power.
author: By William J. Broad, Sarah Kerr, Marc Santora and Tim Wallace

header: The head of the U.N.’s nuclear watchdog visits Ukraine’s embattled Zaporizhzhia plant.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Soldiers Massing Near Ukrainian Nuclear Plant, U.N. Official Warns
desc: Amid signs of offensives and counteroffensives, concern is rekindling about what it will mean for the biggest nuclear plant in Europe.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukraine, Poland and six other countries call for Meta and other tech giants to fight disinformation.
desc: An open letter from eight prime ministers calls for action “against disinformation that undermines our peace and stability.”
author: By Patricia Cohen

header: How Ukraine’s Battered Steel Industry Galvanized Its War Effort
desc: Ukraine’s iron- and steel-producing factories have made body armor, helmets and armored plates for vehicles — and steelworkers risked their lives rolling out heavy machinery at the beginning of the war to help physically block the Russian advance.
author: By Finbarr O’Reilly

header: The U.S. imposes sanctions on a Slovakian accused of trying to broker a Russia-North Korea arms deal.
desc: A White House spokesman said the man would be in violation of several U.N. Security Council resolutions.
author: By Katie Rogers

header: Germany, stressing its long-term commitment, promises additional military aid to Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Christopher F. Schuetze

header: In Berlin, King Charles of Britain lauds Germany’s support for Ukraine.
desc: “Together we must be vigilant against threats to our values,” the British monarch said to German lawmakers.
author: By Carly Olson

header: Ukraine says it will use legal means to remove pro-Russian monks from a revered Orthodox site.
desc: Representatives of the monks and priests have vowed to ignore an eviction order.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: For Ukrainian Convicts, a Strange Odyssey Through Russian Prisons
desc: When Russian troops left Kherson, they took with them 2,500 Ukrainian convicts from local prisons. For some, it was the start of a bewildering, five-country journey highlighting the war’s absurdity.

header: China Draws Lessons From Russia’s Losses in Ukraine, and Its Gains
desc: With an eye on a possible conflict over Taiwan, analysts have scrutinized the war for insights ranging from the importance of supply lines to the power of nuclear threats.
author: By Chris Buckley

header: Ukraine Charges a Leading Ukrainian Vicar, as Russia Pounds Eastern Ukraine
desc: The charge against the religious leader, Pavlo Lebid, came as Russian forces hit the town of Avdiivka, among 70 other targets, along the front line.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Yurii Shyvala

header: Bracing for Fights Ahead, Russia and Ukraine Step Up Recruitment
desc: After a winter of intense battles and heavy losses in Ukraine’s east, both Russia and Ukraine are taking steps to replenish their depleted forces.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Alan Yuhas

header: Sanna Marin, Finland’s Political Rock Star, Could Be Slipping
desc: Parliamentary elections on Sunday are extremely tight among the three biggest parties, with the prime minister’s Social Democrats in a tough fight to lead the next government.
author: By Johanna Lemola and Steven Erlanger

header: In a secret command center, Ukrainians say they have exhausted Russia’s relentless assaults on Bakhmut.
desc: NA
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: Soon after Russia invaded Ukraine, Finland laid out its argument for joining NATO.
desc: A Finnish defense official said his country had long prepared to defend itself but that Russia’s war changed the calculation.
author: By John Ismay

header: Russia and Ukraine make recruitment pushes as they prepare for a long war.
desc: NA
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: Russia assumes the presidency of the U.N. Security Council on Saturday.
desc: NA
author: By Farnaz Fassihi

header: Belarus, echoing Russia, raises the prospect of nuclear conflict.
desc: Because of the conflict in Ukraine, President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus said, “a third world war loomed on the horizon with nuclear fires.”
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: New Weapons Aren’t Enough: The Challenges of Ukraine’s Coming Assault
desc: With powerful Western weapons, newly formed assault units and even a reconstituted Azov battalion, Ukraine is poised for a critical spring counteroffensive. But overcoming casualties and keeping war-weary troops motivated will be stern tests.

header: The Children’s Rights Advocate Accused of Russian War Crimes
desc: Maria Lvova-Belova says she is running a humanitarian evacuation of abandoned Ukrainian children. The International Criminal Court accuses her of abducting them wholesale.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Inside the Ukrainian Frontline City Residents Are Refusing to Leave
desc: Huddled in basements just over a mile away from the front lines of Avdiivka, over 1,800 residents are refusing to be rescued from one of the most active battlegrounds in eastern Ukraine.
author: By Yousur Al-Hlou and Masha Froliak

header: Russia Accuses Dissidents and Ukraine of Killing Pro-War Blogger
desc: The authorities detained a woman they said had delivered the bomb, hidden in a statuette, that killed the blogger, and called it the work of antigovernment activists and Ukraine.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Influential Russian Military Blogger Is Killed in St. Petersburg Bombing
desc: Vladlen Tatarsky represented a radical wing of pro-invasion bloggers and activists who backed Moscow’s war but also criticized what they saw as the flaws in the Russian Army.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Wagner claims ‘legal’ control of Bakhmut, while Ukraine says it is still fighting.
desc: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the Wagner group founder, said Russian forces had raised their country’s flag in the center of Bakhmut.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Strange Days at the U.N. as Russia Takes the Helm of the Security Council
desc: The monthlong presidency of an organization dedicated to preserving world peace is now in the hands of a nation waging the biggest land war in Europe in decades.
author: By Farnaz Fassihi

header: Russian Shelling Kills 6 as Assault Stalls in Ukraine’s East
desc: The attack came after President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said that permitting Moscow its monthlong presidency of the Security Council showed “the complete bankruptcy of such institutions.”
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Maria Varenikova and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Russia’s assault in eastern Ukraine appears stalled.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: The St. Petersburg bombing is the latest attack that Russia has blamed on Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Daniel Victor

header: Zelensky Gets Hero’s Welcome in Poland, Cementing Ukraine’s Ties
desc: Polish leaders backed Ukraine’s bid for NATO membership, but even without that, Russia’s invasion is making the alliance’s eastern flank more united, and more important.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Finland Joins NATO in a Power Shift and Rebuke to Putin
desc: The Nordic country became the alliance’s 31st member on Tuesday, spurred by the war in Ukraine, in a strategic setback for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

header: ‘If I Stop Now I’ll Have Nothing’: The African Students Who Fled Ukraine
desc: One student, accepted at a Georgian school, had her visa application rejected. Another, 18 months from his medical degree, received a deportation order from Germany. “It just makes you want to stop in the street and scream,” he said.
author: By Monika Pronczuk

header: Macron, in China, Says He’ll Urge Xi to Work for Peace in Ukraine
desc: President Emmanuel Macron of France spoke of the need for a “shared responsibility for peace and international stability.”
author: By Roger Cohen

header: ‘Outrageous’: Russia Accused of Spreading Disinformation at U.N. Event
desc: Moscow used its rotating presidency of the Security Council to host a session on deported Ukrainian children, leading some officials to walk out.
author: By Farnaz Fassihi

header: China’s Ambassador to the E.U. Tries to Distance Beijing From Moscow
desc: The ambassador, Fu Cong, said China was not on Russia’s side in the war in Ukraine. “‘No limit’ is nothing but rhetoric,” he said, referring to a statement from last year about the countries’ relationship.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Steven Erlanger

header: What We Know About the Bomb Attack on a Russian Pro-War Blogger
desc: The killing of Vladlen Tatarsky came at a volatile moment in Russia, and could herald a further crackdown on dissent. Here’s how the case has developed so far.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Near Bakhmut, Death Is Delivered Remotely and Watched on Video
desc: Using aerial drones to spot the enemy and direct artillery fire has become a staple of war for Ukraine and Russia, especially in the savage fight for control of Bakhmut.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine says Russia attacked the Odesa region with drones.
desc: NA
author: By Erin Mendell

header: Can China Make Peace in Ukraine? Macron Isn’t Saying No.
desc: The French president hopes Beijing can be useful in pressing Russia to end the war in Ukraine. How exactly is not clear.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: How Russia’s Offensive Ran Aground
desc: Whatever happens in Bakhmut, a once-ambitious winter offensive never really went anywhere.
author: By Josh Holder and Marco Hernandez

header: Xi and Macron Call for Ukraine Peace Talks, but the Path Is Murky
desc: It is not clear that the Chinese and French leaders — much less Russia and Ukraine — have compatible terms for talks or peace, and Mr. Xi has not publicly agreed to pressure Moscow to negotiate.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: Macron’s meeting with Xi could affect the direction of the war.
desc: NA
author: By David Pierson

header: Ukrainian forces are ‘not going anywhere,’ Prigozhin says.
desc: Yevgeny Prigozhin, who leads the mercenary group, also said that Russia would need better organization and more ammunition to push beyond the besieged city.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Divisions emerge in NATO over giving Ukraine a pathway to membership, officials say.
desc: The debate on the status of Kyiv will continue up to the military alliance’s mid-July summit meeting.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: Russia took 2,500 Ukrainian convicts with them as they left Kherson. For some, what ensued was absurd.
desc: NA
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Ekaterina Bodyagina and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: China and France issue a joint statement supporting ‘all efforts to restore peace in Ukraine.’
desc: The statement was issued after a three-day summit by Xi Jinping and Emmanuel Macron in China.
author: By David Pierson

header: Explosions hit a village in southern Ukraine where Russia had massed troops, a Ukrainian official says.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Zelensky’s aides send mixed messages on Crimea and the possibility of negotiations.
desc: Top government officials in Kyiv clarify that their mission remains to reclaim all Ukrainian territory from Russia.
author: By Anushka Patil

header: Ukraine is poised for a critical spring offensive. The looming campaign will test the military’s resolve.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: The Russians Took Their Children. These Mothers Went and Got Them Back.
desc: Making a nerve-wracking 3,000-mile journey from Ukraine, into Russia-occupied territory, and back again, a group of mothers managed to recover their children from the custody of the Russian authorities.
author: By Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Daniel Berehulak

header: Fight for Roads Into Bakhmut Has Hit a Stalemate, Ukraine Says
desc: Even as Russian forces made some gains in the battered eastern city last week, Ukraine’s forces say they have thwarted Moscow’s efforts to sever supply lines. For now.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Europe Has Pledged a Million Shells for Ukraine in a Year. Can It Deliver?
desc: Probably not, experts say, given the shrunken state of its military industrial sector. A look at a major munitions maker helps explain why.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: Leaked Document Shows Dire Nature of the Battle for Bakhmut
desc: An assessment that appears in a new batch of leaked classified documents appears to show that Ukraine was close to losing a key battle of the war in February.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russia promises bonus pay to troops who destroy NATO tanks, documents say.
desc: Unconfirmed reports from leaked Pentagon documents show plans to shore up troops’ morale and sharpen their tactics as Ukraine takes delivery of more advanced weapons.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Ukraine Says Russia Is Preparing to Evacuate Civilians From Occupied Areas of South
desc: Ukraine is widely expected to launch a counteroffensive in the coming weeks to recapture territory from Russian forces. Some Ukrainian officials say it could focus on the south of the country.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Yurii Shyvala

header: Leaked Documents Show Seoul Torn Between U.S. Demands and Its Own Policy
desc: The documents showed the United States most likely spied on a key Asian ally as pressure built for South Korea to help Washington supply ammunition to Ukraine.
author: By Choe Sang-Hun

header: French Diplomacy Undercuts U.S. Efforts to Rein China In
desc: Allies don’t always see things the same way, as Emmanuel Macron’s cozy visit to Xi Jinping made abundantly clear.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: A Quick Guide to What the Leaked U.S. Intelligence Documents Say
desc: The authorities have so far made one arrest in the case, Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old air national guardsman. But many questions remain about the classified documents that have been appearing online.
author: By Eric Nagourney

header: A pro-Russian hacking group may have targeted Canada’s energy infrastructure.
desc: NA
author: By Dan Bilefsky

header: How Ukraine’s Power Grid Survived So Many Russian Bombings
desc: Russia was determined to break Ukrainians’ will by plunging them into cold and darkness. Its failure, in the face of Ukrainian resilience, offers lessons as winter has released its icy grip.
author: By Marc Santora

header: After protests in Poland over Ukrainian grain supplies, Kyiv and Warsaw reach a deal.
desc: Poland, Romania and Hungary, all of which border Ukraine and are members of the European Union, have struggled with a glut of grain and other Ukrainian agricultural products since last year.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: A leaked document outlines 4 ‘wild card’ scenarios in the Russia-Ukraine conflict.
desc: The scenarios, as assessed by the Defense Intelligence Agency, include the deaths of Presidents Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine.
author: By Haley Willis, Julian E. Barnes and Christiaan Triebert

header: Lethal Surprises Hidden in the Grass: Russia’s Trip Wires and Land Mines
desc: As Moscow’s troops set booby traps in forests, houses and backyards, finding them has become a dangerous art for Ukrainian soldiers.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russia Moves to Make Draft Evasion More Difficult
desc: A new law would bar anyone called up to fight in Ukraine from leaving the country, among other restrictions, even as the Kremlin insists it is not planning a new conscription.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko, Neil MacFarquhar and Vjosa Isai

header: The Pentagon says it is investigating the scope of the documents leak but declines to give specifics.
desc: The Pentagon is leading a separate team, including the White House, State Department and intelligence agencies, to determine the extent of the damage caused by the disclosures.
author: By Eric Schmitt and Michael Crowley

header: Russia Adopts ‘Scorched Earth’ Tactics in Bakhmut, a Ukrainian Commander Says
desc: Gen. Oleksandr Syrsky visited Bakhmut on Sunday and said the situation is difficult but under control.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Near Ukraine’s front lines, soldiers learn how to deal with combat stress.
desc: NA
author: By Yousur Al-Hlou and Masha Froliak

header: Leaked Documents and Accusations of U.S. Spying Spark Outrage in Seoul
desc: The reaction to the leak in South Korea is perhaps the strongest so far as the Biden administration scrambles to contain the damage from apparent spying on allies.
author: By Choe Sang-Hun

header: From Red Carpet to Doghouse: Macron Returns From China to Allied Dismay
desc: Criticism of the French president’s performance in Beijing has been scathing among some allies, who saw him as cozying up to Beijing.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: The Final Blocks: Inside Ukraine’s Bloody Stand for Bakhmut
desc: Pushed into a shrinking corner of the devastated city, the Ukrainian military is determined to hold out for strategic reasons, even as allies question the cost.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Mauricio Lima

header: New Leaked Documents Show Broad Infighting Among Russian Officials
desc: The additional documents also suggest the breach of American intelligence agencies could contain far more material than previously believed.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Aric Toler, Julian E. Barnes, Christiaan Triebert and Malachy Browne

header: Ukraine investigates after a video appears to show the beheading of a prisoner of war.
desc: The U.N. mission monitoring human rights in Ukraine said it was “appalled” by the video, which appeared to record the beheading of a Ukrainian soldier by Russian troops.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: A Problem for Ukraine: Countries Like Brazil Won’t Sell It Arms
desc: Ukraine wants to buy weapons from Brazil, but the South American giant has repeatedly declined. Instead, it is offering to broker peace.
author: By André Spigariol and Jack Nicas

header: Biden, Blending the Personal and the Diplomatic, Thanks Ireland for Backing Ukraine
desc: “I’m at home,” the president told the Irish Parliament to thunderous applause. “I only wish I could stay longer.”
author: By Michael D. Shear and Katie Rogers

header: Leaked document says Russia’s ally Serbia is sending arms to Ukraine.
desc: The revelation could create tensions between the Kremlin and the Balkan nation.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: F.B.I. Arrests National Guardsman in Leak of Classified Documents
desc: Authorities say Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old member of the Massachusetts Air National Guard, posted sensitive materials in an online chat group.
author: By Haley Willis, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Aric Toler, Christiaan Triebert, Julian E. Barnes and Malachy Browne

header: Ukraine asks India for more humanitarian and diplomatic support.
desc: NA
author: By Sameer Yasir

header: The Airman Who Gave Gamers a Real Taste of War
desc: A group liked online war games. But then Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old National Guard airman, began showing members classified documents, they say.
author: By Aric Toler, Christiaan Triebert, Haley Willis, Malachy Browne, Michael Schwirtz and Riley Mellen

header: Zelensky asks G7 finance officials to expand support for Ukraine’s economy.
desc: NA
author: By Alan Rappeport

header: Pentagon Leaks: New Twists in a Familiar Plot
desc: Some in Ukraine even welcomed the disclosures as confirming what they have been saying for months — that its forces desperately need more weapons and munitions.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer, Erika Solomon and Eric Schmitt

header: Ghosts Past and Present Cross Paths as War Comes to Nuclear Wasteland
desc: Not everyone evacuated when the Chernobyl nuclear plant melted down in 1986. The few who stayed lived through another calamity when Russian troops marched in.
author: By Marc Santora and Emile Ducke

header: Death Toll From Russian Missile Attack in Eastern Ukraine Climbs to 11
desc: Rescuers were searching through rubble a day after the city of Sloviansk was struck as fighting raged in Bakhmut.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: A Ukrainian toddler was pulled from the rubble after a missile strike, but he did not survive.
desc: The 2-year-old boy and at least seven other people were killed after a Russian attack in Sloviansk, Ukrainian officials said. His father is believed to still be trapped in the carnage.

header: Why China’s Leader Hasn’t Called the President of Ukraine
desc: China had been Ukraine’s top trade partner, importing barley, corn and arms. Now, Russia’s war raises the question: Is there still a relationship?
author: By Vivian Wang

header: Brazil’s Lula Meets Xi in China as They Seek Path to Peace in Ukraine
desc: Brazil has been reluctant about choosing sides in the war, as its new president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, seeks to rebuild the country’s ties with Beijing.
author: By Keith Bradsher

header: In Beijing, Brazil’s leader endorses China’s stance on Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Keith Bradsher and André Spigariol

header: This is how Ukraine has survived the war on its power grid.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: The Russians took their children. These mothers went and got them back.
desc: Making a nerve-racking 3,000-mile journey from Ukraine, into Russia-occupied territory, and back again, a group of mothers managed to recover their children from the custody of the Russian authorities.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko

header: Russia’s Defense Ministry offers rare acknowledgment of Wagner cooperation.
desc: NA
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: When Freezing Sperm Makes a Patriotic Statement
desc: Some Ukrainian soldiers are trying to ensure that even if they die in the war, their partners can still build families. They also want to send Russia a message of defiance.
author: By Emma Bubola

header: Russian Invasion of Ukraine Revolutionizes NATO Military Strategy
desc: Shocked by Russian atrocities, NATO is becoming the war-fighting alliance it was during the Cold War, committed to defending “every inch” of its territory from Day 1.

header: E.U. Cries Foul as Poland and Hungary Ban Ukraine Grain Imports
desc: The European Union lifted tariffs on Ukrainian grain last year. But farmers say they are suffering from a glut of produce in Europe.

header: Under the Shadow of War, Kyiv Celebrates Orthodox Easter
desc: Thousands of Christians gathered in the Ukrainian capital to mark Holy Week, one year after Ukraine’s army forced Russian troops back from the area around Kyiv.
author: By Brendan Hoffman and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: A revered Russian theater director is reborn.
desc: Dmitry Krymov, one of Russia’s most eminent directors, is among the dozens of artists who have left their homeland since Russia invaded Ukraine.
author: By Dan Bilefsky and Jeremy Fassler

header: Harsh Sentence for Putin Critic Highlights Kremlin’s Repression
desc: A Moscow court sentenced Vladimir Kara-Murza to 25 years in prison, making it clear that any criticism of the war can lead to prison time.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Ukraine seeks to reopen transit routes for its grain as more countries look to impose import bans.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: A missile strike on Sloviansk is one of the deadliest for Ukrainian civilians this year.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Five of Ukraine’s allies team up to try to push Russia out of the nuclear fuel market.
desc: NA
author: By Edward Wong

header: The opposition activist convicted of treason has long rankled the Kremlin.
desc: Vladimir Kara-Murza was sentenced on Monday to 25 years in a Russian penal colony.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: ‘Our Own Guys Are Shelling Us’: How Russian Propaganda Plagues Ukraine
desc: A year into the war, some residents of eastern Ukrainian towns still confound officials and the police with their support for Russia despite the constant bombardment from Russian forces.
author: By Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko, Dyma Shapoval and Daniel Berehulak

header: Zelensky and Putin Make Dueling Trips to Front Line in Ukraine
desc: The visits by the Ukrainian and Russian leaders came as both sought to display strength and confidence ahead of an anticipated Kyiv counteroffensive.

header: The Wrong Mr. Kozlov: When Sanctions Spell Trouble for Regular People
desc: After Russia invaded Ukraine, the European Union blacklisted about 1,500 people linked to the war. That has complicated the lives of those who share their sometimes fairly common names.

header: Russian artillery and aerial attacks against Bakhmut are growing fiercer, Ukraine says.
desc: According to a top Ukrainian general, Kyiv’s forces remain in control in the ravaged city, the focus of months of fighting, but Russian forces are turning it “into ruins.”

header: U.S. Defense Secretary Urges Swift NATO Membership for Sweden
desc: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III, visiting Sweden, said he hoped that objections to adding the country to the alliance would be ironed out by midsummer, when member states meet in Lithuania.

header: Blinken and Top Diplomats Stress Unity on Russia and China
desc: The foreign ministers of the Group of 7 nations affirmed their shared visions on Russia’s war on Ukraine and China’s assertiveness after talk flared this month over different strategies.
author: By Edward Wong

header: Ukrainian survivors of Russia’s occupation give harrowing testimony at a House hearing.
desc: NA
author: By Anushka Patil

header: Ukraine Diary: Ukrainians collect the bodies of dead Russian soldiers.
desc: NA
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: Germany lists the Patriot system it promised to Ukraine as delivered.
desc: NA
author: By Christopher F. Schuetze

header: Zelensky and Putin make dueling trips to front line in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Victoria Kim

header: Russia’s onslaught includes years of propaganda directed at Ukraine’s east.
desc: NA
author: By Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Dyma Shapoval

header: Ukrainian officials express frustration at the pace of weapons deliveries.
author: By Anushka Patil and John Yoon

header: How Freeing Ukraine’s Trapped Grain Rankled Farmers Elsewhere in Europe
desc: When Russia’s war blocked vitally needed grains at Ukrainian ports, officials succeeded in finding other routes out. But the solution brought its own problems.

header: Ukraine’s Social Media Stars Rethink How They Wield Their Influence

header: Pentagon Speeds Up Tank Timeline for Ukraine but Resists Calls for Jets
desc: The U.S. will begin training Ukrainian troops on M1 Abrams tanks in the next few weeks, officials said, and combat-ready tanks could reach the battlefields by the fall.

header: ‘A Quick Death or a Slow Death’: Prisoners Choose War to Get Lifesaving Drugs
desc: An estimated 20 percent of Russia prisoner recruits are H.I.V. positive. To some, the front lines seemed less risky than prisons where they said they were denied effective treatments.

header: With needs so great in Ukraine after a year of war, some amputees are finding their way to a clinic in Minnesota.
desc: NA
author: By David Guttenfelder and Eric Nagourney

header: U.S. tanks might arrive soon, but Ukraine’s allies are struggling to meet other weapons pledges.
desc: Documents that were among leaked classified military assessments of the war reveal the struggles of Western allies to fulfill their pledged deliveries of tanks and other weapons systems.

header: NATO’s top official, visiting Kyiv, says Ukraine’s ‘rightful place’ is in the alliance.
desc: “I am here today with a simple message: NATO stands with Ukraine,” Jens Stoltenberg, the alliance’s secretary general, said at a joint news conference with the Ukrainian president.
author: By Enjoli Liston

header: The arrival of Abrams tanks would be a major step in arming Ukraine.
desc: Accelerated timeline means the tanks could enter the Ukrainian war in a few months, officials say
author: By Helene Cooper

header: Ukraine Says Russian Troops Are Evacuating Civilians From Occupied Areas of South
desc: Russian troops are forcibly relocating residents near the southern city of Kherson as fighting there intensifies, Ukrainian officials said Sunday.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Olha Kotiuzhanska

header: Russia’s Technocrats Embraced the West, Then Enabled Putin’s War
desc: The expertise of economic officials who continue to work in the government has helped President Vladimir Putin largely keep the economy afloat in the face of Western sanctions.

header: Under Russian Fire, a Ukrainian Soldier Evacuates the Wounded
desc: Valentyn is a Ukrainian soldier tasked with moving injured troops — and dead bodies — away from the front lines. He described the relentless work of responding to casualties under fire.

header: Zelensky Signs Ban on Russian Place Names in Struggle Over National Identity
desc: The action late Friday was the latest in a series of steps by Ukraine to distance itself from a long legacy of Russian domination.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Olha Kotiuzhanska

header: United States Says Wagner Has Quietly Picked Sides in Sudan
desc: Wagner has offered powerful weapons, including surface-to-air missiles, to R.S.F. paramilitaries, American officials said.

header: ‘I Cry Quietly’: A Soldier Describes the Toll of Russia’s War
desc: For Valentyn, a Ukrainian soldier in the Donetsk region, the war’s death toll is more than a statistic. He is tasked with moving wounded troops — and dead bodies — away from the front lines, often under Russian fire.

header: As War Rages in Sudan, Countries Angle for Advantage
desc: Even before its two leading generals went to war last week, “everyone wanted a chunk of Sudan,” an expert said of the strategically located country rich in natural resources.

header: Angry Farmers Pierce Europe’s United Front on Ukraine
desc: A grain deal that got Ukrainian exports moving and eased a global food crisis is now fueling protests in Romania and among other staunch supporters of Kyiv.

header: Ukraine Diary: Spring flowers bloom in Kyiv’s streets, a sign of life returning to the city.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Evelina Riabenko

header: Ukraine Diary: In frontline villages, animals are hard to leave behind.
desc: Although most people have fled villages near the fighting, some who stayed behind did so out of a desire to not abandon their farm animals.

header: At Ukraine’s Gravesites, a Spring Ritual Hints at Renewal
desc: A decimated village welcomes back displaced residents for a day of remembrance and hope.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Mauricio Lima

header: Battlefield update: Russian forces have hit civilian areas around the southern city of Kherson, Ukraine says.
desc: NA
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Olha Kotiuzhanska

header: The Kremlin’s spokesman says his son fought in Ukraine.
desc: Dmitri S. Peskov’s comments highlighted the Moscow elite’s uneven participation in a war that has cost the lives of tens of thousands of Russian soldiers.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: The stakes for Ukraine’s spring offensive? ‘Everything.’
desc: NA
author: By Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt, Adam Entous and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: A grain glut leaves some Eastern European countries caught between solidarity with Ukraine and survival.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Ukraine’s social media influencers have been dropping the Russian language, even at the cost of reach.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Russian-Led U.N. Meeting on Peace Draws West’s Accusations of Hypocrisy
desc: Taking advantage of its turn as president of the Security Council, Moscow sent Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov to preside over a session on peace and diplomacy.
author: By Farnaz Fassihi

header: A Symbol of Loss in Almost Every Ukrainian Kitchen

header: Ukrainian Troops Repel Russian Attacks, and Hope Western Arms Turn the Tide

header: Xi and Zelensky Talk at Last, but Words Are Chosen Carefully
desc: Volodymyr Zelensky has urged discussions with Xi Jinping since the Russian invasion, but in its official account of the phone call, China left out two words: “Russia” and “war.”

header: Ukraine War ‘Turned Everything Upside Down’ in This Polish Town
desc: A Polish town that was once occupied by the Soviets used to embrace its history with military re-enactments and Lenin banners. But “nobody wants to be reminded of Russia these days.”

header: Save Ukraine, a small but effective nonprofit group, searches for missing children.
desc: NA
author: By Julian E. Barnes

header: Ukraine Has Nearly All Combat Vehicles Allies Promised, NATO Says
desc: Gen. Christopher Cavoli, also the top commander of U.S. forces in Europe, made the comments to the House Armed Services Committee.
author: By Eric Schmitt

header: A reporting team for an Italian newspaper comes under fire in southern Ukraine, and one journalist is killed.
desc: Another reporter was hospitalized in the city of Kherson and described the attack to the paper, La Repubblica.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Relations between China and Ukraine have been uncertain since Russia’s full-scale invasion.
desc: President Xi Jinping of China and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine last communicated in January 2022, less than two months before Russia invaded.
author: By Vivian Wang

header: Russian forces pound Zaporizhzhia before an expected Ukrainian counteroffensive.
desc: NA
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Pope Francis and Ukraine’s prime minister have first known meeting since the start of the war.
desc: NA
author: By Gaia Pianigiani

header: Deadliest Russian Attack in Months on Ukraine’s Cities Kills at Least 25
desc: The first widespread barrage on civilian targets in more than a month underscored the vital role of Ukrainian air defenses.

header: Life in Ukraine’s Trenches: Gearing Up for a Spring Offensive

header: The E.U. will keep letting in Ukrainian grains without tariffs.
desc: Five countries whose farmers have been hurt by the policy, including Poland, will get carve-outs and compensation, under an agreement reached Friday.

desc: A Russian-installed local official blamed the blaze on “enemy drones.” Ukraine, which typically maintains a policy of strategic ambiguity about strikes in Crimea, did not claim responsibility.

header: In Uman, a mother holds out hope her children will still be found alive.
desc: A Russian rocket slammed into a nine-story apartment building before dawn in the central Ukrainian city of Uman.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Russia’s latest strikes underscore the limits of Ukraine’s air defense systems.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: The wrong Mr. Kozlov: How sanctions are spelling trouble for regular people.
desc: NA
author: By Monika Pronczuk

header: An unreleased report finds faults in Amnesty International’s criticism of Ukraine.
desc: The rights group commissioned an independent review of its August accusation that Ukrainian forces illegally put civilians in harm’s way.
author: By Charlie Savage

header: The Kremlin steps up efforts to Russify occupied parts of Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

desc: The fight for Bakhmut, the ruined city in eastern Ukraine, has become a focal point of the war as both sides have poured troops into battle and sustained heavy casualties.

header: Both sides report attacks before an expected Ukrainian counteroffensive.
desc: The attacks follow a weekend of explosions deep behind Russian lines. A Ukrainian official said the depot fire is part of preparations for “the broad, full-scale offensive that everyone expects” Ukraine to launch soon.

header: McCarthy Pledges Continued Support for Ukraine
desc: The speaker, who warned last year that there would be no “blank check” for Ukraine, told a Russian reporter he would continue support to Kyiv against Russia’s invasion.

header: U.S. Says 100,000 Russian Casualties in Ukraine in Past 5 Months

header: As Signs Point to Counteroffensive, Russia and Ukraine Step Up Attacks

header: Ukraine’s Military Says Crimea Blast Was Preparation for Coming Offensive
desc: Late Sunday, a day after the Crimea blast, explosions rocked Pavlograd in central Ukraine, and air raid sirens sounded across Ukraine.
