header: Defending press freedom, an eye on China and more on Ukraine’s grain: What to watch for this week.
desc: NA
author: By Anushka Patil and Juston Jones

author: By Haley Willis and Riley Mellen

header: At a U.N. event on press freedom, the publisher of The New York Times warns of dangers to democracy.
desc: NA
author: By Christopher Mele and Andrea Kannapell

header: The U.S. will send an additional $300 million in military aid to Ukraine.
desc: The latest package includes ammunition for howitzer cannons and High Mobility Artillery Rocket Systems, or HIMARS.

header: Zelensky says Russia is trying to stoke support at home by blaming Kyiv.

header: Russia’s claim comes as Ukraine is readying for a counteroffensive.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: The pope’s secret ‘mission’ for peace in Ukraine may demonstrate the limits of his influence.
desc: NA
author: By Jason Horowitz

header: Attacks on Russian infrastructure help set the stage for Ukraine’s counteroffensive, analysts say.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: The Dnipro River, Axis of Life and Death in Ukraine

header: Russian soldiers could replace Wagner in Bakhmut, but daily combat would likely change, experts say.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Explosions rock Kyiv and Odesa overnight after the Kremlin incident.

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora and Michael Schwirtz

header: Ukrainians Return Home, Renewed and Resigned

header: As Putin Bides His Time, Ukraine Faces a Ticking Clock
desc: Ukraine is feeling short-term pressure from its Western backers for success in a looming counteroffensive. Vladimir Putin seems to be operating on a longer timeline.

header: Wagner Chief Appears to Backtrack on Threat to Pull Fighters From Bakhmut
desc: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin said his mercenaries had been promised the ammunition and equipment they needed and would not have to withdraw from Russia’s fight for the eastern Ukrainian city.

header: Car Bombing Injures Prominent Russian Nationalist Writer, State Media Reports

author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Anton Troianovski

header: Russia launched a large wave of attack drones over Kyiv, Ukrainian officials say.

header: The U.S. is providing $1.2 billion for Ukraine to buy air defense missiles and other crucial equipment.

header: Homemade, Cheap and Lethal, Attack Drones Are Vital to Ukraine
desc: Fighting superior Russian firepower, Ukrainian forces turn off-the-shelf drones into deadly weapons by adapting them to carry explosives.

header: An A.F.P. journalist was killed by rocket fire near the intense fighting in the area around Bakhmut.

desc: A three-stop tour by China’s foreign minister this week has everyone trying to balance economic and security interests when it comes to Russia and Ukraine.

header: Fearing Attacks and Perhaps Unrest, Russia Plans Muted Victory Day
desc: The Kremlin will commemorate the Soviet Union’s defeat of Nazi Germany in World War II, but many towns have canceled events on Tuesday.

header: On Muted War Holiday, Putin Tries to Justify Invasion of Ukraine

header: As Putin bides his time, Ukraine faces a ticking clock.
desc: Ukraine is feeling short-term pressure from its Western backers for success in a looming counteroffensive. Vladimir Putin seems to be operating on a longer timeline.

header: Ukraine’s Black Sea grain exports slow as a deadline looms on a key shipping deal.
desc: NA

header: On one Ukrainian official’s screen, a map tells the story of Russia’s constant strikes.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

desc: Ukraine’s president played down the chance of an imminent military move, but the claim was greeted with some skepticism.

header: The Justice Department transfers funds seized for sanctions violations to help rebuild Ukraine, a first.
desc: NA
author: By Charlie Savage

header: Zelensky’s comments about needing more time for a successful counteroffensive set off a debate on any hidden agenda.
desc: NA

desc: NA
author: By Lara Jakes

header: The United States is wiring Ukraine with radiation sensors to detect nuclear blasts.

header: Top E.U. diplomat vows to stand with Ukraine for the long haul.
desc: NA
author: By Anushka Patil

header: Recriminations plague Russian forces as Ukraine steps up pressure.
desc: NA
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: China will send an envoy to Russia and Ukraine in a quest for peace talks.

author: By Vivian Wang

header: Kyiv’s gains near Bakhmut raise alarms in Russia that Ukraine’s counteroffensive has begun.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer

desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: With a new tranche of weapons, Ukraine has much of what it needs for a counteroffensive, analysts say.
desc: The additions to Ukraine’s arsenal, which include more tanks, drones and other weapons from Germany, may signal that Western officials believe Kyiv’s forces could reclaim significant swaths of territory.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: The U.K. promises more missiles and drones for Ukraine.
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine met with Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain and said he was “very pleased” with new weapons packages pledged by allies.
author: By Mark Landler

header: As Ukraine Makes Inroads in Bakhmut, Devastation Still Reigns
desc: The fight for Bakhmut is now the war’s single longest and bloodiest battle. Although the Ukrainians are making small gains, Russia still controls about 90 percent of the largely ruined city.
author: By Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks

header: Ukrainians Send a Message With Their Bombs. On Them, Too.
desc: Ukrainians have a lot to say to Russia, and many have chosen to say it in ink on the sides of rockets, mortar shells and even exploding drones.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: Zelensky Visits Germany, Praising Weapons Pledge and Seeking Jets
desc: The Ukrainian president was received with military honors in Berlin, where he thanked Germany’s leaders for standing with his country.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: In European Tour, Zelensky Reaps Billions More in Promised Military Aid
desc: His trips to Britain, Germany, France and Italy demonstrated the shifting political landscape when it comes to supporting Kyiv, as concerns grow about U.S. backing as the presidential election looms.
author: By Mark Landler

header: Ukraine Diary: Under the threat of airstrikes, a film crew in Kyiv forged ahead to ‘tell a story.’
desc: NA
author: By Nicole Tung

header: To work around sanctions, cars, electronics and more get to Russia through Dubai.
desc: NA
author: By Anton Troianovski and Jack Ewing

header: The Wagner leader disputes a report that he offered to betray Russia.
desc: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the private military group, dismissed a report from The Washington Post saying that leaked intelligence showed he had offered to share Russian Army positions with Ukraine.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Ukraine claims further advances around Bakhmut.
desc: Ukrainian soldiers made further advances around Bakhmut over the weekend.
author: By Marc Santora, Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko

header: The Latest Flash Point Among Ukraine’s Allies Is Whether to Send F-16s
desc: The United States is resisting a European push for the powerful fighters. But will it relent, as it did before with tanks, rocket launchers and air defense missiles?
author: By Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt

header: Gains Near Bakhmut Raise Ukraine’s Hopes of a Turning Tide
desc: The advances have been small, and Russians still hold most of the city, but Ukrainians say they see a meaningful shift in momentum.
author: By Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks

header: As Ukrainian Attack Looms, Putin Faces Setbacks and Disunity in Russian Forces
desc: The problems that have hindered Russia’s 15-month war are still festering: stretched resources and disunity in the ranks. Still, Mr. Putin’s resolve augurs a willingness to prosecute a long war.
author: By Paul Sonne and Anton Troianovski

header: Ukraine’s push around Bakhmut presents Russia with tough decisions about its resources.
desc: Kyiv’s forces have reclaimed ground near the city that it took Russian forces months to seize, raising pressure on Moscow to devote more fighters and equipment there.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Russian-Controlled Dam Risks Flooding in Southern Ukraine
desc: The development is a dramatic turnabout after the reservoir had reached a historic low. The dam, which lies along the front line, has been a point of tension throughout the war.
author: By Riley Mellen and Haley Willis

header: Ukraine Says It Shot Down Hypersonic Russian Missiles Over Kyiv
desc: A Russian barrage also damaged a U.S.-made Patriot air-defense system, but officials said it was still working.
author: By Victoria Kim and Eric Schmitt

header: The chief of Ukraine’s Supreme Court has been detained and accused of taking a $2.7 million bribe.
desc: ‘This is a dark day in the history of the court,’ its judges said.
author: By Daniel Victor

header: Ukraine and Russia Renew a Deal to Allow Ukraine to Ship Grain
desc: Russia last year blocked exports of Ukrainian grain across the Black Sea, a vital part of the global food supply, but they resumed last summer under a fragile pact.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Gulsin Harman

header: Ukraine Diary: A rebuilding effort brings together Ukrainians from across generations.
desc: NA
author: By Nicole Tung

header: Ukraine’s first lady requests nonlethal military aid from South Korea while in Seoul.
desc: While Olena Zelenska asked for military equipment to fight the war, South Korea pledged more nonmilitary aid to help Ukraine rebuild.
author: By Anushka Patil

header: In a Sharp Reversal, Biden Opens a Path for Ukraine to Get Fighter Jets
desc: The president told allied leaders that he would allow Ukrainian pilots to be trained on American-made F-16s, and is prepared to approve other countries’ transferring the jets to Ukraine.
author: By David E. Sanger, Jim Tankersley, Michael Crowley and Eric Schmitt

header: Another Casualty in Ukraine: Teenage Years
desc: In a battered Ukrainian city, the war has stolen the normal experiences of teenage life. The youths mostly use humor to deal with the ferocity of the fighting around them.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: What Is the F-16 Fighter Jet and Why Does Ukraine Want It?
desc: The versatile and lightweight American warplane is seen by many of Ukraine’s allies as an important deterrent against Russia.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: Ukraine Arrests a Top Judge as Crackdown on Corruption Expands
desc: At least three more Supreme Court judges, in addition to the chief justice, have been implicated in a growing bribery case, prosecutors say.
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: As Russia Tries to Pummel Kyiv, a Blast in Crimea Hints at Ukraine’s Reach
desc: Ukrainian officials did not claim responsibility for a train derailment on the occupied peninsula, but it was the latest in a series of explosions hitting the railways and supply lines of Russia’s war machine.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukraine and China Will Dominate G7 Summit, but a New Threat Lurks: A.I.
desc: The leaders are expected to hold their first talks on a common regulatory approach to generative artificial intelligence.
author: By David E. Sanger

header: A strengthened Zelensky lands in Japan for the G7 meeting.
desc: The Ukrainian president will address world leaders on Sunday. His arrival in Japan came after President Biden opened the door to other nations eventually providing F-16s to Ukraine.
author: By Victoria Kim

header: Zelensky Urges Arab Leaders Not to ‘Turn a Blind Eye’ to Russian Aggression
desc: Addressing an Arab League summit in Saudi Arabia, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged Arab nations to stand with him against Russia and called out their reluctance to take sides in the war.
author: By Vivian Nereim

header: A Ukrainian government program received 10,000 applications to repair homes.
desc: NA
author: By Anushka Patil

header: A Chinese diplomat ends his Ukraine trip with no sign of a breakthrough.
desc: NA
author: By Chris Buckley

header: Wagner Chief Says Bakhmut Is Taken; Ukraine Rejects Claim
desc: The head of the Russian paramilitary group said his forces had captured the eastern city, a claim Ukrainian officials were quick to deny even as they called the situation “critical.”
author: By Marc Santora

header: Biden Announces More Aid for Ukraine as Group of 7 Powers Meet in Japan
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine received vows of resolute support and promises of further weapons shipments even as Russian forces claimed to have seized the war-torn city of Bakhmut.
author: By Peter Baker, Motoko Rich and David E. Sanger

header: In Bakhmut, the Tides of Battle Are Ever Shifting
desc: Ukraine, this month, pressed ahead with three days of maneuvers that gained ground on the flanks of Bakhmut. But Russian forces still appear to hold the center of the strategic city.
author: By Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks

header: As Russia Claims Victory in Bakhmut, Ukraine Sees Opportunity Amid Ruins
desc: Military analysts say that if Moscow continues to send reinforcements to defend the city, that could weaken Russian forces’ ability to hold off a broader counteroffensive that Ukraine has been planning.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Ukraine May Be Finally Getting the F-16s It Asked For. Why Did It Want Them?
desc: Ukraine’s sizable contingent of fighter jets come with a few problems. President Volodymyr Zelensky said F-16s would “greatly enhance our army in the sky.”
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: The key events in the battle for Bakhmut, the war’s longest-running sustained fight.
desc: The city has for months been the center of the fighting in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine. Here’s a look at the critical moments.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Wagner’s chief says Bakhmut was captured, but the Ukrainian military says that’s not so.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Russia sees a victory in Bakhmut. Ukraine sees an opportunity.
desc: Capturing Bakhmut would be Russia’s most significant territorial gain in Ukraine since last summer, but its ability to hold the city or advance further is in question.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: ‘We have Ukraine’s back’: Biden announces $375 million more in military aid for Ukraine.
desc: The president announced the new arms package while meeting with President Volodomyr Zelensky of Ukraine on the sidelines of the Group of 7 summit meeting in Japan.
author: By Peter Baker

header: Biden defends his hesitancy over F-16s for Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Peter Baker

header: Russia Claims Bakhmut, but Some See a ‘Pyrrhic Victory’
desc: A top Ukrainian official essentially acknowledged that the devastated city had been lost. Thousands of Ukrainian and Russian soldiers died there, but the cost for Moscow was especially steep, experts say.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Marc Santora

header: China and Russia, Targets at G7 Summit, Draw Closer to Fend Off West
desc: Beijing and Moscow are holding visits this week as alarm grows in China that Western countries backing Ukraine are turning their attention to Asia.
author: By David Pierson and Chris Buckley

header: The Kremlin blames ‘Ukrainian militants’ amid a rare cross-border assault.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Valerie Hopkins

header: U.S. Shift to Support F-16s for Ukraine Began A Month Ago
desc: The U.S. defense chief first asked Biden officials to support the plan after meeting with European allies. He made his pitch to President Biden last week.
author: By Helene Cooper

header: Who Are the Soldiers Behind the Free Russia Legion?
desc: The unit has taken responsibility for a rare assault in Russian territory, and a member says it is just the beginning.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Ukraine Got the Keys to the F-16. Now Come the Lessons.
desc: Ukrainian pilots have a lot to learn before they can start using U.S.-made fighter jets, but experts say it might take less time than once thought.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: Anti-Kremlin Fighters Take War to Russian Territory for a Second Day
desc: The cross-border attacks by fighters aligned with Ukraine were an effort to force Russia’s military to divert troops from the front line, an official said.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Valerie Hopkins and Michael Schwirtz

header: Why Bakhmut? It’s a Question as Old as War.
desc: The twists and turns of a war are rarely easy to predict. In Ukraine, they landed on a city in the east that few had ever heard of. And then the whole world watched for months.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Bakhmut Is Gone: An Aerial Look at the War’s Destruction
desc: Drone footage taken by The New York Times captured the scorched buildings, destroyed schools and cratered parks that now define the city in eastern Ukraine.
author: By Tyler Hicks and Marc Santora

header: The Battle for Bakhmut, in Photos
desc: Times photographers have been documenting Ukraine’s defense of the Eastern city since May 2022.
author: By The New York Times and Marc Santora

header: Russia’s Old Bombs Elude Ukraine’s Modern Defenses
desc: Ukrainian and American officials say Russian warplanes are dropping Soviet-era bombs, some modified to glide long distances, which are almost impossible to shoot down.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Eric Schmitt

header: Fighters aligned with Ukraine warn of additional attacks inside Russia.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: What Does Russia’s Success in Bakhmut Mean for the War in Ukraine?
desc: Moscow has declared victory in its long, bloody assault. But a full capture of the ruined city may not help Russian forces advance deeper in the Donbas region.
author: By Cora Engelbrecht

header: Wagner Says It Is Leaving Bakhmut, Posing Challenge for Russia
desc: After seizing the city in eastern Ukraine after a long, brutal fight, the Wagner mercenary force is turning it over to the depleted Russian Army to defend.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Marc Santora

header: What’s Next for Russia After Spilling So Much Blood for Bakhmut?
desc: Seizing the city took 10 months and untold lives. Most likely, analysts say, Russia’s exhausted forces will settle into a defensive crouch, preparing for Ukraine’s counteroffensive.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Fresh From Attack on Russian Soil, Raiders Taunt the Kremlin
desc: The cross-border raid by Russian fighters based in Ukraine appeared intended in part to force Moscow to divert its soldiers from the battlefield.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Valerie Hopkins

header: The Wagner group forecasts disaster if Russia does not move into total war footing.
desc: Yevgeny Prigozhin has been ramping up pressure on Russia’s military leadership and extending his criticism to the country’s moneyed elites.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Ukraine and Russia engage in dueling drone attacks.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: A unit of Ukraine’s security services likely orchestrated the Kremlin drone attack, U.S. officials say.
desc: NA
author: By Julian E. Barnes, Adam Entous, Eric Schmitt and Anton Troianovski

header: Ukraine’s intelligence chief says it needs ‘significant reserves’ of weapons for a counteroffensive.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: Barely Noting War in Public, Putin Acts Like Time Is on His Side
desc: Vladimir V. Putin of Russia looks like a commander in absentia, treating the war in Ukraine as unfortunate but distant. His options have narrowed, but he is still betting on outlasting his foes.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Paul Sonne

header: ‘It’s Time’: Ukraine’s Top Commander Says Counteroffensive Is Imminent
desc: A blunt statement, accompanied by a slickly produced video of Ukrainian troops preparing for battle, appeared designed to rally the nation and to spread anxiety among Russian forces.
author: By Marc Santora and Eric Schmitt

header: If a Divided Germany Could Enter NATO, Why Not Ukraine?
desc: West Germany joined NATO in 1955, choosing security over immediate territorial integrity. Some suggest the same path could be the best guarantee for Ukraine.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: Kyiv Repels Its Largest Ever Drone Attack Launched by Russian Forces
desc: More than 40 drones were intercepted over Kyiv, where city officials said at least one person had been killed, probably by falling debris.
author: By Marc Santora and Andrés R. Martínez

header: For Ukraine Military, Far-Right Russian Volunteers Make for Worrisome Allies
desc: Some fighters who led an incursion into Russian territory this week have neo-Nazi ties. “I worry that something like this could backfire on Ukraine because these are not ambiguous people.”
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: As Both Sides Step Up Long-Range Strikes, Russians Hit a Ukrainian Hospital
desc: A Russian missile killed at least two people and wounded dozens more at a hospital, while apparent Ukrainian strikes hit occupied cities in the south.
author: By Marc Santora

header: U.S. public opinion remains firm against Russia’s invasion but is divided on arming Ukraine, a new poll finds.
desc: NA
author: By Anushka Patil

header: The Battle for Bakhmut, in photos.
desc: NA
author: By The New York Times and Marc Santora

header: Here’s what to know about Russia’s capture of Bakhmut in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Cora Engelbrecht

header: A Russian strike on a medical complex killed at least two people, Ukrainian officials say.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora

header: A Russian Deserter’s Flight to Norway Presents a Fraught Dilemma for His Host
desc: Andrei Medvedev fought with Russia’s Wagner mercenaries in Ukraine, then requested asylum in Norway. The authorities there must now weigh his plea against solidarity with Ukraine.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Henrik Pryser Libell

header: Ukraine Sees New Virtue in Wind Power: It’s Harder to Destroy
desc: Bombarding the power grid has been an essential part of Russia’s invasion, but officials say it would take many more missile strikes to badly damage a wind farm than a power plant.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: Russia Targets Kyiv With Third Wave of Strikes in 24 Hours, Killing One
desc: The attack came after a rare daytime assault on Monday. Russia has stepped up attacks on the capital this month as Ukraine prepares for a counteroffensive.
author: By Marc Santora and Victoria Kim

header: Russian Missile and Drone Attacks on Kyiv Send Civilians Racing for Cover
desc: A drone attack on Tuesday came after a barrage of missiles on Monday sent schoolchildren running for shelter as explosions echoed across the Ukrainian capital, rare daytime aerial assaults on the city.
author: By Marc Santora and Natalia Yermak

header: Shocks, Beatings, Mock Executions: Inside Kherson’s Detention Centers
desc: Ukraine has charged four members of Russia’s National Guard with war crimes in Kherson. The four acted with such impunity, the authorities say, they did not mask their identities.
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: Russian strikes damage at least one airfield in western Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Marc Santora and James C. McKinley Jr.

header: Southern Ukraine is seen as a possible target for Kyiv’s counteroffensive.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: West Germany may provide a model for admitting Ukraine to NATO.
desc: NA
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: The Russian public appears to be souring on war casualties, analysis shows.
desc: Support for the war in Ukraine remains high but could potentially turn if concern over the high numbers of casualties persists, according to FilterLabs AI.
author: By Julian E. Barnes

header: Will Erdogan’s Victory Soften Turkey’s Opposition to Sweden in NATO?
desc: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, re-elected as Turkey’s president, is expected to toughen up at home but seek better ties with Washington and ratify Swedish membership of the military alliance.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: Drone Strike in Moscow Brings Ukraine War Home to Russians
desc: At least eight drones were intercepted, the Kremlin said, but the foray raised questions about Russian air defenses.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Ivan Nechepurenko and Eric Nagourney

header: Another Early Morning Attack in Kyiv Kills 3
desc: Russia has recently increased the pace and intensity of its strikes on the Ukrainian capital.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Nicole Tung and Victoria Kim

header: Russia Denounces West Over Drone Strike on Moscow
desc: Kremlin officials said Ukraine’s allies should have condemned the strike, and argued again that its real war was with the West.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Moscow Drone Strikes a Psychological Blow, Russian Nationalists Say
desc: The Kremlin says the Defense Ministry responded well to the attack, but critics argue that the assault shows a lack of leadership from a government that promised only a “special military operation” in Ukraine.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: The aerial assault in Moscow draws attention to Ukraine’s drone arsenal.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Macron urges West to give Ukraine ‘tangible and credible’ security guarantees.
desc: NA
author: By Aurelien Breeden

header: Blinken arrives in Europe with a focus on NATO support for Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Michael Crowley

header: What We Know About the Drone Attack on Moscow
desc: Russia’s Defense Ministry said that at least eight drones had targeted Moscow and the surrounding region.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Russia has carried out more than 1,000 attacks on Ukrainian health care facilities, the W.H.O. says.
desc: NA
author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce

header: Defense start-ups get praise in Ukraine, but face challenges at home.
desc: NA
author: By Eric Lipton

header: What It Takes to Protect Kyiv From Russian Bombardment
desc: Russian air attacks on Kyiv have come in relentless waves. Yet very little has penetrated the patched-together but increasingly sophisticated air defense network. Here’s why.
author: By Marc Santora

header: A Russian official says Ukrainian shelling has forced the evacuation of 2,500 people from his border region.
desc: ‘The conditions are quite difficult,’ the local governor of the region said on social media.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Ukraine’s counteroffensive promises to be deadly. These recruits signed up anyway.
desc: “We’re going to die, probably,” one recruit said bluntly, as he trained on Friday with several hundred others at a military camp in Yorkshire, England.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: A Belarusian tennis star avoids the press after pointed questions from a Ukrainian journalist.
desc: NA
author: By Matthew Futterman

header: ‘Lots of Explosions and Shooting Outside’: Giving Birth in Wartime Ukraine
desc: The mental burden of Russia’s invasion has exacted a heavy toll on civilians. As the fighting drags on, pregnant women are among those facing the toughest trials.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: In Finland, NATO’s Newest Member, Blinken Details Russia’s ‘Failures’
desc: A speech by the U.S. Secretary of State struck a triumphal tone, while also warning against a rush to short-term solutions to the war in Ukraine.
author: By Michael Crowley

header: As Kyiv Reckons With Deaths by a Shelter, Russia Evacuates Border Towns
desc: In Ukraine’s capital, residents struggled with the question of who was to blame for a shelter closed off to two women and a child. In Russia, the authorities described evacuations in a border region.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak

header: Zelensky pushes for E.U. and NATO membership at a meeting of European leaders in Moldova.
desc: “This year is for decisions,” President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said at the European Political Community gathering, which sought to showcase Western solidarity amid the Kremlin’s war.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Mother and Child’s Desperate Run for Cover in Kyiv Ends Outside Locked Shelter
desc: They were among three people killed in a Russian missile attack, officials said. Ukraine opened an investigation, as Russians described shelling and evacuations in border regions.
author: By Marc Santora and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Turn off public webcams, Ukraine’s intelligence agency pleads.
desc: NA
author: By Anushka Patil

header: ‘Everything Changed’: The War Arrives on Russians’ Doorstep
desc: With cross-border strikes, residents of the Russian region of Belgorod are starting to understand the horrors of war being waged at their doorstep.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Explosions Hit Southern Ukraine as Both Sides Brace for Counteroffensive
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky, in an unusually personal speech, urged his compatriots to show their gratitude to the country’s soldiers.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Vivek Shankar

header: Car Bombing in Russian-Occupied Ukraine Shows Reach of War
desc: The blast in the Zaporizhzhia region of southern Ukraine killed a cafe owner who was registered to run in elections seen as an attempt to legitimize Moscow’s illegal annexation of the area.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: In Russian Schools, It’s Recite Your ABC’s and ‘Love Your Army’
desc: The curriculum for young Russians is increasingly emphasizing patriotism and the heroism of Moscow’s army, while demonizing the West as “gangsters.” One school features a “sniper”-themed math class.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva

header: A Pacifist Sect From Russia Is Shaken by War, and Modernity
desc: The Ukraine conflict is causing soul-searching among the Doukhobors, a peace-loving group that emigrated to Canada in 1899.
author: By Dan Bilefsky

header: China and U.S. Lay Out Rival Visions for Asia as Ships Nearly Collide
desc: China’s defense minister says the best way to avoid accidental conflict is for countries outside the region, like the United States, to leave and “mind your own business.”
author: By Damien Cave, David Pierson and Chris Buckley

header: Growing Protests in Serbia Demand Social Changes After Mass Shootings
desc: The protests, which have gathered momentum since two massacres in May, are denouncing a “culture of violence” and the increasingly authoritarian rule of the country’s leader.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: With Rainbow Flags, 2 Students Test China’s Shrinking L.G.B.T.Q. Space
desc: The students at an elite college in China found themselves on a collision course with the authorities amid a crackdown on gay and transgender expression.
author: By Nicole Hong and Zixu Wang

header: He’s the Biggest Power Broker in Canada Whom You’ve Never Heard Of
desc: This week, the government announced a new clerk of the Privy Council, an unsung role that is one of the most important in the federal government.
author: By Ian Austen

header: As Ukrainian Attacks Surge, U.S. Officials See Signs of Counteroffensive
desc: Kyiv has not formally announced the start of operations. But on Tuesday, Ukraine said the Russians had blown up a dam on the Dnipro River, potentially imperiling residents and the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt

header: Destroyed Ukrainian Dam Floods War Zone and Forces Residents to Flee
desc: Experts suspect an explosion collapsed the dam on the Dnipro River. Kyiv and Moscow blamed each other, and residents downstream were forced to evacuate to escape the cascading waves.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora, Haley Willis and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Ukraine Dam Disaster: What We Know
desc: Thousands of residents fled rising floodwaters in southern Ukraine, a day after a dam on the Dnipro River was destroyed.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Internal Blast Probably Breached Ukraine Dam, Experts Say (Cautiously)
desc: With Russia and Ukraine blaming each other for the collapse of the Kakhovka dam, experts say that an external attack or even structural failure might explain the disaster, but that it is not likely.
author: By James Glanz, Marc Santora and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: Mapping the Flooding From the Dam Breach in Southern Ukraine
desc: Maps show where villages were inundated by floodwaters downstream a destroyed dam in southern Ukraine.
author: By Lauren Leatherby, Lazaro Gamio, Marco Hernandez and Haley Willis

header: As Water From Destroyed Dam Rises, Ukrainians Face a Fresh New Horror
desc: Many Ukrainians have learned to live with occupation and shelling. On Tuesday a new menace began lapping at their doors.
author: By Marc Santora and Evelina Riabenko

header: Storming a Trench Is Treacherous Business. Here’s How It’s Done.
desc: Assaults on trenches can be stealthy, or deafeningly loud. Either way, they are nerve-racking. Here’s how one Ukrainian unit says it carried out one recent successful attack.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Nazi Symbols on Ukraine’s Front Lines Highlight Thorny Issues of History
desc: Troops’ use of patches bearing Nazi emblems risks fueling Russian propaganda and spreading imagery that the West has spent a half-century trying to eliminate.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Fake Putin Speech Calling for Martial Law Aired in Russia
desc: The Kremlin said it was investigating what it called a “hack” after a bogus speech aired on some radio and television networks.
author: By Paul Sonne

header: Ukraine and Russia blame each other for the dam’s destruction.
desc: NA
author: By Paul Sonne and Marc Santora

header: Ukraine Mounts Multiple Attacks on Russian Occupiers
desc: The assaults, with Western tanks and armored vehicles, appear to mark a long-awaited counteroffensive that Ukraine hopes will retake territory and shore up allies’ resolve to keep supplying weapons.
author: By Eric Schmitt and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Disaster Upon Disaster: Flood Deepens Misery in Ukraine War Zone
desc: “We were getting used to the shelling, but I’ve never seen a situation like this,” said one woman rescued in Kherson after a dam upstream was destroyed.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Mauricio Lima

header: Floodwaters Engulf Front Line in Ukraine War
desc: As rescue efforts plucked people from rooftops, and offered fresh water and shelter, Turkey’s president called for an international investigation into what caused a dam to fail.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Paul Sonne and Victoria Kim

header: Recent attacks suggest Ukrainian forces are increasingly on the offensive.
desc: The fightin i
author: By Eric Schmitt, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Andrew E. Kramer

header: A flooded Ukrainian community under Russian occupation pleads for help online.
desc: People searched for information on loved ones in messages in a chat group for residents of the Russian-occupied town of Oleshky downstream from the dam.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: Ukraine condemns pro-Russian authorities over a claim that children from flooded areas are being taken to camps.
desc: NA
author: By Emma Bubola

header: ‘It just keeps coming’: Rescuers reach an inundated neighborhood to find fetid water and exhausted people.
desc: Low-lying areas of Kherson were a panorama of water and floating debris. One man stood on a cabinet in his living room waiting for hours for help.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova

header: Cross-Border Skirmishes Heighten Anxiety for Ukrainian Villagers
desc: Even as new attacks have brought the war into Russia, the Russians have responded with force, raising the threat for the few civilians left in towns along the border.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko

header: Zelensky Visits Ukraine’s Flood Zone, Where Residents See ‘Horror’ Float By
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky traveled to the city of Kherson, trying to rally rescue crews. Russian forces shelled the city not long after his visit.
author: By Marc Santora and Maria Varenikova

header: Sunak to Talk Tech With Biden, but the War in Ukraine Is Likely to Surface
desc: While economic cooperation and the challenges posed by artificial intelligence are on the agenda, Russia’s invasion presents immediate threats.
author: By Mark Landler

header: With Probes of Russian Lines, Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Takes Shape
desc: Ukraine is using its new arsenal of Western tanks and armored vehicles in what is expected to be one of the largest military operations in Europe since World War II.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: A drone factory that Iran is helping Russia build could be operational next year, the U.S. says.
desc: Washington is trying to raise the pressure on Tehran and make it more difficult to complete the work on the factory, which would enable Russia’s military to produce drones domestically.
author: By Julian E. Barnes and Christoph Koettl

header: The U.S. announces another $2.1 billion in weapons to Ukraine.

desc: NA

desc: NA

header: Allies announce an additional $441 million in security aid to Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Gabriela Sá Pessoa

desc: NA

header: Allies will grapple with questions about Ukraine’s postwar reconstruction.

header: Ukraine retakes some villages but its forces face minefields and more airstrikes.

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Ukraine’s counteroffensive grapples with miles of defensive lines.
desc: NA
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff

desc: NA
author: By Gaya Gupta

desc: NA
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

author: By Steven Lee Myers

header: Two U.N. reports document atrocities against civilians in Ukraine.
desc: NA
author: By Gabriela Sá Pessoa

author: By Anushka Patil

header: The top U.S. general defends Ukraine’s counteroffensive, arguing it is making slow and steady progress.
desc: NA
author: By Eric Schmitt

header: The U.S. asked Ukraine not to conduct covert attacks in Russia during the rebellion.

author: By David Pierson and Olivia Wang

header: Zelensky said he warned allies the counteroffensive would proceed slowly amid the wait for weapons.

header: Biden defended the ‘difficult’ decision to send cluster munitions to Ukraine.

author: By Paul Sonne

author: By Natasha Frost

header: Despite the grain deal’s collapse, Putin and Erdogan still rely on each other.

header: Zelensky says the counteroffensive is slow-going. He blames the wait for weapons.
